name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Seventy years ago, on January 27, 1945, the Auschwitz concentration camp was liberated by Soviet soldiers. The images that the liberators saw and captured still shake the world to this day: the mountains of corpses, the crematoria, the mountains of shoes, glasses and human hair as testimonies of plundered life, the images of the exhausted survivors, closer to death than to life, these images have burrowed into the collective memory of humanity. For the vast majority of prisoners at Auschwitz, the rescue came too late. More than a million people have been murdered in this extermination camp – through hunger, disease, criminal medical trials, torture, execution and, above all, systematized death in the gas chambers. Especially Jews from Hungary, Poland, France, Holland, Greece, people of Jewish faith from all over Europe, Sinti and Roma, the disabled and the sick, homosexuals, prisoners of war, political prisoners and – especially abhorrent to anyone who has ever visited Auschwitz – countless children. These people, declared by fanatical Nazi ideologues to "subhumans", to pests whose lives were considered to be lifeless, these people should, yes, the butchers want this life to be destroyed and eradicated. Auschwitz was not the only place, but the central place of organized mass murder, the worst breach of civilization in human history. "This place is always an outcry of despair and a reminder to humanity," it says on the commemorative plaque in the concentration camp. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, this should be Auschwitz forever, an outcry of despair and warning. The perpetrators may have taken personal guilt into the grave, but the responsibility arising from their atrocities is a joint responsibility of the international community, and it is certainly a special responsibility of the people to which I belong, the Germans. As future generations, we bear the responsibility to honour the oath of "Never again" for all time. History does not repeat itself, but the present emerges from the past, and how we deal with history determines our future. That is why, knowing that the incomprehensible happened at Auschwitz, we want to vigorously defend freedom every day. That is why we want to stand up for the unconditional dignity of human beings every day, knowing that this freedom is being jeopardised. That is why, every day, we want to take action against the return of ways of thinking that we in Europe thought had been overcome and in which we must nevertheless see that they always exist: hatred, xenophobia, anti-Semitism, ultranationalism and intolerance. If today, 70 years after the liberation of Auschwitz, Jews in Europe fear for their safety and fear for their lives, then that must upset us and it must awaken us. Now we must stand together against fear, not let ourselves be infected by the hatred that the paris attackers, for example, carried. We must not respond to hatred with more hatred, we must not respond to violence with even more violence, but must combat a growing distrust, defend the freedom of all and protect the dignity of every individual. That is the task that, 70 years after the end of the Second World War and the liberation of Auschwitz, we have to carry out in a special way here in this Parliament, as the multinational assembly of nations. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Italian Presidency's balance sheet (2014/2855 (RSP)."

name: Matteo Renzi
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President Schultz, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, I take on my own the words that you, the President, addressed to this House on the occasion of the memory of what happened seventy years ago in Auschwitz and I assure you of the commitment of the Italian Government and people to combat the terrible infamy that characterised Europe decades ago, while maintaining high attention today for a debt that we have towards the past but also for a great investment that we must make on the new generations.  I believe that your greeting, your speech, Mr President, allows us to go into the substance of the budget for the six months of the Italian Presidency, remembering where we started. Taking as our starting point the role of Telemachus, also in continuity with the Greek Presidency, we had asked ourselves whether today these institutions, these politicians, these representatives of the territories that make up the great dream of the European Union, were able to assume the right to be heirs.  What does it mean to be heirs? It means being able to think that Europe is not just a memory for us: Europe is first and foremost a hope; it declines to the future, not just to the past. It has the warmth and color of opportunity before even concern. Have we been able to rise to this challenge in these six months? Of course I am aware that the press, that the operators, that the insiders, before addressing this great theme underline and highlight: "But, first tell us about the results, tell us if you are satisfied with what you have done in Europe for Italy!" That is a question that has not been asked, Mr President! Because those who make politics are never satisfied, if they are satisfied it is good that they change their profession! Also because you do not lead a semester thinking about the interest of your country, you lead a semester thinking about how Europe can have a chance for the future! We Italians, of whatever political colour, know perfectly well that our challenge is not here, it is at home. It is not simply a question of evoking the cliché of structural reforms. It means saying that Italy, if it wants to be in the global competition, must change and in these six months we have done a lot in our country, what Italy needs to do is the Italian citizens, not the European institutions, and the Italian citizens must be much more aware that in recent years we have provided Europe with much more resources than we have taken. Every year, Italy gives the European institutions around EUR 20 billion and receive no more than half of it.  In recent years, Italy has helped to save not only neighbouring states, but also banks, credit institutions in other countries, and it has done so not because of an act of generosity but because it believes in the European institutions. It did so without putting a penny of the money from the European institutions for the benefit of its credit institutions, which, in fact, after the stress tests, were forced to increase capital. It did so because it believes in Europe, Italy is a country that does not come to the European institutions to ask for help, it comes to offer a great history that began in Rome with the signing of the Treaty, but perhaps we can say that it began much earlier, started in the values that made our country great, that made our continent great.  We have this idea of Europe: the idea of a great place of hope for future generations and we know that our problems we have to face at home, as we are doing with the reform of the Constitution, electoral law, justice and public administration, all realities that the Italian Parliament has put forward in these six months.  We have done so with a European and Pro-European vision, which has so many authoritative representatives in the history of our country – and I will allow you, Mr President, the Members of the European Parliament to recall one for all, which has been and has also been the guide for our country in these six months – I would like the European Parliament to welcome the President of the Italian Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, from here today. , a convinced Pro-European who will be leaving office at this very moment, having made a long journey of change and having dealt with the difficulties in Italy with the intelligence, wisdom that many of you have acknowledged to him by working alongside him in this House in past years.  Well, in these six months Italy has used two major objectives: the first, that of giving political value to your work, ladies and gentlemen: on 2 July when we came here to begin the six-month period there was still no new Commission. We have been co-operating with all the other governments, a choice which I consider historic: the result of the elections of 25 May has been chosen to be of political value. The The appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as President of the Commission does not simply arise from the recognition of a result which in itself would not have been enough, because the party that presented Jean-Claude had not obtained the majority of the members necessary to have a vote of confidence, but of a political agreement with a capital P in which, valuing the popular choice against President Juncker, it was decided to give profound meaning to the citizens' vote. , linking the Juncker Commission to a reform package, a political project for the coming years. This is the first time that this has happened in the history of the European institutions, and I believe that it should not be the last and that it should be codified to some extent by political custom, but it is a very significant step forward.  Alongside this, Italy has proposed a change in the economic paradigm that has characterized these years in our continental debate. I believe that either Europe is changing gears on the economy or we are becoming the taillight of a rapidly changing world. Mr Juncker has taken up this reasoning, he has broadened it with the members of his College, and I find it symbolic that today, at the Meeting of the College, Mr Juncker will present the communication on flexibility and the strategic investment lintel fund of the investment plan. These are two operations on which we are in favour, we recognise that we are moving in the right direction, in our opinion we need to do even more and we are ready to play our part. We are ready to be generous with the Fund, we are ready to believe deeply in investing in flexibility, not least because if there had not been flexibility, so many of the countries from which we come and come would not have the economic conditions they have today. If there had not been flexibility, reconstruction in Germany would not have been so easy, if there had not been flexibility, the policy would have been erased from this House today.  But what I want to say is that in these six months we feel like we have seen a profound change in direction, not yet in fact. I remember the Ypres Summit, it was June of this year, I remember the very tough discussion with my friends and fellow Heads of Government, when we stressed the importance of investing in growth, when we stressed the importance of investing differently in the relationship between economic and flexibility. How much time seems to have passed, yet only six months have passed! These are the two results that I think are together: investment in politics with politics, of the Commission choosing a direction.  I could, of course, discuss at length the results, the climate and energy agreement, the policy of transition from Mare Nostrum to Triton, the institutional transition carried out in spite of the negative wishes in a climate of positive cooperation, the automatic mechanisms to combat evasion, the investment in a different policy of international cooperation, the declassification, which was so much in the concern of this Parliament. , of the negotiating agreements for TTIP, GMOs, even with some defeats, I consider President Schultz to be a defeat and on made in the commitments that this Parliament, understood as an institution – because it was in April last year – but nevertheless this Parliament, understood as an institution, by asking the Council and the Commission to promote themselves, have not been successful. On made in it is incomprehensible the resistance that some countries are making.  For convenience, we have presented this document, it is a document that presents all the results of this six-month period and you will allow me, then, to move immediately to the second and final part of my reasoning. In other words, to return to the basic question: have we managed in recent months to restore a soul to Europe? It is difficult to approach this debate at a time when the debate on the profound meaning of Europe today sees an embarrassing demagogy pitted against that idea of places of hope and politics of Europe which, for example, His Holiness Pope Francis – who wanted to bring his speech to this Assizes during this very semester – explained with this clarity and with this beauty : the idea of Europe as something that the world needs and, on the other hand, the attempt to invest in demagoguery, fear, the attempt to block and curl up our values within a small frame and inside a fortress. The place of Europe is not the fortress is the square! The place of Europe is not the trench is the museum, it is the school! Europe's key word is not conflict and confrontation, but dialogue and encounter!  So from this point of view, Mr President, let me be very clear: we in this very House have opened up the I am proud and shivering to say that Europe is that in these six months we have allowed that woman to return to freedom and to take her born child to a prison to live free. Because for us, Europe is first and foremost freedom. Let me say, Mr President, that I am excited when, on 20 August, I had – on behalf of you too – the dramatic beauty and difficult situation of entering a refugee camp in Erbil; I remember the reaction of a young man in his twenties, of so many young people in his twenties, when in Srebrenica Europe did not have the courage to open its mouth and even the blue helmets witnessed astonished and squalid in the face of violence and genocide.  Today we have before us so many places where situations of pain, terror and horror are taking place. I believe that Europe must be there, and friends of the European Parliament know this well, those citizens who took to the streets in Paris. They know this well because some commentators have said: the historical photo is the photo of the leaders, no it is not the photo of the leaders walking together, the historical photo is the photo of a people, first and foremost the French people, whose history of lights and cathedrals, of reason and beauty, I place entering Strasbourg, a European headquarters but also a city French , a tribute, the tribute of all Italians and all Italians after what happened; but it is also, let me tell you, Mr President, that profound idea, that extraordinary experience that we had hearing the songs of the Marsigliese as we walked. Seeing the images of women and men who did not resign themselves to the idea of terror and fear and who said with their presence in those squares, that Europe is greater than threats, that our values are stronger than their attacks and that each of us, if we really want to be faithful to the idea of European Union and European unity , today it has the task of identifying an enemy.  Because the enemy is there! Woe betide those who pretend not to know that the enemy is there! Of course there is the enemy, but to those who say that religion is the enemy, I invite them to go and reread a great speech made by the Egyptian President – among the many appointments of this semester I would like to emphasize how the bilateral we did both in Cairo and in Rome, with the Egyptians, is one of the fundamental turning points for the Mediterranean – but that speech that Al Sisi gave on the first day of the year at a university in Cairo , at a university where he explained that the enemy is not religion, but it is that ideology that aims to kill even the very idea of religion that people and al Sisi leaders try to carry on on a daily basis.  The enemy is there, it is ideology, it is fanaticism, but the great risk that we run is not to not see the enemy, it is to think that fear can stop us, it can immobilize us, it can block us; So I believe that closing in, isolating one's isolation, raising limits, raising walls means not being European. Mr President, someone is currently going further, in the political debate, but also in the cultural debate, and goes so far as to say that we must, in the name of our security, live in fear and snuggled up. We have come to say that the word identity is contrary to the word integration, as a man of government, as an Italian man, let me say it as a left-winger, I want to say forcefully that we will never leave the word identity to those who shout loudest, because the word identity is a beautiful word that belongs to us, that concerns us, the word identity is a word that expresses the profound meaning of being European.  I am proud of my roots, I am proud of the streets where I played football, I am proud of the schools where I grew up, I belong to my land, I am proud to be European, Italian, Florentine, I am proud of what my small personal history represents, because my identity is a fundamental trait. The opposite of identity is not integration, the opposite of identity is anonymity, the opposite of integration is disintegration, it is rupture, it is destruction.  So today we must have the strength to say very clearly, with great determination, that when we think within the European institutions and outside that we are defending our identity by locking ourselves in fortresses in the name of security, we must always tell ourselves that freedom and responsibility are the conditions of security, that there is no possible security without freedom in Europe and that in this world our enemies cannot kill us aim to change our way of life. We cannot allow anyone to change the way we live if you want to call it the words you think is most appropriate; do you want to call it war? do you want to call it conflict? you can call it what you want!  There is a real reality, the bogeyman of demagoguery can bring an extra decimal vote, but if we are a ruling class here, if we are leaders and men here who are capable of leading the institutions, today's challenge is to get Europe back to doing its job, and this step leads me to say something very simple to close: if we are seeing politics return to Europe today it is because in these months and years we have since the world demands more Europe, not less Europe; But we have to tell the truth: this kind of Europe that we have built in recent years has given the impression that it is all too often a model based solely on the economy, on parameters, on constraints, on austerity.  I believe, Mr President, that at the end of these six months we can tell ourselves that this attitude was a mistake and that the change that the Juncker Commission is bringing about in these six months is a change that probably had to be imagined over the last six years, not in the last six months. Today the world is changing, the world is trying to invest in the future, Europe is not! We've been to Brisbane, along with the G20, and the words of growth, investment and innovation are words that have resonated everywhere. We must be at the helm of this phenomenon of change, not at the end of the day.  We will only be if Europe comes back to look itself in the eye with the awareness of those who represent a non-economic superpower, a value superpower, the same superpower of values that certain part of demagoguery would like to erase. In handing over the baton to the Presidency of Latvia, I would remind myself that when this Parliament was called to direct elections it was under the Italian Presidency, it was 1975. Under the Italian Presidency, agreement was reached to move on to direct voting and the direct election of MEMBERS of the European Parliament, it was a very important, very beautiful and very significant moment. Forty years ago Latvia was not only not part of the European Union, but was in a totally different history.  Today we are showing that Europe is capable of change, but we must also think that this change must first of all make us look at the neighbourhood policy in a different way, and this is the legacy that we give first of all to the new Presidency, neighbourhood policy means different attention to the Mediterranean, it means different attention to the enlargement of the European Union, because we cannot do without Albania , Serbia, Montenegro, and we cannot allow this debate on enlargement to be dictated and spoiled by fear. Of course, it also concerns the relationship between Ukraine and Russia, which has been one of the most sensitive issues of this six-month period and which I fear will continue to go through the season we are experiencing.  In meeting you at the next international events of Italy, starting from the EXPO, which on May 1st will address a great theme, for those who believe in politics: feeding the planet, changing the lives of men. This means making a great investment in lifestyle, but also in the fight against hunger. I would like to leave you not with a thought on Telemachus but with a thought about Ulysses, because it is difficult – reading more than two books is difficult for some of you, I understand it – but I have learned what Europe was not in the corridors of the institutions, I have learned what Europe was, Mr President, in studying the history of my city. In my city there is a great character who is Dante Alighieri, who when he puts in his mouth a small prayer in Ulysses, makes a reference that I find extraordinarily effective today, at the moment when they would like to holed up in the house afraid and upset, dante says making Ulysses speak: facts were not to live like brutes, but to follow virtue and canoeing. I think it's a great message for each of us today.  The European Parliament is at a crossroads, choose whether to imagine living like brutes, chasing a demagogic message that may bring a few more points but which will not allow Europe to govern and, on the other hand, there is the possibility of following virtue and knowledge, that is, of being European. And we, the excited and the responsible, believe that Today Europe is the real place of tomorrow's challenge.  In this spirit, I thank the institutions for their cooperation and say to the President of the European Parliament that Italy, true to its message of civilisation, values and ideals, will continue to work for a Europe that is increasingly the people and less and less bureaucracy.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, dear Matteo Renzi, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, there are times when it is difficult to move from one moment to the next. You rightly mentioned, in opening today's session, the liberation of the Nazi camps. Those born long after the war and those who have a bookish knowledge of the events you are talking about cannot imagine the pains and tragedies that may have swept through Europe between the years 1940 to 1945 but also 1933 to 1945. Watch out for bad beginnings, let's remember the story and learn from it.  And then we are now gathered on French territory. How could I forget at this moment the tragedy, the collective and individual tragedy that has just struck France in the middle of the past week. We remain shocked, outraged, appalled, disgusted by what has just happened in Paris. Yes, we're all Charlie, but around the world there's a lot of Charlies we need to think about today. However, as we are in France, I mean here: "Long live the Republic and long live France!". (Applause) We have reached the end of the Italian Presidency and on the eve of the Latvian Presidency. It is an occasion that invites reflection.  This is the end of an Italian Presidency, a Presidency of a founding Member State, and tomorrow the Latvian Prime Minister of a new member country will speak before us. Who would have thought in 1957 that in 2015 Latvia would preside over the destiny of Europe? Who would have thought that tomorrow we would hear the speech of a Latvian Prime Minister who, speaking before us, will symbolize the reconciliation between European history and geography and who will mark the end of the disastrous post-war decree which would have wanted Europe, forever, to be divided into two irreconcilable parts. I say today: "Long live Europe!" because tomorrow, as today, we will witness a great European moment and we can be proud of what we have achieved over the past decades. We have arrived at the end of the Italian Presidency to which I would like to pay, my dear friend, carissimo amico, all possible tributes. I have chaired the Council five times in my ministerial life, including twice the European Council. I know this feeling of the end of the Presidency. We are relieved, we are happy to hand over the keys to the next Presidency, but we are also frustrated because we were not able to do everything we had dreamed of before the start of the Presidency. But the Italian government has done many things. In particular, it allowed us to agree on the 2014 and 2015 budgets. On this point, the cooperation, collaboration and complicity between the Presidency and the Commission were total and, together with the other branch of the budgetary authority that you are, ladies and gentlemen, we have been able to do a good job together. But without the commitment, without the daily will of the Italian Presidency, this result would not have been possible and if the Italian Presidency had not been able to do what it did, we would find ourselves today in the middle of a budgetary crisis whose effects we would feel at every moment. The Italian Presidency has ensured that we can adopt all legal decisions on the single resolution mechanism for bank failures, a pillar of the banking union. Secondly, we were able to build on the Italian Presidency's desire to move quickly on investment. We agreed during the election campaign, at the time of the Commission's inauguration by Parliament, that we should put in place a virtuous triangle: fiscal consolidation which remains essential, structural reforms which are important but also a dimension of growth and job creation which has found a first concrete translation in the investment plan that I had the honour of presenting before you at the end of November.  Without the will, without the encouragement of the Italian Prime Minister, the Commission would have had a hard time moving forward as quickly as it did in terms of reviving European growth, which remains an essential dimension of the combined political will of The whole of Europe.  We will adopt - and Matteo Renzi has just said this - today, this afternoon in college, all the legal texts that are related to the establishment of the Investment Fund. We will today adopt a Commission communication on the flexibility of the Stability and Growth Pact, flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact and not next to and in parallel. On this point as on others, we owe to the enthusiasm of the Italian Presidency many elements inspiring the action of the European Commission.  To make a long speech more understandable, I would like to say here: "Yes, the Italian Presidency has done, as they say in somewhat approximate French, a good job!". The Italian Presidency has been up to the task and I hope that the Italian Government, when it leaves the Presidency, will remember the noble inspirations that led its work during the Presidency and that Italy, thanks to the genius of its people whom I continue to admire, will remain European just as it was during this Presidency. Viva Italia!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Outgoing President-in-Office of the Council, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Italy is a heartland of the European Union, of great economic importance, culturally of great importance, historically of great importance for our common European house. That is why, Prime Minister, there were also expectations, and the expectations were high for the Italian Presidency when it was launched six months ago. I would like to begin by thanking you, also on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, for the issues that have been put to the council. The results that we now have a stable budget for 2015 are a success for the Italian Presidency. Thank you very much for that – this signals stability and strength. The Italian Presidency has put migration on the agenda. I would like to say thank you to your Minister of the Interior, Angelino Alfano, who has also raised the issue, put it on the agenda and has thus made a contribution to the fact that we, as Europeans, feel that we have a shared responsibility. And we have had the major issues of flexibility and investment that have been raised in this six months. That is why, first of all, thank you for the work, and also the ministers and the experts for the design.  I would also like to thank you for what you have said on the subject of dimensions, to recognise the historical and democratic dimension of the last six months. Your clear statement that we have given the electorate the choice of who should lead Europe, that you, as President-in-Office of the Council, have also supported this in recent months, was an important sign. The fact that Jean-Claude Juncker is sitting in the seat today has been decided by the electorate because they have made the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats the largest group. This basic statement that the electorate has the decisive word – thank you for emphasising this once again. Now for the future: the tasks do not end, of course. Nor does Italy's responsibility end. I have talked about the old dispute – flexibility, investment. You have referred to this. You said that perhaps we should no longer see the Europe of the economy as so crucial, but rather the Europe of values. Honestly, it goes through my mind: why do we always have to build up conflicts in the sense of differences, do one thing and not do the other so strongly? I think we should be aware that it only works together! We will only be able to justify Europe's values internally to the citizen if we remain economically strong, and, above all, we will only be able to represent them externally if Europe remains a strong economy.  That is why I believe that we should not build up the conflict, but underline together what is important to us. When you talk about the EFSI, the investment pact that Jean-Claude Juncker and his Commission will be legisching this afternoon, then, yes, Vice-President Katainen always points to the investment side that we need to invest more in Europe. But it also underlines that part of the investment package is that we are advancing structural reforms and that we need to do more in terms of budget commitments, of the stability of our national budgets.  If flexibility is decided this afternoon, it is our common desire to clarify what flexibility means. However, Prime Minister Renzi, you also decided in the European Council that the rules – six-pack, two-pack – remain untouched, that they remain as they are. It says, for example, that states should strive to get to 60% of gross domestic product in total debt. I believe that both sides are right, that we interpret flexibility – and the Commission has a great responsibility to clarify what that means this afternoon – but that, on the other hand, we also recall what was decided in the Council, namely not to change the rules. Incidentally, it also has a lot to do with values in Europe, that we are reliable and that we implement what we promise people. Ladies and gentlemen, this week has a different tone, because we are all deeply influenced by Paris and by developments on our continent. That is why, in conclusion, I would like to underline once again what unites us as Europeans. The emotions that shape us all should not prevent us from going down a good path for our continent. Above all, I would like to make it clear that what constitutes the so-called Occtous is not the ideas that many radical forces in all the countries of the European Union have come up with. practiced. The West is solidarity, the West is subsidiarity, the West is Enlightenment, i.e. separation of state and religion, freedom of belief. These are the points that make up the West, and we will continue to promote and fight for them in the future. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Renzi, in your opening speech to the Italian Presidency on 2 July, you mentioned this a few minutes ago, and you said that the great challenge was to rediscover the soul of the European Union. On Sunday we were in Paris, the soul of Europe was there, among millions of people.  To those who want to lock us in the house, to those who want to raise walls, instill mistrust, fear, we responded on Sunday by taking to the streets, marching together. The Paris attack is not simply an attack on freedom of thought, of expression, it is an attack on European sovereignty – and European sovereignty means that a people is free to choose how to live and that no one can impose on us a way of life that we do not want.  So be careful not to fall into the trap of terrorism that would like to turn our societies into fortresses under siege: after 11 September, America chose to build more prisons than colleges, let us not make the same mistake in Europe! Europeans want to live in an open society, where freedom and security are together. Rediscovering the soul of Europe is therefore not a rhetorical formula, it means returning to dealing with people's real lives, their anxieties and their hopes; it means giving citizens a free and dignified life and the first freedom is that of need. Blind and deaf austerity has increased unemployment, precariousness and poverty.  The Italian Presidency has laid down the conditions for putting Europe back on track. In July, when you talked about investments to be revived, many smiled, Mr. President. This afternoon, as Mr Juncker and yourself have said, the Commission will approve the regulation of the 300 billion plan. We have a plan for growth, with its strengths and also with its weaknesses, on which my group is committed to taking action to change them. In inaugurating the semester you also talked about flexibility, there was a lot of irony there too: what is this flexibility that Renzi is talking about? It almost felt like a battle of Don Quixote! Renzi Don Quixote who comes here and manages to clear and remove that rigor with which the pact was implemented. Today, the Commission officially presents the communication on flexibility, and I believe that it will contain important elements of which we must be proud. Thanks also to the Italian Presidency, we were able to stop the idea of who actually wanted to commissioner the Member States, imposing sanctions if they refused to implement the reforms decided by Brussels; what was in danger of being bad communication turned into an excellent starting point.  We get an important achievement, the golden rule of investment, it seemed like a dream, a pipe dream: the golden rule on investments is a historic battle of our group, the cofinancing of European investments even those provided for in the Juncker plan will be decomputed by the Stability Pact for those countries that do not exceed the 3% deficit limit. Cofinancing from the Structural Funds, too, seemed like a pipe dream, and that is a fact! A revolutionary fact, of course! Go and talk to the citizens, to the regions, to the private actors, who cannot co-finance the European funds. Yes, we still want to achieve more, but these are important facts and results. Allow me to quote one last quote, Mr Schultz, in a borges story: a child asks a wise man if he is capable of touching the stars and the wise man bends over and touches the earth! So, without noise, with courage but with realism, this Presidency has begun to change Europe, we must move forward for change with you, Mr Renzi!

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Prime Minister Renzi, in June you asked how the EU would look if we were to take a selfie. I am just wondering how the Italian Presidency would look today if it were to take a selfie, and my answer is that there would not be much in it – although that is not surprising, because from the very beginning there was going to be a minimalist legislative agenda reflecting the post-election situation. However, your presidency has managed to broker some agreements between Parliament and the Council on legislation, so let me enumerate some of these. First, money-laundering: the problem here is that the agreement reached on the fourth directive should not only address the burden on innocent people who have been tied up in red tape, but should also indicate how we are to tackle the billions of euros that go towards organised crime and terrorism. Second, GMOs: this is a highly divisive issue, and the deal we are going to vote on soon reflects the fact that some governments are definitely pro-GMO, while others are more cautious. Third, the 2015 budget: it is true that you secured agreement on the budget, but that agreement still leaves significant unpaid bills. I think you missed an opportunity to take responsibility for this unsustainable situation. Fourth, migration in the Mediterranean: I think that is a plus for you. Fifth, the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) talks. We are pleased that, under the Italian Presidency, the Council declassified negotiating directives and, given last week’s publication of the legal proposals by the Commission, it is fair to say that there is more transparency around the agreement, and people’s fears may be dispelled. All in all, if I were to give you a grade, I would give you ‘fair’. I do not know if you would be happy with that. Probably not, but it is quite good, so congratulations anyway.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, first of all I would like to say to Mr Renzi that I was pleased with his pro-European intervention, because I am a little anxious about Italy when I see that in the latest opinion polls the three main opposition parties have around 40%. That is normal in a democracy, but these three main opposition parties are now parties against the euro and against more European integration. So my wish for you is that you succeed in your reforms in Italy in order to stop this anti-European movement in your country, because we certainly need Italy at the centre of the European Union. I would also like to thank Sandro Gozi, who did the concrete work and was the link with Parliament. I remember also the enormous contribution made by Giorgio Napolitano here in this Parliament at the beginning of the year, showing the way for the future. I think when we look at the Italian Presidency, the most important feature of your presidency was to end this discussion, as Mr Weber has indicated, between fiscal discipline on the one side and growth and investment on the other. We need both. I think that can be the conclusion of this whole debate. But that is only the start of this work, because we now need this Investment Plan. I have to tell you, Mr Renzi, that what we need now – and I hope for your support in the next Council – is for all Member States to enter the guarantee scheme of that Investment Plan. The participation of Member States will not count in the Stability Pact – that is certain, and we have known that from the beginning – so there is no reason why all Member States should not enter the guarantee scheme of the Investment Plan to make it a success. I think that it is absolutely unacceptable that some of the Member States are saying that this is not their business. Secondly, we need real structural reforms – not only the announcement of structural reforms – in the near future. Finally, we need a package of legislation to open these key markets, but we shall discuss that with the Commission later. I have only one disappointment with the Italian Presidency, and that is that the Telecoms Package has not been concluded. Let us be honest. We are talking here – everybody is talking – about investment, the digital world, Google… we need to have an answer to that. Are we not capable today, in 2015, of making an agreement with the Member States on the digital market and on the Telecoms Package, getting rid of the roaming charges, installing net neutrality? So that is my only disappointment, but I hope that in the next six months under the new Presidency, the Italians can push forward that absolute need for a digital market.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on Sunday in Paris, millions of citizens finally made the heart of Europe beat and it was a consolation in pain to see Heads of Government parade in the streets, for once in the name of high values rather than locked up in smoky summits discussing 3% decimals.  Six months ago, you deluded us – something that succeeds you well – by opening up a dream book with the magic recipe for bringing European citizens closer to an institution that you described as boring. However, you have promised to commit ambition, energy and courage – skills that I recognise – but there are still words! In six months you have put a lot of energy into looking for small loopholes in treaties that need to be rewritten or scrapped. Or do some lunatic really believe that Italy, with the third public debt in the world, in the presence of recession and deflation, can ever apply the fiscal compact? It did not have the ambition to claim a role for the Mediterranean area other than the fate of the periphery of the Empire! He did not have the courage to call for an end to the austerity that has destroyed the middle class.  It was an un-European and very Italian semester, you were very busy illustrating to Italians bizarre homeopathic treatments how to combat mass unemployment by making it easier to lay off or decriminalising tax crimes to combat tax evasion. Six months ago, Mr Verhofstadt said that ten years had been lost in the relationship between Italy and Europe behind Berlusconi's nonsense, with today we are ten years plus six months!

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, Prime Minister Renzi, I would like to thank the President for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Her Presidency was not an easy one, she was playing in these times of transition. It would have been wrong to expect too much. I would have been pleased if you had spoken a little more openly about the problems that have just come to light in recent days; we talked about it very well yesterday. We must all be grateful to the citizens of France for giving European politics a new chance, as it were, with this marche républicaine, to renegotiate the values and objectives that we have been talking about for a long time between the political camps, but also between politicians and the citizens. Judging by the objectives of your Presidency, it is important now to re-talk about how mistrust can become trust again, not only between the different groups in our societies, but indeed between citizens and politicians. I would have been pleased if you had said in this context how you actually see what the European Union's interior ministers have presented as answers to the challenge of freedom. Having seen how much data was available in France about the assassins, the murderers, I feel rather unsettled when the new answer is the old answer and more data is supposed to provide more security for Europe. We are and must talk about integration, about education, about all this. But even as a Green, I know that this security challenge is a serious challenge. Nevertheless, the answers so far are not at all satisfactory. They had made flight, asylum and immigration a priority of the Italian Presidency. At the moment, I would say that these scrap steamers, these scrap tankers that transport more and more people, desperate people, from Asia and Africa to Europe, actually symbolise what we have done with Dublin I, II and III, and that they also symbolise that, although we are not economically at the end, but one of the richest areas in the world, Europe has not yet been able to create an adequate right of immigration. Greece and the euro – a major issue of uncertainty. Yes, there has been a bit of a tightening up on the euro stabilisation policy and crisis policy. However, I would like to say once again on my group that I do not believe that the euro will become stable without the political elite daring to go to the political and economic integration of the European Union. It is not Mr Tsipras who is the problem in Greece or for Greece, the problem is that we have not been able to build confidence for the economic and political integration of the European Union.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Renzi, six months ago in this House you said: if Europe took a selfie, it would have the face of boreness, the face of tiredness, the face of resignation. This seems to us to be the exact description of your Italian presidency.  Today in this House I see a magician pulling the rabbit out of the cylinder, here we hope to amaze everyone by extracting from his jacket the promise of an agreement to ensure greater flexibility in national budgets, we will see! Unfortunately, from the first rumors, we understand that this agreement is only about the minimum of what was expected, namely that only with investments to co-finance works already identified and promoted by the Commission itself. A little less than the premises of last July!  Let us say that this umpteenth twist will no longer deceive us, we will not be able to distract ourselves from the fact that yours has been the six months of missed opportunities – and I say this because when you lead such an important institution, you have to give absolutely everything, because if you pull hard you benefit everyone, otherwise we are wasting time! It was a missed opportunity, the appointment of his pupil Mogherini as High Representative for Foreign Affairs, he insisted on a role as a façade when we could and should have asked for a portfolio that could really make a difference. Mogherini who, by the way, has not yet brought home the marò.  It was a missed opportunity to increase employment, which you have so much heralded as a priority for the six months, but on which you have not been able to propose any concrete measures, and we see this in Italy where 43% of young people are out of work and total unemployment has reached 13.4%. It was a missed opportunity to protect our businesses, they were asking you loudly to finally reach an agreement in the Council to defend made in, an agreement that this Parliament served you on a silver platter with a rule, but you shamefully threw in the towel.  There have been missed opportunities: – the agreement on energy efficiency, signed downwards, sold off in the interests of who knows what strong powers; - the REGULATION on GMOs condemning our farmers to put themselves in the hands of biotech multinationals; - immigration policies, miserably limited to a programme, Triton, whose budget is once again left to the goodwill of individual states; - the lack of transparency on TTIP, an agreement that risks further putting European companies in difficulty; – the digital agenda programme, which does not provide for concrete investment to make our economy more modern and competitive. To return to the image of the selfie, to you so dear President Renzi, I am sorry to tell you that despite the dazzling smile that persists in unlining in the foreground, behind us we can only see the rubble!

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the six months have not been rejected by the Lega Nord, it has been rejected by this House! I would like the citizens throughout Europe who are following us via TV and the Web to not see my beautiful or ugly face for ten seconds, but thanks to the cameras they would frame this House, turning: it is nothing, it is the desert, it is the worthy end of six months of chatter, not even the men of Renzi's party have wasted a few minutes of their time listening to his nothingness , evidently this deserted Chamber is the best response to the words in the wind of those who gave us 80 pages six months ago. We read: Europe, a new beginning!  Today he gives us more pages on what has been done, what remains in our hands? Unemployment at an all-time high; a wrong currency such as the euro that no one is questioning; on business protection: zero; on the defense of Made in Italy: zero; on the defence of European companies against invasions of counterfeit products from China: zero; to change the Bolkestein Directive, which is putting thousands of beach workers at risk: zero; protection of agriculture: zero; 4,000 rice companies at risk because we are invading with rice from Cambodia: zero; fruit and vegetable companies: zero, you prefer to make agreements with Morocco, in the name of dialogue they close companies and we help the multinationals that go to invest in North Africa, brilliant; we are dealing with problems in half the world and there are two European soldiers who have been detained in India for years, sent back and forth: zero; immigration, you have changed the names but it does not change the meaning, you can call it Mare Nostrum, Triton, Goofy, Pluto or Donald Duck, an unprecedented invasion is taking place that puts at risk the safety of millions of European citizens, on what have you done?: zero; Russia, but at a time like this instead of going around Paris – rightly as so many good people have done – we are talking to Russia, which must be an enemy against Islamic extremism.  I am pleased about one thing, nothing of it, on page 11 of your programme there was an intention to restart negotiations to bring Turkey into Europe, fortunately its nothing has also prevented us from restarting these negotiations. Thank you very much and hurrah for Latvia, which will certainly be able to do something more than the dramatic Italian Presidency.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the President-in-Office The only one who gave very concrete results from this six-month year was the President of the Commission. He spoke of the fact that the budget and the fact that bank resolution were actually brought about. That's right. Otherwise, there has been a lot of talk about European values and about the confidence of the citizens, and then, as a consequence, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the most important thing is that we now have to reverse all policy, and that must take place now, and that would take place today in the Commission meetings.  I hope it does not happen. After all, what has been politics up to now has been a policy of reliability, stability and growth! This was an attempt to make progress step by step through the given words and appointments that we made together – six-packs, two-packs. We have also made step-by-step progress in this, if I see it correctly, when I look at Spain, when I look at Ireland. After all, progress has been made in many countries. In some, progress has not been so good, that is true.  But we have to ask why. Is the answer that you are now simply throwing everything overboard, that you are now counting investments, that you are loosening stability criteria, that you are only living on the fact that you have to promise structural reforms, but that you do not have to comply with them at all? I don't think so.  People's confidence will depend on whether we deliver results, whether we deliver progress, whether people feel that things are really moving forward, that we are getting growth. This does not depend on more money, it does not depend on more programmes, but on reliability. This also means that what has been decided is respected. That is what I would like to see from the Commission, from Parliament and from the Council and, incidentally, from the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I wonder: would you agree with me that what we have seen from Mr Renzi today is a virtuoso performance with absolutely wild ideas and arrogance beyond words when describing the people who oppose him? Or maybe you agree with him that people like me – who are just poor brutes and who do not have the opportunity to have a democratic point of view – should maybe be quiet in the face of such civilised and learned people and not bother representing the people who voted for us?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work I think that this Presidency has produced a few results, which have been presented. Then the President-in-Office of the Council proposed political demands that everything should be reversed here. I do not share that at all. I have said this just as precisely and clearly. That is the difference. But I would never deduce a general insult to politicians and politicians. That is of no use at all. This does not take a step forward.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Mr Juncker, Mr Renzi, the Italian Presidency will be remembered for a number of initiatives, notably with regard to the bank resolution fund or money laundering, but it will be remembered above all for having the courage and the intelligence to put on the political agenda some of the key issues for the survival of the euro and the European project.  The reconciliation between the discipline of public accounts and the survival of the economy and employment or the need not to kill strategic investment just because public spending needs to be contained may seem trivial and, nevertheless, they are not.  The Italian Presidency has taken these issues seriously as topics for discussing Europe's fundamental policies. The European Commission is new, it has changed, Parliament has changed, Europe continues, however, to plunge into stagnation with risks of deflation, with frightening unemployment and with the loss of citizens' confidence in the European project.  True, the Italian Presidency has not yet brought the shock of energy and vitality that Europe urgently needs, but perhaps that would be impossible. But after years of dogmatism, blind and impoverished and hopeless austerity, the new Juncker Commission and the Italian Presidency have begun to open up the issues of interest and point in the right direction. Nothing is concluded, but the doors have been opened to the work we have to do, certainly at the level of each country, but certainly also collectively, now that the limits and gaps of European architecture and, above all, of the single currency are evident. The reflection must continue. I hope that the Latvian Presidency will not miss the moment, but I also hope that Italy, once in the Council, will not lose its way. Europe needs Italy, the citizens represented here in this House need to find hope again and to find europe's soul above all. Thank you to the Italian Presidency and a light of hope opens up in front of us.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I would like to first congratulate Italy on the Presidency of the European Council and I would like to take this opportunity, dear Prime Minister Renzi, to also thank you for finally launching the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy of the European Union in the belief that the countries covered by this strategy will have a new opportunity. The four Member States of the European Union, Italy, Croatia, Slovenia and Greece, and the four non-member countries, which are an integral part of this Adriatic-Ionian strategy, have reason to expect much. I urge you, Mr. Prime Minister, that Italy, in these coming years of creating this strategy, will really remain true to this strategy because it will be very difficult without the strong involvement of your state for this strategy to actually come to life. Expectations are high in the Balkans, in the often restive Balkans, regarding this strategy and I expect your active participation in the realisation of the strategy.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would suggest abandoning the metaphor of the selfie, you would risk seeing a lot of smoke of the rhetoric behind this selfie and perhaps in the backlight the inscription: leave all hope or you who enter. I propose that we abandon this narcissistic gesture and look into the eyes of the generation that has been called Erasmus, which has been called telemachus and which would be the highest generation with youth unemployment that Europe can remember.  I want to disassemble one by one the words I have heard here: – growth; growth would be the Juncker plan? - flexibility; Would flexibility be compliance with all treaties and stability pacts, as was mentioned in this House? Or the democratic embection of TTIP? Or the EXPO where thousands of unre paid young people will work? I believe that the hope for Europe comes from the thousands of people who demonstrated in Italy against a further process of insecurity, with the social strike, with the general strike and coming from Greece. We cannot talk about Europe, assuming that Greece is expelled from our continent. We believe that in Greece, with the victory of Alexis Tsipras, the hope of another possible Europe can be reopened.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, as a Frenchman, I would like to thank you for your participation in the historic event in Paris and for the sensitive and just words it inspired you. I would also like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker for the words that came from the depths of his heart.  Mr President of the Council, we join you when you say that during this six-month period, what you have done most useful for Europe is finally the reforms carried out in Italy itself. Other governments, including my country's, could draw on your courage.  The European balance sheet itself is not entirely at the level of the verbal ambitions that were originally displayed. I will just talk about two ambiguous results.  First, the budget. Yes, the EU has a budget in 2015, but the backlog of 25 billion unpaid bills will prevent the European Commission from launching any new policies this year.  Second, maritime control in the Mediterranean. We salute the performance and courage of the Italian navy with Operation Mare Nostrum. Triton succeeded him, but has no money and may be less effective in saving the castaways and controlling migratory pressure.  In both cases, the substantive problems were simply postponed.  (The speaker agrees to answer two "blue card" questions (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Do you not agree with me, Mr Renzi, that the Italian Presidency will be remembered only for two things: the collapse of the euro and the potential exit of Greece and Italy and, of course, the LuxLeaks scandal, which has been dogging this presidency?

name: Giulia MOI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you said that the Italian Presidency inspired you, and I would like to know whether you have also inspired you with regard to the scams and thefts that are coming to light, which our political class has carried out over all these years. The EXPO in Milan, there is the Mafia, there are infiltrations of 'ndrangheta and for years they have done nothing and have hidden everything; the MOSE in Venice, they stole billions of public funds and they never said anything and they are all corrupt and no one is guilty and everyone has bargained; in Rome, is there the mafia capital and all this inspired it? Congratulations!

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. I will say to both speakers that, unlike them, I am not a European federalist. Therefore, I consider that what may have happened in Greece, Luxembourg and other European countries during these six months did not depend on the European Union or the Italian Presidency, but on each of the countries concerned.  In the same way, I would say that the reproaches that can possibly be made to Italian politics should not be addressed to the European Parliament, but to the Italian Prime Minister here.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the words with which Mr Juncker has today acknowledged that the two important decisions that the College of Commissioners is about to take, namely the investment regulation and the communication on flexibility, were inspired by the Italian Presidency, should close the debate on the results of this Presidency, which I only see as an incurable partisan provincialism that is a little self-harming, instead persists in fuelling in Italy and partly in this House.  These are concrete, very important results, which go far beyond the traditional tasks of a six-monthly presidency, and they have been important in substance. I understand Mr Weber's nervousness, but the communication will clearly show that the rules contain flexibility, and the problem is that in previous years these rules, that is, flexibility in the rules, were not applied with great damage not to the rules themselves, but to the economy of our continent. These results are particularly important for the method, this Presidency has insisted, it has invested in the nascent parliamentary political dimension of Europe and if the streets and squares of Paris have shown us that Europe is not just a procedure, I believe that this gamble of a nascent political Europe is the main and most lasting legacy of the Italian Presidency. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you talk about concrete results, I know that in Italy public debt has increased, unemployment has risen, businesses that close have increased. Did you read this data? Are you talking to the citizens, to the entrepreneurs? Because this optimism that you and our Prime Minister Renzi express is not felt in Italy! The situation is only getting worse, so enough of these announcements and fine words, because in practice the problems are there and have increased during this European Semester.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I see that we are in the middle of a national debate, but the Italian economy is in a worrying situation, not least as a result of wrong choices made for many years, including those made by the governments to which you and your party have for many years given their confidence. During this six-month period, the foundations have been laid for a change of direction in European policy.  Of course, expecting a communication passed at 1.00 p.m. to have its results retrospectively is perhaps a little too much for any presidency, even I think Superman would not be able to do that. I believe that with the results that the College of Commissioners will be delivering today – with all its limitations – we are putting the foundations in practice for a change of direction in European policy, and this is a fact that cannot but be recognised and is an extraordinary political success.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I must also thank Mr Renzi for what he has been able to achieve during the last six months. Mr Renzi, you came along with an ambitious agenda at a time when the financial crisis was still hitting hard on all of the Western world. You also came at a time when we have a new Parliament, when we have a new Commission. I would like to stake out two points where I actually feel that we – and especially the Presidency – could have done much more. The first one is the digital single market, which my leader, Guy Verhofstadt, also mentioned. But the second one is maybe the biggest task that we have to address for the future, and that is the climate goals, where the Council actually lowered the ambitions which were set high by this House. I do hope that slowing down on the Green path for the future does not mean that we lose investments and pace for the future, because that task is something we have to keep up during the whole legislature to be able to tackle the tasks that we have to address in the future for business and especially for the citizens of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – You have pointed out very well. You said that you find that the European Commission has dropped certain claims, you have only linked yourself to the environment - personally, I think other claims that we, as Parliament, have supported. Are you willing to support a resolution by our group to improve the Commission's programme?

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: blue-card answer. – I am always in favour of taking steps forward when it comes to Green policies, because I am among those in this House who believe that the future lies on the Green path, which is beneficial for our industries and economies, as well as for jobs. However, we are not speaking about the Commission’s working programme at the moment; we are reviewing the Italian Presidency. I think more could have been done, but actually much was also achieved if we take the circumstances into account: a new Parliament, a new Commission and also the devastating effects of the financial crisis that we are in. But that does not mean that we have an excuse not to do the right things on the Green path.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that it is clear to everyone that, despite the goodwill we are putting in, Mr President, there is not much enthusiasm, we would have expected something more concrete. After so many years in Europe, we Italians have also made a good habit of becoming concrete, because here we are used to getting to the bottom of the matter and, therefore, if we have somehow opened up a credit in the opening speech, when you have nevertheless transported us with so many fine words to the future and future Europe, today this momentum that you continue to have towards Europe that persists in declining to the future , is a little off topic.  We are here today to take stock, so surely everything will be on those cards, but perhaps it was more useful to be able to open the cards here at the moment to have some debate between us. It is not that we have so many opportunities and this one of the Italian semester closes today and the budget is not the most exciting. We would have expected to repeat something more concrete, something more concrete about the rows that have been broken there, on which we will continue to work hard convinced that these are important things for our fellow citizens, but we would have expected something more on the economy and development.  You mentioned made in, you mentioned many things that have not been put into practice but above all you have said nothing and you have not given some direction on how to manage the emergencies of these last hours of the Triton mission, nothing about the attitude that Europe should have towards ISIS, which has become an example and shelter for all Islamic terrorists around the world.  Not even the hope that security expenditure will be ed out of the Stability Pact could be something that could be done, I believe in a few hours. From the Telemachus with which we had begun to make the journey six months ago, I think we were left with the image of that slightly dispassionate boy who saw his mother weaving and undoing with his gaze pointed towards the horizon waiting for new ones that took so many years to arrive. We hope to do better in the next six months! (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to ask Mr De Clercq whether he is aware of the fact that there is a very good deal to be said. Gardini: we are saying here that our main objective is to bring Europe back to growth and growth is investment. Now, these are two results – that not only of the Juncker plan, but of the possibility through Goldenrule of being able to activate investments directly and indirectly also of states – absolutely essential. Do you not think that these are concrete results? The others have already mentioned others and I do not have time to do so myself, but these seem to me to be very concrete and above all in line with what we have asked for in recent short months, but which you have certainly asked for in the past unnecessarily.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we do not believe that this is a common line. I am pleased that the Italian Presidency – as President Junker said earlier – has cooperated and not hindered but helped along this path, but it was a path that had already been taken, for example, with regard to the PPE, even last spring long before the Italian Presidency, at our Congress in Dublin. In concrete terms, I mean, we have not heard anything about how this speech will be declined in Italy. That is all very well, but the President-in-Office of the Council did not mention it.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President You have become President of the Council at a turbulent time. The wind has literally blown, and when the wind blows – I know as a sailor – there are always two types of people: some retreat into the native walls and the others set sail and try to get somewhere. I feel like you tried to set sail. However, this tanker european Union is still difficult to control even in good winds, and that is not why everything is always as you like, and it requires, above all, hard work. I have heard this hard work from the Italian Presidency. I was the chief negotiator for the so-called gigaliners, these giant trucks that some people want to drive through Europe. Hard work has been done to create a sensible package, a sensible solution, with which everyone is now satisfied. That is a good thing, that is what distinguishes your Presidency, and I do not understand those Members who do not take part in this work at all, who are always against everything, who sit at the back right here and then accuse you of nothing going on. Colleagues, that is simply hypocritical.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, President Juncker, Prime Minister Renzi, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Italian Presidency for a very good job in this area after area. After the events of the last few days in France, however, it feels almost a little palery to discuss small things such as trade mark rules, but perhaps that is the strength of our Union – that at the same time we are able to deal with big important issues and a little less. As rapporteur for the reform of European brands, I have had the privilege of working with very skilled diplomats and experts. Thanks to the great progress we have made, I am convinced that we will soon resolve this issue. The Citizens' Europe was reinforced in the grief manifested by three and a half million citizens over the weekend. They expect us to defend transparency now – the open Europe in which fundamental rights are a cornerstone. That is why it is now so important that this is what we are establishing and promoting in everything we do.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: Mr President, I wholeseed those who praised the success of the Italian Presidency on the day he is accountable for his mandate. I believe that, in the economic sphere, it can be said that they have done so quite satisfactorily and that there have been data and behaviours that have enabled revival and growth, and that recovery is already perceived as solid. And on this point, allow me, Mr President, to quote Spain. In addition, it has been at this time that the Juncker plan has been established, hope and central axis of the future. In the area of transport, I would like to quote that a solution has been given and good agreement has been reached on the single European sky. In foreign policy, it is worth noting the place that follows and will continue to occupy the Ukrainian crisis. And the terrorist attacks of these days show us that the area of freedom, security and justice needs to be strengthened. In particular, we consider that the start-up of the PNR passenger register is a priority. And we mean with all solemnity: in order to guarantee freedoms, it is inexcusable that the role of security should be strengthened. Security is not a fundamental right, but it is a legal good that is essential to preserve the guarantee and exercise of freedoms.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Mr President, Italy took the presidency during the period of renewal of the European institutions. Over the last six months, a new Parliament has been established, a new Commission has been elected, the leaders of the European Union have taken up the role. The Presidency has dealt with the difficult transition between the two legislative cycles with dignity, both through work within its own priorities but also by continuing to work unfinished.  As rapporteur for the legislative proposal to introduce a public eCall emergency system, I had the opportunity to cooperate personally with representatives of the Italian Presidency. It was constructive cooperation. Thanks to the intensive commitment of the Italian colleagues, an agreement has been reached between the Member States and Parliament. The result is support for a proposal that has a positive impact on citizens' daily lives and contributes to strengthening safety on Europe's roads. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to sincerely thank you, Prime Minister, and your colleagues for your work.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, Mr President of the European Commission, at the end of this Presidency, I believe that we can congratulate you on a successful institutional transition between two Commissions of different democratic scope. But this transition has increased your political responsibility. That is why I would like to go back to four priorities.  First of all, I would like to welcome the adoption of the conclusions on the management of migration flows and the launch of the Khartoum process with the countries of the Horn of Africa. This allows for a greater synergy between migration policy and external policies. This is the direction to be taken to establish real diplomacy on migration.  Nevertheless, I remain much more reserved about Operation Triton and its means to achieve the objective of a supportive and effective policy. With regard to the area of freedom, security and justice, I note that the doors of the Schengen area have still remained closed for Bulgaria and Romania, despite the technical criteria. The political deadlock must no longer last. Third, we saw what happened with South Stream. Energy policy must be conceived today as an instrument of regional integration that will enable Member States, including Bulgaria, to continue to support the European project while opening up the prospects for mutual benefits with the countries of the Southern and Eastern Mediterranean. In this regard, I congratulate the Italian Presidency on the inter-ministerial conference held in Rome last November with the Euromed countries. Finally, I regret that this Presidency has not made progress on the only credible legislative dossier on gender equality: the Directive on Gender Balance among Corporate Directors. This is a missed opportunity and I hope that in the future it will no longer be the case.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Mr President Renzi, as President Juncker has pointed out, you have been able to reach agreement on the 2014 and 2015 budgets. We also highlighted your willingness to highlight recovery and growth. But your Presidency could have been better if you had not accumulated two calendar handicaps.  The first one, we see it every five years. It is the renewal of the institutions: the installation of Parliament on 1 July, at the beginning of your Presidency, and then the installation of the Commission, chaired by Mr Juncker, on 1 November. It is normal that legislative production has suffered as a result.  The second handicap is that experienced by all the presidencies of the second semester, who start to work when, slowly, one enters the summer, with two months which are not two months off work - in any case, the month of July has a continuity - but which are a handicap. So my proposal is this: could we not think about starting the semi-annual presidencies on 1 February and 1 August, so as to better distribute the two summer months which are necessarily less productive?

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am a Member of Parliament for the first time and listening to this debate I had the feeling that many of the things that were said after your speech would have been said anyway. Whatever he did during the Italian Presidency, and I am sorry about that because it makes the debate a little depressing and also takes away the effectiveness of some legitimate criticisms that could enrich our work.  I am one of those who believe that the presence of an investment plan of more than EUR 300 billion is a fact and a good thing, it would have been worse not to have it. So I start with this, very humbly. I am also willing to make some reasoning on the merits, that plan is a plan that has good characteristics but also shadow cones, leverage from 1 to 20 is demanding. For example, it deprives many investments that would be strategic but have little capacity to generate profit from this plan, for example, investments in the railway sector.  People who want to work on the real problems, people who want to go all the way in this great attempt, in this great adventure to build a Europe that is not the subject of a debate or a conference, but is a place to grow up and make a family and do business, there is. I assure you it's there. It is often true that this House is empty, unfortunately often those who accuse this House of being empty here are not here, but what I say is that those who are there want to work and study, knowing that our proposal is a proposal that has clear roots and I repeat them once again: they are Christian Judaeo roots that we know have been attacked at the moment. We are not waiting for any more signals! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marco VALLI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the floor after the third blue card that you did not listen to and did not see, perhaps.
