I wanted to ask you, Salini, given that you are new, but you sit in a party here in the European Parliament that strongly supports the Stability and Growth Pact if what President Renzi has not achieved in this six-month period to amend the Stability and Growth Pact and then the fiscal compact will then be fiscally sustainable for Italians? That is my question: I want to know if this is sustainable for you, because the Italians must know that they will become impoverished in the coming years.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced of one thing, I have also been the local administrator, I have been president of the province and therefore I have experienced the Stability Pact on my own skin. It is not true that the Stability Pact prevents us from existing, it prevents us from existing to those who have no alternative proposals to administer public life. We – and we will be discussing the revision of the regulation this afternoon – have asked not to avoid it, the Stability Pact, but to revise it, to reconceive it, so its concerns are also ours but with 'some concrete proposals' .

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Juncker, the six months of the Italian Presidency that have just ended marked a first turning point in Europe's political priorities. If the issues of intelligent flexibility, investment and growth policies have come firmly on the agenda of the European political agenda, if in the Mediterranean, together with italian ships, today cross those of other European countries, this is due to the changed political framework that emerged from the Elections in May, but above all to decisive action by the Italian Presidency.  Together we should turn this political breakthrough into a constituent phase that will give us a more authoritative Union in the world, more attentive to social priorities and growth based on the real economy. The events of the last few days have shown us once again that only with more Europe will we be able to face the challenges of the coming years. We would like to see the image we have all seen on Sunday, that of European leaders marching together, to translate into political action today. To quote Altiero Spinelli: the way forward is neither easy nor safe, but it must be travelled!

name: Boris ZALA
text: Mr President, colleagues, when assessing the Italian Presidency, we must not forget that the past six months were probably the most challenging from the perspective of foreign policy: from the Russian aggression in Ukraine to the rise of Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq and Syria, which have fundamentally altered Europe’s strategic environment. Under Italy’s stewardship the EU responded well enough. We came together to agree on a robust sanctions package in response to Russia’s blatant violation of international law, and this in itself counts as a historic achievement for our common foreign policy. In the southern neighbourhood, several EU Member States, including Italy, joined the international coalition against ISIS which halted its military advance and forced it to retreat. Italy also steered the EU’s response to the immigration crisis in the Mediterranean Sea – the Triton operation. For the moment, we should take some comfort from the fact that, in both the southern and eastern neighbourhoods, things look a little more stable than they did in the summer. We have averted the worst-case scenarios, and for that the Italian Presidency deserves credit.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Since yesterday, we have heard a great deal of beautiful words about European solidarity in this House (also during today's debate), but when our farmers needed solidarity, when they were affected by the Russian embargo, our solidarity turned out to be 10% by measuring the scale of aid. It is in these situations, when countries that oppose the security of our countries, try to probe our resilience, our solidarity in the most peaceful way, that we should show that we are prepared to take on such challenges. Therefore, in the future, balancing this half-year, we should act so that we are ready to show the ability to help the security of our peoples, the interests of our citizens, and loyalty to our friends.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Renzi, I believe that the Italian Presidency played a fundamental and political role in the year of parliamentary change and also in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy, that is to say, to put at the centre of our attention and our work an investment policy that President Juncker has reconfirmed as inspired components and not only accompanied by the Italian Presidency; I would also like to add the important triangle: Research, Education, Culture and Audiovisual. This is a subject that I know very much about the President and I must admit that we have done an excellent job, and I say this also as chairman of the Committee on Culture, with the Italian Presidency, with the Minister for Culture, Youth and Sport, because there has been a great deal of work on these issues.  I would like to remind you, from this point of view, that an important result is that education will be one of the five priorities of the investment plan. it will have to give more opportunities not only for work, but for cultural tourism and again also economic development to be at the heart of the review of the Europe 2020 Strategy. I would like to thank the Presidency for that.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, there has been much talk in the Italian Presidency about identity. A European identity. This identity was composed of the European social model, based, inter alia, on social dialogue and the importance of collective bargaining, with a balance in industrial relations through labour law. And yet, at the end of this Presidency we have seen, once again, how reforms continue to be proposed that dismantle the basic structures of social and labour protection. Also in Italy, as before in Spain and other countries. No work has been done to ensure economic recovery or employment. We have little hope in the Juncker plan. We've heard of Ulysses, an adventurer. But in The Odyssey there is also Penelope, a besieged woman who weeds and weans her net to preserve the heritage, precisely, of Ulysses. You and your nefarious policies are managing to dismantle the social heritage of Europe and its citizens, thereby laying the groundwork for the loss of European identity to which so much is appealed. It is a good thing that a hope of change is opened through precisely Syriza, to which we wish great successes.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Renzi, today we have heard a surreal speech in a surreal atmosphere. You spoke of a europe that is changing gears, of a new course on flexibility and growth, of a European vision; but what vision and what change President? That of the unrealised Eurobonds and the 21 meagre billions of the Juncker Commission? Yet another troika horse, to distract and deceive the citizens of Europe? The one in which we have again forgotten to propose a minimum and compulsory income of citizenship for the continent? Of dignity, of life, in the deafening silence of the lack of a Europe of social dumping?  Your vision, yes, that in which my generation in Italy and in many other countries is broken in half, between submerged and saved, in the flood of universal unemployment. Since you like literature, I will tell you that the youth of Southern Europe are like autumn in the trees leaves, Mr President! You didn't deprive her of a dream in the drawer, you stole her entire desk! For them and for all the last of Europe, we are here, in order to break down together with the other peoples of the Mediterranean that horrid new wall that is exiled to the north the civilization of the welfare state, condemning the South to the barbarity of anti-social hyperliberalism. Because those who have lost a job, those who close the business of generations, those who are eighty years old and are reduced to stealing in supermarkets, today do not need our opinion, they need our courage, a coherent and courageous example, this is Europe, this is Italy.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, The President-in-Office, Mr Renzi, promised a great deal of commitment to small and medium-sized enterprises, and indeed the efforts he made to save his father's industry from bankruptcy with public funds while the other small Italian entrepreneurs commit suicide, heartfelt and desperate together with their employees. We receive daily appeals, including one on the table, from entrepreneurs in our country, small entrepreneurs and workers who would like to save their businesses.  We wonder whether President Renzi, who is still the Italian Prime Minister today, wants to stop making fun of people and wants to commit himself to seriously saving jobs, to solving the problem of youth unemployment, to doing for others what he did for his father's company, which had to fail if it had not been the company of the President of the Council and , protempore, of this Europe.

name: Matteo Renzi
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - Thank you, Mr Tajani, there are three major issues that we are discussing.  The first concerns the technically intended budget: I am grateful to the Members of the European Parliament for pointing out things that I did not list in detail, referring to the final text, but I am pleased that there have been recognitions from the reflection on everything and on the work done on the budget to the positive issues that have been addressed during this six-month period that paradoxically have come from this House and not from us. That seems to me to be a good thing.  I must say quite frankly that Verhofstadt is right when he points out some un positive facts: we have not only closed the made in that is an issue on which we will continue to work, but which is certainly an element of objective negativity for us, but also the subject of the telecommunications dossier. A complicated, difficult dossier, which has seen many, many meetings, 11 times we have met with the working groups, which were the subject of a very intensive discussion at the working dinner of ministers at the informal Council in Milan in September, the two draft texts that we have proposed, some aspects have seen progress, net neutrality, not roaming unfortunately , on which I think there have been the greatest divergences.  So, there is no doubt, there are also many aspects that have not been achieved as we would have liked, that part of the debate that has focused on the results of the six-month period is, however, a part of the debate that has particularly impressed us for the attention also given by colleagues from other political forces or other countries to the objective results achieved.  Then there is a second element that is the debate – as is often the case in the country of origin – the opportunity of the end and the beginning of the semester is always the opportunity for a political debate – made more complicated certainly in Italy because the difficult Italian transition has seen the leadership of the government, political governments of one side and technical governments and then political governments of alliances and coalitions led in some cases by opposing components. However, I find it really strange that the Members of the European Parliament representing Italy should show with this great care all the negative aspects of our country – I say this to you, Mr Tajani, who has also served the European institutions in another capacity, not only in Parliament and who knows this well and knows this element even if we come from different political families.  I am thinking, for example, of Mr Maltese, who is not here, when he says Italy has the third largest public debt in the world: it is true! Italy has a significant public debt, think two billion euros! Yet no one points out that Italy has the world's first private saving, four billion euros! And when the 5-Star Members come to highlight how families are getting poorer, this mussel, as sometimes happens, against the reality of the facts and the numbers. Think, in a time of crisis, Italian families have seen their savings increase from 3.5 billion euros to 3.9 (from 2012 to 2014).  Why did this happen? This has happened because the Italian economy – Parliament will forgive me if I am forced to respond also on domestic issues – is experiencing a phase of terror, of concern, the messages that arrive are messages marked not simply by austerity – which is a philosophical-cultural debate that we could hold for a long time – but to terror and fear of the future, to consider the future as a threat. Therefore, we come to the paradox that in recent months Italy has seen its savings and money increase, families are paradoxically enriching because they have concern and fear.  It is very difficult to convince you of the reality, but reality is slowly necessary, as I say to Mrs Moi, a 5-Star Member, who highlights the serious problems of corruption in Italy. Just in 2014 the Italian Parliament, on a proposal from the government, chose – think about it, but perhaps they did not have time to tell it! - unanimously, on the government's proposal, to entrust Raffaele Cantone with the task of leading the anti-corruption authority that has made it possible to commissioner the MOSE, an experience to which Mr De Clercq has put forward a report. Moi referred, which allowed the EXPO to close the season of illegality and to open the great theme of content, which made it possible to intervene with legislation that is unprecedented in Europe.  It is difficult to stress the positive aspects of one's own country when one considers the European gallery as the forum in which to go and speak ill of ourselves. This is not the case with Mr Beazley. Salvini, to whom I recognize a consistency of behaviour rather than content – I think he has done very well he has emphasized the difficulty and also the sense of bitterness that citizens feel when they see the Halls of the Parliament empty. In the meantime, I am very pleased that Mr Syley has done a good deal. Salvini found his desk in the European Parliament given the large presence in the Italian media and the perhaps small presence within the European institutions that has been needed for 11 years now. When Mr President, I would like to say a good report, i.e. Salvini, who is engaged in a national political battle and which I respect, because he is on the other side, will arrive at the election campaign – in three years' time, in four years' time, when he will be (in three years' time, I would not like to extend the legislature!) – when Mr Syley is not here today. Salvini will be in the election campaign, it will be easy for Italian citizens to ask him: ok, we will ask Renzi what he has done in Italy and we will ask Salvini what he has done in these 15 at the service of Europe!  However, I can say here today, and then to conclude quickly, that on this day the political group which represents Mr Sleyley's model is not a political group. For example, Salvini proposed the suspension of the Schengen Agreements. This is an objective which Mr Ayley has just said is a very important one. Marine Le Pen explained not in the Chamber, but she explained very carefully at the press conference. I would like to quote what the Italian Minister of the Interior, a member of the same Party of the Northern League, led by Salvini, said exactly this: suspending Schengen would be the end of Europe, I believe – as Maroni said in that case – that Italy must be totally opposed to the closure of the Schengen area.  This agreement, this consideration, this phrase by Mr Beazley, the commission of the European Parliament, the Committee on The Salvini, who is trying to turn left but will not be able to achieve the political result, shows very strongly and very clearly something very simple and that is that there is an impressive distance between demagoguery and reality. There is a crazy distance between those who invest in an idea of politics that can excite and those who bet on fear. And that, Mr President, is also the final point I would like to leave to the European debate. Let me explain: today, in Italy, there is a derby, it is the derby between those who see the difficulties but stand up and try to solve them and try to imagine for our country a future at least as big as the history from which we come and, on the other hand, there are those who, seeing the difficulties, bet on failure, those who bet on fear, those who bet that we will not succeed. It is perhaps a convenient message at the electoral level – although, I want to say to my UKIP colleagues that they are not there now and who have spoken before shouting that I would call those who are voters brute – I represent the party that has taken the most votes of all in Europe, the Democratic Party 11 million and 200 thousand people and therefore we do not consider the people who vote to be brute; we consider brutes those who deny the reality of the facts and the reality is that we will get out of this crisis situation not by investing in fear, not by betting on failure, but by trying to make it clear that the only possible solution for our children is that Europe is not an heirloom, it is not a place of memories, it is not the wax museum. , is not a set of clichés and phrases made! Europe can only make sense if it succeeds in putting the lives of people who want to believe in tomorrow back at the centre and who are not afraid, and who do not have the concern to regard what is happening in the world simply as a threat. Is the world scary? Yes, I think, I believe and hope that it will be a common conviction that Europe is greater than fears and threats and Europe is much stronger in its values than any attack that may exist. This is the difference between us and those who want to live as brutes, we think that the future that awaits us will depend on the commitment of each of us and if we are able to be consistent with our history, this future is a future that will see the stars of Europe lead the way and navigation, even in our country.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you to the Italian Presidency for the work it has done over the last few months. Good luck to Italy, a country of which I have the honour of being a citizen, a founding country of the Union. I now give the floor to The President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Junker.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, at the conclusion of this debate, I would like, once again, to pay tribute to the quality of the work of the Italian Government, the Italian Presidency and the President of the Council, Matteo Renzi.  For the rest, I would not want to prolong the Italian-Italian debate. We are, it seems to me, here in the European Parliament, and as I promised you the other day never to interfere in the domestic politics of another country, I will be immediately silent.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Today, the Italian Presidency of the Council of the EU has ended. Despite the great proclamations, no one has noticed the direction given by Italy to the EU. Everything had to change and instead, in a form of gattopardismo 2.0, nothing has changed at all. Mention will be made of the investment plan presented by Juncker and the efforts made to promote flexibility, as well as the appointment of Federica Mogherini as High Representative. These are semantic scams, demagogic responses, the sole purpose of which is to throw smoke in the eyes of European citizens and divert attention from the really important issues. Nothing has been done, for example, in the area of tax harmonisation and, on the contrary, evolved forms of tax competition that harm taxpayers and damage the project of European integration continue to be tolerated. In this regard, the case of the so-called web tax is emblematic. It was Renzi himself who solemnly promised that he would take action in the Council. However, the Italian Presidency has ended and nothing has changed. Renzi pied piper struck again. It is a pity that it is always only the citizens who suffer the consequences. I hope that the Latvian Presidency will do something more. It shouldn't be very difficult

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This Italian Presidency, which was to have "great ambitions" came to an end on 12 January 2015 without any real progress for Europe. That was to be expected... Matteo Renzi, however, declared in July 2014 that Europe must make a "face change to regain its soul". We were promised to loosen the stranglehold of austerity by giving more flexibility to the Member States of the euro area. We were also touted the great recovery plan planned by the Juncker Commission. Last spring, the idea of including public investment in the calculation of deficits disappeared completely, thus succumbing to german wishes. It is quite clear that this decision is not likely to promote growth, which has already been undermined in the euro area. Forget also the project on my net neutrality or the labelling on the origin of products as well as the additional credits for youth employment. The Italian Presidency still succeeded in setting up "Operation Triton", a new colander operation that opens the door to uncontrolled mass immigration for the sole benefit of mafia networks of smugglers.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Today, Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi presented the results of his country's presidency of the Council of the European Union and handed over the helm of the Presidency to our neighbour Latvia. I agree with the Prime Minister that the economic crisis has left a deep scar, but Europe must face another major challenge: rediscovering confidence in its citizens and Europe. I believe that we need to fight the economic recession even further and abandon austerity policies. Europe must respect the principles of the social dimension, invest in man, in his mind and in the future of our children. Italy has failed to achieve encouraging results in areas that directly affect the lives of our people. I hope that Latvia, which has taken over the Presidency, will be able to find a consensus among the Member States on the Maternity Leave Directive and we will not lose it. I very much hope that the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which many Europeans are waiting for, will be blocked. In addition, the fate of the Women's Companies Directive must also be addressed, as the Member States have not yet agreed on it. I would like to call on Latvia to take account of current issues, because without freedom there will be no citizens' security and their rights. It is essential to continue the work that has been started, namely to ensure the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact, to carry out the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, to implement the European Semester in the Member States with a view to intensifying economic recovery and growth.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. The Italian Presidency of the Council has practically opened at the same time as the start of the new parliamentary term of the European Parliament. The challenge we faced last July was clear: to show that the European institutions could change direction and free themselves from the dogma of austerity, could react to the economic and social crisis with concrete actions, with policies that were attentive to the needs of citizens and businesses and not just to budgetary balances. Just today, as President Renzi speaks in Parliament, the Commission is meeting to approve the proposal for a regulation on the 315 billion investment fund and the new guidelines on the flexibility of national budgets. Can we say that Europe has changed towards just six months? Rather than with the new Parliament, the Commission set up in November and the exceptional contribution of the Italian Presidency, I believe that we have finally begun the manoeuvres to change direction. In Italy, the Government has chosen the motto "Step by step". I believe that this is a message that can also work in Europe. The manoeuvre has begun, the engines must now be given strength, and in order to do this Parliament will have to be able to turn the pressure of the citizens into the best of fuels.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. With regard to investments, Italy has been working since the beginning of the six-month period to put this issue at the heart of EU policy action. The purchase of cheap liquidity will be an important resource for the market over the next two years, thanks to ecb action, and effective and strategic projects will be a useful tool for this. At the last Ecofin of the Italian Presidency, the details of the 'Single Resolution Fund' were finalised, which will be capitalised over the next 8 years, taxing European banks for 1% of deposits. Under the Italian Presidency, a number of environmental dossiers were given final impetus until they were approved. Among the many: - the directive on the freedom of the ban on the cultivation of GMOs; - agreement on the rules for the elimination of single-use plastic bags; - the ratification of the extension of the Kyoto climate agreements. Finally, many files on tax avoidance and evasion were successfully pursued during the Italian semester: - the directive regulating the taxation of the parent company and its subsidiaries in different countries; - the one on the automatic exchange of tax information. Austria and Luxembourg have also renounced banking secrecy. This is perhaps the area in which Italy has been best able to play its mediating role.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. President Renzi speaks to a half-empty Chamber and this in itself is an eloquent and merciless judgment of MEPs from all countries and from all political affiliation on the Italian semester. An empty Chamber for an empty six months could be summed up. But what is politically more serious is the fact that Renzi preaches well after rocketing badly. Even today, in fact, he has said the right thing that we have been advocating for a long time: to question European constraints and austerity in favour of a season of greater flexibility. It is a pity, however, that Italy has done nothing in this six-month period to reverse course. Indeed, just in recent months, even with regard to the law of stability, Renzi has suffered all the diktats in Brussels. That he is now also preaching to us about overcoming constraints is a little too much. What is more, Mr Juncker himself has denied this in real time by reiterating the berlin-Brussels argument - which I absolutely cannot support - namely that the only acceptable flexibility is that already provided for in the current Treaties. One final point, for me and for the whole of Italy very important: renzi's silence on the case of the marò is serious and disappointing, even today.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – The Italian Presidency conducted its work during a period still affected by the ongoing economic crisis and its bad social effects. Last year there were European Parliament elections, when EU citizens proved to be united in their demand for a better Europe. The Italian presidency, taking into account the demands of European citizens, has successfully promoted an agenda for change. This agenda is focused on the need for increased growth and greater prospects for employment. It pushes for a public investment programme that can give an alternative to the unsuccessful politics of the troika and demonstrate how EU institutions can be closer to citizens. Let me thank the Italian Presidency for its outstanding activity, its accomplishments in achieving more flexibility, dealing with the challenges of immigration and strengthening a common foreign policy. I am especially thankful for the efforts that have been made for the accession of Romania (and Bulgaria) to the Schengen Area, which is of the utmost importance in order to show that we, Europeans, support dialogue, inclusion and solidarity both inside and outside the borders of Europe, especially after the abominable terrorist attacks in Paris.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. Many have been the obstacles overcome in these 6 months by the Italian Presidency: a Union budget for 2015 which, although limited, meets the expectations of the European Parliament, to ensure transparency and integrity during the 7th round of TTIP negotiations with the United States, the launch of initiatives for more forceful and supportive joint action on issues such as migration and to lay the groundwork for more efficient and coherent development cooperation achievements that have taken place in a difficult political framework. It has been a presidency that has set in motion the way out of the nefarious policy of austerity by driving a stability package based on innovation, investment and growth. These have been first steps – but important as a whole – and I hope that with the following presidencies we will be able to obtain legislative agreements on key issues for growth and employment, as well as for a single digital market, a sustainable energy union and a common foreign policy that strengthens solidarity and humanitarian aid.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. – The Italian Presidency is a monument to failure since it has not even dared to question in practice the implementation of the mercely austerity and violent fiscal adjustment which has filled the European South with armies of unemployed and poor. At the same time it failed to secure serious resources for the creation of new jobs, supported the policy of socialising bank losses, did not challenge regional disparities and continued to support the illegal policies of the Troika in Greece. It is obvious that during the Italian Presidency the peoples of Europe experienced the same problems and the same huge social impasses. Europe's young people have continued to look for opportunities for new jobs. But they saw no real result since the European Central Bank's famous liquidity never reached the real economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises continued to suffer from overtaxation, while the rural populations of southern Europe saw the cost of production constantly increase and their products could not be sold at good prices. In conclusion, the Italian Presidency, while creating many expectations with the great promises it made, finally ended up implementing the same failed recipe that serves the Brussels bureaucracy and German Europe.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing.  It has been said on many sides that no great results could be achieved, given the unfavourable time-lag of the Italian Presidency. On the contrary, President Renzi today recalled many successes of this "short semester". Despite a difficult institutional transition, the issues of employment, infrastructure investment and flexibility have returned to the european agenda. There has been a renewed commitment to policies aimed at growth, sustainable and inclusive, also witnessed by the Juncker Plan, on which we, as Socialists and Democrats, have insisted and will insist. The launch of Operation Triton marks the transition to a European immigration policy. The publication of the TTIP negotiating mandate, the commitment to transparency. A Common European Position has been established for the Lima Conference, despite resistance from some Member States, including with the 2030 Framework Agreement on Climate and Energy. Results that can always be improved, of course. But important steps towards a renewed political and not just an economic agenda of the EU, not by chance also recognised by colleagues from other European countries and authoritatively by President Juncker. This is the real demand of european citizens who left the polls in May: more politics, more culture, more European citizenship. Let us reiterate that a Europe as a 'superpower of values'.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. President Renzi's speech on the italian presidency's budget was very disappointing. Interventions have been mentioned, such as the one on flexibility, which had already been widely planned in previous semesters. It is also very serious that the dramatic issue of our Marò in India and the role that Italy had to play in finally resolving this absurd imprisonment, which has now lasted for three years, has not been touched on in the slightest. To be able to give Renzi a one-to-ten vote would be a good four!

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. - The Italian Presidency was marked by a number of extraordinary events that certainly affected the work and results achieved in the six months of the presidency. Thus, in agriculture, for example, the Italian Presidency had to pay significant attention to remediating the consequences of the Russian embargo on imports of agricultural products from the EU, triggered by the EU's sanctions on Russia. In the area of fisheries, an important agreement has been reached on fishing opportunities within EU waters as well as outside EU waters for 2015 with a view to conserving stocks. I hope that the protection of small fishermen will also find its place on the agenda in the near future. While the crisis in Ukraine has been a foreign policy top topic of italy's presidency of the Council of Ministers, Mogherini highlighted libya's problem and migration as top priorities for Italy in July. Italy has averted a huge number of tragedies with a new rescue mission at sea, Mare Nostrum, which has rescued tens of thousands of migrants this year. The operation was halted and replaced by a much smaller-scale operation, Triton. I therefore call on the Latvian Presidency to pay particular attention to strengthening common migration policies. In conclusion, I congratulate my Italian colleagues on their work and wish the future chairpers a lot of success in their work and an even more successful presidency.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Italian Presidency of the Council of the EU has been associated with the elections to the European Parliament and the election of a new composition of the European Commission. However, this was not just time spent on organisational issues, although technical issues related to the start of the new institutional cycle prevailed. However, for the last six months, a smaller scope of work in a purely legislative context has involved an intensified debate on the eu's objectives and agenda for the coming years, as well as the establishment of a strategic investment fund. The State presidency during such a period therefore has a particular opportunity to join and influence the Union's programme debate.  The title of the Presidency's programme was a call for a kind of revival – "Fresh start", which in itself suggested a willingness to take on important European topics, rather than just focusing on organisational and formal issues. This programme worked very well with the guidelines for the current European Commission term of office , 'A new start for Europe', which has helped to send a strong signal to citizens that the EU wants to make positive changes and ambitious improvements to its functioning. Among the issues that the Italian Presidency decided to address were, inter alia, anti-crisis policies and the related recovery in economic growth, based on further deepening the integration of the internal market, implementing structural reforms and promoting investment.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – Italy has made bold plans for its Presidency. Tackling youth employment through the effective implementation of the Youth Guarantee scheme, together with investment in education, training and labour mobility, has been given priority. Here, I think that the Italian Presidency has not disappointed and created the preconditions for continuing for the next Presidencies and creating the right legislation within the EU. Another very important priority was to address the challenges of asylum and migration policy in Europe . We have been pushing this problem for a long time, but so far no state in the Presidency has addressed this issue. Italy, as the state that receives and rescues migrants the most from countries where they are at risk of hunger, misery and often save their health and life by fleeing their own country, has very openly started talking about asylum policy and the issue of migrants. The problem for the south of Europe must be that of the EU. Therefore, the creation of a common asylum and immigration policy must also be a priority for the Commission and for all Member States for the future.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – One of the three main priorities of the Italian Presidency was to give new impetus to the European Union's foreign policy. I myself agree with this objective, and the need for it has been demonstrated by developments in the Middle East and Ukraine. These events, although they took place outside our borders, have a direct impact on neighbouring Member States and thus on the entire European Union. The Italian Presidency has rightly recognised the objective, but the Latvian Presidency still needs to make significant progress in this area. This will require the support of the Member States in addition to the European Parliament. If, in the context of the most important foreign policy events, the Union is unable to present uniform and effective measures, the whole Union will be weakened. That is why, for my part, I support Mrs Mogherini's goal of showing Europe's global role by taking joint action. I thank the Italian Presidency for its actions in this area and I call on the Latvian Presidency to speed up this process through its instruments.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Italian Presidency is over and we have heard many fine words about successes. Unfortunately, I cannot join the congratulations, because the Italian Presidency was unspectacular. This is understandable, because Italy is one of the largest economic disaster areas in the euro area, and it is crucial that the Italian Government first takes care of the situation at home. What about Italy? Youth unemployment has risen to 44%, industrial output is 30% below its peak, banks are sitting on more than 180 billion bad loans, and private lending has been in negative territory for more than two years. The government quota has been regularly above 50% for years. Six years ago, the euro crisis erupted, and only now are the first reforms being cautiously launched. Nevertheless, Italy is already tired of "austerity". Italy's substance is being lost, its young people no longer have prospects, and only Mr Draghi is keeping the country afloat with his transfer policy. Dear Italians, you have already had a lost decade and cannot afford a second one. Exit the euro, restructure your debt, reform your state, and give yourself and your children a new perspective for the future!

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - "I change Europe in 6 months", this is Renzi's promise at the beginning of the Italian Presidency. It could have been the semester to change course from devastating years of austerity and recession. It could have been an opportunity to build a common front against German hegemony in order to re-discuss unsustainable budgetary constraints which have proved extremely damaging to the economy. But the opportunity to dictate the European agenda in the interests of millions of citizens has been shamefully wasted, to the sole benefit of the countries of the North and the strong powers. Not only has there not been a renegotiation of the fiscal compact, but Renzi has also failed to close crucial dossiers on which only the Council's agreement was lacking. Like the one on "made in", blocked by Germany, which would actually help Italian SMEs. Or the one on the tax on financial transactions, opposed by lobbies, which would have curbed speculation, freeing up 35 billion a year for the real economy and the fight against poverty.  Renzi closes by leaving us only the embarrassing Juncker "investment" plan. A EUR 21 billion fund that is expected to be transformed by the effect of a mysterious multiplier into EUR 315 billion. Probably the best symbol of what will be remembered as the semester of media bluffing and missed opportunities.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. Today we are closing the six months of the Italian Presidency of the European Union, six months of great ambition and expectations, which have unfortunately been resolved into a real 'nothing done'. In no way has Italy succeeded in imposing its own line, and this is a failure in view of the enormous political heritage and strength that Renzi had after the European elections in May. In Europe, his slogans in July remained so, and nothing has been done to change the face of a sick Union, according to the President-in-Office of the Council himself. These "non-results" are the result of Renzi's political line and probably of the very inability to change the fate of the European Union in any way, if not through some particularly strong and incisive action. At this point, our initiative to ask the Italians what they think of the single currency, which is certainly doing us more harm than good, is all the more valuable: if the Italian politicians who would have had the opportunity to change this Europe have not done so, all that remains is to rely on the people to decide what the fate of what was now a dream that is now in danger of becoming a nightmare should be.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The Italian Presidency of the European Union has created high expectations. Mateo Renzi's inspiring intervention in the European Parliament and the priorities set - Europe for Jobs and Economic Growth, a Europe closer to citizens: a space for democracy, rights and freedom and a new impetus for the European Union's foreign policy - have generated hope that has only been partially reciprocated. If, in terms of external relations, it was notorious for an effort of greater prominence of the European Union in the multiple economic and military conflicts that plague the world, in terms of growth and employment the Italian Presidency has failed to turn words into acts, certainly not out of lack of effort, but because it continued to prevail in Europe a punitive hegemony of some countries in relation to others , instead of having evolved to a level of cooperation and solidarity that would benefit everyone.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – I would like to thank Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi for presenting the achievements of the Italian Presidency. Italy took over the Presidency in July 2014, at the end of the mandates of the European institutions. It was not easy, but it must be acknowledged that the Italian Presidency has contributed to the consolidation and completion of the new European institutional structure, which is a prerequisite for the FUNCTIONing of the EU. Italy can also boast smaller steps, such as the compromise on genetically modified organisms (GMOs) between Parliament, the Council and the Commission. This compromise, which we have been waiting for since 2010, will be approved in Parliament today. Italy has also achieved some other important objectives in the areas of tax policy, bank resolution, migration problems and the European budget, not least in consolidating the 'soul' of Europe. For many, however, Italy was not successful. However, important work now awaits a small country with a big heart - Latvia, particularly in the area of securing new jobs, by empowering the EU in the neighbourhood and in the world, and continuing to deliver European values and culture.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the recommendation for second reading from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC as regards the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in their territory (10972/3/2014 – C8-0145/2014 – 2010/0208(COD)) (Rapporteur: Frédérique Ries) (A8-0038/2014).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, we are almost an hour and a half late, which sometimes happens with the Italian speakers who have gone before us. This was important, of course, but I am a little sorry that the possibility of my colleagues - and there are many of them - to participate in the "Interventions on Demand" procedure is limited. For we have come a long way with this dossier on the cultivation of GMOs, as a few months ago the situation was completely blocked on the side of the Member States caught up in endless legal disputes for almost ten years with, to take only the most recent examples, Italy and Poland, respectively condemned in 2013 and 2014 for breach of our European legislation.  The Council finally gave birth to a common position in July so that our Parliament could take second reading of this text on the question of the free choice of European countries to grow GMOs on their territory.  My gratitude goes right away, of course, to the shadow rapporteurs who accompanied me valiantly throughout this second reading: Elisabeth Kostinger for the EPP Group, Gilles Pargneaux, Julie Girling, Lynn Boylan, Bart Staes and Eleonora Evi, not to mention, of course, Giovanni La Via, the chairman of our Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety - I think he is there - who has , with great energy, facilitated negotiations throughout the proceedings. Thank you, of course, also to all my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety who, at the end of December, largely supported the result of the trilogue: 42 votes in for, 17 against. It is a very clear support that foreshadows, I hope, this lunchtime vote. I now come to the bottom of this legislation, which aims to revise the 2001 directive on the voluntary spread of GMOs in the environment, but also the 2003 regulation on human or animal feed containing these famous GMOs. It is important, and I do do, to make it clear at the outset that its scope is limited here to cultivation. The text therefore does not concern imports or transport. This is not about opening up the broader debate about the usefulness or not of GMOs in agriculture and food.  I come to the heart of our work, to the voice of Parliament and to the results of this last-minute trilogue, and therefore to this long night of 3 December and, of course, to the progress made in relation to the Council's position last July, which are real.  This is the case on the very important issue of the coexistence of cultures. It was Parliament's almost unanimous position to move forward on this issue. The two co-legislators have made concessions, of course. This is the raison d'être of the trilogue, but it is the Parliament's version that prevails since, contrary to the 2001 legislation, the minority of Member States that grow GMOs will now have to take mandatory measures in the border areas in order to avoid possible contamination of traditional or organic fields.  This is also the case with what is at the heart of the directive, namely the famous opt-out procedures that a Member State that does not wish to cultivate GMOs can resort to.  With regard to phase 1, therefore during the authorisation procedure, with this new role which is de facto given to the requesting undertaking, it is true that the European Parliament has, roughly, accepted the Council's text in the face of - and I must say this and all my shadow rapporteurs will confirm this - to a complete absence of leeway left by the Member States and therefore the Council.  However, the Parliament's delegation forced two major points. First, the lifting of conditionality between phase 1 and phase 2. The Member State therefore has two jokers instead of one, two windows of opportunity to restrict the cultivation of GMOs on its territory. It may negotiate with the seed company during the authorization phase, but it is no longer obliged to do so as in the July version of the Commission.  Moreover, the Member State now has ten years, not two - this is essential - to oppose the cultivation of GMOs on its territory and to operate this phase 2 on the basis of an open list of reasons. I am thinking of agricultural policy, soil and environmental protection or the socio-economic impact during this second phase.  Last but not least, the Council eventually complied and agreed to extend the ban to GMO groups defined by culture or characteristic.  Let us be clear, and I am speaking mainly here to the undecided, there is no credible option but this agreement and the status quo, contrary to what I hear, is not one, except to satisfy this current legal jungle or embark on an unlikely conciliation with an increasingly inflexible Council. Clearly, a status quo would be the best way to prevent President Juncker from carrying out his reform for greater transparency and respect for the majority in the GMO authorisation procedure.  Citizens are asking us to give Member States the means to respect their choice, their legitimate choice. With this legislation, we hear them and move forward. (Applause)

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I am very glad to be here today. It has been a long road – close to five years – but we are almost at the end of our journey. Some time ago I could not have imagined I would be standing here at the end of a successful second reading. I want to thank the rapporteur, Ms Frédérique Ries, for her efficient steering. I also thank the shadow rapporteurs for their support during the discussions. These collective efforts helped us to reach the agreement with the Council and to complete this task successfully. Allow me to recall some facts about GMO cultivation in the European Union. Currently there is only one GMO authorised for cultivation in the EU. It is cultivated in five Member States. Nine Member States have taken measures to prevent its cultivation in their territory, but these measures have not been considered scientifically justified by EFSA. As a result, they are regularly annulled by national judges. This means that the countries wishing to ban GMO cultivation in their territory cannot do so. This is because the current legislation does not allow Member States to take into account their national contexts and the views of their citizens. This creates extreme tensions between law, politics and public expectations. EU citizens, farmers and the biotech industry may feel that we do not address their interests. It also weakens the credibility of everyone involved in the process of GMO risk assessment at European level – namely EFSA, the Member States and the Commission. This is why, in 2009, 13 Member States asked for a solution. The Commission proposed a legally sound and pragmatic response to this call in 2010. It had a dual objective: firstly to maintain a strong science-based EU authorisation system for GMOs, securing uniform safety across the European Union, and secondly to recognise – in full respect of the Treaty – the freedom of each Member State to decide whether to allow GMO cultivation in its territory. I am pleased that the text in front of you fully meets these two objectives. Member States will have the final say on GMO cultivation, depending on their national situation. The Member States that already cultivate GMOs will be able to continue. Those opposed will be able to restrict or prohibit cultivation in their territory. Freedom of choice will be secured. The EU countries that cultivate GMOs will have to implement measures to avoid cross-border contamination in neighbouring Member States. The criteria used to assess the risk to the environment will be updated shortly. This will reflect the latest scientific and technical progress. Let me stress that Member States will still be able to adopt measures to address unforeseen risks that may be detected after a GMO is authorised. If you vote in favour of the legislative proposal on GMO cultivation, you will provide the Member States with legally-sound tools to decide on GMO cultivation in their territory starting in spring 2015. The EU has repeatedly been asked to do more to live up to citizens’ expectations. I would like to believe this EU legislation is responding to the call. In this context, I would like to make the following declaration: when proceeding with the authorisation of GMOs for cultivation, the Commission will – in full respect of its obligations – take account of elements at its disposal, including the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory as provided for by this directive.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work. After four months of hard work, we have now succeeded in presenting to the plenary a compromise agreed with the Council on the self-determination of the European Member States in GMO cultivation. After three years of deadlock, we have finally cleared the hurdle in the Council, and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Frédérique Ries, very warmly for their constructive cooperation.  The legal text is a major step towards greater subsidiarity and greater self-determination. In recent years, too, opposition to genetic engineering has formed within governments. In the vote on the approval of Pioneer 1507 in February last year, 19 Member States have already voted against it. This fact cannot be ignored.  The national governments concerned have already taken this into account. Eight EU Member States have banned the cultivation of the GMO plant poppy 810 in their respective territories by means of the only instrument currently available to them, the so-called safeguard clause, and have thus even risked legal action by manufacturers because the safeguard clause allows only temporary bans.  We have now put a stop to this intolerable situation by finding a legally watertight solution. The two-stage procedure, which allows the country to choose whether or not to include the applicant in the opt-out procedure, provides the highest possible legal certainty and, at the same time, strengthens subsidiarity. It is certainly not the wisdom of the last conclusion, but it is a step in the right direction. That is why I would really like to ask colleagues to vote in favour of this compromise.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today, if a Member State bans the cultivation of a GMO on its territory, it is systematically condemned by the European Court of Justice following a complaint by Monsanto.  The agreement reached on December 3rd in a trilogue is a game-changer. It is important to remember this in this debate. Without this agreement, we would have retained the current situation, where the European Commission allows the cultivation of a GMO because of the lack of a common position in the Council. This situation could not last any longer. It systematically put Member States at odds with Member States that wanted to say no to GMOs, such as France. In this long and difficult negotiation in the face of an inflexible Council, together with Frédérique Ries, our rapporteur whom I would like to welcome, we have succeeded in strengthening the protection of consumers, farmers and Member States. This directive means more security for Member States opposed to GMOs.  For spring 2015, Member States will be able to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs in their territories on the grounds of environmental, agricultural and socio-economic reasons. This means more safety for farmers who support traditional or organic crops. Within two years, Member States will take steps to prevent contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops in cross-border areas. This means more security for European consumers. The European Commission has pledged to review and strengthen the rules for risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Authority within two years. In another victory for European consumers, we have convinced the Commission not to grant any new authorisation for GMO cultivation before this directive comes into force. It was a tough fight and we got there. I think we have won, but this directive is just the beginning. This is a good start, but we will have to continue the fight against GMOs.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the overall agreement broadly reflects the Commission’s original intention: that Member States should have the option to decide whether or not to cultivate GMOs. The intention was to unblock the wholly unjustified failure to grant final approval of GMOs by the Commission. In other words, we are now present at the final act in a long and expensive process initiated simply to avoid repeated exposure of the Commission’s lack of political courage. On a more optimistic note, this does show that EU competences as defined by the Treaties are not absolute, and I look forward to such flexibility being shown in other areas as my Prime Minister continues his negotiations to reform the EU. Of course, as with all controversial proposals, the devil is in the detail. There are many details here which I find unacceptable. The agreement will permit Member States to proceed directly to national bans post-Union authorisation, rather than first seeking a more legally-sound opt-out from authorisation, as initially proposed. It allows for national bans to apply to groups of GMOs, rather than on a case-by-case basis, and fails to completely rule out the possibility of Member States citing environmental and public health grounds for national bans. This conflicts with the EFSA risk assessment process, whereby the environmental and public health risks of GMOs are examined on a case-by-case basis prior to Union authorisation. On principle, I cannot accept a proposal which allows for the scientific assessment of GMOs to be undermined in this way. The European Parliament’s negotiating position on this file has led to this unsatisfactory outcome. Based on a disproportionate demonisation of GMOs along the ‘Frankenstein foods’ lines promoted in the tabloid press, Members are cutting off a route to higher yields, lower pesticide use and less use of water, and denying access to new-generation GMOs, such as Omega-3-rich camelina, which will have widespread health benefits. I hope that the cobbled-together, legally-fragile compromise that Parliament has promoted will be robust and that the authorisations will start to flow. Member States that want to continue to develop European agriculture as the best in the world are holding their breath, counting on this not being just a charter to ban, but also a key to unlock progress.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Parliament is now deciding whether eu member states will be given more freedom to decide on the cultivation of GM crops in their territories. Ministers have already decided on this matter, and it is now Parliament's turn. This means adding an article to the former directive which increases the rights of Member States to legally justify a national or regional ban on GMO cultivation. This is a matter for the Member States to decide. The genetically modified product arouses emotions. It is very important that the European Food Safety Agency examines these matters closely. It is important that the authorisations granted by this agency are really well founded so that, after the authorisation, the Member States can decide for themselves and independently what to do. In Europe, Asia and many other countries, genetically modified products are treated much more freely than here in Europe. We have been reluctant about this and, in fact, I think it is the right principle. There is still a lot to explore here, a lot of things that we do not know about today. Both researchers and decision-makers are responsible for not granting authorisations for products that are then subsequently found to be harmful.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, almost five long years have passed since the Commission initially tabled this hugely significant proposal on national updates for GMO cultivation. The long and winding path to today’s vote reflects the highly controversial nature of genetic modification for consumers, farmers, national governments and MEPs in this Parliament. Consistent polls show that citizens across the European Union continue to be wary of GM – a wariness that biotech companies casually dismiss as lack of understanding. I would argue the opposite. Citizens are acutely aware of the implications of GM. They have seen the impact that GM cultivation has had in America and India: increased herbicide resistance and the need for stronger pesticides and more frequent pesticide use. The ups and downs of this legislation have, unfortunately, ended on a disappointing note. Parliament’s first reading and Frédérique Ries’s report from last year were both excellent rebuttals to the initial weak proposal by the Commission in 2010 and the very worrying Council position of June 2014. The Council position introduced a system whereby democratically-elected governments would politely ask a biotech company to remove their territory from the authorisation procedure. The concept of a private company being placed on an equal footing with a sovereign country is deeply undemocratic and set a worrying precedent. While I welcome the fact that this system has been improved in the final document, I nevertheless believe that the legislation before us is flawed. Parliament wanted to ensure that Member States would be able to use justifications for opting out based on environmental and health grounds additional to those examined in the European risk assessment. Unfortunately the key word ‘complementary’ has been removed to a recital, and the language is contradictory and would be worrying if it were ever challenged in court. There has been further weakening of the text with the change of the legal basis, environmental considerations relegated to the recitals, and the crucial liability scheme being removed. For countries such as Ireland, where the agriculture sector is vital, it is essential that opting out should be definitive. In order for me to vote in favour of this report, opting out would have to be absolutely legally watertight, and I do not believe this legislation makes it so.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Within the Council of Ministers, there is a large majority who oppose the admission of commercial GMO crops. The example of pioneer 1507 is clear: 19 Member States oppose, five abstain and four are in favour. President Juncker has therefore announced that he will democratise the entire licensing process. Commissioner Andriukaitis will have to come up with a proposal before May 2015. What's ahead now is going in the wrong direction. It is a real Trojan horse, which is ultimately intended to break the resistance of a large number of Member States in the Council in exchange for the possibility of banning gmo on its own territory or in parts thereof. In reality, it is the renationalisation of important European legislation. In this sense, this is anti-European policy. Certainly, the European Parliament, the chief negotiator Mrs Ries, the whole negotiating group, we all managed to improve the final result. That is our merit and was rightly emphasised by the previous speakers. The Greens/VEA will overwhelmingly reject this text. Why? Because the new law will lead to the renationalisation of European policies. Because the new law does not make the admission procedure more democratic. Because we let the GMO giants play a role in the decision-making process through phase 1. Because the new law is not sufficiently strong on coexistence measures and does not ensure that GMO crops contaminate traditional agriculture and bio-farming, and finally because the scheme does not respond to the financial responsibility of those who potentially contaminate common farmers and bio-farmers. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree with me that it is absolutely disgraceful to block 50 amendments all together under one vote when some of the amendments actually contradict one another? For example, Amendment 20 genuinely gives some power back to the Member States, whereas many of the other amendments actually make that impossible. Do you think this is a wrong or a right way to produce legislation?

name: Bart STAES
text: "blue card" answer. I think you are asking this question to the wrong MEMBER. It is the services that organise the vote. To my knowledge, it has always been the case that, in votes like this at second reading, we first present the agreement reached at second reading - my group will vote against it - and then the result of the Committee on the Environment in this case is presented in its entirety. The result in the Committee on the Environment is the result of a democratic vote which we cannot simply put aside. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: blue-card question. – The European Union has diversity as a principle. Do you not think that it is diversity that in one state there will be a GMO and in the other there will not?

name: Bart STAES
text: "blue card" answer. We need to know what we are talking about. We have a European law on which we voted here in the European Parliament in 2001, which clearly regulates the authorisation procedure for GMOs. Since 2001, two GMOs have been allowed, one of which is currently in force, the Mon 810. Within the Council of Environment Ministers, there is a large majority of Member States - 19 out of 28 with five abstentions by the last vote, i.e. 24 Member States - which are definitely not in favour. Then I think that the Commission is now speaking and that it must do what Mr Juncker has promised, which is to ensure that this procedure is democratised and that a clear majority in the Council also leads to a clear decision for or against. That is the job of the European Commission and I hope that Mr Andriukaitis will ensure that, as promised, he comes forward with a strong proposal before 1 May 2015, which we can then discuss here with all of us.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today brings to an end a negotiation process that has lasted more than four years during which Parliament had already voted by a very large majority on the position of the first reading. This Parliament had clearly indicated its desire to include in the text of the agreement certain elements considered fundamental. Among the most important changes was the possibility for Member States to be able to act as managers of public health and environmental risk when it comes to deciding whether or not to grow transgenic plants, to be able to ban their use in view of the environmental and health hazards that EFSA continues to want to ignore, to ensure the application of the 'polluter pays' principle and so on.  These same amendments were confirmed at second reading and voted for by a very large majority in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, which had also expressed its total opposition to the council's obscene proposal that it could be envisaged that a Member State should recognize in biotech companies interlocutors with whom to agree on national restrictions, and it was on these lines that we gave the green light to the trialogue.  None of the points mentioned, however, survived the final negotiations, deleted from the text, which ended up lengthening the long list of useless recitals. Companies will remain able to give their green light or not to restrict the geographical scope of authorisations, but will not be required to reimburse them in the event of contamination. Political agreements are the result of compromises in which both sides give up some of their initial positions. Faced with Parliament's capitulation to the Council's demands, we can therefore only vote against the closure of this agreement.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: The legislation at issue would allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GM crops. It is indeed a restriction, a restriction on national self-determination. Both the Reporter and the Commissioner said: this gives the Member States the right to choose freely! Do not mislead the people of Europe in this Parliament. Why is there a free choice? The Government of a Member State considers that, for scientific, sociological and social reasons, it does not wish to allow the cultivation of a GENETICALLY MODIFIED product, the process starts, at the end of which the Union, the Commission can say no, I do not accept the arguments! This means that it forces it to accept the cultivation of this crop. Why would that be a free choice? Moreover, it is included in the reasons for the need for a compelling reason. So, in vain, the scientific merits – there is a new law – are not compelling. By the way, the current proposal, the One in December, is a compromise, not a compromise. Nor should we be under any illusions that one of the fundamental goals of the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT, TTIP – we see american pressure – is precisely the spread of GM products in Europe. So please do not say in the next debate that you will give the Member States free opportunity and free choice, because it is not.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! I would like to express my thanks to all those who have contributed to this compromise, as coordinator of the PPE-DE, above all our shadow rapporteur Elisabeth Köstinger and Giovanni La Via, who, as chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs, very skilfully chaired the trialogue. I do not think that if we had less effort, we would not have had such a good result. I would remind you that it took the Council four years to find a common position. Four years! And that went all the way to the top. I can report from the Member State i know best that there were serious concerns with the Chancellor as to whether such a compromise could be made at all, because we are already interfering very much in the internal market. These concerns have also been raised time and again in our group during the debate. Those who now say that this does not go far enough, and we do not want to do so, should take this into account. The GROUP of European Democrats will vote in favour of the compromise because it also takes up the concerns of citizens that exist in many Member States. To those who are now threatening rejection, the Greens – Mr Staes, I otherwise appreciate your work very much, but I found it quite amusing that our otherwise very good interpreters have reproduced your statement, the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, rejecting the compromise, with 'EFDD'. And you are here in a boat with the EFDD. You should think about that. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats agree with the compromise. I believe that a majority of this House should do the same. Not populism, but good governance! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Although I myself would like to sing victory hymns in the context of a compromise reached, I would be a little more cautious around this time, although I appreciate the compromise. My question is this: if we open up the scale so broadly to the process of free action, how will this become a common European position in the TTIP negotiations?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. First of all, it must be said that anyone who rejects the compromise will vote in favour of the current legal situation. This means that Member States cannot actually ban cultivation at all. This was made clear in Mrs Ries's speech. Tomorrow, a company can go to the ECJ and file a lawsuit in Austria, Hungary or anywhere else where the population and the government do not want to do so, to decide on cultivation. As far as TTIP is concerned, the European Commission has a clear position that we are not giving in to the Americans at this point. Yesterday, there was again information to the contrary in the media. But if you look at it, it's not actually substantial. We are defending our rules, including the national ban on cultivation, if we decide today, and we should do so.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Madam President, the fundamental objective of the directive we are voting on today is to give greater flexibility and freedom to those Member States which decide to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territories. The agreement reached with the Council, with its virtues and shortcomings, remains the heir to the Three Main Principles of the European Union in the Management of GMOs: the principles of caution, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. When reforms are implemented, we must see, from experience, whether mandatory coexistence measures are feasible or if they present the difficulty of how to put barriers to the field.  What is clear is that conventional and ecological agricultural activity must also be protected. To this end, we already have one of the most comprehensive regulations in the world on GMOs, which the proposed new directive will serve to complete. In addition, we have the European Food Safety Authority, which must always, from absolute independence, work permanently on risk assessment.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We welcome the adoption of this agreement because the current legal situation is absolutely unacceptable. It is clear that every politician must consider the environmental, health and, above all, emotional and cultural aspects that exist in our countries. We welcome the fact that it is precisely the Member States that will be able to adopt appropriate legislation prohibiting or authoriting the cultivation of GMOs. However, does this agreement contain all possible proposals? Well, no.  First, however, it does not fully resolve the issue of refusal to register a GMO crop in a Member State. It appears that those who wish to introduce these crops will be able to assert their rights in court, and this justification may be challenged.  Secondly, I regret that no liability has been laid down for the operator of GMOs, because I know of cases where even an institution such as EFSA (this was another matter, Emma, Emma's predecessor) issued such a permit, and later it turned out that the drug was unfortunately bad and caused enormous havoc. We also do not know exactly how these GMO crops will affect human health.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking The compromise is regrettable to me, but the only possible one, so I hope it will be voted through. I have never been able, and none of us could ever, defend the way gmo technology is used today. It is of no use to man or to the environment. It only benefits the profits of the very large companies. Never forget, however, that a technique itself is never evil or good. It depends on who does what. I would like us, above all, in Europe to regain control of this type of plant breeding from the United States.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Madam President, there has long been a heated debate about the issue of gmo cultivation and their possible ban in individual Member States. Many profit-a-profit lobbying groups certainly have their share of the blame. And the profit here is, in my opinion, above all. This was last seen at the end of last year, when the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety voted on the committee's recommendations for second reading. Many controversial amendments at the time passed by just one vote. GMOs are a danger to the environment itself, the genetic pool and species diversity, as well as, above all, to human and animal health. I would like to point out that most of the impact studies carried out on GMOs have always been financed mainly by multinational corporations, headed by their representatives from lobby groups. The harmfulness of GMOs to human health is not talked about in public at all, yet we already know about them from independent studies. It must be said that I am very disappointed with the current state of the text presented. The European Parliament went into negotiations with a very good text that we could and should have defended, but this did not work. I therefore personally refuse to support the current text of the proposal in any way. We must stop GMOs in the European Union.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that this compromise is a lazy compromise, and in the end we in Europe will have a patchwork: countries that have genetic engineering, countries that do not have one, and that in a common market. This will not lead to more consumer confidence, but to less consumer confidence, and it will serve everyone, but not clarity for new rules. The exciting question, Commissioner, is there now more authorisations, more authorisations, because now Member States simply agree to authorisation in the belief that they can then ban it again at home? Do we have to expect a wave now, or what is to come? What has actually become of the compromise, of clear rules for the coexistence of GM-free agriculture? What has become of clear rules by introducing liability rules for those who do not want to grow genetic engineering? None of this is included in this compromise. Commissioner, it is now up to you, you have promised, or Mr Juncker has promised to really shape new licensing rules in Europe, and they must then become more democratic and finally meet the majority will of European consumers, who do not want genetic engineering in their vast majority, including the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
