text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Do you not, however, think that a ban on GMOs at national level will result in fewer GMOs in Europe and the public being given the opportunity to put more pressure on their own governments on this issue? This will reduce the range of GMOs in Europe precisely by allowing opposing GMOs to put more pressure on governments. In Poland, such pressure exists and GMOs do not exist and will not.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, sir. We do have a situation at the moment where we have authorised only one type of genetic engineering throughout Europe: poppy 810. So who is saying that we in Europe now have a lot of genetic engineering? The alleged threat from corporations that we will then get more genetic engineering has, so to speak, been ineffective so far. The exciting question will now be, and I have just meant this: what is actually now when the wave of procedures comes? Will some Member States then say, yes, we are growing more genetic engineering, and others, perhaps directly the neighbouring state, will say that we are not growing? I believe that we are getting more genetic engineering. That is my firm conviction, because the political pressure on the European Commission is now simply no longer there.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Dear colleagues, the agreement reached is an optimal compromise and gives Member States the right to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their territory. GMOs shall not be authorised if this is contrary to the will of elected governments or their citizens. This directive, although not the best, ensures this, and I believe that it needs to be supported. I believe that gmos should only be allowed if there is strong evidence that this does not harm and cannot harm us and our children. We cannot allow, under pressure from lobbyists, to leave legal loopholes in legalising the cultivation of GMOs in the European Union and to impose it not only on the people of Lithuania, but also on the people of all your countries without their wish. Each country must decide for itself, taking into account the precautionary principle. We must not succumb to pressure from the country and allow the GMO empire in the European Union to take root. This principle must be introduced in EU instruments, including the free trade agreement with the United States. Sooner or later, interference in the affairs of mother nature will turn against us. Therefore, dear colleagues, let us be vigilant, let us love nature and support this document.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: You're running out of time, so I'll try to help you. We are talking about genetically modified organisms today, but we are actually talking about something much bigger. We are talking about more, about the self-determination of sovereign states. As Ronald Reagan, former President of the United States, said, "If a country has no control over its borders, then you cannot speak of a country." The MEMBER States in the EU are therefore not countries. But it goes further, because they also do not have access to the use of their tax money. They have no access to their own legislation. So, whether it is about the admission of budgetary rules, the admission of foreigners, or the admission of GMOs, the EU should not interfere. That is up to the Member States themselves.  [Speaker responds to a blue card question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules.]

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. –  Mr Stuger, do you agree not only that it is an incorrect procedure to be discussing in this place the nation states and what they do with their crops, but also that there is a lack of information for the people about this particular subject that would enable them to advise their representatives so that we can truly be democratic? So do you agree with me that there is a great democratic deficit in this debate, and in all debates we have here?

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer. – There is a large lack of democratic content. This is not only true of this debate, which applies to all debates, whether it is very simple or very complex decision-making. It is a godsend that we are sitting here together without any democratic legitimacy on your part. So I fully agree with this and I hope that we will be able to have a lot of discussion here.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after four years of work, we have finally reached agreement on a sensitive issue such as genetically modified organisms, which has been widely felt by the public and which is the subject of major scientific and political debates.  I would like to begin by thanking my colleague, the rapporteur, Mrs Ries, for the work she has done for Parliament, as well as my colleagues from all the other political groups who have helped to improve the text and have worked actively together to reach agreement on this dossier. I would also like to thank Mr Galletti for his excellent cooperation during the negotiations, which enabled us to reach agreement on a joint text by the end of last year with your support, Commissioner.  In my opinion, this compromise is the only possible agreement and, like any good compromise, it must leave the same bitter taste in everyone's mouth. Parliament wanted to pursue certain positions on certain issues and was unable to do so, it had to sacrifice them on the altar of an agreement, and that is the only possible agreement. I believe, however, that it should be remembered that, over and above the various positions that can be taken on this issue, the main objective we set ourselves as politicians and legislators was to create a certain legal basis in this area. In fact, faced with a situation of uncertainty that had given rise to multiple appeals, we will finally have legal certainty. I therefore call on all my fellow Members to support this agreement, which I repeat was the best possible agreement between all those we have examined.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too believe that we have done a good job, a good compromise, certainly a step forward after four years of deadlock. Of course, there is not everything we would have liked, but we are certainly building a text that takes us one step further and that is not comparable to the current situation. For those of us who want to preserve typical products, who want to defend biodiversity, which is a wealth of our land, for those who want to avoid product approval, this text allows us to take a step forward. The Commissioner is right, Europe defines the criteria, the safety grid, the authorisation methods and the nation states finally have a certain legal basis for action. It is a step forward that allows us to overcome years of uncertainty and that allows all those who care – I repeat – the defence of typical products to finally be able to say: we have made it! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – My question is quite simple: at what point, in either this regulation or the proposals that you have, is it absolutely clear that you can ban GMO products? Surely the very nature of this proposal, and of the compromise you have put forward, makes it obscure and unclear, and makes it impossible for the public in Europe to say with absolute certainty that there will be no GMO products. This is once again an EU mess-up in an EU directive that impacts on the European people.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think the exact opposite is true: until now we have had an uncertain rule and an uncertain legal basis, we now have a certainly more precise rule that allows us to take a decision as the European Parliament and give clear directives to the nation states and not refer everything back to the Court of Justice.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The cultivation of genetically modified foods should therefore be returned to the national parliaments, strengthening the subsidiary character of the European Union. This is, of course, good in principle, because that is one of the demands that we, as the AfD, have always made. That is why I can well understand why Mr Liese has mentioned the Chancellor's concerns here, because now the chancellor, who has so far gladly handed this over to Brussels and then had nothing to do with it, will have to worry about 88% of German citizens who are very concerned about this cultivation. , have to deal with this, and she will have to give an answer, something that our Chancellor is particularly reluctant to do. But, of course, what is being decided here does not go far enough, because we are indeed going to have quite a lack of competence chaos. Above all, as a Parliament, we will have to be careful that, in the end, as was the case with the association agreement with Ukraine, this regulation will not be lifted via TTIP.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: For years, we in Europe have been stressing the importance of knowledge and innovation. Innovations in the field of genetic modification are promising and can provide a better and more efficient food supply.  I therefore find it worrying that the European cultivation of new GMO crops has become a wash. Our agriculture is lagging behind in this. Biotech companies, which provide a lot of highly skilled work, are looking elsewhere. Hopefully, this new legislation will give more leeway and better start the licensing process. If this fails, new measures will have to be taken. The choice is ours: let us think about opportunities and not risks. European agriculture is still one of the most innovative in the world. Let's keep it that way.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I am very sorry to have to tell you that we are being brought a real charade here today. You know better than anyone that a state's freedom to allow GMO crops is a widespread imposition of transgenic feeding. Because they know, as well as I do, that it is not possible to preserve peasant agriculture, organic or conventional agriculture, free of GMOs unless in their delusions they think they will be able to stop the wind or insects.  Because biodiversity, health, the environment, non-multinational peasant agriculture, healthy food and food sovereignty remain among our main objectives, we want a directive for the prohibition of GMOs and also for the Free Trade Agreement to stop with the United States.

name: Jill EVANS
text: Madam President, I am against this proposal because I have always worked for a GM-free Wales in a GM-free Europe. This is the latest attempt to get more GM authorisations agreed at European level by putting the decision to ban GMOs in the hands of individual governments. In theory this could be appealing for a country like Wales, where agriculture is devolved. Wales was a founding member of the GM-free Regions Network. We do not have the same policy as the UK Government on GM crops. We are proud of our high-quality agricultural produce and we do not want to see that jeopardised. This proposal would open the door to GM crops in Europe, with real risks of cross-contamination. Increasing GM authorisations in Europe would also send a signal to the rest of the world that GMOs are becoming more acceptable. This is certainly not the case for my constituents in Wales.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Evi referred a moment ago to efsa's questionable role. We are convinced that the lack of confidence of Europeans in GMOs and also in the control agencies is based precisely on the failure of this European agency to demonstrate impartiality and independence in its assessments, including, and above all, on GMOs. EFSA has never felt that it should refuse permits to any GMOs, even when it was biotech companies themselves that recognised that there were statistically significant differences between GM and traditional plants or, for example, in the physiological response of GMO-fed animals to controls.  This is superimposed by sad stories of conflicts of interest and disturbing episodes of revolving doors involving experts from transgenic plant evaluation panels. And here it is perhaps easier to understand the public's mistrust of GMOs and EFSA itself. That is why we believe that The Member States can and should be able to intervene by banning GMOs, not even because of the environmental and health risks that their cultivation and use entail. This directive does not go in this direction and we shall vote against it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Madam President, GMOs as imposed on us by multinational agrochemical companies, the United States and the European Union are unacceptable and dangerous. On the one hand, the investment required to create a new GMO plant is high. As a result, this technology may lead to a decrease in the number of crop varieties grown. Diversity is agriculture's best asset against disease and pest problems. On the other hand, the vast majority of GMOs are Roundup Ready varieties. Crops can be watered with Roundup, a weedkiller highly toxic to wildlife but also to humans. Other GMO plants secrete pesticides themselves. Some of these pesticides are probably ingested by consumers. It should be noted that the amount of Roundup residues tolerated in soybeans increased fourfold in the United States in 1997 to allow the sale of transgenic soybeans. Roundup is a potentially very dangerous carcinogen. Consumer health here seems to be an adjustment variable. Finally, farmers need to replenish their supplies of GMO seeds each year; they are enslaved and not liberated by this technology.  The new directive you want us to vote on is a trap. You will give a little sovereignty to the states by allowing them to authorize or ban a GMO on their territory. However, due to the principle of free movement, French supermarkets will be increasingly welcoming GMO products from other EU countries on their shelves. French consumers will therefore be increasingly exposed to GMOs despite their strong opposition to this technique. Mandatory labelling of GMO-containing foods - unfortunately not visible on packaging - will be the last bulwark against those who intend to impose them without limitation, particularly through the European Union/US free trade agreement.  As usual, you therefore legislate against the will of the people on a crucial subject, thus favouring the interests of multinational agrochemicals at the expense of the health of consumers and farmers, the diversity of cultivated plants and rejecting a fundamental principle: we must feed without making sick.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, you would like to congratulate rapporteur Frédérique Ries and our fictional rapporteur Elisabeth Kostinger, and thank President La Via for the important role he played in this negotiation.  Until now, we had a system without tails or heads, which discouraged research and innovation in the biotechnology sector by its complexity and which, on the other hand, brought to justice the Member States - such as France - which are hostile to the cultivation of GMOs.  We have a compromise - after five years - that offers freedom of choice and, nevertheless, greater legal certainty. What is important to me is that the assessment of GMO seeds and their safety takes a scientific approach and is not subject to purely ideological debate.  Secondly, Member States have an obligation to adopt co-existence measures in cross-border areas to avoid contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops. I fought for it because I believe that farmers should be able to remain free from the choices of their crops.  This compromise is certainly not the outcome we could have dreamed of for the GMO file. For my part, I would have preferred a truly European solution to break the deadlock, but the best of course being the enemy of the good, I now call for everyone's responsibility to establish a stable legal framework for GMO crops in Europe.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Madam President! With the directive to be adopted today, we are creating a comprehensive and legally sound regulation for the cultivation or non-cultivation of genetically modified plants in the European Union.  We Social Democrats would have preferred a general ban on cultivation, because that would have made it even clearer in keeping with the wishes of the more than 500 million consumers. Unfortunately, the Council of Ministers did not follow suit. What we are getting now is a patchwork of cultivation and non-cultivation. This is a major challenge for the European internal market.  Nevertheless, I am seeking approval of the compromise that has been reached. This means that the Member States must decide on legally safe cultivation or non-cultivation in their own area. This gives us more legal certainty and can therefore also achieve a strict ban.  The mandatory coexistence rules between Member States, which are also very important to me, make it possible for GMOs to coexist with conventional or organic farming. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". It is as follows: it has already been said by our colleague Mrs Melior that it creates freedom of choice, but she would have found it better, it would have been possible to ban it in general, because that is what people want. However, not all people have said that they do not want genetically modified organisms. Do we not have EFSA specifically to ensure that we really examine in a scientifically sound way what is now being made available in research and what can be grown? Is it not the case that we are always in favour of innovation and research? And is it not the case that, in this case, we are totally questioning the scientific findings?

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. This does not call into question scientific knowledge, nor is EFSA's work in question. But what you are ignoring here is the great desire of consumers, because in Germany, our common country, too, 84% say no to GMOs, to green genetic engineering.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Madam President! This discussion clearly demonstrates the concern that is being expressed about GMOs. The citizens and the government will hopefully have more self-determination, and that is a good thing. The Danish delegation in the ECR Group will vote to ensure flexibility for Member States so that it is possible to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs. We need to protect our citizens, who for the most part still oppose GMO cultivation in Europe, because the uncertainty about the relationship with human health is still too great. That is why it is important to give Member States greater sovereignty in GMO cultivation in order to give them more freedom to decide independently on GMO cultivation in their own territory.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: Madam President, the idea of national opt-outs from GMO regulation is unworkable and ignores the wish of the vast majority of EU citizens that our continent should remain GM-free. The new system would allow countries whose governments are more subject to lobbying from agribusinesses – and I am ashamed to say that my country is one of those – to introduce GM crops as a Trojan horse to undermine the EU ban on this dangerous technology. They will be allowing their own priorities to work against the desires and wishes of other EU citizens. For this reason, the proposal is inherently inimical to the single market and to European unity. Before we vote on this proposal we should ask ourselves how we come to be here. We are not voting on an end to the GM moratorium because of lobbying from our constituents. I have not received a single e-mail from my constituents in the south-west calling for more GM crops. We have arrived here because of relentless, high-powered, well-funded lobbying by the biotech corporations, who have no interest in our welfare and are simply interested in swelling their own profits, even at a risk to public health. Citizens across Europe have rejected GM, and we must continue to respect their view and condemn the specious arguments and profiteering instincts of the agricultural corporations.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the actors in this agreement, because we were facing a very ideological and emotional debate and that makes solutions very difficult. According to our legislation, in the European Union the marketing of GMOs is only used while preserving, above all, the protection of health and the environment, and always with the scientific support of the risk assessment of the European Food Safety Authority, which is independent and rigorous. However, it is logical and lawful that there are countries that are contrary to their cultivation and legal certainty had to be given to the companies that market them and to the States that want to exercise this right, because we were in an unsustainable situation because of the absence of an effective decision-making system that undermined our strength on the international scene. That is why I am very pleased with this agreement. This agreement will make it possible to unblock a situation that was not acceptable, so that Member States wishing to grow GMOs, which are always authorised, will still be able to do so, while those who do not wish to do so may also prohibit it. The approved text ensures respect for the principles of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: Madam President, the report we are about to vote on today represents a balanced compromise that takes both the science and the views of the public into account. It provides for a strengthened environmental impact assessment on new GMOs. Furthermore, it requires Member States which choose to cultivate GMOs to introduce co-existence measures for border areas. This should be good news for the fast-growing, environmentally-friendly and job-creating sector of organic agriculture, which cannot afford contamination with GM crops. It strikes the Labour Party that the British Conservatives are opposed to the proposed exclusion of biotech companies from the decision-making process. This only shows once again that the Tories remain in the hands of big business lobbyists and have little regard for the views of the general public, little regard for the consumer and little regard for common sense.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Today there will be an important vote on the cultivation of GM crops. The proposed draft directive allows Member States to retain their competence to ban GMOs in their territory.  This is of exceptional importance for my country, Polish, because the great diversity, biodiversity of agricultural soils in Poland and the lack of GMOs are a great asset for the promotion of healthy eating and export of very good quality Polish agricultural products. Our soils are capable of producing natural food, and the use of GMOs would inevitably expose them to degradation. Currently, gmo crops in Poland are fortunately banned. Poland is and must remain free from the cultivation of genetically modified food.  Member States have different attitudes towards GMOs and the provisions on this matter should be subject to their sovereign decisions.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The compromise on GMO cultivation allows Member States to take decisions in accordance with their own interests, the specific situation and the opinion of their citizens. It is important to inform the public what GMOs really are and what effects it can have on agriculture, the environment and health. This issue should not be ideologized and politicised, but presented according to facts, available knowledge and research. The substantive discussion should make it possible to assess the real risks and possible benefits of growing GMOs. This is a difficult and emotional discussion in each Member State. Therefore, the support for the compromise facilitates, in my opinion, the possibility of internal dialogue and will not cause the community to object to the decision imposed from above. It is important, it should be emphasised, that this compromise makes it easier for Member States to ban GMOs. Further research is important because scientists are not unanimous in assessing benefits and risks.  GMO crops must be fully safe and ensure that the country where gm crops are grown does not infect neighbouring countries, organic and traditional crops. I hope that this approach will allow the politicised discussion to be concluded and for governments to make a rational, responsible and best decision for the people.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his This compromise is certainly not a reason to break out in blind cheers. But if you look at the current situation over many, many years, the uncertain legal framework on which countries such as Austria have prevented the cultivation of genetically modified organisms through the safeguard clauses, this compromise is one that I very much support today.  I have the impression that the Greens and the GUE/NGL are playing a very bad game today. It is not up to us to decide whether we want to allow genetically modified organisms to grow throughout the European Union, or whether we do. Today, it is a question of agreeing to this compromise or of continuing the situation we had before. And this situation would have brought about exactly what you are putting on the wall here today, namely that it would have made it possible for the groups to bring legal law to those Member States which have decided not to allow genetically modified organisms to be grown on their territory, and possibly even to force them to grow.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Genetically modified crops pose a threat to the environment and human and animal health. In countries where GMOs have been cultivated for years, the harmful effects of these crops can be seen, as evidenced by research by independent scientists. Despite this, GMO seed and plant protection chemicals companies are aggressively lobbying GMOs in search of new markets m.in in Europe. The only effective solution is to introduce a total ban on GMOs throughout the European Union.  I regret that, instead of introducing such a ban, only a far-from-ideal agreement has been reached. On the one hand, it gives the Member States the theoretical possibility of banning GMOs, and I hope that my country, Poland, that the government of that country will make use of this opportunity. On the other hand, this opens the door to the easy legalisation of GMOs in the future. The subject of genetically modified organisms should be the subject of careful work by the Committee on Agriculture, and this was not the case. Citizens do not want genetically modified food on their plates, so politicians should listen to the public and ban such crops.

name: Ivo BELET
text: This agreement is far from perfect, but as is often the time in politics, the ideal is the enemy of good. It is good that we finally have an agreement, so that there is a legal framework, not only for businesses, but also for consumers and for governments. That's how we know where we're at. We apply the precautionary principle, which is essential in such dossiers, to the maximum so that applications for GMOs have to be subject to very rigorous screening, so that there is no risk to either public health or the environment. The obligation to provide buffer zones, particularly at the border, is also a good thing, of course. Allow me to refer to my own region, Flanders, where there is already a strict legal framework today, so that producers will in the future be obliged to take clear precautions and avoid a risk. In short, we now have a very clear, strict framework in Europe, probably one of the strictest frameworks in the world for the authorisation of GMOs. And do not forget that the Commissioner will also be carrying out an evaluation within four years, so that we will have additional guarantees.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his The amendment to the law that we are voting on here today allows the Member States to decide for themselves whether GMOs should be grown on their territory.  I think it is a balanced compromise, and I will vote in favour of it. It respects the fact that we have different approaches and approaches to GMOs. This enables the Member States to decide for themselves. I think it is a good thing on an issue like this that divides. There are different views, and it is important to respect the will of the people.  For my part, I think we should listen very much to science and to the evaluations that EFSA, for example, are doing. We shall also start from the precautionary principle. It is important not to rush into difficult issues, or to allow things that could have negative effects on human health and the environment. The agreement also foresees measures to deal with the cultivation of GMOs, known as buffer zones between Member States. I think that is very important.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Madam President, the document we're about to vote on is not ideal but it meets its main objective. Member states will have more independence to allow or ban the cultivation of GMO on their territory.  I am pleased that my amendment obliging biotechnology companies to cease all activities related to the sowing of GMO cultures in the period from proposing to the entry into force of national prohibition measures has been respected. I consider the poor move to significantly mitigate the provisions on the financial liability of polluters in the event of a cross-border expansion of GMO to countries where it is prohibited. I think in time it will prove to be the worst possible way.  In conclusion, I do not consider GMO to be some kind of devilish seed but as long as we are not fully sure about its impact on health and biodiversity, states must have the option of banning it. In addition, the market for traditional and organic agricultural products is growing and small European countries, such as Croatia, have multiple economic benefits from being GMO free.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, as a person who advocates the principle of subsidy, I believe that Member States must have autonomous opportunities to defend or limit the lowering of living genetically modified organisms into the environment. So I ask that this right be respected. I am proud to live in Croatia, which is a GMO free country and I am pleased that we are surrounded by neighbors who have also decided to be free of GMO. Over 4 500 local self-government units and more than 150 regions in Europe have taken decisions in their representative bodies to ban sowing GMO seeds on their territory.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Madam President, I think we are faced with something, indeed, unclear: we have to choose between a worse situation and a situation that is less bad. I will oppose in my country, in the country where I come from, the cultivation of GMOs. My problem is: can I defend the citizens of my country as long as the rapporteur himself has told us that the improvement is only about banning or restricting cultivation, and not transport and import?  I think we need to think about a principle, which is economic development, it must not compromise on the environment and health. I believe that we must assume, this Parliament, to improve what we now want to approve, because we started from a worse situation. I do not think that this is the favourable situation, and I do not believe that we can defend citizens - they are part of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection - and I believe that free movement will lead to the compromise of traditional agriculture, and different prices will make small farmers disappear from the market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, I see the issue of GMO cultivation as one of the bigger points of controversy within the European Union. This report is a step in the right direction, as it establishes a more efficient system than that proposed by the Council. But I don't think it goes far enough in transferring jurisdiction to member states. I deeply believe that each of us has the right to choose our own destiny and that no member should be prevented or imposed on the cultivation of GMO. I see Croatia as a state free from GMO, but I also give everyone the right to see their country differently.  I therefore believe that the Commission's primary role in this case should be to monitor and ensure that those who choose GMO do not contaminate those who do not want it. The bulk of quality regulation from a European level should go primarily towards the effective establishment of appropriate buffer zones between GMO-free areas and the GMO-free area.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, I thank you for this useful debate and different opinions. I really hope that the majority of you will vote in favour of this legislative proposal. As I said previously, if you vote in favour you, will provide Member States with legally-sound tools to decide on GMO cultivation on their territory starting in Spring 2015. I look forward to your positive vote.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – For statistics, as many as 58% of EU citizens are opposed to the cultivation of genetically modified crops in the European Union. So far, however, this issue has not been adequately addressed at EU level, especially with regard to the decision-making process itself for the production of genetically modified organisms. It is not justified when 19 of the 28 governments oppose the legalisation of the new GMO crop, but the final decision is taken by the Commission without taking into account the positions of democratically elected governments. With regard to today's document, I can only welcome the fact that Member States are given a broader mandate to decide on the cultivation of GMOs in their territories. Although these new rules do not address the labelling of GM products, this issue remains relevant. GM products must be properly labelled and residents must be able to choose whether or not to consume products containing GM crops.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their territory. The 5-Star Movement has strongly opposed this because the text adopted today will make it easier to authorize at Community level and will therefore give the green light to gm crops in those Member States that so wish. That is why we voted against it together with our colleagues from the Green Group in the European Parliament and the GUE.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. We have been debating for several years how to deal with the introduction, or rejection, of GMOs in the European Union. Until recently, our differences prevented any possibility of agreement. However, we cannot be satisfied with fragmented and uncoordinated procedures. We now have the opportunity to give a clear framework to private, public and associative actors in this sector. I believe that this opportunity must be seized. However, in the absence of agreement on the content, we had to confine ourselves to the container: no decision on the appropriateness of GMOs left to the Member States, this European text will ultimately be purely procedural. It would be wrong to make this agreement a precedent in other areas that would risk in the longer term that the law and policies of the European Union would be deprived of its substance.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The health of the peoples of Europe is not negotiable. We cannot cause an upheaval in our food and our environment. Behind this text of technical reforms lies an attempt to develop genetically modified organisms in Europe. In addition to health risks, GMOs are a means of controlling agriculture by agri-food groups via patented seeds. Will the European Parliament be the relay of international economic oligarchy? The hypocrisy of this text is striking. While It is envisaged that Member States will have new tools in the authorisation of GMO crops, the text does not call into question the obstacles to the most basic freedoms of States. Indeed, what would a ban on GMO cultivation in one country mean if it is impossible to ban the movement of GMOs grown in another Member State? One of the first forms of state sovereignty is the control of all flows that pass through it. This text maintains supranational tutelage over states when standards and evaluation procedures are not satisfactory. I am aware that security has a price, but we cannot sell off the food security of our peoples and the independence of their agriculture.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – It is in the interest of Hungarian farmers that the GMO exemption for Hungarian agriculture be ensured. This objective is also stated in the Hungarian Constitution. The current GMO authorisation system is also very vulnerable to the preservation of GMO exemptions. It is very difficult to introduce and maintain the safeguards. On the one hand, very costly scientific studies are needed to establish a safeguard bond, to which the owners of varieties do not give away seeds protected by their patents. On the other hand, on the basis of the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority, which has always taken a positive stance on the GMO, the maintenance of prohibitions will be decided by the other Member States on a proposal from the Commission. So far, the Commission has always proposed the abolition of member states' safeguards, against which it is almost impossible to obtain a qualified majority. The proposal for a new GMO authorisation system to be voted on today gives a much more secure opportunity to preserve the GMO exemption for Hungarian agriculture than under the current system. A ban would be simpler, based not only on environmental and health reasons, but also on other reasons, including many related to agriculture. This would make it much less possible to challenge Hungary because of the ban in an international or national judicial forum than in the current situation. Therefore, the most important thing for me is that we have in our hands as soon as possible an effective instrument on the basis of which prohibition is simpler and more defensible than in the current system. I therefore support the adoption of a proposal containing an agreement between the Council and Parliament.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. – The agreement reached on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory provides a clearer framework and increased flexibility as to the reasons for such refusal. At the same time, it must be said that it is an agreement that leaves many of us dissatisfied, both those who are strongly opposed to the cultivation of GMOs in the European Union, due to the existing environmental risks, which science cannot exclude, such as those who believe that the scientific evidence available on the health effects of GMOs is irrefutable and that the obstacles that are raised to this technology contribute to killing European science and small enterprises in the sector. I end up saying that I believe that this agreement represents a small but important step as it preserves the robust scientific evaluation process by the European Agency for Food Security and reserves the possibility for Member States to act, in defence of the will of their citizens, according to a number of pre-established criteria.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing – I personally welcome the European Commission's intention to give Member States more powers to ban the cultivation of GM crops. However, it should not be forgotten that the main factor is not the existing rules, but the demand, which will be very difficult to influence by the possible modification of legislation in the area in question. It is well known in Europe that the primary reason for the low production of GM crops is the lacklustre market interest in their supply. After all, we cannot expect farmers to produce something that is very difficult to sell to their trading partners, and, moreover, many in practice often find that customers explicitly demand evidence that the goods supplied are not genetically modified. However, I welcome the fact that the envisaged new rules are intended to give Member States greater control over the prohibition of the cultivation of this type of crop in their national agricultural sectors. However, it should also be remembered that countries that so choose to prevent the cultivation of GMOs on their territory may face legal attacks from the biotechnology industry, so it is also appropriate to introduce measures to protect them properly.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.  Today, we are completing a piece of legislation that is of great importance to European citizens. We all know how much the issue of GMOs polarizes positions on the ground and creates public concern. It was therefore not a foregone conclusion to reach an agreement after five years of negotiations. We are now faced with a certain regulatory framework, which is based on the fundamental principles of freedom of choice and scientific safety. The final word on the entry and production of GMOs now rests with the Member States: those who oppose it can restrict their entry and will have guaranteed maximum safety in controls. The role of The Member States in introducing control measures for areas of contamination and coexistence between border countries remains crucial when implementing the new legislation from next spring. Health protection, consumer protection and the enhancement of local production are some of the principles on which Europe bases its sustainability model: today we are making a concrete and important gesture to strengthen Europe as a place of food quality and safety.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The new legislation on limiting the production of GMOs is a major step in the European fight against GMOs. It is the result of a right and responsible decision. The common success of all of us, one of the keys of which was excellent Austro-Hungarian-Croatian cooperation. The result achieved is Hungary the european union, as this will give us a Guarantee at European level that our agriculture's GMO exemption, as enshrined in the Basic Law, can be guaranteed at European level. Nevertheless, it must be said that there are many of us who would have liked to have seen more, stricter regulation. However, we must recognise that a realistic compromise has been reached in the current circumstances. In addition to the continued opposition of Member States supporting the cultivation of GMOs, the main objective of ensuring member states' free choice has finally been achieved. However, in terms of research and food safety, we still have a brigade of work ahead of us, and we must continue to address the long-term health effects of GMOs. While maintaining the delicate balance reached by this compromise, we must go further on the ground of science to ensure the highest level of protection for European consumers. We can see that the regulation of GMOs shows that environmental protection is a European issue that does not stop at national borders. The safe cultivation of GMOs in Europe should be based on a respect-based dialogue between Member States that choose and reject GMOs. In order to avoid cross-border pollution, the necessary measures should be taken and liability for the damage caused should be taken.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – The new GMO legislation, which the European Parliament is negotiating at second reading following the agreement with the Council on 4 December, gives Member States more lee way to prohibit GMO cultivation than the Council proposal, but represents a significant step backwards from Parliament's position at first reading. The new directive can be booked as a partial success, but rather as a failure. A number of important issues, such as damage caused by cross-border pollution and damage caused by the cultivation of GM crops, remain open and unsettled.  A lasting, reassuring settlement of the latter issue and the effective enforcement of the polluter pays principle have not been achieved, as the Council has unfortunately not supported Parliament's stricter position, the requirement of mandatory measures for the prevention and management of pollution. This is linked to the case of financial liability for damages, essentially att to biotechnology companies, to which the final text contains only a vague reference.   In practice, this means that the injured party, i.e. the injured Member State, its authority, farmers and taxpayers, can continue to bear the burden of pollution. The Council should have been more decisive in defending the legitimate interests of non-GMO Member States.  In addition, reform of the authorisation and risk assessment process at EU level remains essential. We cannot allow member states to allow gmo licensing to become more superficial.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. "The new legal base is an important tool for member states that want to keep the use of genetic engineering out of their fields. However, there were weaknesses in the legislation that jeopardise real freedom of choice.  Firstly, the new law relies on EU internal market legislation. It should have been incorporated into environmental legislation, as GM cultivation and products remain a potential risk to the environment and public health. The principle of the free movement of the internal market may prove to be a strong weapon in the court for a company wishing to extend the cultivation of its GM potatoes to all Member States.  In addition, the legislation lacked measures to define actions in situations where GM material is inadvertently present in areas for which it is not wanted. This is a common problem, for example in border regions with states. At present, for example, a Portuguese organic farmer would have to pay a financial loss for making his crop unsable to sell.  A system must be set up at EU level that is binding on all states and operators, in accordance with the 'polluter pays' principle. We are not yet sufficiently familiar with the long-term and double effects of genetic variants, so it is better to adhere to the precautionary principle before we make irreversible solutions.  There is no need for more genetic engineering to feed the world's population – we are already importing food for 14 billion people. However, almost half of the food is wasted, and it is more important to focus on finding solutions for how the food produced is distributed more evenly among the world's population.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – The Member States of the European Union have long called for legislation on existing legislation that would allow them greater freedom and flexibility in limiting or prohibiting the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. However, negotiations were blocked by the Member States themselves for four years, and the resulting Council compromise proposal, adopted by 28 Environment Ministers in July 2014, was far from perfect. However, during the debate in the European Parliament, the text was significantly improved, in particular as regards the weakening of the powers of companies seeking to market GMOs in the EU for the benefit of the governments of the Member States. It was also essential to strengthen measures to ensure the coexistence of cultivated crops by Member States and, in particular, to prevent cross-border contamination. Overall, this is a good compromise, helping, inter alia, to protect European biodiversity and preserve natural habitats and ecosystems. Nevertheless, as Vice-President of the ENVI Committee, I would like to see a text that would further reflect public opinion in Europe, which is increasingly turning against GMOs and, in particular, their presence in food. The debate between supporters and opponents of GMOs is not over, and we will be watching with anticipation the actions of Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, who has pledged to strengthen the democratic process of authorising GMOs in Europe and to ensure that related research is truly independent.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – I am in favour of unlocking the European decision-making process with regard to the authorisation of GMOs at European level. The legislative proposal concerns responding to the request from the Member States of the European Union to be able to restrict or prohibit, where appropriate, the cultivation of a GMO crop and does not alter the European authorisation system. Furthermore, the fact that Member States that will grow GMOs will be bound to take measures to avoid cross-border contamination should be regarded as a respectful action towards the decision of other States that decide differently. The positive or negative effects of a GMO crop remain for the evaluation of scientific operators. In Romania, universities and research institutions need to become more involved in this area, work more with their European correspondents and carefully analyse the studies carried out by EFSA, in order to provide political actors with the necessary basis for decisions. In this context, I am convinced that only thorough research can provide adequate protection of the environment and the health of European citizens. We need more public debate by scientific researchers together with academia, the OP, civil society and state institutions to clarify the effects of GMO cultivation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The production of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) is a sensitive and controversial issue within the European Union (EU). Negotiations aimed at providing the EU with an appropriate and modern legislative framework have been taking place for five years but face many obstacles given the significant differences of opinion. The compromise reached by the Union will allow Member States that wish to grow GMOs and those who do not, to ban them legally. In practical terms, the application process for authorisation is clearer and more transparent: a company seeking authorisation to exploit genetically modified crops must nevertheless, after the approval of the European Food Safety Authority, obtain the authorisation of the Member State that will host the crops on its soil. I would also like to point out that, with regard to cross-border areas, the agreement reached obliges Member States to adopt coexistence measures to avoid contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops. In the end, this system is certainly not perfect, but it allows us to get out of a blocking situation. It will be important to ensure that a European solution is found in the medium term.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – I welcome this regulation which confirms the right of Member States to prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms in their territory.  Many European citizens fear the still unknown effects of GMOs on the environment. But until now, Member States that wanted to ban these crops were running into uncertainty at the legislative level and feared legal sanctions. This regulation will change the situation, as it provides a basis for banning GMOs at the level of each state. In addition, it will also ensure improvement of safety assessments for GMOs, while also imposing mandatory buffer zones to prevent crop contamination in border regions. They are really important and positive steps.  At the same time, however, there is a significant risk that we must take into account. By ensuring the legally clear right to ban GMOs at national level, it is possible, paradoxically, to increase the number of authorisations at EU level. Why is that? Because those Member States which have so far contributed to the blocking of these authorisations may decide to renounce their resistance at Community level, since they may exercise at national level their right to ban GMO crops. It's not the ideal scenario, but it's an improvement in the current situation.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) pose a danger to the environment and human health. It seems right to me that Member States should be able to restrict and even prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. It would also seem to me to be correct to implement a financial liability mechanism for compensation in case of accidents/contamination of organic crops. In this respect, I regret that the European Parliament has not given the necessary support for the implementation of such measures.  On the other hand, this report envisages the establishment of border co-existence measures against crop contamination - measures beneficial to the Member States and thus to farmers, who consider organic agri-food products. I do not find it logical to involve, or rather, such a strong role of biotech companies in the licensing phase of the cultivation of genetically modified products. There should be not even an attempt at equality between governments/Member States and biotech companies. It is, however, positive that there has been a reduction in the role of these companies in the first phase of the GMO cultivation authorisation. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the results and I hope that we will have the support of our colleagues for the compromise package reached.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The new GMO legislation will be on the european Parliament's voting agenda this lunchtime. We were successful. Member States of the European Union now have the freedom to decide whether or not to allow the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their soil. A real victory, the culmination of four years of legislative struggle. The pro-GMO lobbies, led by several multinationals and Great Britain, were ultimately unsuccessful. Moreover, we have obtained a legal basis for the refusal to implement GMO crops, an extension of the list of reasons for banning. These reasons for prohibition could include, for example, land-use planning obligations, socio-economic consequences, measures to prevent the accidental presence of GMOs in other products, or agricultural policy objectives. The prohibitions could also apply to groups of GMOs determined by species or characteristic. We have also demanded binding measures of coexistence. We have ensured that states have the power to impose sanctions to prevent the contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Mr President, the debate on the Directive of Parliament and the Council touches on a very important question that the European Union has to answer and which is important for all europeans. This is about authorising Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms. A lot is known about the threat of GMOs, but it is worth remembering something. It is not possible to stop the spread of modified genes. Irreversible contamination of GMOs will always follow. This will mainly affect small and medium-sized family farms that cultivate organic farming, in countries such as Lithuania. The cultivation of transgenic plants creates monoculture areas where many traditional varieties perish. The farmer practically becomes addicted to chemical corporations (seeds are patented and have to buy them every year). In addition, the cultivation of GMOs contributes to the decline of production and replaces the natural balance in existing ecosystems. The worst consequences follow below: infertile soil, poor harvest, constant threat of diseases. In addition, pesticides and herbicides become ineffective, forcing farmers to use several more toxic mixtures of them. As a result, the incidence of allergies and respiratory diseases increase among the population. When we vote, we must take into account the growing dissatisfaction of European public opinion with regard to GMOs. The vast majority of citizens do not support GMO farms in Europe, and we should therefore allow Member States to ban GMO farms in their territories by increasing their competences in this matter.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: João FERREIRA
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, I would ask you to calm the mood of that bench, please. First of all, I would like to point out that our group has proposed a debate on fisheries in this session, a debate which would include the debate on this report on the fisheries agreement between the European Union and St Thomas and Principe.  We regret that all the other groups have refused this debate. It is incomprehensible, especially since you cannot claim that we properly have a full agenda, yet yesterday was without any debate.  As far as this agreement is done, it is important to remember that this Parliament merely approves or rejects the proposals negotiated by the European Commission and cannot make any changes to them. We could make these amendments, the proposal that is being discussed and voted on here would certainly be very different from the one we have, because a profound change in the philosophy, objectives and results of these agreements is needed.  It is important to approve this agreement, it is important for St Thomas and Principe and for the Member States of the European Union, but this does not erase, it cannot erase the overall negative balance of what has been left behind, nor does it erase the need for profound change. Among other things, an improvement in the quantity and reliability of catch information and, in general, on the state of conservation of fisheries resources, more and better support for the training of observers and the development of the control capacity by S. Tomé and Príncipe, more and better sectoral cooperation, changing the course of the last three decades of life than this agreement , in various forms, already leads, with respect for the sovereignty and legitimate options and priorities of St. Thomas and Principe.  These are requirements for a fair and truly sustainable fisheries agreement that the European Commission should take into account in the coming years.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The report approves the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe. Its objective is to adapt European tuna fishing in Sao Tome and Principe to the scientific recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). The rapporteur has made a request to the Commission and the Council in the text to ensure that Parliament is informed of all stages of implementation and renewal of the Protocol. The democratization of fisheries policy control and its environmental sustainability are necessary conditions to ensure the employment and development of this sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — I have positioned myself in favour of this text because it will allow access to the waters of Sao Tomé-et-Principe (28 tuna boats and 6 surface longliners) for 34 EU vessels. The counterparties seem reasonable, as they amount to 710,000 euros in the first three years and 675,000 euros in the fourth year. They are all the more so because these sums include 325,000 euros per year for the support of the sectoral policy of Sao Tomé-et-Principe (support for small-scale fishing, fight against illegal fishing, surveillance, control).

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The renewal of the fishing protocol between the Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe and the European Union allows for a beneficial relationship between the two parties. I voted in favour of this text because the countries of Europe are taking advantage of this additional reserve and the European presence in this region is an element of stability that is part of the long term.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — In essence, this Agreement allows the European Union to pay money to fish the waters of a much poorer country.  This seems to me to be unjust and exploitative.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because this support meets the objectives of national fisheries policy, including the needs of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe in terms of support for small-scale fisheries and the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. — The conclusion of this protocol between the European Union and Sao Tome and Principe is very important not only for the development of the African nation, but also from the European point of view, as it will allow our vessels to expand their fishing area while enabling better environmental and sustainability control.  It is also an important way of strengthening the European Union's relations with a country that has long had a strong link to Portugal and with which we have every interest in cooperating. My vote in favour of this report is the wish that it be implemented as soon as possible and that Parliament should be kept abreast of developments in this process.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to renew the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Prince. This agreement provides EU vessels with access to national waters. Under the previous Protocol, 40 EU tuna fishing vessels were allowed fishing activities. The financial contribution amounted to EUR 682 500 per year; more than 35 % of this amount was allocated to support the fisheries sector of the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Prince. I support the new protocol, which is foreseen for the next four years and which provides for the right of fishing activities for 34 EU vessels. In the first three years, an annual financial compensation of EUR 710 000 will be granted and eur 675 000 will be allocated in the fourth year, of which a significant part will be allocated to support the fisheries policy of the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Prince of Prince. I agree that the agreement needs to be renewed and that the recommendations made may increase support for the fisheries sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — I voted for this new four-year protocol in favour of a fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe. The main objective is to offer European Union vessels fishing opportunities in TheMian waters, in accordance with the advice of scientific experts in the field. The second objective is to strengthen cooperation between the Union and Sao Tomé and President to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Santomean fishing area, for the benefit of both sides. The overall financial consideration of the protocol is 2,805,000 euros over the entire 4-year course.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — This protocol sets out the fishing opportunities and financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe. The protocol, which came into force in May 2014 for a period of four years, is expected to allow 34 European Union vessels to fish there. In return, Sao Tomé-et-Principe will receive 2,805,000 euros over the entire 4-year period (this may be revised upwards if the annual amount of catches exceeds the annual reference tonnage set). This text seems fair and balanced, so I voted in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this agreement, which provides for the possibility for EU tuna vessels and vessels to fish in the waters of the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the proposal, for a number of reasons. Although today's fisheries agreements between the EU and non-EU countries are far better than before, especially for fish stocks, there are several problems. Fisheries policy must have a functioning social dimension. Instead, the EU continues to exploit the waters of developing countries. The alternative should be to help these countries build their own sustainable fishing activities. In this case, são Tomé and Príncipe will also receive extremely low compensation for fishing, and the chances of this money contributing to the local fishing industry are low. It will receive EUR 35 per tonne in year 1, which will increase to EUR 70 per tonne by year 4 (compared to the EU-Seychelles (Mayotte) agreement, where the price in year 1 is EUR 110 per tonne and eur 6 125 in the year. At the same time, reliable catch data for the area are lacking and capacity monitoring is low. The existence of corruption in the area also leads to the 'disappearance of development funds along the way'. Finally, sharks are also hunted in the area. All in all, this led me to vote against the proposal.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to fish in their waters. The previous Protocol was in force from 13 May 2011 to 12 May 2014 and allowed 40 EU tuna to be worked. The financial contribution amounted to EUR 682 500/year, of which approximately 35% was earmarked for support for the policy of the fisheries sector of Sao Tome and Principe. A new Protocol was initialed on 19 December 2013, valid for four years from 23 May 2014 and will allow fishing activity to 34 EU vessels. The annual financial contribution has been set at EUR 710 000 for the first three years and EUR 675 000 for the fourth year, of which EUR 325 000 will be used to support the sectoral policy of Sao Tome and Principe. I think it is a balanced agreement, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the Protocol, although noting, as the rapporteur in the report does, the need to consider that the achievements in sectoral cooperation are limited, a reality which needs to be changed.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this recommendation in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Princeín. This agreement is part of the tuna fishing agreement network in West Africa and provides EU vessels with access to national waters. The first agreement in the fisheries sector with the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Prince-of-One was signed in 1984. Since then, eight protocols have been implemented, two of which have been implemented under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. Until now, however, the results of sectoral cooperation have been very limited. This situation should be urgently changed. This Protocol, together with other development assistance measures, such as the European Development Fund, should promote the real sustainable development of the fisheries sector and other related industries and activities of the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Prinsipe, and increase the added value of the country through the use of the country's natural resources. The European Parliament rapporteur believes that the Commission needs to take the necessary steps, including a possible revision of the part of the agreement relating to sectoral support and an increase in funds, in order to effectively change the direction that has been taking over the last 20 years.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported the fishing partnership between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe because I consider it important to help one of the main sectors of the country’s economy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe is part of the network of agreements on tuna fishing in West Africa. In particular, it allows 28 seiner tuna and 6 longliners to fish in the Sao Tomé EEZ. While we agree in principle with this agreement, we express our deep concern about the multiple illegal fishing activities that are observed in the maritime area of the Gulf of Guinea. Due to the low capacity of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé to monitor territorial waters, the European Union must immediately strengthen the traceability of its imports of fisheries resources from countries suspected of covering illegal fishing activities. It is therefore with reservations that I voted for the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission, aimed at transparently communicating all stages of the procedures relating to the protocol and its renewal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation, because the agreement strengthens cooperation between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe with a view to establishing a sustainable fisheries policy and the rational exploitation of fisheries resources, in the interests of both parties. At the same time, this agreement provides the possibility for European Union vessels to fish in the waters of São Tomé and Príncipe, in accordance with the available scientific opinions and recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna. I believe that the European Union states will benefit from this agreement and the effects will be positive and long-lasting

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The agreement provides for the possibility for our tuna vessels and vessels to fish in their waters. It increases the economic compensation compared to the previous agreement.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe is one of the EU's tuna agreements in West Africa. It allows European Union vessels to fish in the waters of that country. This agreement is beneficial to both parties because it allows the development of the European market for fisheries products and the sectoral development of fisheries in Sao Tomé-et-Principe. The rapporteur stresses that the European Commission must be more committed to monitoring the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, while respecting the sovereignty and legitimate choices and priorities of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The first fisheries agreement concluded between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe dates back to 1984. Since then, eight protocols have been implemented, two of them under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. However, the results achieved so far in the field of sectoral cooperation are very poor. This agreement, combined with other development support instruments, such as the European Development Fund, should promote the sustainable development of the São Tomé and Príncipe fisheries sector, as well as related industries and activities. I have today voted in favour of this recommendation to call on the European Commission to take the necessary measures, including the revision and deepening of the sectoral support component of the agreement, in order to ensure a real reversal of the path followed over the last twenty years and to ensure maximum commitment to verifying the principles essential for the proper use of aid.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) We are voting in favour of the conclusion of this agreement, which guarantees support for sao Tomè fishermen for a further four years and at the same time allows European vessels to operate in their territorial waters.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text, which opens up new opportunities for our fishermen. It will allow access to the waters of Sao Tomé-et-Principe (28 tuna boats and 6 surface longliners) by 34 EU vessels. It also offers support to artisanal fishing to which I am attached because it values traditional know-how, guaranteeing quality fishing.  Finally, the text plans to tackle the fight against illegal fishing, a necessary measure for the preservation of our ecosystem.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — On the basis of the previous agreement (2011-2014) and the agreement just concluded between the European Union on the one hand and Sao Tome and Principe on the other, I voted in favour. This agreement further strengthens economic and trade relations and, above all, allows the exploitation of marine resources which also benefits the local populations.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I support my compatriot João Ferreira's report on the new protocol to the fisheries agreement between the EU and Sao Tome and Principe authorising 34 vessels from Spain, France and Portugal to fish in their waters. I share your criticism of the fact that there was no political will to discuss these agreements in plenary, especially when the agenda was not loaded at all and I agree with the added value that this Agreement represents for the effective sustainable development of the fisheries sector of this Lusophone country. This protocol provides for fishing opportunities for 28 seiners and six surface longliners, allocated by vessels from Spain, France and Portugal and involves an overall financial contribution of EUR 2,805,000 over four years.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution for the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe for two reasons. First of all, this agreement has the advantage of preserving European fishery resources and, at the same time, of developing partnership agreements with third countries, thus leading to an extension of European diplomatic relations. Secondly, the economic impact is entirely proportionate to the benefits of Europe, especially when one considers that, in view of the reduction from 40 to 34 in the number of vessels allowed to fish, the number of vessels with purse seines has remained unchanged, i.e. the type of vessel that has benefited most from the use of fishing opportunities.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report that recommends giving consent to the conclusion of the agreement which forms part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to fish in that country’s waters. The report also calls for measures so that resources are exploited sustainably and training should be provided for observers monitoring catches. More transparency and information on the procedures relating to the protocol and its renewal are being requested.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fisheries agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to operate in West African waters. I voted in favour because I believe that the European Commission must take the necessary measures to ensure a real reversal of the path followed over the last twenty years. I am voting in favour because I believe that the European Commission should make greater efforts to verify the principles that are essential for the proper use of aid, while respecting the sovereignty and legitimate choices and priorities of São Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The report approves the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe. Its objective is to adapt European tuna fishing in Sao Tome and Principe to the scientific recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). The rapporteur has made a request to the Commission and the Council in the text to ensure that Parliament is informed of all stages of implementation and renewal of the Protocol. The democratization of fisheries policy control and its environmental sustainability are necessary conditions to ensure the employment and development of this sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the report that deals with the renewal of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe that forms part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa. This new protocol will cover a four-year period from 23 May 2014 and provide fishing opportunities for 34 EU vessels, and will also include the necessary support of funding. The agreement will contribute to fostering the sustainable development of the São Toméan fisheries sector and of related industries and activities.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This report proposes the ratification of the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. The four-year agreement is part of the network of agreements on tuna fishing in West Africa. It allows the development of support to the local fishing sector in exchange for access by European Union vessels to fish part of the fishing surplus in the waters of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. This is a balanced agreement and, for that reason, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Through its network of agreements on tuna fishing in West Africa, EUROPEAN Union vessels can fish in the waters of a number of countries in the region, including the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. With the vote of the new protocol between the European Union and Sao Tomé and Principe, the European Union rightly perpetuates the access of its ships to waters rich in tuna while taking care to pay for this access at its fair value. This remuneration is aimed in particular at supporting the sectoral policy of Sao Tomé-et-Principe.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe. The new protocol, lasting four years, will allow fishing activities to be carried out on 34 Eu ropean Union vessels, in exchange for an annual financial contribution of EUR 710 000 for the first three years and EUR 675 000 for the fourth year.
