The agreement also provides that EUR 325 000 of the European financial contribution will be allocated to support the sectoral policy of São Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. — The Eu has negotiated a new four-year fishing protocol with Sao Tomé e President to establish the modalities and conditions under which EU-flagged vessels could fish in the waters of Sao Tomé e Pràncipe.  The first fisheries agreement between the EEC and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé e Prencipe dates back to 1984. Eight protocols have since been implemented, including two on the fisheries partnership agreement. However, the results achieved to date in the area of sectoral cooperation are very meagre. There was therefore an urgent need to remedy this situation. This agreement, in coordination with other development support instruments, such as the European Development Fund, should, in my view, promote genuine sustainable development of the fisheries sector in Sao Tomé e Pràncipe, as well as related industries and activities, by increasing the added value that remains in the country as a result of the exploitation of its natural resources. So I decided to vote in favour.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — This agreement between the Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe will improve the control of access to the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) concerned by a better presence of observers. This will ultimately encourage monitoring of tuna catches and fisheries in this area, an activity of significant environmental stakes. The preservation of natural and animal resources is indeed a condition of sustainable development in the field of local economic activities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it seems to us to be a balanced Partnership Agreement, as it emphasizes support for the development of the Sao Tome fisheries sector, which has been very limited in the last twenty years. Among the aspects to which special attention is recommended are those related to the reliability of the evaluation of Santo Tomé's fisheries resources, the development of control capacity by local authorities, the obligation to declare catches and the development of infrastructure in the sector. It requires greater commitment on the part of the Commission in verifying the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and options and priorities of Sao Tome. The need to strengthen cooperation in the development of the Santo Tome fisheries sector as a requirement for joint and sustainable exploitation of Sao Tome's fisheries resources is therefore highlighted.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We are voting in favour because this agreement serves the interests of the EU without prejudice to national interests.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. — 30% of the world's seas are overfished and the survival of marine fish stocks may be at risk. I support the proposal for a sustainable fisheries agreement between the European Union and São Tomé and Príncipe, because it seeks to limit tuna fishing in West Africa to a more sustainable framework than at present. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural values of these areas, unlike marine aquaculture areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly strict and unnecessary sustainability standards. These are only justified for marine fisheries and aquaculture. Efforts should be made to clearly divide the concept and regulation of marine and freshwater aquaculture in the future.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The previous protocol, which was in force from 13 May 2011 to 12 May 2014, allowed 40 EU tuna workers to operate: 28 seiners and 12 surface longliners. The financial contribution amounted to EUR 682 500/year, of which around 35 % was to support Santomense sectoral policy. With this new protocol to the fisheries agreement between the EU and Sao Tome and Principe, 34 vessels from Spain, France and Portugal are allowed to fish in the waters of that country. The Protocol also aims to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and to support Santomense sectoral policy. The overall financial contribution is 2,805,000 euros over four years. I also believe that the European Commission should take the necessary measures, including the possible revision and increase of the component of the agreement on sectoral support, to ensure an effective reversal of the path taken in the last twenty years.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The EU-Sao Tome and Principe Fisheries Agreement is part of the tuna fishing agreement network in West Africa. The first fisheries agreement concluded between the EEC and Sao Tome and Principe dates back to 1984. Since that date, eight protocols have been implemented, two of which two under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. Nevertheless, the results achieved so far in the field of sectoral cooperation are very scarce. This is a reality that needs to be changed. This agreement, in conjunction with other development support instruments such as the European Development Fund, should promote effective sustainable development of the Santomense fisheries sector, as well as related industries and activities, increasing the added value in the country as a result of the exploitation of its natural resources. The European Commission must take the necessary measures – including the possible revision and increase of the sector support agreement component – to ensure an effective reversal of the path taken over the past twenty years.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the agreement providing for the possibility for EU tuna vessels and vessels to fish in the waters of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé e Principe. The economic compensation compared to the previous agreement is increased, but greater fishing opportunities are given priority in the evaluation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe: fishing opportunities and financial contribution, because this agreement serves the interests of the EU without prejudice to national interests.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Recommendation in considering that it is part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa which allow EU vessels to fish in their waters. The main objective is to offer fishing opportunities to European Union vessels in SantoTomian waters while respecting the best available scientific opinions and the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna within the limits of available surpluses. The aim is also to intensify cooperation between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe with a view to the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Sao Tome and Principe fisheries area, for the benefit of both sides.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — Not only has the EU managed to strip our own waters of fish stocks (not to mention discarding thousands of tons of perfectly healthy fish), but it is now seeking to do the same throughout the rest of the world – by giving money to the wealthy in order to get fishing rights from poor fishermen. This is just neocolonial exploitation.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of renewing the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe because I believe that establishing sustainable fisheries policies in Sao Toméan fishing zones is in all our interests. I welcome the fact that, through the newly negotiated protocol, more reliable data on catches and the conservation status of fishery resources will be made available to the São Toméan authorities, enabling them to scale up the fight against illegal fishing. I urge the Commission to investigate carefully concerns regarding by-catch of sharks or other endangered species under the protocol, and to take the necessary steps immediately to address this problem if it occurs.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the agreements, cooperation and negotiations, as well as for a purely economic interest, for the exploitation of resources, are an opportunity for growth and maturation both for the European Union's external relations network and for the countries with which it is confronted.    The agreement with São Tomé and Príncipe is one of these moments, for our vessels, which thus have the opportunity to fish in other seas, but above all for the small island of our partner in this agreement.  I voted in favour of this agreement, but I would like to stress that the European commitment must go far beyond mere partnership in the fisheries sector. Europe has a duty to ensure that the financial compensation, and in particular the 325 000 that are earmarked for sector policy, is used by the island of São Tomé and Príncipe to improve catch reliability, the quality of fishing and the development of infrastructure. For 30 years now, the agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe has been in place, how many aspects of the sector could have changed with effective policies, it is not too late to start.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. "I will vote for this proposal because this agreement is in the well-understood interest of both parties.  On the one hand, it will allow access to 34 European Union ships in the waters of Sao Tomé. Among these vessels, there are 12 French tuna boats. On the other hand, the European Union grants fair compensation to Sao Tomé: 710,000 euros in the first three years; 675,000 euros in the fourth year.  These sums include EUR 325,000 per year for the support of sectoral policy, which will support small-scale fishing and combat illegal fishing.  Finally, shipowners will pay 35 euros per tonne in the first two years, 60 euros in the third year and 70 euros in the fourth year. It therefore appears that neither side is harmed, although the rapporteur points out that the results achieved at the moment in sectoral policy are insufficient.  In particular, we should improve our knowledge of fish stocks, but above all support the development of Sao Tome's own monitoring capabilities. It is on this condition that this agreement could really be part of a sustainable fishery.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it seems to us to be a balanced Partnership Agreement, as it emphasizes support for the development of the Sao Tome fisheries sector, which has been very limited in the last twenty years. Among the aspects to which special attention is recommended are those related to the reliability of the evaluation of Santo Tomé's fisheries resources, the development of control capacity by local authorities, the obligation to declare catches and the development of infrastructure in the sector. It requires greater commitment on the part of the Commission in verifying the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and options and priorities of Sao Tome. The need to strengthen cooperation in the development of the Santo Tome fisheries sector as a requirement for joint and sustainable exploitation of Sao Tome's fisheries resources is therefore highlighted.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe: fishing opportunities and financial contribution, because this agreement will foster the genuinely sustainable development of the fisheries sector.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur, however, noted that to date there has been a lack of data in this fishery, and he has called on the Commission to remedy this situation. He has also called for greater efforts to be made in developing São Toméan fisheries infrastructure. I fully back these calls.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this Recommendation because we think it is a balanced Partnership Agreement, as it emphasizes support for the development of the Sao Tome fisheries sector, which has been very limited in the last twenty years. Among the aspects to which special attention is recommended are those related to the reliability of the evaluation of Santo Tomé's fisheries resources, the development of control capacity by local authorities, the obligation to declare catches and the development of infrastructure in the sector. It requires greater commitment on the part of the Commission in verifying the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and options and priorities of Sao Tome. The need to strengthen cooperation in the development of the Santo Tome fisheries sector as a requirement for joint and sustainable exploitation of Sao Tome's fisheries resources is therefore highlighted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the signing of the Protocol setting out fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Prinsipe, as the refreshment of the Protocol allows EU vessels to fish in the waters of St Thomas and strengthens cooperation with that Republic. However, in this context, I consider it necessary to pay particular attention to the sustainable development of St Thomas' fishing sector and the benefits there is. I also support the intention to provide the St Thomas' authorities with reliable information on catches and fishing resources, and to establish an effective supervisory authority in this regard. In addition, I believe that when stimulating investments in the country, it is necessary to ensure the development of fishing infrastructure.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — The renewal of the fishing protocol between the Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe allows for a beneficial relationship between the two parties. I voted in favour of this text because the countries of Europe are taking advantage of this additional reserve and the European presence in this region is an element of stability that is part of the long term.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Ferreira report on the fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe (an archipelago located in the Gulf of Guinea). This report should enable the adoption of the new fishing protocol allowing European Union vessels to fish in the waters of that country for a period of four years. I supported this report because I believe that the agreement in question benefits both sides by allowing European vessels to fish for certain surplus resources in a regulated environment, while providing sectoral financial support for the development of sustainable fishing in the waters of Sao Tomé e Pr-fle.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report allowing the adoption of the new protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe for a period of four years. This new protocol will allow 34 european Union vessels to fish there, with an annual financial consideration set at 710,000 euros for the first 3 years and 675,000 euros in the fourth year.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement, as it is simply a renewal of an expired protocol that strengthens cooperation between the parties. Establishing sustainable fisheries policies is also crucial, especially in terms of fighting illegal fishing.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of mr Joao Ferreira's report because I see the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Sao Tomé and Principe as an opportunity for our economy. The agreement makes it possible for all vessels of Community origin to fish for tuna in West African waters.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to fish in their waters. I am voting in favour, given that this new Protocol which was initialed on 19 December 2013 will be valid for four years from 23 May 2014 and will allow fishing activity for 34 EU vessels, although it should be noted that some of the achievements achieved with this international cooperation need to be strengthened.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The report approves the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe. Its objective is to adapt European tuna fishing in Sao Tome and Principe to the scientific recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). The rapporteur has made a request to the Commission and the Council in the text to ensure that Parliament is informed of all stages of implementation and renewal of the Protocol. The democratization of fisheries policy control and its environmental sustainability are necessary conditions to ensure the employment and development of this sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to fish in their waters. The results achieved to date in the field of sectoral cooperation are extremely limited, so greater commitment on the part of the Commission is required to verify the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and legitimate choices and priorities of Sao Tome and Principe. It is also necessary to facilitate the participation of representatives of Parliament as observers in the meetings of the Joint Commission. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this proposal for the conclusion of the Protocol.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In August 2014, an agreement was reached between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Prinsipe establishing a four-year protocol for 32 fishermen from the European Union for tuna fishing on the shores of West Africa and the shores of St Thomas and Prinsipe.  Under the protocol, St. Thomas and Prinspe will be paid 710,000 euros for the first three years of the agreement, 675,000 euros for the fourth year of the agreement and 325,000 euros to encourage the development of st. Thomas and Prinsipe's fishing sector. The protocol will include financial contributions from fishing owners, which will amount to 55 euros per tonne of catches for the first two years of the agreement, 60 euros per tonne for the third year, or 70 euros per tonne per catch for the fourth year.  I supported the report on the Partnership Agreement between the European Union and St Thomas and Prinsipe, as the implementation of this agreement will open up opportunities for European fishermen in the waters of West Africa and St Thomas and Prinsipe and encourage the development of that country's fishing sector.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour, as did the whole socialist and democrat political group. The European Union fishes everywhere around the world. This agreement is a sign of partnership between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Recommendation because I believe that this will strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the People's Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe on the formulation and implementation of a long-term fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the São Tomé and Príncipe fishing zone in the mutual interest of both parties.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this report. The Fisheries Partnership Agreement, alongside other instruments providing development support, such as the European Development Fund, should foster the genuinely sustainable development of the São Toméan fisheries sector and of related industries and activities, so that more of the added value resulting from the exploitation of São Tomé’s natural resources remains in the country.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe. The aim of this agreement is to promote and strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé e Príncipe, so as to contribute to a genuine sustainable revival of the Sao Tomé e Principe fisheries sector and its related industries and activities.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Ferreira, because I believe that the partnership agreement in the fisheries sector between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is a source of benefit to the entire Community.   The Agreement, in fact, establishes the possibility for the European Union to fish for tuna in West Africa, while at the same time allowing vessels of Community origin to operate in the waters belonging to those territories.   I also believe that the financial criteria it defines are sufficiently admissible and rational.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the understanding that this agreement is important for Sao Tome and Principe and for the Member States of the European Union, although I regret that the European Commission insists on maintaining a philosophy on the drafting of these agreements, which does not contribute to improving the sustainability of resources and does not include, or take into account, the legitimate options and priorities of Mr Tomé Príncipe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I have made an advance of confidence with my positive vote: it is now up to the Commission to support the proposals for improvement mentioned in the report!

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to fish in the waters of that country. The previous protocol, which took effect from 13 May 2011 to 12 May 2014, allowed 40 EU tuna snags to operate: 28 seiners and 12 surface longliners. The financial contribution amounted to EUR 682 500/year, of which around 35 % was to support Santomense sectoral policy. Following the negotiations on the renewal of the Implementing Protocol, a new Protocol was initialled on 19 December 2013, which will be in force for 4 years from 23 May 2014 and will enable fishing activity to 34 EU vessels (28 seine tuna vessels and 6 surface longliners). The annual financial contribution was set at EUR 710 000 in the first three years and EUR 675 000 in the fourth year, of which EUR 325 000 was earmarked for support for Santomense sectoral policy.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — The Fishing Partnership Agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe will benefit the fishing industries of both the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe. The conclusion of the agreement will lead to the development of tools to prevent the over-exploitation of São Toméan fishery resources. EU vessels will also be able to fish in São Toméan waters in a responsible manner. This agreement aims to further the sustainable development of the fisheries sector and of related industries and activities in São Tomé and Príncipe. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The protocol to the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Sao Tomé-et-Principe is a continuation of the various fisheries protocols signed since 1984. I therefore welcome this agreement which will allow THE Union's ships to continue fishing in the waters of the archipelago while guaranteeing financial rewards. These will support the sustainable development of the fishing sector and related industries and activities in Sao Tomé-et-Principe. However, I agree with the rapporteur's position, which calls for improved reliability of information on catches and the state of conservation of fisheries resources and the development of the archipelago's control capabilities.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe, which forms part of the network of tuna-fishing agreements in West Africa and will provide fishing opportunities, as well as a financial contribution and development support, to the São Toméan fisheries sector.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted "for" this text, which I thought was fair and equitable. We are talking about the fishing opportunities and the financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. In force since May 2014 and for a period of four years, this protocol allows 34 vessels from European Union member countries to fish there. In exchange for this authorization, the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe will have to collect 2,805,000 euros over the previously defined 4-year period (an upward revaluation may of course be envisaged if the annual amount of catches exceeds the specified annual reference tonnage).

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of supporting the agreement as it provides continued opportunities for fisheries cooperation with São Tomé, with the addition of more reliable data (on catches and on the conservation status of fishery resources) being made available to the São Toméan authorities.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which authorises the implementation of a new fisheries partnership between the EU and Sao Tomé e Prencipe. This partnership is beneficial for all parties: it allows 34 ships of the European Union to access the tuna resource of the waters of Sao Tomé e Prencipe, in return for the payment of royalties that will be used to develop and structure the local fishing sector.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — We welcome the conclusion of this Protocol, but consider it essential that this agreement be implemented through the use of other specific support instruments, such as the European Development Fund, so as to contribute to a genuine sustainable revival of the Sao Tomé e Principe fisheries sector and its related industries and activities. Our ultimate goal remains to help the country exploit its natural resources. We therefore believe that the European Commission must be more committed to verifying the correct use of aid, to improving the quantity and reliability of catch information and, in general, to the conservation status of fishery resources. It will also be necessary to monitor and strengthen the monitoring capacity of the competent authorities in the exclusive economic zone, as well as to encourage investment in support of the development of infrastructure in this sector.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Public Health and Industrial Policy. Ferreira on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Sao Tomé and Principe on tuna fishing in West Africa and the permission of our fishing vessels to operate there. This agreement can benefit both our vessels, which will be able to continue fishing in those waters, and Sao Tomé and Principe, which will benefit from the financial compensation which will be of particular benefit to the support of their sectoral policies.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this project because the collaboration between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Principe is a long one. This project is useful for the fishing industry, but we still need to ensure that the negative results of previous collaborations will not be replicated in the future.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the agreement. The favourable conditions arising from the agreement for the whole region will give new impetus to trade, fishing and fish processing and to the region.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows a limited number of European tuna fishers to fish in the waters of the island of Sao Tomé-et-Principe, in return for European funding in support of the country's sectoral policy. This type of fisheries agreement is a reasonable way to support the development of African countries while limiting overfishing in the oceans.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because it also allows European Union vessels to fish in the waters of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Príncipe and also supports its fisheries policy. It is important to expand the opportunities of EU market participants.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I welcome the conclusion of this agreement. The new four-year agreement will bring mutual benefits, taking into account the interests of both parties. In particular, European Union fishing vessels will be granted fishing opportunities in São Tomé and Prince waters. In addition, cooperation between countries will be strengthened and the same principles of good regulation of the fisheries sector and sound maritime governance are promoted worldwide. Enhanced cooperation between the two countries will enable the implementation of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible use of fisheries resources. It should be noted that the EU has a great responsibility in ensuring the conservation and sustainable management of international fisheries resources. In this context, the Commission should pay greater attention to controls in order to ensure the effective use of the support. The control mechanisms applied shall be proportionate. They must not violate the sovereignty and legitimate priorities of the country.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe is part of the network of tuna fisheries agreements in West Africa and allows EU vessels to operate in west African waters; whereas in May 2014 a new protocol came into force for four years, allowing fishing activities to be carried out on 34 EU vessels; Given that the EU and São Tomé and Príncipe representations welcomed the conclusion of the new four-year protocol, I am voting in favour of it for these reasons.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The protocol between the European Union and Sao Tomé and Prencipe will allow fishermen from the Member States to travel to the territorial waters of that country. To the extent that fisheries resources are preserved, it is good that boats can expand their business space within a well-defined framework. I therefore vote in favour of this protocol.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the Recommendation on the Proposal for a Council Decision on the Signature, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol that set out fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and St Thomas and Prinsipe. This Recommendation enables the development and application of new fishing opportunities and, with increased attention from the European Commission, could achieve the main purpose of the Protocol, which would constitute the use of fishing opportunities for European Union vessels, while respecting the priorities and sovereignty of St Thomas and Prinsipe. European Union ships should be authorised to explore new fishing opportunities, bearing in mind that the final results, the possibility of earning money and the prospects for the future are explored in more detail. I believe that this Protocol would contribute to stronger cooperation between the European Union and St Thomas and Prinsipe in the field of establishing and developing a sustainable fisheries policy. In the interest of both parties, in accordance with the authorisation to exploit fishing opportunities for EU ships, I support the recommendation to use and apply the best opinions of renowned scientists when developing and researching.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — The new Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement concluded by the European Commission with the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncía in May 2014 builds on the previous protocol, which expired in 2014. The new proposal was signed in order to achieve two main objectives of allowing EU vessels to fish within the limits of the available surplus in São Tomé waters, but also allowing the EU to promote and oversee the real implementation of the more responsible tuna catch policy defined by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. I fully support the deepening of cooperation between the EU and this former Portuguese colony, which is a significant partner for the EU, not least from a geopolitical point of view. The inhumane way of fishing for tuna is a major global problem and the European Union should do its utmost to ensure that the funds it spends under its fisheries policy are always allocated as a result of sustainable fishing. This should also apply to this Protocol, which should ensure more targeted financial intervention, in particular towards strengthening control mechanisms in the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé e Príncipe because it forms part of the type of tuna fishing agreement in West Africa, and it is a renewal with certain amendments to the previous protocol that had produced satisfactory results. As we know, thanks to it, EU vessels can operate in the territorial waters of São Tomé and Príncipe with a large fleet of fishing vessels. The conclusion of the agreement contributes, together with other instruments, to ensuring that there is an increase in development in the fisheries sector and related activities in São Tomé and Príncipe, allowing the sustainable exploitation of its natural resources. I regret, however, that the results achieved so far in the field of sectoral cooperation are poor and I hope that the European Commission will make constructive efforts to verify the principles necessary for the correct use of the aid always given while respecting the sovereignty of São Tomé and Príncipe. I also hope that the proposal to provide Parliament with an annual report on the results of the multiannual sectoral programme on compliance with the obligation to report on catches will be accepted.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — With this vote, the European Parliament voted in favour of the extension of a mechanism allowing tuna fishing in the waters of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe. To the extent that this agreement allows both sustainable resource management and the extension of development agreements in consultation with this Republic, I vote in favour.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is part of the network of tuna fisheries agreements in West Africa. The new protocol was signed on 19 December 2013, following a previous protocol which had been in force from 13 May 2011 until 12 May 2014. It is intended for a period of four years from 23 May 2014 and will allow 34 EU vessels (28 tuna vessels and 6 surface longliners) to engage in fishing. The annual financial contribution was set at EUR 710 000 for the first 3 years and EUR 675 000 for the fourth year, with EUR 325 000 eargoing for sectoral policy support in Sao Tome and Principe. I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this Recommendation because we think it is a balanced Partnership Agreement, as it emphasizes support for the development of the Sao Tome fisheries sector, which has been very limited in the last twenty years. Among the aspects to which special attention is recommended are those related to the reliability of the evaluation of Santo Tomé's fisheries resources, the development of control capacity by local authorities, the obligation to declare catches and the development of infrastructure in the sector. It requires greater commitment on the part of the Commission in verifying the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and options and priorities of Sao Tome. The need to strengthen cooperation in the development of the Santo Tome fisheries sector as a requirement for joint and sustainable exploitation of Sao Tome's fisheries resources is therefore highlighted.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has given its approval to the conclusion of the protocol to the new EU/Sao Tomé-et-Principe fisheries agreement. The previous protocol, which was in force from 13 May 2011 to 12 May 2014, allowed the activity of 40 EU tuna boats: 28 seiner tuna and 12 surface longliners. The financial consideration amounted to 682,500 euros per year, of which more than 35% was intended to support the sectoral policy of Sao Tomé-et-Principe. A new protocol was signed on 19 December 2013 and came into force on 23 May 2014 for a period of four years. It will benefit 34 EU vessels (28 seiner tuna and 6 surface longliners). The annual financial consideration was set at 710,000 euros for the first three years and 675,000 euros in the fourth year, with 325,000 euros earmarked for the sectoral policy of Sao Tomé-et-Principe.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — This Recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the new 4-year Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial consideration provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Principe deserves my vote in favour, as it allows EU vessels to fish in the waters of that country , by means of an annual financial contribution which will allow a signalable amount to be channelled to support santomense sectoral policy. Nevertheless, I would like to point out, like the rapporteur, that it is imperative to adopt a more integrated vision of sectoral cooperation with this country, which will, inter alia, allow greater information to santomense authorities of the catch index, conservation of fisheries resources, increased training of observers and the supervisory capacity of the Santomense EZE, as well as support for the development of fisheries infrastructure so eu to export fishery products to the European Union. , among others.  It is therefore not sufficient to allocate financial considerations. It is imperative that these are aggregated credible sectoral policies that allow the development of the Santomense fishing sector, with respect for sovereignty and legitimate aspirations and objectives of the country in this sector.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because the agreement provides for the possibility for EU tuna vessels and vessels to fish in their waters. It increases the economic compensation compared to the previous agreement but, overall, I consider the possibility of operating in those waters to be a priority.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it seems to us to be a balanced Partnership Agreement, as it emphasizes support for the development of the Sao Tome fisheries sector, which has been very limited in the last twenty years. Among the aspects to which special attention is recommended are those related to the reliability of the evaluation of Santo Tomé's fisheries resources, the development of control capacity by local authorities, the obligation to declare catches and the development of infrastructure in the sector. It requires greater commitment on the part of the Commission in verifying the principles necessary for the proper absorption of aid, respecting the sovereignty and options and priorities of Sao Tome. The need to strengthen cooperation in the development of the Santo Tome fisheries sector as a requirement for joint and sustainable exploitation of Sao Tome's fisheries resources is therefore highlighted.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The report approves the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe. Its objective is to adapt European tuna fishing in Sao Tome and Principe to the scientific recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). The rapporteur has made a request to the Commission and the Council in the text to ensure that Parliament is informed of all stages of implementation and renewal of the Protocol. The democratization of fisheries policy control and its environmental sustainability are necessary conditions to ensure the employment and development of this sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Through the recommendation adopted today, I have decided to support the conclusion of the protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial compensation provided for in the Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé e Príncipe. 28 tuna seiners and 6 surface longliners flying the flag of an EU Member State will be able to fish in Sao Tomé e Principe waters, observing the best available scientific advice and recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT).  The payment of the financial compensation by the European Union will certainly be an important aid to the Republic of São Tomé e Príncipe in order to promote a more responsible exploitation of fishery resources, to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and to strengthen surveillance, control and fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. — Like Mep and rapporteur João Ferreira, I, as shadow rapporteur for S&D, have positively assessed this agreement. Nevertheless, I have to make some considerations which, in essence, I consider opportunities for improvement for future fisheries agreements of the European Union. The agreement lacks references to target species, protected species such as sea turtles, marine mammals and seabirds, and mitigation or control measures for sharks are also not mentioned. One of the biggest threats to sea turtle populations is precisely industrial fisheries. Sao Tome and Principe have until recently used sea turtles in both food and local handicrafts, but for some years now both government authorities and local communities associated with NGOs have been undergoing sea turtle protection programs, including their nesting sites. The European Union must be sympathetic in this environmental protection effort and this should have been shaped by this fisheries agreement. Finally, I would like to point out that it is important for the activity to provide for the inclusion of independent observers whose costs are financially borne by shipowners. This, moreover, should happen in all fisheries agreements.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in support of the conclusion of the new protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe. It will cover a four-year period from 23 May 2014 and provide fishing opportunities for 34 EU vessels. The annual financial contribution was set at EUR 710 000 for the first three years and EUR 675 000 for the fourth year. The main purpose of the Protocol to the Agreement is to grant fishing opportunities to European Union vessels in São Toméan waters. In addition, the Protocol will strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe with a view to establishing a sustainable fisheries policy and sound exploitation of fisheries resources in São Toméan fishing zone, in the interests of both parties.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I have given my consent to the conclusion of the Protocol on fisheries partnership between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Prinsipe, as I support the purpose of the Agreement, which is to give fishing rights to European Union vessels in the waters of St Thomas. The aim of the protocol is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Prinsipe, but also to establish a sustainable fishing policy and sustainable exploitation of fishing resources in these fishing zones, of course in the interests of both parties. In future negotiations, I believe it is important to allow parliament's representatives to participate as observers in the meetings of the Joint Committee. I also call on the Commission to present to parliament and the Council during the last year of application of the Protocol, and before starting negotiations on its extension, a full report on its implementation without excessive restrictions relating to access to the document.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the EU-St Thomas and the Principle Fisheries Partnership Agreement. This agreement generates financial and fishing benefits for the stakeholders of the agreement and thus the European Union as a whole. The new Agreement would apply for a period of four years, would open up a business opportunity for 34 fishing boats from the European Union and should already be a financial contribution of hundreds of thousands of euros in the first three years. The agreement also opens up opportunities to assist in the research and development of fisheries of the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and Princip, as the European Union could financially support the development and control of sustainable harvesting and the preservation of the fish stock. It is known that the information currently available is very modest and insufficient to determine in detail the state of the fish stock in the Democratic Republic of St. Thomas and Princip. The European Union should provide a longer-term fish supply channel and contribute to the development and research of the fish stock of the Democratic Republic of St Thomas and the Principle, implying benefits for all participants of the Agreement.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Agreements should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national interests.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the text on the Council's proposal for a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol setting out the fishing possibilities and the financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tomé and Principe. I regret, however, that there was no debate when the agenda of this session allowed it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I find the extension of the EU-St Thomas-Prinsipe Fisheries Partnership Agreement beneficial for both sides, as it allows EU countries to continue fishing in the waters of St Thomas and Prinsipe and the EU participates in the implementation and development of projects in that country in exchange for fishing. I also find the extension of this agreement useful because the EU can make a profit in tuna hunting in this area despite the increased amount that shipowners have to pay to St. Tommy and Prinsipe. However, I cannot support this agreement because I am concerned about the lack of effective protection of sharks, which are frequent by-catches in the waters of St Thomas and Prinsipe. As the Commission did not take the necessary measures to prevent this and protect sharks, I voted abstaining.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - The Partnership Agreement in the fisheries sector between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Principe is part of the network of agreements on tuna fishing in West Africa and allows EU vessels fishing in its waters. Following negotiations to renew the protocol, which will be valid for four years, will allow fishing to 34 EU vessels (28 tuna seiners and longliners 6). Overall, I am in favor of collaborative arrangements that ensure a "fair play" between the parties. But in this case I agree with the rapporteur about their concerns to ensure sustainable exploitation of resources and enhancing support for training observers and the development of the ability to control Sao Tome and Principe. Deficiencies in this area to date are substantial and the Commission can not ignore it. I think very positive support for infrastructure development in the sector, especially of a reference laboratory to develop the fisheries sector of São Tomé and Príncipe and to get investments to the country. I see necessary to keep Parliament informed annually on the development of this Agreement.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it consists of a renewal of the existing agreement - which expired on 12 May 2014 - in which the environmental interests of fishermen and countries of origin converge.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The report approves the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe. Its objective is to adapt European tuna fishing in Sao Tome and Principe to the scientific recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). The rapporteur has made a request to the Commission and the Council in the text to ensure that Parliament is informed of all stages of implementation and renewal of the Protocol. The democratization of fisheries policy control and its environmental sustainability are necessary conditions to ensure the employment and development of this sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. — The ECR group abstained on my proposal in the vote on the EU-Sao Tomé and Príncipe fisheries partnership agreement. Voting in favour of that agreement was too far-off. Unfortunately, although this relatively small agreement contains positive elements, including more extensive support for local fisheries, there is unfortunately no important aspect. The agreement does not include any agreements on the protection of sharks, whereas by-catch of sharks is a major problem in these waters.  I am disappointed that this is not sufficiently recognised by the European Commission. It is a missed opportunity that no protection measures have been agreed in the agreement to reduce bycatch of sharks. I hope that the European Commission will keep an eye on this issue in the implementation of this agreement and ensure that the broader international agreements on by-catch of sharks in tuna fishing are respected. Also in the waters at the island group Sao Tomé and Principe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This agreement is important for Sao Tome and Principe and for the Member States of the European Union.  However, this does not erase the overall negative balance of what has been left behind. Nor erases the need for profound change. There is a need to improve the quantity and reliability of catch information and, in general, on the conservation status of fisheries resources. More training actions are needed for observers and more support for the development of control capacity by Sao Tome and Principe. We also believe that more and better sectoral cooperation is justified, always with respect for the sovereignty and legitimate options and priorities of São Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — I have voted in favour of this proposal. In general, such an agreement is to be supported. However, the Commission is now called upon to actively support the proposals for improvement mentioned in the report. In particular, the information on the general conservation status of the captive species must be sound in order to continue such an agreement in the future.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The first fisheries agreement concluded between the EEC and Sao Tome and Principe was concluded in 1984. Since then, eight protocols have been implemented, two of which have under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. However, the results achieved so far in the field of sectoral cooperation are very scarce. This is a reality that is urgently changing. This agreement, in conjunction with other development support instruments such as the European Development Fund, should promote effective sustainable development of the Santomense fisheries sector, as well as related industries and activities, increasing the added value in the country as a result of the exploitation of its natural resources. The European Commission must take the necessary measures – including the possible revision and increase of the sector support agreement component – to ensure an effective reversal of the path taken over the past twenty years.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — This report concerns the agreement signed between the Republic of the Seychelles and the territory of Mayotte, which acceded to the status of outermost region on 1 January 2014. In doing so, fishing resources in Mayotte's exclusive economic zone became under EU competence, forcing the adapting of old fisheries contracts to the rules of the common fisheries policy. Due to the proximity between the Seychelles and Mayotte, a limited number of Seychelles boats had traditionally fished in the waters of Mayotte. The agreement allows this practice to continue, in accordance with European fishing rules. As a result, I voted in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — This agreement will provide a legal framework for a historical habit of Seychelles vessels, all in accordance with the common fisheries policy. So I voted in favour. Its implementation will allow Seychelles fishing vessels to access Mayotte's waters and biological resources. In return, shipowners will pay royalties that will benefit Mayotte as part of the financing of its port infrastructure.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The island of Mayotte has recently become a French department and as such, it is necessary to undertake a regularization of relations with France's neighbours in that region, in this case, the Republic of Seychelles, through clearer procedures of suspension and surveillance. It is also a question of maintaining fisheries activities essential to the economies of both territories. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — In essence, this Agreement allows the European Union to pay money to fish the waters of a much poorer country.  This seems to me to be unjust and exploitative.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because it is beneficial to the economic development of Mayotte and Seychelles and it respects the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy and the CTOI on the preservation of the resource.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to support the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles on the operational possibilities for fishing vessels in Mayotte waters. The agreement shall cover the operational possibilities of vessels flying the flag of Seychelles and the exploitation of marine biological resources in Mayotte waters. This Agreement is special because vessels flying the flag of a third country are authorised to fish in European waters. In order to obtain a fishing permit that could be retained on board, shipowners will pay taxes directly to the European Union. These fees will be collected by France and redistributed to Mayotte in order to effectively meet the sectorary needs of the island in terms of port infrastructure, landings, controls and placing products on the market. I support the conclusion of this agreement because it will benefit both parties, as well as the economic development of Mayotte and Seychelles.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — This "access" agreement between the EU and the Republic of Seychelles will grant permission to third country-flagged vessels to fish in European waters. This agreement benefits the economic development of Mayotte and Seychelles and respects the rules of the common fisheries policy and the CTOI on the preservation of the resource.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — This agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles should allow Seychelles-flagged fishing vessels to access Mayotte's waters and marine biological resources under EU jurisdiction.  Since Mayotte became an ultra-peripheral region of the EU in 2014, its exclusive economic zone (EEZ) has been part of the EU's waters, reflecting a loss of sovereignty for France of the use of the zone. This agreement nevertheless allows a limited number of Seychelles-flagged vessels, which have a historical habit of fishing in the waters of Mayotte, to continue their activities and I therefore voted for the text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I abstained from voting on this recommendation, which does not deal clearly and articulately enough with the implications of the agreement.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the proposal. This agreement is different in that it is a question of the EU giving fishing rights to another country. However, this is problematic. Local fishermen from Mayotte, for example, have not been included in the negotiations, and even the committee's rapporteur is critical of this and of the fact that only 24 nautical miles are reserved for local fisheries. Mayotte should also be given the opportunity to develop its own sustainable fishing industry. Today, for example, there is a lack of infrastructure to deal with big fishing, which means that the local community is unlikely to benefit from this agreement. Although France is invited to use the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund to create an appropriate administrative framework, monitoring activities, physical infrastructure and sufficient capacity to meet common fisheries policy requirements, none of these conditions are met at this time. I believe that this must be put in place before a fisheries agreement is concluded. Seychelles are also known to allow other countries to fish under their flag. So I voted 'no'.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Since May 2003, there has been an EU-Seychelles Fisheries Agreement. It is the EU's most important agreement in the Indian Ocean. An 'access agreement' between the two parties is now envisaged so that Seychelles vessels can continue fishing in Mayotte, a French outermost region for which their territorial development is also pursued. The agreement lasts for six years and provides that it is France, on behalf of the EU, that manages the agreement and economic counterparties. It has no financial impact on the EU. It provides for a joint monitoring committee and places particular emphasis on the issue of respect for human rights.  The European fisheries sector has expressed its interest in the agreement. It seems like a balanced agreement, as far as my vote has been in favour, in accordance with the recommendation of the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament and considering that the rapporteur of Parliament has nuanced in his report that it is the local population of Mayotte who receives the full benefits of the agreement and, of course, , that the management of funds be done in a transparent and effective manner.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this recommendation in support of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles on the operational possibilities for fishing vessels in Mayotte waters. This agreement concerns the operational possibilities of vessels flying the flag of Seychelles and the exploitation of marine biological resources in Mayotte waters. This agreement was negotiated between the Republic of Seychelles and the European Union (on behalf of Mayotte) in order to allow a number of vessels flying the flag of Seychelles which historically fish in Mayotte waters to continue their fishing activities in the exclusive economic area of Mayotte, in accordance with the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy. This Feasibility Agreement is the first of its kind, and is special because vessels flying the flag of a third country are authorised to fish in European waters. In order to obtain a fishing permit that could be retained on board, shipowners pay taxes directly to the European Union. These fees are collected by France and redistributed to Mayotte in order to effectively meet the sectorary needs of the island in terms of port infrastructure, landings, controls and placing products on the market.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — Traditionally, Seychelles-flagged ships fish in the waters of Mayotte. This French territory became an ultra-peripheral region of the EU at the beginning of the year and the exclusive economic zone of Mayotte has since been communitised under the Common Fisheries Policy. Following the change in status, an agreement was negotiated to allow a limited number of Seychelles vessels to fish in the exclusive economic zone. An agreement provides for the payment by each ship of a financial consideration. These royalties will be collected by France and redistributed to Mayotte. These are expected to be devoted, in particular, to port infrastructure and to the control and marketing of products, as part of the Sustainable Tuna Fishing Partnership Agreement, which came into force on 10 May 2003 between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles. I therefore voted in favour of adopting Alain Cadec's report which proposes to approve the agreement.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the EU-Seychelles agreement because I consider access for fishing vessels to the waters of Mayotte to be important.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — A Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement (APPD) governs fisheries relations between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles. It should be remembered that according to Article 3 of the TFUE, the conservation of fisheries resources is an exclusive competence of the Union, a competence whose legitimacy we formally challenge, since it constitutes an indispensable element of France's maritime territorial sovereignty. However, in the best interests of Mayotte's economic development and in particular the fishing sector, I support this agreement because the royalties paid by the Seychelles shipowners will be directly redistributed to Mayotte. Indeed, the mahorese fishing is still very artisanal and supports nearly 5,000 people. Rather than opening up fishing areas to large industrial tuna, it is preferable to promote cooperation in the archipelago and to use royalties wisely to enable Mahorese fishermen to improve their fishing equipment while preserving their artisanal know-how. That is why I voted in favour of the draft resolution approving the conclusion of that agreement.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that this agreement is nothing more than a continuation of the protocol already concluded by the two parties in 2013 for a specified period and which has now ceased to be valid.          Currently, vessels flying the flag of the State of Seychelles can only fish in Mayotte waters on the basis of an agreement between the Prefect of Mayotte and vessels flying the flag of Seychelles owners.     That is why the agreement will now allow ships from the State of Seychelles to continue to have access to Mayotte waters as well as marine biological resources under the jurisdiction of the European Union.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I abstained. The stakes for the EU are negligible.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — My report on the agreement allowing Seychellois ships to access part of the exclusive Economic Zone of Mayotte was adopted by a large majority by the European Parliament. This agreement is a strong signal for Mayotte, which has become the 101st French department. The fees paid by shipowners will be redistributed for the development of fishing and aquaculture in Mayotte, in particular with regard to port infrastructure. I have been assured by the French government that this money will be redistributed entirely to the fishing industry. The other part of the economic zone remains reserved for local fishing in order to preserve the mahorese artisanal fishing, thus French.  This agreement allows for sustainable fishing because it respects the rules on the proper management and preservation of the tuna resource as well as the rules of the common fisheries policy. In the context of the fight against illegal undeclared and unreged fishing, this agreement strengthens the credibility of the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles concerning the access of vessels flying the flag of seychelles to the waters and marine biological resources of Mayotte. This agreement is unique, authorising a third country for the first time to fish for tuna in European waters.  I voted in favour of this agreement because it is beneficial to both parties, bringing benefits to both the economic development of Mayotte and that of the Seychelles and respecting the rules of the common fisheries policy. Furthermore, given the migratory nature of tuna and the existing agreement allowing EU vessels to fish in Seychelles' waters, I consider this agreement to be important as it goes in the direction of further strengthening the status of seychelles as the EU's most important partner in that region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The Seychelles is the European Union's most important partner in the Indian Ocean. This Agreement allows Seychelles vessels to fish in the exclusive economic zone of Mayotte (France).

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this agreement, which should allow Seychelles fishing vessels to access the waters and biological resources of Mayotte. It is in fact a question of giving a legal framework to a historical habit of Seychelles ships, all in respect of the CFP. Valuing the habits and traditions of peoples, when they are respectful of the common good, should always be the main work of the legislator.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this agreement, which I believe is a virtuous example of development cooperation. Studying the cards reminded me of the old maxim that in order to satisfy a man's hunger you have to give him a fish, but if you want to feed it you have to teach him how to fish. Here: the EU allows less developed countries to have job opportunities aimed above all at the local population and conditioned by compliance with European standards and values. Congratulations to my colleagues who negotiated the agreement.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the draft decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles because, after the territory of Mayotte has acquired the status of an outermost region of the European Union, the agreement reached between the European Commission and the Seychelles, our main partner in sustainable tuna fishing in the Indian Ocean, is beneficial to both parties. In fact, given the undoubted economic benefits and the preservation of trade relations between the Seychelles and the territory of Meyotte pre-existing at the latter's entry into the EEZ, the agreement contains important safeguard clauses protecting the interests of the parties in the event of a serious and manifest breach of the undertakings entered into and provides for an interim review clause that will allow the parties to assess the effectiveness of the medium-term agreement.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report that recommends giving consent to the conclusion of the agreement between the Republic of the Seychelles and the European Union (for Mayotte) that allows a limited number of Seychelles-flagged vessels that have a tradition of fishing in Mayotte’s waters to continue to fish in Mayotte’s Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) with due regard for the rules of the common fisheries policy. The agreement benefits both parties as it is beneficial for the economic development of Mayotte and the Seychelles and it complies with the rules of the common fisheries policy and the Indian Ocean Tuan Commission (IOTC) as regards preservation of resources.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — This Agreement allows vessels flying the flag of seychelles to fish for highly migratory species in accordance with the rules of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (CTOI). I voted in favour of this agreement, as it benefits both parties, benefits the economic development of Mayotte and seychelles and respects the rules of the common fisheries policy and the CTOI on the conservation of resources.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — This report concerns the agreement signed between the Republic of the Seychelles and the territory of Mayotte, which acceded to the status of outermost region on 1 January 2014. In doing so, fishing resources in Mayotte's exclusive economic zone became under EU competence, forcing the adapting of old fisheries contracts to the rules of the common fisheries policy. Due to the proximity between the Seychelles and Mayotte, a limited number of Seychelles boats had traditionally fished in the waters of Mayotte. The agreement allows this practice to continue, in accordance with European fishing rules. As a result, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I support this report as it deals with the request of the Seychelles for an access agreement for Seychelles-flagged vessels to the waters of Mayotte, which has just become an outermost region of the EU. This access agreement is the first of its kind in granting third-country-flagged vessels the right to fish in European waters. As a result, the vessel owners pay the fees directly to the EU in order to obtain a fishing authorisation on board. The fees are collected by France on behalf of the EU and redistributed in Mayotte so as to respond effectively to Mayotte’s sectoral needs. The agreement also contains a clause suspending the agreement in the event of a clear violation of human rights, democratic principles, the rule of law and good governance.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This report proposes the ratification of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles granting access to access to part of the exclusive economic zone of Mayotte under the jurisdiction of the European Union. This is a balanced report, since in exchange for access to the waters of Mahor, The Seychelles ships pay royalties which will be paid in full for the development of fishing and aquaculture in Mayotte, including port infrastructure. In addition, the rest of the economic zone is preserved as it is reserved for artisanal fishing in Mahorese and for the development of the infrastructure of the Mahorese fishery. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Since 31 March 2011, the Department of Mayotte has officially become the 100th department of France and its fifth overseas department. It has also become an ultra-peripheral region throughout the European Union and, through this balanced text, it is now important to conclude an agreement between the European Union and Seychelles on access to Seychelles fishing vessels in the waters and marine biological resources of Mayotte. In return, shipowners will have to pay royalties, a source of income that is particularly necessary for this department, which is in the grip of a difficult economic and social situation, to have the means to comply with the rules of the common fisheries policy.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — On 1 January 2014, the territory of Mayotte acquired the status of an outermost region of the European Union and as a result mayotte's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) has become an integral part of Union waters. I voted in favour of the agreement between the Republic of Seychelles and the European Union because it will allow a limited number of vessels flying the Seychelles flag to fish in the Mayotte EEZ for a period of six years, in compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy. The owners of Seychelles vessels, in exchange for fishing authorisation, will pay royalties to be collected by France on behalf of the European Union and redistributed to Mayotte, which will be used to develop the island's port infrastructure. The agreement is of strategic importance because it allows us to maintain the privileged relations that the European Union has with the Republic of Seychelles, our most important partner in that region.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — Since 1 January 2014, Mayotte, the 101st French department, is an ultra-peripheral region (RUP) that is an integral part of the European Union. As such, its exclusive economic zone, the maritime area over which a coastal state exercises sovereign rights in the exploration and use of resources, is now communitized under the Common Fisheries Policy.  With the change in status, an agreement between the Republic of Seychelles and the European Union was to be negotiated to allow a limited number of Seychelles-flagged vessels with a very long history of fishing in the waters of Mayotte to continue fishing in the Mahorese EEZ in accordance with the rules of the common fisheries policy. This agreement will preserve the European Union's privileged relations with the Republic of Seychelles.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. — This agreement allows Seychelles-flagged vessels to continue their activities in the waters and marine biological resources of Mayotte, despite the fact that Mayotte has become a French region that is part of Europe as of 1 January 2014. It is important, in my view, to point out that this is the first tuna agreement whereby the European Union allows ships from a non-EU country to fish in its waters on the payment of taxes. The agreement allows eight tuna seiners to operate in The waters of Mayotte under EU jurisdiction for the next six years in exchange for the payment of a licence and fishing right. I believe that this agreement will strengthen cooperation between the EU and Seychelles by introducing high quality fisheries in terms of sustainability, transparency, control, and monitoring of the respective fleets. This agreement also benefits both sides, it benefits the economic development of Mayotte and Seychelles and it respects the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy and the CTOI on the preservation of the resource.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — Mayotte has recently become a French department and, as such, it is necessary to undertake a regularization of relations with France's neighbours in that region, in this case, the Republic of Seychelles, through clearer procedures of suspension and supervision. It is also a question of maintaining fisheries activities that are essential to the economies of both territories, which is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Recommendation which endorses the Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Seychelles, as it benefits both sides, is positive for the economic development of Mayotte and seychelles, and respects the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy and the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (CAOI) on resource protection. This Agreement will allow the continuation of a traditional economic activity in that region, taking into account criteria of good management and protection of resources. It will also promote the local economy and infrastructure development of the fishing sector on the island of Mayotte and the Republic of Seychelles and strengthen good relations between the latter and the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We are voting in favour because this agreement strengthens fisheries while preserving water resources.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Seychelles in the fisheries sector are governed by a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement. This is the union's most important agreement in the Indian Ocean region, making Seychelles its main partner in that area. This Agreement consists of an access agreement on access for fishing vessels flying the Seychelles flag to the waters and biological resources of Mayote. Before the change in the status of Mayot, due to the geographical proximity between Mayote and the Seychelles, relations between European fishing vessels and Seichelenses, on the one hand, and Mayote, on the other, were governed by a private agreement.  This access agreement is the first of its kind and is exceptional in that it authorises vessels flying the flag of a third country to fish in European territorial waters. The agreement provides that eight tuna vessels and two refuelling vessels flying the Seychelles flag may access the area between 24 and 100 miles over a renewable period of six years.
