text: In writing. — The Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement is an important European Union policy to strengthen the European Union's ties with the entire Mediterranean. With this in mind, the agreement allows Bulgaria and Romania to be integrated following their accession to the European Union. So I'm voting for it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The Euro-Mediterranean partnership between the EU and the southern Mediterranean countries began in 1995 with the Barcelona process. Between 1998 and 2005, the EU concluded Euro-Mediterranean association agreements with seven countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, including Tunisia (Decision 98/238/EC on the conclusion of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tunisia, of the other). In essence, such agreements aim to promote regular dialogue on political and security matters; economic, trade and financial cooperation (progressive liberalisation of trade, sustainable development of regions and investment) and social, cultural and education cooperation between the parties. With Bulgaria and Romania acceding to the EU with effect from 1 January 2007, it was necessary to ensure the full participation of these two Member States in bilateral relations with Tunisia. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Tunisia, in order to take account of bulgaria and Romania's accession to the EU.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which gives the green light to the conclusion of an additional protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between Tunisia and the European Union. Signed in 1998, this agreement is regularly updated to reflect the accession of new Member States to the European Union. In this case, it was enlargement to Bulgaria and Romania. Through this association agreement, Tunisia and the European Union maintain a regular dialogue on policy and security, and cooperate on economic, commercial, financial, social, cultural and educational issues. I support such association agreements which contribute to the spread of the fundamental principles of the European Union and encourage cooperation and the development of peaceful relations with the neighbouring countries.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on Euromed. While the Protocol to be adopted is a formal procedure without further practical consequences, we wanted to express our disagreement with the EU's policy towards Tunisia. For example, with the loan agreed last year, which was granted with conditions similar to those usually put by the IMF, and with the mobility agreement, which opens the way to admission agreements that delight the management of migration flows in the African country.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The accession of new Member States of the European Union to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement must be decided through a protocol to this agreement. the protocol is concluded by the Council, on behalf of the Member States, within a simplified procedure, and by the third country concerned, in this case Tunisia. The European Parliament was therefore asked to approve it, which I did by voting for this report (and this does not change the nature of the agreement itself).

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement signed in the 1990s aimed to establish an association between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia, on the other, by replacing the cooperation agreement and the ECSC products agreement signed in 1976. In 2012, the Protocol inherent in the above-mentioned agreement was signed with the aim of taking into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. To that end, this recommendation on the draft Council decision was in favour of me, not only because it is a natural legislative derivation resulting from the applicability of the Treaties, but also because it deals with an agreement which bears witness to the strengthening of Euro-Mediterranean policy, based on principles such as partnership and reciprocity.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it because this protocol will keep the current trade agreement between Tunisia and the European Union unchanged.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We abstained in the vote on Euromed. While the Protocol to be adopted is a formal procedure without further practical consequences, we wanted to express our disagreement with the EU's policy towards Tunisia. For example, with the loan agreed last year, which was granted with conditions similar to those usually put by the IMF, and with the mobility agreement, which opens the way to admission agreements that delight the management of migration flows in the African country.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The EU Association Treaties contain, in Article 2 therein, a clause which conditions their validity on respect for human rights. This condition is usually violated: in the case of Tunisia, from its same negotiations with ben Ali's regime. This demonstrates once again the hypocritical nature of European foreign policy, which uses this article to legitimize or withdraw its support for the signatory governments. By contrast, the economic objectives of these treaties are very clear: to deepen the liberalization and economic dependence of EU-associated States, for the benefit of European capital. This report is presented as a technical formality extending the existing Association Treaty between the EU and Tunisia to Bulgaria and Romania. A vote against would mean new discrimination with regard to the status of the other Member States. However, I cannot vote favourably on a report confirming the current Association Treaty between the EU and Tunisia. For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in support of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States and Tunisia, to take account of the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. The most important aspects of the protocol are the provisions for the accession of the new Member States to the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement, and the inclusion of the new official languages of the EU, to take account of the enlargement of the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the Consent of the European Parliament with the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia, on the other, which would take into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. Namely, upon the accession of the new Member States to the European Union, there are new circumstances that need to be aligned with the existing ones, and I therefore supported this co-compliance of the European Parliament.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The European Union is committed to its role in building stronger ties and relations with neighbouring countries. A better relationship between countries is built on political and economic dialogue that promotes mutual understanding and the creation of common value. The conclusion of the Euro-Mediterranean Association agreement with Tunisia is a step forward in promoting regional cooperation between Mediterranean countries, thereby fostering economic, social, cultural and political development. Furthermore, Tunisia is the first country in the south of the Mediterranean to sign an association agreement with Europe in 1995. Since then, the determinant of the Tunisian Government has been to satisfy all relevant proposals, especially those for the liberalisation of trade made by the European Union. Moreover, Tunisia is an excellent example of how mutual assistance and dialogue can create an effective path towards sustainable and inclusive growth and development. Tunisia's advantage and strong political will should set an example for other countries in the region, leading to greater prosperity and prosperity.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I strongly agree with the proposal, as it can help to facilitate freer trade between EU countries and Euro-Mediterranean countries in the future. The breaking of trade barriers between countries leads to greater prosperity and freedom for all parties involved. Moreover, given that more than eight years have passed since Romania and Bulgaria joined the EU, it is long overdue for this agreement to be concluded.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Financial assistance to third countries through the conclusion of trade with them primarily serves the interests of economically powerful States without the corresponding economic benefits for the weaker economic countries.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union and its Member States, of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Tunisian Republic, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the decision to conclude the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the European Community and Tunisia, which would take into account the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union, which entered into force on 1 January 2007, as well as the decision to forward the position on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Institutions of the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia. I consider euro-Mediterranean agreements important because they primarily envisage the establishment of a free trade zone, contribute to the development of political dialogue between countries that depend on the European market, and promote closer regional and economic cooperation in a multitude of sectors. In this case, I would particularly highlight the possibility of implementing measures and operational programmes with regard to trade liberalisation for agricultural and industrial products.  Finally, I believe that the importance of the Protocol is reflected in the establishment of the Euro-Mediterranean Area of Peace and Stability, which is based on the basic principles of respect for human rights and democracy, infrastructure development, financial assistance provision and the emphasis on cooperation and understanding between cultures of free societies.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — Anything to improve relations, coordination and cooperation in the Euro-Mediterranean arc can only be a positive thing for all parties, therefore I am in favour of this draft resolution, which I am sure will not only provide an economic but also a cultural return .

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The EU Association Treaties contain, in Article 2 therein, a clause which conditions their validity on respect for human rights. This condition is usually violated: in the case of Tunisia, from its same negotiations with ben Ali's regime. This demonstrates once again the hypocritical nature of European foreign policy, which uses this article to legitimize or withdraw its support for the signatory governments. By contrast, the economic objectives of these treaties are very clear: to deepen the liberalization and economic dependence of EU-associated States, for the benefit of European capital. This report is presented as a technical formality extending the existing Association Treaty between the EU and Tunisia to Bulgaria and Romania. A vote against would mean new discrimination with regard to the status of the other Member States. However, I cannot vote favourably on a report confirming the current Association Treaty between the EU and Tunisia.  For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. — The adoption of this Protocol by the European Parliament ensures that this Association Agreement creates a framework between the signatories that lays down the conditions for the freer movement of goods, services and capital. I can fully remember this. It is also important for the European Parliament to approve these types of agreements so that the European Union speaks with one voice.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — In 1995, Tunisia was the first country in the Mediterranean basin to sign an association agreement with the European Union. This agreement, concluded at the time with dictator Ben Ali, provided for political, cultural, economic and social cooperation. He also announced the launch of negotiations on a free trade agreement.  Today, it is a purely technical protocol to take into account the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU in 2007. Since then, the Tunisian revolution has gone through this. This protocol could therefore have been an opportunity for the EU and its Member States to take into account the stakes of the democratic transition in that country and the urgency of the economic and social situation.  But this is not the case since the EU chooses instead to pursue its policies which aggravate the debt, condition financial aid to ever more liberalism and refuse, beyond words, any mobility agreement. This technical agreement is not the place to fight this battle. I have therefore chosen to abstain in support of the only principle of EU-Tunisia relations.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This protocol is departing from the treaties. It considers the draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia on the other, and takes into account the accession of the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to the European Union. We have nothing to owe because the rights of the peoples to their independence and sovereignty are respected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The accession of Romania and Bulgaria to the EU requires the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement to extend to these two countries the scope of the creation of a so-called free trade area. The conclusion of this Protocol is not, however, a neutral act, bearing in view of the scope, increasing the territory and population concerned. It is an agreement that virtually destroys a country's ability, in this case Tunisia, to take sovereign management measures of its economy, allowing large economic groups on both sides freedom of establishment without added costs, benefiting them to the detriment of SMEs, small and medium-sized farmers and family farming and small-scale fishing. Its effects on increased competition and the pressure exerted on workers to reduce wages, lower export costs, lower prices to the final consumer are well known to destroy local production, once again to increase them when it detains the hegemony of production and/or trade, without benefit to quality and food security and generating an even greater destruction of the environment.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The vote calls for consultation with the EESC on the INI report 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Taking stock and moving towards sustainable mobility'. The participation of social actors in the legislative process is essential and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The European Economic and Social Committee is an inefficient institution and is an unnecessary item of expenditure for the European Union. I am opposed to the procedures that maintain this budgetary burden. I have chosen to vote, therefore, against the opening of this consultation.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I support this request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on the 2011 White Paper on Transport: an overview of sustainable mobility and progress in implementation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — This report will open the door to a revision of the Transport White Paper, which will focus on sustainable mobility. It seems to me essential that mobility in our cities can be reviewed so that it is more efficient and less polluting.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — I have spoken against this point regarding a request for consultation by the European Economic and Social Committee on the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport policy, since I question the legitimacy of the EESC. Moreover, Marine Le Pen and 5 other colleagues of our European coordination tabled a proposal for a European resolution on 17 December to abolish the European Economic and Social Committee considering that much of these activities do not correspond to the fundamental mission of this institution and that some of the work is already done in Parliament and could be achieved through direct contacts between the European institutions and representatives of civil society. , employers or workers.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this text. The European Parliament already has sufficient expertise, resources and instruments to be able to fully analyse the level of implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee, whose legitimacy, usefulness and cost to the European taxpayer to maintain such bodies I question.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Economic and Social Committee is a veritable gas plant which I dispute the legitimacy of. Moreover, I supported the motion for a resolution (B8-0400/2014) tabled by Marine Le Pen, Matteo Salvini, Marcel de Graaff, Harald Vilimsky and Gerolf Annemans, calling for the outright abolition of the European Economic and Social Council and Article 13, paragraph 4, of the Treaty on European Union. Faced with a serious payments crisis, the European Union must implement a genuine plan of budgetary savings, starting by abolishing institutions that serve absolutely no purpose, other than to appoint technocrats disconnected from reality. That is why I voted against the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Consultation of the Economic and Social Committee is a step forward in stabilising the European strategy towards more sustainable mobility so as to ensure compliance with the Union's obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We are happy to support progress in this direction.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — I welcomed the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee on the White Paper on transport. I believe that it is important to involve stakeholders more in European decisions, both to bring Europe closer to its citizens and to take decisions that are more legitimised. On the contrary, I would also like to see greater transparency on the part of the European Economic and Social Committee in the future, so that citizens can recognise it as a valid interlocutor in the European legislative process.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The European Commission's White Paper on transport presents the EU's roadmap towards a single European area with regard to competitiveness and sustainability. The White Paper published in 2011 sets ten targets for achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 60%. It has aspects that can be shared, including the gradual abandonment of cars powered by traditional fuels until they are completely eliminated, the use of means of transport with less environmental impact, and improved safety for passengers. At the same time, however, there are negative aspects such as ten-t networks and the use of major transnational works and corridors. It was decided to prepare an own-initiative report to assess the implementation of the Transport White Paper with regard to detection and pathways to sustainable mobility. I voted in favour of calling for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on this matter. Under Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, Parliament may request that the European Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general matters or on specific points, as in this case.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The vote calls for consultation with the EESC on the INI report 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Taking stock and moving towards sustainable mobility'. The participation of social actors in the legislative process is essential and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament is preparing an initiative report on the implementation of the Transport Policy White Paper, published by the European Commission in 2011. This initiative report aims to assess the extent to which the actions announced in 2011 have been implemented and to identify the next steps to be taken, particularly with regard to sustainable mobility. The European Parliament, under Article 137 of its internal regulation, is asking the European Economic and Social Committee to issue an opinion on this report. Concerned about the constant dialogue with civil society and European economic and social actors, I voted in favour of this consultation, which will enrich the content of the initiative report prepared by the parliamentary committee "Transport and Tourism".

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. — On 28 March 2011, the European Commission published its white paper entitled 'Roadmap for a Single European Transport Area - Towards a Competitive and Resource-Efficient Transport System'. As part of an initiative report on the implementation of this white paper, I voted in favour of consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC), the European Union body that allows civil society organisations to express their views at European level. The EESC consultation will contribute to enriching the thinking on European transport policy.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The European Economic and Social Committee is an inefficient institution and is an unnecessary item of expenditure for the European Union. I am opposed to the procedures that maintain this budgetary burden. I have chosen to vote, therefore, against the opening of this consultation.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this request to the European Economic and Social Committee on the report assessing the implementation, so far, of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: the EU Strategic Document setting out the main lines in transport policy. It is a question of taking stock and knowing the degree of achievement of the objectives set out in a document that promotes the development of a single transport space that addresses the different challenges that arise for the future: efficiency, sustainability, infrastructures, etc., which are objectives framed in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This request, provided for in Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure, allows committees to request that the European Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. The consultation follows the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: balance sheet and path towards sustainable mobility, which pushed the transport sector on the path of market liberalisation, building the European transport market, leading to privatisation of public transport companies and resulting in situations of social dumping, deteriorating quality of services and the concentration of the sector in monopolies and oligopolies , problems which Parliament itself identified in December 2011 as consequences to be avoided. At that time, at the time of the vote, we warned that such a path would not bring either the improvement of the quality of service, nor better prices, nor more jobs, on the contrary, the registration is of damage to users, workers and national economies and the promises of more employment is in plain sight. We voted in favour of consulting the European Economic and Social Committee on the matter, however with the concern that it will no longer be an instrument for legitimising the exploitation of workers and deepening neoliberal policies.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — It is the duty of the British Government and the British Department for Transport to write our own legislation, and it is not for the EU to meddle.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this request to the European Economic and Social Committee on the report assessing the implementation, so far, of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: the EU Strategic Document setting out the main lines in transport policy. It is a question of taking stock and knowing the degree of achievement of the objectives set out in a document that promotes the development of a single transport space that addresses the different challenges that arise for the future: efficiency, sustainability, infrastructures, etc., which are objectives framed in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour on the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: taking stock and way forward towards sustainable mobility’ because I think that consultation with the Economic and Social Committee with be useful for Parliament’s work on this issue.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this request to the European Economic and Social Committee on the report assessing the implementation, so far, of the 2011 Transport White Paper: the EU strategic document setting out the main lines in transport policy. It is a question of taking stock and knowing the degree of achievement of the objectives set out in a document that promotes the development of a single transport space that addresses the different challenges that arise for the future: efficiency, sustainability, infrastructures, etc., which are objectives framed in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted to adopt a consultation request with the European Economic and Social Committee on 'Implementing the 2011 Transport White Papers: analysis and the way forward towards sustainable mobility' due to the need to produce Parliament's report. Since the application is based on Article 137 TSO, The Rules of Procedure, on the proposal of the rapporteur himself, and since I believe that in this regard the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee can certainly contribute to the quality of the report itself, I am of the opinion that there are no obstacles to the adoption of this requirement.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the request for consultation on the European Economic and Social Committee on an initiative report by the European Parliament on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport Policy. Parliament has the opportunity to ask the EESC to give its opinion on Parliament's initiative reports, in order to give continuity to its political position. I welcome the positive result of the vote.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the initiative report presented in the Parliamentary Committee on Transport entitled "Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport Policy: The Point and The Way forward for Sustainable Mobility". Requests for consultation by the European Economic and Social Committee are governed by Article 137 of the European Parliament's internal regulation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the request to have a consultation in order to underline how important sustainable mobility is in relation to jobs, growth and tackling climate change in Europe.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. — Transport policy is not only an issue which must be addressed at European or national level – it is also an important topic for the regions of Europe. Furthermore it has an impact on the economy of our Union. Therefore, I voted in favour of consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The vote calls for consultation with the EESC on the INI report 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Taking stock and moving towards sustainable mobility'. The participation of social actors in the legislative process is essential and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The European Commission presented a 2050 transport development strategy in the 2011 Transport White Paper. The aim of this strategy is to increase the competitiveness of the transport system in the European Union, which will increase mobility, eliminate bottlenecks in key transport routes, reduce dependence on fossil speeches and reduce CO2 emissions by 60 percent by 2050.  To succeed in achieving these objectives, the European Commission has set targets that must be achieved by 2050: - increase by 40 percent the use of fuels emitting less CO2.  - increase by 50 percent the use of trains in long-distance transport instead of cars - gradual replacement of cars running on conventional fuels with cars using alternative fuels or drive.  I supported the report on the application with the European Economic and Social Committee on the 'Implementation of the 2011 Transport White Deal'. In my view, the road plan for transport development must also include social partners and civil society in order to develop roads in the European Union as efficiently as possible and reduce the burden on important European roads.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour because I consider it particularly important to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport, particularly in relation to the assessment and the future path towards sustainable mobility in this area.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I supported this request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: taking stock and way forward towards sustainable mobility’.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I naturally supported the right of the CRP to request the hearing.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree with the recommendation of the Committee on Transport to return to the Commission and return to the EP for discussion in the near future.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the request for Parliament to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: taking stock and way forward towards sustainable mobility’.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which provides for the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) on the initiative report entitled "Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Balance Sheet and Way forward for Sustainable Mobility". Representatives of employers' associations, employees and other European interest groups will be able to express themselves freely and transparently on the future of European transport policy. This is a major and cross-cutting issue that combines employment issues with environmental requirements.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The Economic and Social Committee is one of those institutions that are of little use and cost a fortune, whether at the regional, national or European level. I therefore voted against the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2050 White Play on the Future of Transport, in order to achieve the objectives as quickly as possible through consultations with civil society experts and representatives. A number of challenges the EU has set out are aimed at removing administrative barriers and fostering innovation to create a single European transport area, to make the mobility of people, goods and services faster and more efficient.  In today's circumstances of increased traffic volumes and excessive environmental pollution, priority objectives of diverting road freight to rail or water transport, reducing the EU's dependence on oil imports and carbon dioxide emissions, and linking a fragmented network of roads to the single TRANS-European TRANSPORT NETWORK TEN-T should be addressed. The Adriatic-Ionian direction for the merger of Central and Southeastern Europe is very important, which will stimulate the development of the economy and tourism in Croatia.  I would like to highlight the need for a new role for local units, which can most quickly assess traffic overload and pollution problems, and use EU funding sources to develop sustainable urban mobility. Transforming European transport by mobilising funds through the Connecting Facility will boost jobs, economic growth and greater passenger safety. In doing so, greater mobility must not have a negative impact on the environment. That is why I welcome the dialogue with the EESC on transport development in the EU.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — Consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee is in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty governing the functioning of the European Union, which expressly provides for it on occasions such as this. The Opinions of the Economic and Social Committee on the INI report "Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport: detection and pathways to sustainable mobility" will then be examined by the TRAN Commission, of which I am a member, as the committee responsible for the matter.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The 2011 Transport White Paper is a very ambitious document focusing on future challenges and initiatives that need to be taken immediately in order to effectively overhaul the transport system, create modern infrastructure and multimodal mobility supported by smart governance and information systems. The Book also sets out the objective of creating a system that underpins economic progress in Europe, characterised by a high level of competitiveness and austerity. The Committee on Transport and Tourism will soon analyse the level of implementation of its objectives. Nevertheless, it is clear to us today that the old challenges of European transport policy are still relevant and new ones are constantly emerging. Huge delays in the development of Central and Eastern Europe's transport infrastructure are moving Europe away from achieving the book's objectives. Only the concentration of investment in the poorest regions will allow the construction of an efficient single European transport area. In the hope of obtaining a complete picture of the state of the infrastructure and its implications for citizens, I also today supported the request for the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the White Paper.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Representatives of employers' associations, workers and other interest groups may express their views on issues relating to the European Union through the European Economic and Social Committee (EEC), which delivers opinions to the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament.  In March 2011, the European Commission adopted a strategy for implementing a competitive transport system that would increase urban mobility, overcome key obstacles in key transport sectors and boost oil and employment growth, including proposals to drastically reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and reduce transport carbon emissions by 60% by 2050.  This request, provided for in Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure, follows the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: balance sheet and path towards sustainable mobility. I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this request to the European Economic and Social Committee on the report assessing the implementation, so far, of the 2011 Transport White Paper: the EU strategic document setting out the main lines in transport policy. It is a question of taking stock and knowing the degree of achievement of the objectives set out in a document that promotes the development of a single transport space that addresses the different challenges that arise for the future: efficiency, sustainability, infrastructures, etc., which are objectives framed in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, not only because it is a legal obligation, but also because it considers that it is a body that is assumedly competent to formulate a consistent and reasoned opinion on what the future of Europe in the field of transport should be. We all know that transport activity is a sine qua non condition for economic development, and mobility is synonymous with the vitality of the internal market and the quality of life of citizens. Since 2001, the date of the publication of the last White Paper on this matter, remarkable progress has been made. Nevertheless, the sustainability of the transport system remains a challenge, in particular as regards its dependence on oil, the use of renewable sources, CO2 emissions, congestion costs and regional accessibility disparities.  For this reason, I agree with the request for consultation with the Economic and Social Committee to comment on this document, which provides an overview of developments in the transport sector, the challenges to be addressed and the policy initiatives to be considered in the coming years.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this request to the European Economic and Social Committee on the report assessing the implementation, so far, of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: the EU Strategic Document setting out the main lines in transport policy. It is a question of taking stock and knowing the degree of achievement of the objectives set out in a document that promotes the development of a single transport space that addresses the different challenges that arise for the future: efficiency, sustainability, infrastructures, etc., which are objectives framed in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this consultation because I consider the opinion of the Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport to be useful. An opinion that also looks at the strictly economic aspects on such an important issue, such as sustainable mobility, can only be of benefit to all European citizens.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The vote calls for consultation with the EESC on the INI report 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Taking stock and moving towards sustainable mobility'. The participation of social actors in the legislative process is essential and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — Transport is a key element for our economy and society. It helps economic growth and job creation. Considerable progress has been made since the publication of the White Paper on Transport in 2001. In air, road and partly rail transport, there was a further opening of markets. However, the transport system is still not sustainable. Its sustainability is one of the basic attributes for streamlining its functioning. As mobility is one of the important aspects for the internal market and increases citizens' living standards, completing the single transport market should be one of the EU's fundamental objectives. Moreover, strong international cooperation needs to be promoted, as transport is global in nature.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the implementation of the 2011 Transport White Card, as the implementation of the plan needs to be continuously monitored and upgraded, and transport is also the cornerstone of economic sustainability. The programme foresees the levelling of transport infrastructure in western and eastern Member States and their quality integration. It has been noted that there are many challenges posed to the Union's transport policy, while also showing that the problems of the past have not been addressed. The EU has committed to significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions and reducing it as planned, while some other international actors are not adhering to this agreement. Most transports today use oil and its derivatives and the use of new technologies should be more intensively encouraged to reduce emissions, and the EU could make a much wider contribution, as european companies are a world leader in the transport industry. Since the adoption of the White Book in 2011, a lot has been achieved in aviation and rail, but much effort still needs to be made to achieve the levelling of transport infrastructure.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. — I formally oppose the consultation of bodies whose legitimacy I question, namely the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The vote calls for consultation with the EESC on the INI report 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: Taking stock and moving towards sustainable mobility'. The participation of social actors in the legislative process is essential and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The consultation follows the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: balance sheet and path towards sustainable mobility.  This book pushed the transport sector on the path of market liberalisation, privatisation of public transport companies and resulted in social dumping, with deteriorating quality of services. It promoted the concentration of the sector in monopolies and private oligopolies, problems that Parliament itself identified in December 2011 as consequences to be avoided. In the white paper vote, we warned that such a path would not bring either improved quality of service, better prices or more jobs, but on the contrary, the register is of harm to users, workers and national economies and the promises of more employment is in plain sight. However, we voted in favour of the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the matter, however, with the concern that it is no longer an instrument for legitimising the exploitation of workers and deepening neoliberal policies.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This request, provided for in Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure, allows committees to request that the European Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. The consultation follows the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: balance sheet and path towards sustainable mobility, which pushed the transport sector on the path of market liberalisation, building the European transport market, leading to privatisation of public transport companies and resulting in social dumping, deteriorating quality of services and concentrating the sector on monopolies and oligopolies , problems which Parliament itself identified in December 2011 as consequences to be avoided. We voted in favour of consulting the European Economic and Social Committee on the matter, however, hoping that it will no longer be an instrument for legitimising the exploitation of workers and deepening neoliberal policies.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - In 2011, the Commission adopted the White Paper on transport, with the aim of outlining a competitive system capable of increasing mobility, removing the main obstacles in urban areas and fuelling growth and employment, ensuring sustainability. Among the various ambitious targets, there was also the reduction of both Europe's dependence on oil imports and carbon emissions due to transport (a reduction of up to 60% by 2050), as well as the withdrawal of traditional-powered cars from the city market by 2050, and the passage, by 2050, of more than 50% of goods from road transport to alternative means , efficient and green. The Committee on Transport is preparing to draw up a report to assess the implementation of the measures contained in the White Paper, and I support the request to consult the Economic and Social Committee on this matter, because I believe it is essential to listen to the voice of associations representing groups and citizens, which are better aware than any other body of the needs of the actors involved and of the population in general. The comments that will emerge from this will undoubtedly be of great use in making the report more complete and effective.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Madam President, this report provided a great opportunity to protect European standards and the GMO status of countries like Ireland. This report could have acted in the best interests of citizens and instead it has moved towards the interests of biotech companies. Other groups and parties in this Parliament may be willing to succumb to pressures from the Council to basically rush through legislation, but we in Sinn Féin and others cannot stand over this legislation or any that slyly offers dangerous loopholes to private companies. I want to commend my party colleague Lynn Boylan who, as shadow rapporteur on this report, has clearly outlined the position of the vast majority of Irish and European citizens. We will continue to press for absolute clarity that Member States will be in a position to ban GMOs in the interests of our communities and of our local food and agriculture industries.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I welcome the compromise agreed, because I believe that this solution does not satisfy either supporters of such modified organisms or opponents. It is a compromise that will allow nation states to prohibit and restrict the cultivation of such crops on their territory on the basis of legal, clear reasons. This is, in my opinion, the right position. A position that is central, European and which would force some states to grow such crops or, on the contrary, ban crops for the whole of the European Union would, in my opinion, be incorrect and interfere with the sovereignty of individual nation states.  After all, the position of the Czech Republic, which I represent here, has long been that it should be left to national competence whether or not nation states allow these crops on their territory. So I welcome the compromise and believe that it is a good basis for a debate on what specific crops to allow or not.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: I support the agreement reached today and was happy to support it because it corrects the wrong regulation of 2001. In 2012, as agriculture minister, I participated in the Council, and I know how hard the negotiations have been and how some countries have been relentless in reaching such a compromise, and I also offer my sincere congratulations to Parliament, the coordinator and also to everyone who participated in this compromise, including the Chairman of the Committee on the Environment. The key solutions that are in this compromise are, of course, well known. The thing is that, without risking being sued by multinationals, countries can choose not to grow GMOs, and that countries that cultivate must also further protect the area of trans-border impacts. What is also important is that we have adopted this in the European Parliament before negotiations with America begin, because this agreement will be one of the key areas.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Madam President, I welcome this decision, I supported it. I supported it for two reasons, firstly because it is always good to give nation states the opportunity to adapt an issue with their own legislation where European regulation is not strictly necessary. And this is precisely the case where European regulation is not strictly necessary. Secondly, in some Countries there is, in my opinion, unjustified in the European Union, and I would even say, in some cases, anti-scientific hysteria against GM crops. I do not take his views from anyone, if they ever want to ban the cultivation of GM crops in any country, please do so, but do not force other countries to follow suit. I am glad that this decision, I hope at least, will unblock the possibility of such a veto at European Union level.

name: Vicky FORD
text: Madam President, if we are to feed the world’s growing population and combat weather changes and diseases, then we must harness the best science in crop areas. The stalemate on GM has gone on for far too long, and for that reason I support this vote, which returns decision-making to Member States. The region I represent has some of the best crop scientists in the world: in Cambridge, at John Innes, where they have invented blight-free potatoes, and at Rothamsted with their aphid-resisting wheat. Crops that will reduce the need for chemicals but help feed the population. It would have been best to have a science-led solution across the single market, but given that this has been stuck for so long, we must allow those countries that support science to move forward.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the trilogue obtained on the night of 3-4 December is a minimum agreement that allows states to ban the cultivation of GMOs on their soil.  However, this point should not be deluded and that is why I disagree with the text submitted to us. Indeed, this is not the first phase of a sovereignist political response to the issue of GMOs, but the last very symbolic concession that is left to states as a alms.  The problem of GMOs is a food security issue. Nothing is said about the ability of states to impose traceability and labelling of GMO food wherever it is produced.  The problem of GMOs is a problem of contamination of other crops. Nothing is said about the risk of cross-border contamination of a state that refuses to grow GMOs on its soil.  Finally, the problem of GMOs is even civilizational in that it is a tool in the hands of very powerful firms to manipulate the living from an immediate profit perspective.  We do not have a debate beyond the prosaic aspect when this debate is taking place elsewhere, particularly in Russia.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Millions of citizens, organic farmers, consumers, and also in this common Europe, have been and are millions of citizens, of organic farmers, and also in this common Europe, who, after years of blockade in the Council and after the great resistance in the genetic engineering companies, have made these successes possible today. And although it is a compromise, it is an important step towards a Gm-free Europe. With my vote in favour today, I pay tribute to all those citizens, to environmental and other civil society organisations, to the 62 GM-free regions in Europe. But I also pay respect to all those in Upper Austria, where the fight with the Greens, with Rudi Anschober, began eleven years ago, with my approval today. The glass is half full, but there is still a lot and a lot left. It is unacceptable that genetic engineering companies should have a say in the decisions of the Member States! Above all, we need a more democratic authorisation procedure, which President Juncker has promised and to which he has instructed Commissioner Andriukaitis to make a proposal by the beginning of May. That must be the case!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, I have been reticent about this proposal for a directive, because despite being improved, it does not fully protect member states' right to their sovereignty or protect the model of subsidiarity, which I discussed in detail in the debate.  Caring for biodiversity and caring for food production is the duty of us, MPs. Genetic engineering involves introducing genes of one species into another species, and this can cause far-reaching consequences for the environment, food production and human health. Multinational companies want to manage the entire food chain and we should have shown them with this directive that this is not acceptable and that they cannot be flush with the Member States, which unfortunately we have failed to do.  We haven't protected ourselves enough from multinationals, but we haven't protected ourselves enough from potential GMO pollution. Europe should have been wiser and used its advantage as a green continent. I hope that the Commission's proposal, promised by the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, this year, will be more in favour of a Europe without the GMO I stand for.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the cultivation of GMOs still gives rise to heated debate, not only among the Member States, but also within the countries of the European Union, where public opinion is still strongly divided, especially since the effects on the health of citizens are still unclear.  The text voted on today comes after three years of negotiations: it is a balanced compromise, which introduces clear rules compared to the 2001 directive, which help to provide greater legal certainty as to whether states can ban or restrict, in whole or part of their territory, the cultivation of genetically modified organisms. States are given freedom of choice, based not only on assessing the environmental risk and the effects of crops on citizens' health, but also on taking into account reasons relating to socio-economic impact and agricultural policy. I therefore believe that the compromise is heading in the right direction, ensuring greater protection and protection of citizens' health, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have really voted with conviction for this text, which we have been waiting for for almost four years and which allows Member States to restrict or prohibit transgenic cultivation on their national territory. I believe that it is essential to have applied the principle of subsidiarity on such a sensitive issue, which concerns environmental safety and environmental safety.  The broad support that has been received from this text by the various parliamentary groups underlines once again that Parliament is an institution sensitive to the demands of the citizens, who have once again made it clear that they want to preserve the foundations of healthy, safe and quality agriculture. There is only one regret that the issue of financial responsibility has been excluded from the text. I believe that we will have to make further efforts on this, because it is essential – in my opinion – to consider the economic damage that can be caused by GMO crops on surrounding crops, and it is also crucial to determine who should pay for this damage that is caused.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we all know how much the issue of GMOs is infiamious in the debate, but this fervour confuses public opinion, which we know is mostly opposed – around 58% – against GMOs. There obviously seem to be two opposing positions to emerge from excessive simplification: the scientific position, which belongs to that of the so-called bad guys, of those who declare themselves in favour of GMOs; the emotional one, the good guys, all those who are against the cultivation of GMOs because they are actually afraid.  In fact, it is precisely the scientific world that does not agree on this issue: unfortunately, not having unambiguous answers from scientists has inevitably led to an ideological debate, which has marginalised the scientific aspect and therefore limited the important research factor. Each of us members will help to encourage research and debate in our country of origin for responsible and fruitful choices. The agreement reached is a more than balanced agreement, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! I must confess that I do not really like the compromise, but I have nevertheless voted in favour. I voted in favour because the compromise, if you like, is a reflection of the political reality and, above all, it reopens a procedure for us. After all, as has happened so far, it has not been possible to continue, namely that the Commission and the Council have constantly hindered each other. We now have a procedure under the rule of law, and we can at least deal with the problem. Secondly, I have one more wish. The wish would be that we should nevertheless be able to carry out further research in this field of genetic engineering in Europe, in the European Union, and above all for us to participate in the risk assessment. My opinion is quite clear: simply being against it is not enough. It is better to carry out scientific studies, analyses and also to participate in the risk assessment in order to define opportunities and risks properly in this relatively new procedure.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Madam President, the text before us is a Trojan horse, because under the guise of giving freedom to States, it delivers our populations, consumers and farmers to multinational agrochemicals. The effects of GMOs on the health of our compatriots but also on the fauna and flora are already known and unacceptable. Defending the free movement of GMO products means chaining ourselves even more in globalization through the specialization of growing areas, it is losing the typicality of our landscapes and our food. To serve whom? Not the people, but the shareholders of a few publicly traded companies, when we already know that it is possible to feed humanity without GMOs. This is about making the right political choices.  The GMOs imposed on us with this text are incompatible with any food sovereignty. This sovereignty is to the people what freedom is to the individual. We must be able to choose and produce at home what we want to eat and to make our children eat without risking our health. That is why I voted against it.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Plant breeding is of all times and is not only realized through gene technology. The Flemish interest is not against science but urges caution, because the dangers are known and real. It can lead to monoculture and dependence on agro-industries. The Ries proposal is an apparent improvement. It does allow Member States to restrict or prohibit cultivation, but not to import or trade it into their territory. That means a double disadvantage. Farmers are not allowed to grow them, but the unwitting consumers will get the GMO products on their plates unsolicited. This is where, of course, the shoe is rubbing: GMOs must be recognisable and identifiable, so that the freedom of choice of consumers and producers is guaranteed. That is why, in order to avoid any misunderstanding, I voted against this text, but with this explanation of vote.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Madam President, I supported this proposal because, in my opinion, the Member States of the European Union will soon be able to obtain an instrument in the form of a new directive enabling them to effectively regulate the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. States are now given freedom to restrict, tighten or even ban permitted GMOs. This changes the current situation, which was governed by the 2001 Directive, according to which GMOs were in principle authorised centrally throughout the European Union and there was only a reporting obligation for national authorities. The European Food Safety Authority will continue to assess only the risks of gmo cultivation. I thus see this decision today as fulfilling the principle of subsidiarity, which is often talked about at European level but is not always respected.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Madam President, one of the questions I often ask myself in deciding how to vote is whether my vote will improve the current situation. I believe that my vote today in favour of this report is a positive step. The current situation, where Member States can be sued by multinationals if they ban approved GMs, is totally unacceptable. Before today’s vote the Commission could approve GM crops even though a majority of Member States disagreed. We had the case where 19 Member States rejected the Commission proposal to approve the cultivation of a particular type of GM maize, Pioneer 1507, yet it was approved, leaving Member States open to being sued. Now, however, we have the opportunity for Member States to take those decisions individually. Ireland can take the decision to ban GMs, even though the Commission might approve their use, and this is surely the most democratic outcome. After today’s vote, Irish citizens can hold an Irish agriculture minister to account for decisions on GM cultivation. I think this is a situation which the vast majority will support.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: The citizens of the European Union, but, as I can see, we politicians, do not have a unified view on the issue of genetically manipulated food. On the one hand, it is said that if we want to solve the issues of hunger in the world, we cannot do without genetically modified food. The arguments against call for caution against the possible adverse effects of consuming such foods. Caution is in place in this situation. I therefore support the agreement reached, which will lead to a change in the existing approval regime and strengthen the possibility for Member States. Under the directive in force so far, GMOs were authorised centrally for the whole of the European Union, and the national authorities had very limited possibilities. The new legislative framework will provide wider scope and greater legal certainty for Member States wishing to ban, restrict or authorise genetically modified food.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, I wonder why we have the European Food Security Authority at all if we ignore the last twenty-five years of research, with millions of euros invested in assessing GMOs. So far, no evidence shows risks for food security, animal welfare or health. I understand that many people are concerned, but policy in this House should be based on science, not on emotions. The debate has instead been carried by Green ideology; it has created the fears that GMO is something artificial. By letting Member States so easily opt out, we are fragmenting the single market. How does this go along with a common agricultural and food security policy? The answer has not been given. We need free choice, but for consumers. That is why it should be labelled if it is GMO or not. We need it for producers, so that all producers – and not only big companies – can produce GMOs, rather than having Member States opting out. Science, research, development, technology, innovation – that is the way ahead in Europe.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: Madam President, when it comes to GMOs, we all want sensible decisions to be based on scientific evidence. Not all the countries here in the EU want to base their decisions on the hard evidence, but this vote today will allow Member States to make their own decisions on GM crops. The UK will see decision-making returned to it from the EU. This is what we Conservatives have been working for and will continue to work for, and I welcome the return of these powers to the UK.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Madam President, this particular motion was regarded as an opportunity for nation states to have subsidiarity and regain for themselves the power of  making decisions on GM products. You have just heard from a member of the Conservative Party saying this is a good reason. This is not the case. Fifty clauses in this motion made sure that the nation states would have to be subject to the EU in all of those 50 clauses before they could make such decisions. This is not a choice of Parliament: it was a choice of the Council and the Commission, once again showing up this place for the fraud that it is and how much power it has. There was no debate on whether GMOs are good. There is no clear labelling regime to ensure that the people of Europe have the opportunity to choose the food that they want. There is no clear system to prevent cross-contamination. There is no clear opportunity for the people of Europe to say ‘no’ to GM foods if they do not want them, or ‘yes’ if they do.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Madam President, the British press and many MEPs have reported that this vote was to give powers back to our government regarding GM crops. In fact the report is misleadingly entitled ‘Possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs’. However, as is always the case with this place, nothing is as it seems. We actually voted on 52 amendments, not the legislation. Fifty of the amendments were lumped together. Amendment 20, the only amendment giving any powers back, was drowned out by the dozens of other amendments, each reasserting EU supremacy over Britain. I therefore abstained.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm a rá gur vótáil mé leis an tuarascáil seo agus le mo ghrúpa, an EPP agus, mar a dúirt tú féin, bhí móramh cáilithe ag teastáil. Is is sin níos mó ná 50 % of in Feisirí sa Pharlaimint. Ach ó thaobh na vótála féin, vótáil 70 % i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus is deacair argóint leis sin mar tugann sé cead do Bhallstáit pé rud is mian leo a dhéanamh bunaithe air thaighde eolaíochta.  Inár dtír féin ní thugtar cead barraí GM a fhás agus ní dóigh liom go n-athrófar is sin go fada an there. Ach b'fhéidir go dtiocfaidh Ballstáit eile air chinneadh difriúil agus tugann sé seo an cead sin a dhéanamh. Dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom gur dul chun cinn is cé nach bhfuil sé b'fhéidir go hiontach ag deireadh an lae.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Madam President, I supported the rapporteur's proposal because I think it is reasonable and contains new provisions that it definitely needs. The issue of the prohibition of GMOs in the Member States is a key issue. In Bulgaria there is a strong suspicion of the cultivation of GMOs, as well as against the realization of goods containing GMOs.  While this report does not contain provisions governing the placing on the market of products containing GMOs, it fulfils one main objective and it is to give Member States the necessary freedom to prohibit or restrict the cultivation and distribution of GMOs in their national territories. I believe that citizens of the Member States should have the right, through their managing authorities, to decide whether and how to grow GMOs on their territory. It's part of national sovereignty. As far as Bulgaria is concerned, Bulgarian society is for the most part against the cultivation of GMOs and I share this opinion and these concerns. I am now calling on the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council to continue the conversation on the issue of the placing on the market of GMOs or GMO-containing goods. It is necessary to enable Member States to determine for themselves whether and how products containing GMOs will be produced and marketed on their territory.

name: David COBURN
text: Madam President, this was not a vote on whether or not Great Britain can or cannot grow GM crops: this is merely one amendment among 52 which allowed it. The rest did exactly the opposite. The EU still decides. The British Parliament – and only the British Parliament – should make decisions about GM crops. Furthermore, UKIP is opposed to the EU-Seychelles Agreement for fishing access to the Mayotte waters, as we consider this to be neo-colonialist. The EU gives money to the Seychelles ruling class and takes away the waters of ordinary fishermen. All I can say is this: this Parliament professes one thing and does exactly the opposite. Same as usual.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, it is a funny thing: when we talk about climate change in this Chamber, we are constantly told that the vital thing is to venerate the scientific consensus. And yet the people who make that argument most insistently and most loudly play by very different rules when it comes to this question of genetically modified food. Suddenly it is not about where the scientific consensus is, but whether it feels right. Well you know what, it is a democracy. People are visceral as well as cerebral creatures; consumers might well have an objection that is not completely logical, but that does not make it invalid. If it just gives you the willies, if you are superstitious, then fine. It would be just as wrong to impose GM foods on an unwilling customer as to ban someone who wanted to buy it from doing so. Ideally we would have that decision made consumer by consumer, but at the very least let us make it through our national democratic mechanisms and procedures rather than imposing one set of rules on 600 million Europeans.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: Madam President, on the face of it this seemed an easy one for UKIP. Here was the opportunity to allow some power back to Member States, and we would have presumably voted in favour. But on a closer look at the thing, it was anything but. The Commission was going to be involved at every single stage, even to a greater extent than it is now. Therefore, we have reluctantly had to abstain from this. Crucially, though, Amendment 20 should have been voted on on its own, because that genuinely did give some power back to Member States. However, that got subsumed in the rest of the thing and would have been effectively drowned out. It will be very interesting to see, in those Member States which decide not to cultivate these crops, whether they will ban their consumers from eating them when all the constituents are imported. That will be a remarkable sight when people see they have not got enough to eat because of this legislation.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: Madam President, we voted to abstain from this. I do apologise. I read the wrong line. We are always in favour of the repatriation of powers. However, the problem is that the amendments are, as always, contradictory. But the final problem is that, in truth, the TTIP agreement will render all of this talk redundant.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, UKIP could not support this block vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. — (IT) A text has been voted on today in plenary on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of GMOs.  From the title of the legislative text, it would appear that the Member States are being empowered to decide whether to restrict or even prohibit this type of cultivation on national territory. Unfortunately, that's not the case. Important points on which we had negotiated at length and voted by a large majority in the ENVI Commission were not included in the new text. These include the obligation to insist GMO crops to cope with possible compensation in the event of contamination of traditional or organic crops. Instead, points have been included that give biotech companies the opportunity to negotiate directly with national governments, which will come under unspeakable pressure. Furthermore, the latter will not be able to use, in the grounds for the calls, specific national environmental impacts that do not give the same result as the environmental impact conducted by EFSA (European Food Safety Authority).  The Member State will only be able to stop cultivation for socio-economic reasons. We believe that the issue of GMOs is mainly linked to the health of citizens and only as a result of the economic aspects. As far as I am said, our delegation voted against it.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — Positioning itself on an initial Commission proposal, the European Parliament voted in 2011 to expand the list of cases of restriction and prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). In 2014, the Council adopted a radically different proposal, which greatly limited the assumptions of a ban on GMOs. While Parliament was able to partially restore its initial position by means of the amendments made to the report as it passed through the Committee on the Environment, the final wording departs from what was adopted in 2011 and introduces enormous ambiguity respect for the cases in which States could ban the cultivation of a GMO.  In addition, the regulation of GMOs was restored to the domestic market and almost entirely diluted the financial responsibility regime previously advocated by Parliament.  The rewording makes it easier for large GMO multinationals to market their crops despite opposition from European states and peoples concerned about their consequences, without an adequate mechanism to compensate for the risks arising from this liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — Despite the fact that this directive will allow France to ban GMO plantations on national soil, I have not spoken in favour of this text, as it will not protect the French from the consumption of transgenic foods. Indeed, within the framework of the European Free Trade Area, it will be impossible to assure our citizens that genetically modified foods will not end up on their plates. Neighbouring exporting countries within the EU may indeed have made the choice to use GMOs and resell them in all EU countries, including those that have chosen to boycott them.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. — The agreement on which we are voting today allows Member States that wish to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their own territory to do so. Their decision to limit or ban such crops will provide greater legal certainty, and will prevent them from systematically resorting to moratoriums that can be called into question at any time by litigation proceedings. Thanks to the action of the European Parliament, the text also foresees several other improvements. As requested since 2008, the Commission will have to update legislation on the environmental assessment of GMO risks within two years. Measures of coexistence at the borders between two states, one of which would allow the cultivation of GMOs and not the other, are mandatory. Member States that allow the cultivation of GMOs are allowed to set up liability regimes in the event of damage caused by GMO crops to neighbouring conventional and organic crops. Because of all these advances in the guarantee of Member States and the protection of consumers and farmers, I will support this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — I welcome the new regulation adopted today by the European Parliament, as it gives EU Member States more and legally guaranteed opportunities to ban the cultivation of a gene plant on their territory, even if it is authorised throughout the EU. In the past, Member States were obliged to provide new scientific evidence if they wanted to ban the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). If a so-called safeguard clause was issued and no new scientific evidence was found, suppliers of genetically modified organisms such as.B. Monsanto could sue the Member State. In future, Member States may also point to political reasons such as land use or the socio-economic impact of cultivation. The Commission also announced that it would develop a new legal framework to make the procedures around GMOs more democratic. However, the new rules do not solve the problem of the use of genetically modified organisms in the EU, as the import of these organisms – for example as feed in animal husbandry – remains permitted even in countries that have imposed a ban on cultivation. Here, too, stricter rules should apply, in particular to provide consumers with better information on whether genetically modified feed has been used during the food chain.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. "The proposed text is misleading. Presented as a guarantee of freedoms given to states, it will facilitate the cultivation of GMOs. However, even if a state refuses to grow a GMO, the laws of the internal market prevent it from prohibiting the circulation of this GMO and the products that come from it, intended for consumption. Health, environmental and food requirements are also not sufficient in the authorisation procedures and monitoring of GMO crops. I voted against this text which threatens the health of nationals of the Member States of the European Union and the independence of farmers who will be held by patented seeds.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. There was no possibility to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this block vote.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because at present the socio-economic impacts of GMO cultivation are not taken into account in European regulations. It was therefore necessary for the system to evolve to ensure that each Member State had the opportunity to choose whether or not it wished to grow GMOs on its territory.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers.
