In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments, which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this block vote.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. — In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, we must note that GMO cultivation is an issue to be dealt with in greater depth at Member State, rather than EU institutional, level. Thus, the Member States should be able to decide whether they prefer to restrict or ban the cultivation of certain GMOs on their territory. In addition, we should take into account the problem of crop contamination deriving from GMO cultivation which, according to the reported evidence, has resulted in increased costs for farmers trying to safeguard their crops from contact with GMOs. The motion for a resolution should also make for better consumer protection, which is one of Parliament’s priorities. Improving the authorisation of GMOs, including through uniform risk-assessment procedures and a GMO labelling system in the EU, would give consumers more access to information. Lastly, since the measures taken by Member Status in application of this directive will have to be made public, this will allow for better scrutiny and more transparency in relation to GMOs. Overall, creating more room for manoeuvre and greater legal certainty, with regard to both national and regional legislation, is a substantial step forward in terms of the quality of food security in the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to enable Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs. According to statistics, as many as 58% of EU citizens are opposed to the cultivation of genetically modified crops in the European Union. So far, however, this issue has not been adequately addressed at EU level, especially with regard to the decision-making process itself for the production of genetically modified organisms. It is not justified when 19 of the 28 governments oppose the legalisation of the new GMO crop, but the final decision is taken by the Commission without taking into account the positions of democratically elected governments. With regard to today's document, I can only welcome the fact that Member States are given a broader mandate to decide on the cultivation of GMOs in their territories. Although these new rules do not address the labelling of GM products, this issue remains relevant. GM products must be properly labelled and residents must be able to choose whether or not to consume products containing GM crops.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — I voted against this text, which I consider to be a Trojan horse of multinational agrochemicals: under the false pretext of giving States the freedom to allow GMOs or not, it will impose them de facto on the plates of the French, despite the ban in force today on our territory.  Indeed, to the extent that free movement remains an untouchable dogma within the European Union, how could we ban the importation of GMOs? How can we limit their consumption even though we cannot guarantee traceability and labelling of consumer products?  GMO technology would only be acceptable if we were able to master its design, production and marketing, which is decidedly far from the case.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of this text because it now allows Member States to decide whether or not to allow the cultivation of GMOs on their soil. For example, reasons for prohibition may be related to environmental criteria, land use planning obligations or reasons related to economic impacts.  It is also worth noting the obligation to take measures to ensure the coexistence of crops and the desire to ensure transparency in procedures for restricting and banning the cultivation of a GMO.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC shall give the Member States of the European Union flexibility to restrict or prohibit crops containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in their own territories.  The uncoverings between pro and anti-GMO countries have made this proposal blocked since 2010. This new legislation achieves a balance and simplifies the procedure so that countries can choose the regime to be followed without interfering with or colliding with the authorisation criteria of the body concerned issued by the European Food Safety Authority. That is why, in line with the position of the ALDE group, I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted against the compromise reached out of coherence. The Basque Country is a territory declared GMO-free and that is the policy we believe Europe would have to push forward and approve

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — This recommendation relates to the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council directive amending directive 2001/18/EC with regard to the possibility for Member States to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. Even if it restores some sovereignty to States, which seems positive at first glance, the reality is quite different and is distorted by free movement in Europe, which will in no way prevent the importation of products from countries authorizing GMOs to countries prohibiting them.  Unfortunately, Member States no longer have control over borders, legislation or budgets, so this recommendation is just another artifice.  The European Union, by refusing to listen to the opinion of citizens who overwhelmingly condemn GMOs, is thus subject to multinationals and the future free trade treaty with the United States. Health thus becomes an adjustment variable endangering men and nature and that is why I voted against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the report – this in order to vote in favour of the original proposal from the Committee on the Environment. The starting point for this report was good, but during the very hasty trialogues, many of the most important elements were removed, which has created a text which, on the one hand, stands on a weak legal basis and, on the other hand, does not give Member States an absolute opportunity to decide for themselves whether to abandon GMO crops. The polluter-pays principle is not included in the text and the change in the legal basis of legislation from the environment to the internal market and the transfer of the precautionary principle in the text to a recital entails the risk of loosening the precautionary principle in favour of competition issues and the market access of GMO companies and further undermining the environmental perspective. Therefore, although the proposal contains some improvements compared to the past, I have voted against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I support the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because I believe that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: caution, transparency and protection of health and the environment. I understand that some safeguard measures could have been further reached, but the agreement reached corresponds to the current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this recommendation on the Council position, which negotiates the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). It is important to examine the position adopted by the Council on the directive very responsibly, as more and more Europeans are publicly opposed to genetically modified organisms and, in particular, for GMOs to be contained in food. It should be noted that, according to the December 2010 Restructuring Plan, the Commission will be able to make a decision on the state of the world's external ly than 100% With only 21% of Europeans agreeing (and 58% do not agree) with the report on food risks, and 58% do not agree with the statement that foods produced from GMOs are safe for future generations. The European Parliament considers it necessary to give Member States more flexibility to ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, including environmental considerations, jealousy, the protection of biodiversity or the conservation of habitats and ecosystems. In addition, it is necessary to strengthen the risk assessment approach as the long-term effects of GMO cultivation have not yet been sufficiently taken into account.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — The compromise text reached between Parliament and the Council, after almost four years of debate, introduces for the first time into European legislation a series of procedures to allow a Member State to ban a GMO on its territory, even if it has been authorised in the EU. This decision gives centrality to the choices of European citizens. Member States will have the opportunity to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their national territory for reasons other than those relating to the environmental risk identified by EFSA.  The entry into force of this directive has also sought to create a transparent mechanism and a solid legal basis that can avoid the many cases of litigation raised in recent years before the Court of Justice of the European Union on the authorisation of a GMO. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text of the agreement.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the dossier on the cultivation of GMOs in Europe because I believe that the mechanism granting the possibility of a cultivation ban granted to Member States, which is in itself positive, is cumbersome and remains 'sub judice' in relation to the Commission's wishes; only time will tell how much the free choice of European citizens on GMOs will be respected; Today the danger is that, behind this supposed freedom, there will be a device that, in fact, will allow them to 'break the embankment' of their entry into Community territory, to the detriment of biodiversity and europe's very rich varietal heritage.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this proposal for a directive because I believe that it has been a wasted opportunity for the European Union to protect itself definitively from the pressures of the large multinational agricultural microtechnology companies (such as monsanto company, which has Mon810 mast, which is already grown in five European states). Under the previous rule, Member States could veto GMO crops on the grounds of health and land protection clauses, only to be dragged regularly before the Court of Justice of the European Union. The new directive was also intended to provide greater means of protection for the Member States, but this objective has not been achieved. This directive does not, in fact, have a certain period of application and companies will not be obliged to reimburse them in the event of contamination. The measure was born with the best of intentions, but then it bowed along its legislative process to the Council's demands, until it lost its legal force, thus once again leaving the Member States exposed to the influence of multinational companies that follow market logic, rather than the common sense and good of European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — This text is the result of a birth of a compromise made in pain. I am thinking of that long night on 3 December when the concessions of the Council and the Commission were minor. Parliamentary representation and therefore of the European peoples are not being mocked. Indeed, the choice left to the Member States, the so-called opt-out clause, not to grow GMOs is a real decoy. On the one hand, with the principles of free movement, these GMOs, legally produced and marketed in a Member State, may end up on the plate of a French consumer. On the other hand, the false precaution presented by the rapporteur of the text, according to which "the minority of Member States that grow GMOs will now have to take mandatory measures in border areas in order to avoid possible contamination". A bit like this radioactive cloud of Chernobyl miraculously blocked at the Franco-German border... I am voting against this text which goes against the will of the people, to the detriment of the health of consumers and farmers and against the diversity of cultivated plants. Once again, this Parliament serves the interests of multinational agrochemical companies.  GMOs, as imposed by some multinationals, the United States and the European Union.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported giving Member States this possibility because I believe it is of fundamental importance that every sovereign state should be able to control the cultivation of products that may harm the health of its citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The amendments proposed to amend the 2001/18/EC Directive, which allow Member States to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, are not satisfactory. This GMO directive is a real trap because, under the guise of so-called respect for the sovereignty of the Member States, it offers a gateway to GMO cultivation on the European market. Indeed, it is no secret that some EuDS are in favour of GMO cultivation. However, given respect for the free movement of goods and services, if a Member State can ban the cultivation of GMOs on its territory, it will be unable to refuse the importation of agricultural products from the GMO crop. In practical terms, this directive risks producing the expected adverse effects and thus facilitating the sale of food products on the shelves of French supermarkets. For all these reasons, I voted against the draft resolution and will oppose in the strongest possible terms anything that would facilitate the marketing of products containing GMOs.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — Amending Directive 2001/18 aims to increase the decision of the Member States on the cultivation of genetically modified organisms in their territory. Greater flexibility is needed in this regard, taking into account national or regional characteristics with regard to the use of agricultural land. At the same time, Member States should be able to assess the risks and impacts that GMOs have on citizens, the environment and animal health. I was in favour of amending the directive because I believe that the Member States are in a position to take responsibility for their authorisation and cultivation. Impartial studies are also needed to strengthen scientific knowledge of genetically modified organisms. Their long-term impact on the environment is less well known, so I believe that the development of impact studies and the information coming must be available to consumers. An important aspect is the labelling of products containing genetically modified organisms, european consumers must be informed, with the choice of consumer products. We need a very clear delimitation of areas for GMO cultivation. The authorisation of these areas must take account of neighbouring agricultural crops in order to avoid contamination.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted against. The measure does not contain sufficient protection to guarantee consumers and farmers. We must protect traditional agriculture rather than protect the usual multinationals in this sector.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. — The new legislation, adopted today at second reading after being blocked in the Council for four years, will allow Member States to fully restrict or ban crops containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory, even if they are permitted at EU level. I support this agreement because it will provide more flexibility for Member States that want to restrict the cultivation of GMOs on their territory for reasons of environmental protection, as well as urban or national planning, socio-economic impact or agricultural policy objectives.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the directive on the banning or authorisation of GMO cultivation in the European Union.  This text will allow Member States which, like France, prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory to continue to do so legally. It was certainly necessary to create a legal basis to settle disputes over the use of GMOs in Europe. The situation had been stalled for far too long.  However, this text is a considerable step backwards because the Union preferred not to legislate on a fundamental subject of European dimension and referred the matter to the Member States. I deplore this choice of non-Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory. Almost five years after the European Commission's original proposal, also thanks to the work carried out by the Italian Presidency, the EU institutions have finally reached an important agreement on this issue. I believe that Parliament, and in particular the ENVI Committee, have succeeded in having a positive impact on the text we have adopted. I am thinking, for example, of the fact that Member States where the cultivation of GMOs is permitted will be obliged to adopt coexistence measures for border areas in order to avoid contamination of traditional crops in neighbouring countries, and the important strengthening of risk assessment rules by the European Food Safety Authority prior to the placing on the market of GMOs. I believe that on other points, such as the environmental justifications that member states can invoke to ban the cultivation of GMOs, a stronger and more ambitious text could have been adopted. However, in view of the difficulty with which this agreement has been reached after more than four years, I have decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly billed as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, although Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and reasserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments. We regard that as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this bloc vote

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — We are voting against this resolution which facilitates the authorization of gm crops in the Member States. Guarantees on the quality of food in Europe are being hit hard by the adoption of this text.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "Because I am committed to the principle of sovereignty, I voted against this text: on the face of it, the directive seems to proclaim the freedom for States to restrict or ban GMO cultivation on their territory; this declaration of good intention is a decoy. The principle of free movement of goods enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty, in fact, prevents France from really guarding against the consumption of transgenic plants: many EU Member States have indeed adopted legislation very favourable to GMOs. As a result, French consumers will, against the will of the majority of them, be led to consume more and more food products containing transgenic plants. The true freedom of states therefore requires mandatory labelling of products containing GMOs. I could not vote in favour of a text which, like the European Union, gives people an ersatz of freedom.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. — My constituents have expressed their concerns about the cultivation of GMO crops in the EU on many occasions. While the majority in Parliament voted to allow individual EU Member States to ban or adopt GMO cultivation, I voted against the proposal as the legislation will make the authorisation process for GMOs easy to adopt.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The cultivation of GMOs in Europe has always puzzled me: scientific studies do not agree, but in the meantime we are increasingly consuming products from genetically modified plants directly or indirectly. In this particular case, I believe that the compromise found safeguards the different national sensitivities, albeit to the detriment of the internal market: if Italy has specific demands, it does not necessarily have to conform to the opinion of the other States, and the same must apply to the others. Indeed, I would like a stronger Europe only in areas where there is room for more efficient policies, but less present where diversity is profound.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — For such a controversial and sensitive question, we must leave the decision to cultivate GMOs up to the Member States. This is an historic breakthrough. After three years of stalemate between Member States, we finally have a viable solution. Exaggerated demands of the Greens have been stopped. At last we know where we are heading. Member States, regions, citizens, farmers and industry are finally getting legal certainty. Our most important aim was to shape the option for a national ban in such a way that GMO corporations cannot challenge them legally. This compromise is well-balanced. We must take the concerns of consumers into consideration and their fears seriously.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I support the Ries report as the possible compromise, although I have many doubts about the solution found. I am sensitive to the complexity of the PROBLEM of GMOs and the fact that there are passionate opinions on this subject which are different from Member State to Member State. And I agree that there should be legal certainty when Member States prohibit or limit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) authorised at EU level in their territories, on the basis of environmental reasons such as the maintenance of local biodiversity, socio-economic impacts or land-use criteria, among others.  But I fear that this will not help to strengthen the cohesion of the internal market and I fear the contagion factors that may occur between neighbouring States when one authorises and the other does not, despite the fact that it has been established that Member States must ensure that GM crops do not contaminate conventional and organic crops and should prevent cross-border contamination.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. — I have today voted in favour of the outcome of the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States on new EU standards for GM cultivation. The most important new regulation is that in future the Member States will be able to decide for themselves on the cultivation of genetically modified seeds. In addition, countries using GMOs must ensure that adjacent areas remain protected. The new standards will provide greater legal certainty for all concerned.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on GMOs because the aim is to give member states greater freedom as to the possibility of restricting or banning their cultivation.    More specifically, the two levels of intervention granted to Member States, i.e. at the authorisation stage or after that stage provided that there are adequate reasons, allow them a 360-degree assessment because they are not bound by any time limit.  The proposed text also provides a solid legal basis without interfering in the free movement of GMOs, creating conflicts within the World Trade Organisation or questioning EFSA's scientific expertise and assessments.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report to allow EU Member States (MS) to restrict or ban the cultivation of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO) crops on their territory, even though the crop in question may have been authorised at EU level. This is subjected to very strict conditions. This move recognises the sovereignty and autonomy of Member States regarding GMO cultivation. This will not affect the risk assessment at an EU level which will remain within the remit of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). MS will thus now be in a position to better take into account national specificities.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — (IT) The purpose of this resolution is to free the Member States from the need to provide detailed information with new scientific data on the possible ban on the cultivation of GMOs introduced at national level. In return, the Commission hopes to achieve a relative majority in the committee where the new proposals for authorisation are being discussed. I voted against this resolution because the reasons for banning gmo cultivation are very weak from a legal point of view and the enactment of bans extended to groups of GMOs could make the measures even less defensible in the event of recourse to the WTO or the Court of Justice of the European Union.   I am voting against it because the legal instrument adopted at the end of the negotiations is that of a directive which, however, does not contain any obligations for transposition by the Member States.  It also remains to be clarified from a legal point of view whether and how measures can be implemented without the national legal systems being updated with appropriate transposition measures.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — Positioning itself on an initial Commission proposal, the European Parliament voted in 2011 to expand the list of cases of restriction and prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). In 2014, the Council adopted a radically different proposal, which greatly limited the assumptions of a ban on GMOs. While Parliament was able to partially restore its initial position by means of the amendments made to the report as it passed through the Committee on the Environment, the final wording departs from what was adopted in 2011 and introduces enormous ambiguity respect for the cases in which States could ban the cultivation of a GMO.  In addition, the regulation of GMOs was restored to the domestic market and almost entirely diluted the financial responsibility regime previously advocated by Parliament.  The rewording makes it easier for large GMO multinationals to market their crops despite opposition from European states and peoples concerned about their consequences, without an adequate mechanism to compensate for the risks arising from this liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. — (IT) The text adopted represents an important step forward, since it introduces clearer rules and greater legal certainty for all those concerning the cultivation of GM crops. At the same time, however, greater flexibility is guaranteed for Member States in their decision to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. I believe that Europe must be at the forefront of the fight for the diversity of traditional crops and for minimising the risks arising from gm crops. Only in this way, by starting to equip ourselves first with clear directives, could we be credible when, on the international trade tables (first of all TTIP) we go to defend and claim the goodness and uniqueness of our productions.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. — Parliament has accepted the compromise that EU Member States may restrict (or prohibit) the cultivation of GM crops on their territory even if they are otherwise authorised at EU level. Under the new rules, Member States may also ban the cultivation of GMOs on the basis of environmental considerations or agricultural policy objectives. Member States may also ban certain specific plant varieties or plants bearing certain characteristics. One of the main arguments of supporters of GMOs is that European agricultural production could become more efficient. Opponents of GMOs, on the other hand, warn of risky production results. As a biochemist, I share the opinion of the majority of scientists that at the moment we do not know whether and what genetic changes in the human body are caused by food containing manipulated genes. Scientists also warn that possible human genetic changes triggered by GMOs may only be apparent to the third to fourth generation. The EP has decided to refer this power back to the level of the Member States, so that each Member State is free to decide whether or not to authorise such products. In addition to the technical content of the move, the political moment is also interesting that the EU has decided to strengthen member states' powers on this issue. This will, of course, cause complications in the future, for example when drafting a free trade agreement with the US. I supported this necessary compromise with my vote.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This report calls for extending rights for EU Member States to ban unwanted genetically modified crops in their territory. The EU authorisation system for GMOs aims at avoiding possible adverse effects on human and animal health and the environment while establishing an internal market for such products. This actual legislation reinforces the flexibility of Member States with regard to GMO cultivation. It is based on the principle of subsidiarity and the need to respect diversity in the 28 EU Member States. I voted in favour of this legislation as the possibility for Member States to restrict and prohibit groups of GMOs defined by crop or trait is secured, and as transparency has been reinforced in the text and as the precautionary principle was reintroduced.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the final text on the agreement reached on the cultivation of GMOs, because of the elements added by Parliament there is only the obligation to draw up coexistence plans but, as we have also suggested, limited to the countries in which GMO crops are grown, the possibility of banning groups of GMOs and a list of conditions on the basis of which it is possible to establish national bans which do not, however, contain references to possible environmental impacts. On the other side, the final text provides that Member States may decide whether to require companies to restrict the geographical scope of authorisations during evaluation or to impose unilateral bans.  Although this represents an improvement on the link between the two procedures in the Council text, this will give companies the power to behave in different ways depending on whether the Member State decides to involve them in the process or not. In addition, the reasons for banning gmo cultivation are very weak from a legal point of view, and the enactment of bans extended to groups of GMOs could make the measures even less defensible in the event of recourse to the WTO or the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs, since the new text, the result of significant compromise work between Parliament and the Council promoted by the Italian Presidency, has the merit of providing greater legal certainty to an issue which deserves to be approached with particular caution with the ultimate objective of consumer protection. The agreement allows ample scope for EU Member States to ban the cultivation of GMOs authorised on a European scale throughout or part of their national territory. Each country will therefore be free to decide - without giving any further reasons - to ban GMO crops, also for reasons that go beyond the scientific assessments already within EFSA's competence: I am referring, in particular, to the possibility of invoking agricultural and environmental policy objectives, reasons for land use and urban planning, as well as the possible socio-economic and public order impact. I also think it is important to provide for mandatory coexistence measures that will protect traditional crops from the risk of cross-border contamination with GMOs grown in neighbouring countries.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This report brings to an end a multi-year negotiation on the management of the introduction, or rejection, of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in the European Union. Until recently, differences between the Member States and the European Parliament prevented any possibility of agreement, leaving private, public and associative actors in the face of fragmented and uncoordinated procedures within the internal market. This is therefore a welcome compromise, even if this text remains mainly procedural and does not take a position on the very appropriateness of GMOs, this decision being left to the Member States. I will therefore be careful that this necessary compromise does not set a precedent in other areas, which in the longer term risks emptying European legislation of its substance. However, this text is an opportunity that must be seized and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The text amending Directive 2001/18/EC with regard to the possibility for Member States to restrict or ban the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory is a compromise. Like all compromises, it is not perfect, but it has the merit of ensuring a solid legal basis hithert non-existent. This legal stability will thus protect France from legal action if it takes measures to ban GMOs. In addition, this text guarantees Member States the final say on the use of GMOs on their territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote in favour of this text. Nevertheless, I will remain very careful on this subject, particularly in the context of the negotiations on the free trade agreement being negotiated with the United States.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. — While I welcome the return of national governments to a power that should never have been taken away from them by the EU, I voted against this proposal because it does not give states sufficient legal guarantees to ban genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their own territory.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the agreement reached between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on the reform of the GMO directive. The agreement enshrines the right of Member States to prohibit the cultivation of GMO seeds on their territory, for economic and agricultural reasons. The signed directive also provides that states that decide to use GMOs must pay particular attention to the prevention of cross-border contamination with neighbouring countries.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorisation in accordance with European regulations.  However, there are many disparities between Member States as to whether or not to grow GMOs. That is why the adoption of the directive on the possibility of GMOs restricting or banning the cultivation of GMOs on their territory is a good thing. It provides the Member States, which like France want to ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, with an argumentative legal framework. The European Parliament has also obtained an obligation for Member States where GMOs are grown to take measures of coexistence at borders to avoid contamination in neighbouring Member States where GMOs are not grown.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour because although this agreement is proof of the impossibility of finding a European answer on this issue at the moment (irreconcilable divergence of views between the pro and anti-GMO), it finally establishes legal stability for all parties concerned, including the Member States. Indeed, this system will allow Member States that wish to grow GMOs and those who do not want them to ban them legally. It is a two-tier system that is not perfect, that did not fully satisfy either the pro or the anti-GMO, but that takes us out of the current blocking situation. This agreement must be a first step in finding a European solution in the medium term. Indeed, we need a common answer on the issue of GMOs to avoid distortions of competition between European farmers.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. — Genetically modified organisms (GMO) are approved at European level on the basis of a scientific assessment by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA). However, widely differing opinions of the Member States block this approval process. Currently, 1 GMO is commercially grown in the EU in 5 Member States. Several Member States have banned the cultivation of the GMO in their territory through a safeguard clause. After more than 4 years of negotiations, a vote was taken today on an opt-out for Member States for European approved GMOs. The Commission hopes this will remove the stalemate in the approval process. The N-VA supported the agreement. Flanders is a leader in research into GMOs and there are also many companies active. The N-VA wants to give innovation the necessary opportunities and believes that this agreement can contribute to this. Moreover, the agreement addresses some of our specific concerns: for example, working with the two-step procedure increases legal certainty. It is also essential that the flexibility required does not challenge the credibility of the EFSA risk assessment. A number of points call our attention to the implementation of this legislation. The possible fragmentation of the internal market, the situation in border areas and the workability of the rules should be monitored.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. — This agreement brings to an end four long years of passionate and controversial discussions on the cultivation of GMOs in Europe, which is essentially aimed at enabling Member States wishing to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their own territory to do so. Their decision to limit or ban such crops will benefit from greater legal certainty and will prevent them from systematically resorting to moratoriums that can be called into question at any time by litigation proceedings. Thanks to the action of the European Parliament, the text also provides for the following provisions: the Commission will have to update legislation on the environmental assessment of GMO risks within two years; measures of coexistence at the borders between two states, one of which would allow the cultivation of GMOs and not the other, are mandatory; States that allow the cultivation of GMOs are allowed to set up liability regimes for damage caused by GMO crops to nearby conventional and organic crops. I supported this report as a first step forward, but I believe that the debate must continue in the hope of the precautionary principle and the necessary harmonisation of practices in Europe.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. — After more than four years of discussion, agreement has finally been reached on the delicate issue of GMO cultivation in EU Member States. As far as the authorisation of GMOs is concerned, the scheme remains purely European: it is the Commission which decides, on the basis of scientific advice, whether or not to authorise a particular GMO. As far as the cultivation of GMOs is concerned, it is up to Member States to authorise or ban it. I supported this agreement which confirms the European character of the system while allowing us to respond to the wishes of our citizens in the states where they are clearly speaking out against the cultivation of GMOs.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. "The proposed text is misleading. Presented as a guarantee of freedoms given to states, it will facilitate the cultivation of GMOs. However, even if a state refuses to grow a GMO, the laws of the internal market prevent it from prohibiting the circulation of this GMO and the products that come from it, intended for consumption. Health, environmental and food requirements are also not sufficient in the authorisation procedures and in the monitoring of GMO crops. I voted against this text which threatens the health of the peoples of Europe and the independence of farmers who will be held by patented seeds.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. — Conservatives are committed to a science-based approach to regulating GMOs. The science on GMOs is clear, yet this position allows Member States to ban GMO production without clear scientific evidence.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — The neoliberal majority voted in favour of a Directive which gives more power to multinational biotechnology companies. We voted against it on the ground that amending the Directive would speed up the processing of authorisations for new GMOs at European level, which poses a risk to the environment, biodiversity and human and animal health. For Spain, the country with the largest crop area of genetically modified organisms in the EU, this would mean the uncontrolled entry of GMO crops, transgenic contamination of the food chain, as well as impacts on the organic agriculture sector. The new Directive does not provide any compensation for farmers whose crops have been contaminated with transgenic varieties. There is a danger of creating a 'two-speed' Europe: those States most sensitive to the sustainability of their agriculture would have the possibility of banning these crops, while it would be granted a free way to the entry of new transgenic varieties in those States where the interest of the biotechnology industry prevails. The agribusiness lobby has been pushing for a long time to relax restrictions and liberalise - through treaties such as ATCI and AECG - the entry of unauthorized GMO foods into the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — It is our firm position that the cultivation of GMOs in the EU should be banned in general, and the mere fact that so many precautions are provided for possible contamination by GMOs demonstrates the enormous risks to the safety of citizens posed by the introduction of GMOs. We want them to be completely banned and for all research into their development to be banned.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this block vote.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — This Directive gives Member States the possibility to prohibit or limit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) authorised at EU level in their territories, on the basis of environmental reasons such as the maintenance of local biodiversity, socio-economic impacts or land-use criteria, among others. In 2014, the area cultivated with GMOs in Portugal was 8542.41 hectares, according to data from the Ministry of Agriculture. Among the reasons which may be invoked by Member States to justify a ban or restriction of the cultivation of GMOs are environmental criteria, criteria related to spatial planning, land use, socio-economic impacts, agricultural policy objectives and the need to avoid the presence of GMOs in other products. Member States shall ensure that GM crops do not contaminate conventional and organic crops and prevent cross-border contamination, a request expressed by most European farmers.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. — Once again, European ideology and dogmatism run up against common sense.  Indeed, European integration has now reached such a point that any proposal to refer GMO decisions to the Member States runs up against the mille-feuille of European standards that render them inoperative and obsolete. In truth, what is needed is to question the whole of the European Union building. The sovereignty of states, or even the principle of subsidiarity, must be the rule and not the exception, as is the case today.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The initial good intentions of the majority of this Parliament have once again claudicated the economic interests of biotechnology multinationals. Key points have been taken from the initial proposal, such as the principle of coexistence and the introduction of clean areas between neighbouring countries, subverting and weakening the precautionary principle. According to this version of the proposal, States will have to ask multinationals, which produce and market GMOs, to exclude them from their geographical scope. They may accept or refuse such a request. Unacceptable. It is the total submission of political power to the interests of great capital. If doubts remain about how the majority of this Parliament views this issue and its implications, the mere fact that in this text the legal basis of changing environmental protection to the internal market leaves one more of the intentions of this proposal, inseparable from the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement with the US: to meet the commercial objectives of large US biotechnology companies (GMOs producers).  Although the initial intention of the proposal could be seen as an advance on the current situation, negotiations with the Council resulted in an unacceptable text. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The European Commission's intention to give Member States more powers to ban the cultivation of GM crops is a positive step. However, it should not be forgotten that the main factor is not the existing rules, but the demand, which will be very difficult to influence by the possible modification of legislation in the area in question. It is well known in Europe that the primary reason for the low production of GM crops is the lacklustre market interest in their supply. It is impossible to expect farmers to produce something that is very difficult to sell to their trading partners, and moreover, in practice, it often happens that customers explicitly demand evidence that the goods supplied are not genetically modified.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting against this agreement, which does not protect consumers and does not guarantee the Member States the right decision-making power on such a sensitive issue.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: in writing. — (IT) The proposal to amend the directive is yet another example of a liberal culture which, in defiance of the protection of the environment and the health of its citizens, does not want to accept any real regulation amending or preventing the cultivation of GMOs with objective criteria and public instruments of authorisation and control. The terms of this ugly compromise proposed are clear: it is proposed to vote on an all-encompassing mediation text of all the changes negotiated with the Council in three months, after the Council for 3 years (!!) from 2011 to June 2014 had been unable or unwillingness to reach agreement with a common position between the Member States on GMO cultivation.  Indeed, we reiterate here our opposition to a proposal that actually reduces the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, rather than increasing it. We also note that the 'liability' has also disappeared in the final text, that is to say the rule that 'polluter pays' that the EP had demanded and obtained in its text in order to oblige the producer with GMOs, even if authorised, to be responsible anyway and to have to heal accidental contamination on non-GMO fields and crops.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against report A8-0038/2014. It is my firm position that the cultivation of GMOs in the EU should be banned in general. The mere fact that so many precautions are provided for possible contamination by GMOs shows the enormous risks that are hidden to the safety of citizens from the introduction of GMOs. I want a total ban on their cultivation and any research on their development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation at second reading taking into account that the main objective of this legislative change is to give more flexibility and greater legal certainty to Member States wishing to prohibit, in all or part of their territory, the cultivation of gmOs authorised at European level, including citing environmental reasons, such as the protection of biodiversity and the maintenance of habitats and ecosystems. It is important to include in the legislation the obligation of Member States to ensure the coexistence of crops and to avoid, in particular, any cross-border contamination. It is also important to keep in mind the growing disapproval by the European public of GMOs and, in particular, their presence in human food. The text presented for its vote in the European Parliament is in a position to clarify elements of the Council's position which, in Parliament's view, have not been sufficiently clear, as well as the proposals put forward at first reading which the Council was not in good opinion but which are of particular importance.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — I supported this agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. I understand that some safeguard measures could have been further reached, but the agreement reached corresponds to the current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — MEPs and the UK press billed this vote as giving powers in relation to GM crops back to the UK Government. However, that is very misleading. This was in fact a vote on numerous amendments, not on the legislation. Only Amendment 20 actually gave any powers back, and it should have been voted on separately. However, it was lumped together with 50 other amendments, all reasserting the EU’s right to rule over Britain, and therefore I voted against.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - Crucial in winning my support for this report was the fact that, compared to the original Council position, it provides for enhanced environmental impact assessments of new GMOs, stronger measures that allow for better management of the coexistence of GM and non-GM crops, and increased protection against the unwanted influence of biotech companies. I also believe it is vital that the report benefits smaller, traditional or organic farmers who tend to create more employment in the sector than the large industrial farms that are typically involved in GMO cultivation.  Finally, I welcome the fact that ultimately, it would be up to citizens to decide on whether or not their country will be involved in GMO cultivation, as the report allows for flexible and democratic opt-out.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. — I fully support attempts to unblock the Union process granting authorisation to GMOs for cultivation and import, and can appreciate that dealing with cultivation at Member State level may be the only way forward.  However, the agreement reached by the co-legislators contains, in my view, a number of highly unsatisfactory elements which prevent me from supporting the overall agreement. The text adopted today will permit Member States to proceed directly to national bans post-Union authorisation, rather than first being required to seek a more legally sound ‘opt-out’ from authorisation, as initially proposed by the Council. Furthermore, this text will allow for national bans to apply to ‘groups of GMOs’ – rather than being applied on a case-by-case basis – and fails to completely rule out the possibility of Member States citing environmental and public health grounds for national bans. Both of these elements conflict with the EFSA risk assessment process whereby environmental and public health risks of GMOs are examined on a case-by-case basis prior to Union authorisation being granted. As a matter of principle, I cannot accept a proposal which allows for the scientific assessment of GMOs to be undermined in this way. For this reason I abstained during the vote on the trilogue agreement.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — The neoliberal majority voted in favour of a Directive which gives more power to multinational biotechnology companies. We voted against it on the ground that amending the Directive would speed up the processing of authorisations for new GMOs at European level, which poses a risk to the environment, biodiversity and human and animal health. For Spain, the country with the largest crop area of genetically modified organisms in the EU, this would mean the uncontrolled entry of GMO crops, transgenic contamination of the food chain, as well as impacts on the organic agriculture sector. The new Directive does not provide any compensation for farmers whose crops have been contaminated with transgenic varieties. There is a danger of creating a 'two-speed' Europe: those States most sensitive to the sustainability of their agriculture would have the possibility of banning these crops, while it would be granted a free way to the entry of new transgenic varieties in those States where the interest of the biotechnology industry prevails. The agribusiness lobby has been pushing for a long time to relax restrictions and liberalise - through treaties such as ATCI and AECG - the entry of unauthorized GMO foods into the EU.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Genetically modified crops pose a threat to the environment and human and animal health. In countries where GMOs have been cultivated for years, the harmful effects of these crops have already been seen, as is also confirmed by scientific research. Citizens do not want genetically modified food on their plates, so politicians should listen to the public and ban these crops. The only effective solution is to introduce a total ban on GMOs throughout the EU.  I regret that the Union has not introduced such a ban. The agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council is far from ideal. On the one hand, it gives member states the opportunity to ban GMOs and I hope that Polish government will exercise the right in question. On the other hand, it should be careful that this agreement does not open the door to easier legalisation of GMOs in the future. I voted in favour of the agreement because it improves the current legal order, which did not allow Member States to ban these crops on their territory.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs because I believe it is appropriate to respect the principle of subsidiarity, giving Member States more flexibility to decide whether they want GMOs to be produced on their territory, without prejudice to the environmental and human health risk assessment provided for in the EU GMO authorisation system. Also for measures to prevent the unintentional occurrence of GMOs. It is essential that freedom of choice is preserved and clarity is provided for stakeholders on gmo cultivation in the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Ries Report on the Possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs as it provides a legal basis for Member States to restrict or prohibit GMO cultivation in their territory, even where such GMOs have been authorised at EU level. Grounds for prohibiting GMO cultivation may include agriculture policy objectives, land use, socio-economic impacts, public policy and co-existence. For the first time Member States have legal certainty about the cultivation of GMOs, giving them freedom to cultivate or not in line with their own wishes. The amending Directive respects the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — These new rules further open the European door to genetically modified products and Member States are not given enough opportunities to ban genetically engineered crops (GMOs). Biotech companies will adopt a "divide and rule" tactic. When GMOs are admitted in some Member States, other countries will have to follow quickly so as not to disrupt the internal market. 90% of Europeans do not want genetically engineered crops in the fields, let alone in their diets. Member States should be given extensive and legally guaranteed options to ban these crops on their own, even if Brussels does allow them.  The Party for Animals has been opposed to genetic engineering for years, partly because it leads to more monocultures, while a great deal of effort is being made to increase species wealth.  In addition, these GMOs will increase the use of agricultural poison, further reducing the quality of soil, groundwater and surface water. Instead, we need to focus on cleaner organic farming, which is not dependent on agricultural poison.  That is why I voted against this bill.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. — Legislation on GM crops must be based on a scientific evaluation of risks and benefits. It has been a Swedish position ever since we joined the EU 20 years ago, regardless of political colour. It is regrettable that the new Swedish Government has departed from the principle of scientificity when it chose to abstain from Sweden despite the fact that EFSA gave the green light. The Swedish Government thus chose to base its policy on general opinion instead of science. The fact that the government chose not to anchor the decision-in-principle in the EU Board makes matters worse. The proposal for a national ban on GMOs is another step away from scientific knowledge that we cannot support. It risks fragmenting the internal market and thus threatens the free movement that is the cornerstone of European cooperation. European legislation must be characterised by respect for scientific and objective criteria.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. — MEPs in the European Parliament agreed on Tuesday lunchtime on the principle of a compromise on the thorny issue of GMOs. For years, negotiations had been stalled due to the irreconcilable positions of the pro and anti-GMOs.  The response that has been endorsed by the European Parliament is imperfect. You have to admit it.  The system allows Member States that wish to grow GMOs and those who oppose them to ban them legally.  It is therefore an unfinished response that perpetuates a two-tier system. However, this compromise provides legal guarantees which are essential to curb appeals against Member States such as France which are against the cultivation of GMOs.  That is why I have decided to support this approach.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — The Scottish National Party is opposed to the cultivation of GM crops in Scotland: apart from the uncertainties about the long-term environmental effects, Scottish farming relies on a reputation for quality and environmental sensitivity, and we must not jeopardise consumer confidence in any way. We cannot support this legislation as it is designed to promote the spread of GM crops in Europe. It was proposed with the implicit understanding that Member States which banned GM crops on their territory would drop their opposition to authorisation at the EU level. I voted against because this law would not provide enough safeguards to keep Scotland GM-free. The anti-contamination measures would not apply to the border between England and Scotland, which is a serious concern because England will cultivate GM crops. This deal would not prevent the circulation of GM products in Scotland, and it does nothing on GM labelling. We should focus instead on reforming the EU’s environmental risk assessment and authorisation process to reflect the opposition of a majority of Member States and of Europe’s citizens to the imposition of GM technology.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The neoliberal majority voted in favour of a Directive which gives more power to multinational biotechnology companies. We voted against it on the ground that amending the Directive would speed up the processing of authorisations for new GMOs at European level, which poses a risk to the environment, biodiversity and human and animal health. For Spain, the country with the largest crop area of genetically modified organisms in the EU, this would mean the uncontrolled entry of GMO crops, transgenic contamination of the food chain, as well as impacts on the organic agriculture sector. The new Directive does not provide any compensation for farmers whose crops have been contaminated with transgenic varieties. There is a danger of creating a 'two-speed' Europe: those States most sensitive to the sustainability of their agriculture would have the possibility of banning these crops, while it would be granted a free way to the entry of new transgenic varieties in those States where the interest of the biotechnology industry prevails. The agribusiness lobby has been pushing for a long time to relax restrictions and liberalise - through treaties such as ATCI and AECG - the entry of unauthorized GMO foods into the EU.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I support the European Parliament's decision to transfer all the prerogatives concerning the authorisation of the ban on GM crops to the competence of the Member States. That's the right way to go. It is up to the Member States alone to decide what is best for them. Enough of brussels' administrative machinery imposing the decision. Its previous decisions have already led to a crisis in Europe. GM crops are still an area of great uncertainty. It is therefore the Member States that are best able to read the mood of citizens and decide whether to allow them. I also oppose all the attempts made by the European Commission to punish countries where uncontrolled spread will take place. In conclusion, the less power the European Commission has, the better the law in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive amending Directive 2001/18/EC as regards member states' ability to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMO on their territory, as I appreciate that after many years of stalemate, the problem of planting and sowing GMO in Europe is beginning to be addressed. While I am personally an opponent of the application of GMO in Europe and aware that this report does not set such high objectives, it nevertheless opens the possibility for Member States to make their own political and then legal decision not to apply GMO in their territory.  Even as the Istrian prefect, years ago, I initiated the adoption of the Decision that declared the Istrian County a "GMO free" area. This was basically a political position that did not formally have a legal foothold, but also a clear political expression of the leadership of Istria County.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, while Amendment 20 did give powers back, it was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow MEPs to vote on individual amendments – something which UKIP MEPs regard as undemocratic. It is also of clear relevance to UK voters understanding of the implications involved. Therefore, my fellow UKIP MEPs and I could not support this bloc vote.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the agreement on the possibility for Member States to restrict or ban the cultivation of genetically modified organisms.  The agreement provides that Member States wishing to grow GMOs can and that those who want to ban them are free to do so legally. The agreement also provides for the adoption by Member States of coexistence measures in cross-border areas to avoid contamination of traditional crops.  If this two-speed system is not perfect, it allows to put an end to a long period of blurring and blocking that could not satisfy anyone and from which I think it was urgent to get out. Moreover, it has the merit of finally establishing legal stability on this sensitive issue. Thus, thanks to this agreement, states such as France that take measures to ban GMOs will no longer have to justify themselves before the European Court of Justice. I welcome the adoption of this agreement.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. - Euskal Herria Bildu voted against the report on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs because the outcome raises a scenario in which, on the one hand, the right of Member States to prohibit the cultivation of GMOs is restricted but, on the other, the rights of multinational companies are strengthened. In our opinion, opting out of GM cultivation needs to be absolutely legally watertight – and, unfortunately, in the legislation before us this is far from being the case. What we are left with are legal loopholes enabling biotech companies to take countries to court. The concept of a private company being placed on the same footing as a sovereign country is deeply undemocratic and this is a worrying precedent. Furthermore, the liability system has also been removed so that no compensation will be offered to non-GM farmers whose produce is contaminated by GMOs. The European Parliament entered the negotiations with a very good text which could and should have been defended but Parliament has not managed to defend it. EH Bildu is deeply disappointed by the text adopted today, as we simply believe that we must stop GMOs in the EU.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this text, which puts an end to a deadlock after five years of debate between the European institutions. This new legislation gives Member States more freedom to decide whether to cultivate or ban GMOs on their territory, and provides greater legal stability for all parties concerned. It is certainly not possible at the moment to find a single European response to the problem, which would have avoided distortions of competition between European farmers. However, the progress made by the new text, namely: the expanded list of grounds for legally banning the cultivation of GMOs and the creation of coexistence measures in cross-border areas to avoid contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops, should be welcomed.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Allowing Member States to decide separately on the cultivation of GMO crops is the washing of hands by the Union institutions and the discharge of responsibility.  The European Union imports crops, cereals and feed from countries where GMOs are authorised. Banning THE presence of GMOs in European crops would mean distorting competitiveness between EU growers and those countries where they are allowed to do so. Free hand for Member States to decide on GMOs is also a distortion of competition, including in the internal market. In some countries it will be possible to grow modified plants, increase yields and reduce costs, while in others, where there will be a ban, farmers will become un competitive with their neighbours, who will be able to use GMOs. Ordinary farmers will be charged for political decisions that are not always scientifically supported.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Writing. — I supported the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on a proposal allowing EU Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified plants on their territory. This will be possible even if it is authorised by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) at EU level. This compromise text provides a clear legal basis for banning the cultivation of GMO plants on their national territory, thus enabling Member States to say the 'last word' and ensuring that the principle of subsidiarity is met. I believe it is important to give countries a choice on such a very politically sensitive and polarising issue. The new rules will allow Member States to ban GMO crops for various reasons, such as the environment, urban planning, social and economic, as well as to prevent accidental contamination of GMOs in other products and for agricultural policy purposes. Member States will have to ensure that GMO crops do not pollute other products, with a particular focus on preventing cross-border pollution.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. — This request allows Member States to prohibit the cultivation of GMO crops for environmental, social and health reasons. This is a proposal which is basically to be supported because it leads to an improvement in the current situation. However, it is important to bear in mind that it is questionable whether the Member States' bans are being complied with and whether there is sufficient legal certainty. GMO groups can appeal to arbitration courts, as can a ECJ ruling that such a ban affects the free movement of goods and the mutual recognition of standards and authorisations. Furthermore, it is unclear how long this proposal will be valid: the agreement between Parliament and the Council provides for a review for 2020, but it may be that a) there is no extension or b) the Council considers that the parameters have changed and that a general ban on GMO crops is no longer necessary. Similarly, there is a lack of consumer protection provisions on GMO-contaminated food, so that the ban on cultivation in one country can be circumvented by cultivation, processing and export from another country. I believe that, while the proposal is a one-way move, it is far from sufficient: there is a need for an EU-wide ban on GMOs. That is why I abstained.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the strong measures to allow Member States to limit or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory if they so wish. I believe this compromise allows national governments to take into  account both scientific evidence and citizens’ concerns before making a decision on whether or not to introduce GMO cultivation.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The new GMO rules meet Member States that have banned or plan to prohibit the cultivation of GM plants in their territory, providing an appropriate legal basis and facilitating the decision to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs. However, this prohibition may not apply to scientific research and the marketing of modified seeds. This is important in view of the fact that technologies using genetic engineering are widely used in medicine, in the manufacture of medicines, m.in. insulin, in the study of disease mechanisms, e.g. cancer, in transplantation and many other fields.  The new rules do not restrict countries that grow GMOs on a large scale and still plan to do so. The ban on GMO cultivation remains an option to choose from, depending on the local environmental situation and social attitude.  GMOs are a great hope of humanity, but also of certain risks. Therefore, the current regulations must be complemented by national rules that will ensure adequate control and safety of production using GMOs and guarantee protection against contamination of other products and infection of the territories of neighbouring countries.  The new rules will allow countries such as Poland, where agriculture is based on traditional organic farming methods, to make full use of the ecological and health potential of crops. It is crucial to ensure competitive prices for healthy food so that it is not a luxury item accessible only to the richest.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) With today's vote by the European Parliament on the reform of the GMO directive, we have finally established the right of Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on national territory. This is also at the expense of an authorisation granted at European level by the Food Safety Agency. In the immediate future, therefore, Italy will be able to decide to say no to GMO crops in its territory as a result of socio-economic considerations, land use, land use, land-use planning, transgenic contamination of other crops, as well as mere choices of agricultural and environmental policy. This decision represents a great achievement for our country, which has always been in favour of a quality and environmentally friendly agri-food model. All that remains now is to activate the procedures for national transposition without delay.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - After four years of negotiations, we have managed to reach a difficult agreement on the sensitive issue of GMOs. It recognises the sovereignty and autonomy of each Member State with regard to the possibility, in full respect of the principle of subsidiarity, of prohibiting or restricting, in whole or part of their territory, the cultivation of GMOs which have been authorised or which are under the authorisation procedure at European level. This choice can be exercised on the basis of strict criteria, not contrary to EFSA's health and environmental risk assessment, and the needs of citizens, consumers and individual States will therefore be protected. I would like to thank the rapporteur, the colleagues who have worked on this dossier, as well as Minister Galletti, for the cooperative spirit that has enabled us to reach the best possible agreement, given all the circumstances.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The cultivation of genetically modified organisms has been the subject of a heated debate for years. I therefore welcome the recent decision of the European Parliament to give Member States the right to decide on the authorisation or ban of GMOs. Food safety and health issues are the prerogatives of the Member States, so many debates, sometimes even controversial, are not in the interests of the Member States, but can best be addressed in the interests of the Member State.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this very important European directive on genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The aim was to fill the legal gap that existed in this area at European level, by giving a common legal basis to the Member States. They will now have a legislative framework to practice, restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. This directive is a compromise which does not in reality fully satisfy either pro-GMOs or anti-GOs, but which has the merit of framing the cultivation of GMOs and their marketing within the Internal Market, including in cross-border areas.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
