text: In writing. — The so-called "a la carte" authorisation proposal will certainly facilitate national refusals of crops of genetically modified organisms, but in turn it will favour European authorisations since States will no longer fear being forced by the Commission to allow crops on their territory. Moreover, the logic of authorisation is reinforced by the fact that the very foundations of future national bans are fragile, since on articles related to the Internal Market while Parliament demanded that the legal basis of the text be the environment. Therefore, I refused to join this Pyrrhic victory and voted against it. It has just broken the common European front against GMOs, at the very moment when the Commission is negotiating a major trade agreement with the United States.  Through this national approach it is eroding European opposition to genetically modified American products. How can this ban be continued if at the same time we allow the cultivation of the same GMOs in some European countries? It is at best a tactical error, at worst a voluntary calculation by the Commission negotiators, which I reject as a whole.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. — With this directive, Member States will have the opportunity to ban or allow the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. Due to free movement, the number of GMO-based products is likely to increase sharply in retail trade in all countries. This directive is therefore not acceptable.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. "I voted against this text because it is a decoy intended to deceive the citizens. On the surface, it respects the sovereignty of states since it allows them to prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. But in reality, it doesn't change anything for consumers. Because with the freedom of movement of goods, GMOs will come to French supermarkets from the European states that allow them. And French consumers will eat GMOs without knowing it. It is therefore a text that gives satisfaction to multinationals at the expense of state sovereignty and also of human health, because it must be remembered that GMOs are generally designed to withstand massive doses of Roundup, which are then found in food.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because Parliament wants us to believe that a state can prevent the consumption of GMOs on its territory. This is totally impossible in a globalized economy in the hands of multinationals, where borders no longer exist. True sovereignty must allow a state to be able to ban the consumption of GMOs or, if necessary, to support national research independent of lobbies.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — Positioning itself on an initial Commission proposal, the European Parliament voted in 2011 to expand the list of cases of restriction and prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). In 2014, the Council adopted a radically different proposal, which greatly limited the assumptions of a ban on GMOs. While Parliament was able to partially restore its initial position by means of the amendments made to the report as it passed through the Committee on the Environment, the final wording departs from what was adopted in 2011 and introduces enormous ambiguity respect for the cases in which States could ban the cultivation of a GMO.  In addition, the regulation of GMOs was restored to the domestic market and almost entirely diluted the financial responsibility regime previously advocated by Parliament.  The rewording makes it easier for large GMO multinationals to market their crops despite opposition from European states and peoples concerned about their consequences, without an adequate mechanism to compensate for the risks arising from this liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, The Sweden Democrats could not support this block vote.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I am not afraid of genetically modified maize, but I believe that Member States should have the right to authorise or not to authorise the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. I am voting in favour of this amendment in order to avoid blocking authorisations at EU level where there are Member States that do not want GM crops on their territory.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In July 2010, the European Commission made its proposal allowing Member States to decide on a ban on the cultivation of GMO on their territory. After more than 4 years of negotiations in the Council and Parliament, an agreement has been reached.  Given the high sensitivity of Member States to the cultivation of GMO products, this topic has caused major disagreements within the Union where 149 000 hectares cover GMO crops, mainly in Spain and Portugal, which are also the largest producers in the European Union.  On the other hand, the 21 members of the European Union, including Croatia, do not allow sowing of GMO crops.  This document allows Member States, under certain conditions, to limit or ban GMO crops on their territory even though this same crop is authorized at EU level.  This has achieved political consensus and demonstrated the Union's willingness to listen to and take account of the demands of its citizens when making decisions. I support this report because it allows for the choice of what is of particular importance for Croatia, but I also express the need for quality control of these crops in order to preserve GMOs of clean territories.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — An important step has been taken in the European Parliament today to resolve the case relating to the cultivation of genetically modified food within the European Union. MePs and I have adopted changes to European legislation that allow each EU Member State to take the final decision on the restriction or total ban of GMOs on its territory. The amended legislation provides further legal clarity by allowing countries such as Bulgaria to prohibit the cultivation of GMOs, citing specific grounds related to socio-economic reasons, specific environmental objectives, etc.   The role of the European Food Safety Agency (EASA), which has the right to give an opinion on the safety of a particular GMO product on the basis of in-depth research, remains. Each Member State shall now be free to decide for itself whether to follow the opinion of EASA or to define a regime which is consistent with its national specificities. It is important to note that the texts also require a high level of guarantee from countries that grow GMOs on their territory so as to ensure the protection of the production of neighbouring countries.   Once again, the EP has demonstrated that it ensures that maximum nutritional standards are ensured for the protection of the interest and health of its consumers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — I supported a law that will allow Member States of the European Union to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified plants in their territories, even if authorised by the EU. The proposal, which was informally agreed by the European Parliament and the Council of the EU last December, was tabled as early as 2010, but it took four years for the Member States to reach a common position and was actually only today.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - I personally have a problem with the use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). However, I am aware that we are only able to develop active substances for hundreds of incurable diseases thanks to GMOs. The problem relates solely to the cultivation of GMOs for harvesting or open field research. Imports of GMOs intended primarily for livestock feeding are not covered by this legislation. The main objective of this amendment is to provide wider scope and greater legal certainty for Member States wishing to prohibit the cultivation of GMOs authorised at European level in all or part of their territory. This give the Member State greater independence. It will itself be able to decide to prohibit the use of GMOs on its territory. In the EU, we have some of the strictest rules in the world, and this regulation is a further tightening. I therefore support this compromise.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against this Recommendation because I believe that the Council's position does not confer unlimited power on EU Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I supported this proposal. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, outlining Commission policy to the MEPs on 15 July 2014, set out his intentions: ‘I also intend to review the current legislation authorising the use of genetically modified organisms. I consider it unacceptable that, under current rules, the Commission is legally obliged to authorise the import and processing of new GMOs, even in cases where a clear majority of Member States are opposed to their use.’ In this climate it is right that Member States be given the right to make decisions on GMO cultivation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — In favour of the directive "the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms - GMOs - on their territory". The main objective of this amendment allows individual Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of crops containing genetically modified organisms - GMOs - throughout their territory or part of it so that national and local specificities can be taken into account. The new text, which introduces clear rules in relation to the 2001 directive, helps to provide greater legal certainty as to whether each Member State can decide whether to ban or restrict gm crops even if permitted in the Eu ropean Union.  More than 4 years after the European Commission's original proposal, the European Union has finally reached an important agreement on this issue.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) The aim of the proposal is to provide the Member States with a solid legal basis, establishing criteria for restricting, or prohibiting, the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) within their territories.  The original draft legislation, drawn up by the European Commission, dates back to July 2010. After four years, thanks to an appreciable joint effort on the part of Parliament and the Council, an agreement has finally been reached. My support for mr Ries' report stems from the conviction that the compromise negotiated is the only one possible.   The Member States have very different positions on the cultivation of GMOs. I therefore think it is right that they should be guaranteed decision-making and judgment in this area.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. — I voted against the reason for considering that the cultivation of GMOs poses a serious danger to health, the environment and biodiversity. The decision on this matter cannot be left to the Member States because it is a decision that has repercussions beyond source, not only because of the risk of contamination but also for the distribution and sale of GMO products, even in countries where cultivation is prohibited. Returning the decision in this matter to the Member States is a poisoned gift, because the rights and health of European citizens are being called into question under a false cover of strengthening national sovereignty. It is therefore a farce, especially when we know this is one of the issues that will be negotiated under the Transatlantic Partnership Agreement

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The preparation is inadequate. Unfortunately, it is still possible to import GMOs into food in other Member States.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Ries report on the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs, as it provides a legal basis for Member States to restrict or prohibit GMO cultivation in their territory even where such GMOs have been authorised at EU level. Grounds for prohibiting GMO cultivation may include agriculture policy objectives, land use, socio-economic impacts, public policy and co-existence. For the first time Member States have legal certainty about the cultivation of GMO, giving them freedom to cultivate or not in line with their own wishes. The amending directive respects the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: in writing. — Unblocking the 15-year deadlock on GM cultivation is something I very much welcome. But giving Member States the right to ban their cultivation on non-scientific grounds sets a dangerous precedent. We need to encourage science and innovation, not deter it. We need to base decisions on scientific evidence, not uninformed prejudice. There are enormous benefits that biotechnology can provide. I recently visited Rothamsted Research Station. It is the longest-running agricultural research station in the world, providing cutting-edge science and innovation for nearly 170 years. I was especially interested to hear about their work on Omega-3 oils. These oils have proved to be beneficial to human health. They are currently only available through marine fish. Rothamsted has developed Camelina plants that accumulate Omega-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids in their seeds, thus providing a novel method of creating a terrestrial source of this essential oil, utilising existing farming practice and machinery. This is what GM cultivation is really about: GM technology has much to offer us and we should not deprive our citizens of its potential benefits.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree that Member States have the possibility to limit or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory, in accordance with this now adopted proposal. I also agree with the amendments proposed by the EP which add measures to prohibit or limit the cultivation of GMOs in all or part of the national territory. We must also be able to rely on local or regional environmental reasons and socio-economic impacts in order to carry out these prohibitions. Member States should also, when deciding, take into into mind reasons relating to socio-economic impacts, such as the unfeasibility or high cost of coexistence measures and the risk of contamination of conventional or organic agriculture by GMOs. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because it confirms that it will be up to the Member States to decide on whether to restrict or ban GMOs from their territory. It also recognises that the cultivation of GMOs is an issue that is more thoroughly addressed at Member State level; whilst preserving the internal market by ensuring that the importation of GMOs remains regulated at Union level. It is also important that modifications were proposed to ensure the transparency of the procedure to restrict or prohibit GMO cultivation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I congratulate Frédérique Ries on the adoption of this report, which aims to give Member States a wider legal basis for refusing to grow GMOs on their territory despite the authorisation of seeds by the European Food Safety Authority. In the face of the concerns of our fellow citizens, some Member States want to ban the cultivation of GMOs more. However, they face a legal deadlock that calls into question compliance with current EU legislation. This report therefore makes it possible to better frame the rejection of this culture while giving Member States more flexibility.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing — On the issue of GMOs, GMOs, it is important that we protect the health and safety of EU citizens and Member States in the first place. The vast majority of European citizens do not wish to grow and consume GM crops - nor are animals genetically modified for consumption. From today, Even Member States that do not explicitly wish to do so have a clear right not to grow GMOs on their territory. A minority of states that already grow GMOs must take measures to prevent contamination of fields by those that grow such crops, we are referring here to fields in border areas. The text approved by the Council and, today, by the European Parliament, enshrines the possibility for Member States to opt out of gmOs on their territory, which I believe increases the rights within the meaning of the subsidiarity of the Member States. There is also a safeguard clause against importers from abroad so that they cannot enforce in court the right to import such crops despite their dissuasion to grow them in a country. I think that this text will strengthen three principles, although it is not yet completely perfect, it is a compromise. The three principles are transparency, health and safety.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. — While I welcome the return of national governments to a power that should never have been taken away from them by the EU, I voted against this proposal because it does not give states sufficient legal guarantees to ban genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their own territory.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — The EU authorisation system for GMOs aims at avoiding possible adverse effects on human and animal health and the environment, while establishing an internal market for GM products. However, the existing rules are not sufficient anymore to guarantee flexibility and legal certainty to Member States who want to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs after they have been authorised at EU level. Therefore, I voted in favour of the new rules, which will introduce more legal certainty with regard to the cultivation of GM crops, more flexibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit GM cultivation on their territory, and obligatory coexistence measures to protect GMO-free countries from cross-border contamination by GMOs.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. — (IT) This Parliament has today called on us to take a decision on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their territories. I voted against this measure. I am against this because the good intentions of this agreement contradict the way in which Europe is actually acting. I think it is pointless to give this possibility to individual states, when at the same time the EU is about to enter into trade agreements that also cover agricultural products with countries such as the United States and beyond. There is no point in giving consent to this paradox for which we will still have the products of our land, but they will have to resist competition from GMO products that Europe will be invading after the conclusion of agreements such as TTIP. There is still no point in opening the door to the large multinationals that will exploit the availability of those countries that have not imposed the ban, once again creating a gap - especially an economic gap - between the EU countries. That is why I am asking you to open your eyes and put the health of citizens and the protection of businesses that guarantee eco-sustainable agriculture at the top of your agenda.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — This is an extremely sensitive and controversial subject, which has been under political and legislative debate since the beginning of the Barroso II Commission. In the context of a permanent deadlock at Council level, it is ultimately a common sense solution to enable Member States to decide whether or not to accept GMO crops. It will be important that the co-existence rules of GMO crops with other "normal" crops are solid, so as not to allow the "infestation" of classical crops with genetics from genetically modified ones. The decision does not change the rules of international trade in any way: genetically modified soybeans, for example, can be imported into the EU as before. The only change is that the Member States, and not Brussels, be it the Council or the Commission, will have the hardest say in the decision approving the cultivation, after the EU specialist agency decides that, scientifically speaking, crops are OK in terms of the health of consumers, other plants, etc.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — Despite a misleading title, the text on GMOs put to the vote is not satisfactory in several respects. It amounts to a ban on the importation and free movement of GMOs in territories that have banned the cultivation of GMOs. Such a ban must be validated by the Commission. In the event of a cultivation ban, farmers cannot exploit the technology, but consumers would still find these GMOs on their plates, without the possibility of tracing. Therefore, it is appropriate to vote against this text. GMOs as imposed on us by multinational agrochemical companies and the European Union are unacceptable and dangerous: increased pesticides, enslavement of farmers, ecological disasters on flora and fauna. In order to achieve food sovereignty, GMO technology is acceptable in France under only three conditions: that the State can decide on improvements and properties to be made, that it can be able to produce them on our territory according to our own uses, that it be controlled by the market. The FN is not, on these terms, opposed to further reflection, in particular to prevent a growing technological gap between Europe and the United States.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this recommendation which would amend the 2001/18/EC directive and give Member States the opportunity to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. Even if, on the surface, this text seems to restore some sovereignty to the Member States, in reality it will not be, the very principle of free movement in the European Union distorting the situation from the outset. The ultra-liberal economic model advocated by Brussels will in all cases allow the importation of products from third countries authorising GMOs, destined for EU countries banning them. As Member States no longer have any control over their national borders, the legislation or budgets allocated for this recommendation are just another artifice. Nothing here will prevent multinational agri-food companies and mass retailers from continuing to make profits on the backs of consumer health and nature. The EU, by remaining deaf to the injunctions of European citizens, who overwhelmingly condemn GMOs, remains subject to the lobbies of the agri-food industry. As for the next free trade treaty with the United States, it will obviously only make this situation worse with the application of total deregulation.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as I believe that it leaves the door open for the introduction of a ban on GMO cultivation should such a policy be adopted by any future Labour government. In addition, it also provides for strengthened environmental impact assessment of new GMOs as well as more robust coexistence measures for better management of GM and non-GM crops.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text which clarifies the possibilities for Member States to authorise or not the cultivation of Genetically Modified Organizations (GMOs) on their territory. This text increases legal certainty and keeps Member States the final say in deciding whether or not to allow the cultivation of GMOs. It also provides for the adoption by Member States of coexistence measures in cross-border areas to prevent contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. — On Tuesday 13 January, I voted in favour of the report providing for the possibility for Member States to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. After five years of debate between the European Parliament and the Council, this text does not offer an ideal answer, but helps to unblock the current situation. Member States will be able to ban or allow gmOs to be grown on their soil if they wish, without fear of prosecution. Until now, the lack of clear legislation has made vulnerable states that, like France, were initiating procedures to ban these crops. It also provides for measures of coexistence around cross-border areas, in order to avoid contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops. I support this compromise, which should, in the long run, lead to a European-wide answer.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this recommendation because, first of all, it makes it possible to overcome the deadlock which we have been in for four years because of the disagreement between Member States for or against GMOs, but also because the main objective of this legislative amendment is precisely to provide greater flexibility and greater legal certainty.  These new rules contain greater discretion for Member States, allowing them to limit or ban GMOs on their territory for reasons 'different' from those resulting from EFSA's scientific assessments, i.e. environmental reasons, such as the protection of biodiversity or the conservation of habitats and ecosystems. We consider it important, for the protection of European consumers, to provide for an obligation for Member States not only to guarantee non-contamination of other products, but above all to avoid cross-border contamination with neighbouring countries, which is required and supported by certain european farmers' associations. Finally, we call for new actions to ensure transparency and publicity of the procedure for restricting or banning the cultivation of GMOs in Europe.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Ries on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their national territory.  There is a need for greater flexibility and decision-making autonomy in this area, which is very much felt by our citizens who are increasingly opposed to this type of food, considering it unsafe for future generations.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this draft legislation which allows Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. The draft legislation aims to complement the existing regulatory framework for GMOs in order to allow Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory. The proposed measures relate only to the cultivation of GMOs, and the authorisation system for GMOs at EU level, based on scientific basis, remains unchanged.  The legislative proposal responds to the call of the Member States to have more freedom in the application of a national policy in the field of GMO cultivation, both to Member States interested in restriction and to those interested in the cultivation of GMOs at national level.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: in writing. — Many scare stories are spread about on the issue of GM foods, but all too often these are not evidence-based. In matters like this, I am always guided by one key principle – follow the science. Allowing bans on GM foods on ambiguous grounds does not make for good policy. Policy must be based on sound science. If the EU turns its back on technological innovation in the agri-food industry, how are we to meet the great challenge of ensuring food security and sustainability? With the world population expected to exceed 9 billion in 2050, we will have to face up to producing more food from the same amount of land. If GM crops can produce higher yields and are resistant to disease without having a negative impact on human health, then I believe we should be more open to exploring their use, if that is the direction Member States wish to take. While I welcome the proposal, insofar as it goes some way to breaking the GM logjam, it does not ultimately provide a balanced, reasonable outcome on this issue, and that is why I chose to abstain.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. — The proposal on the possibility for states to limit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory constitutes a compromise that could remedy today's ambiguous situation in this area. Furthermore, it is positive that the way in which the safety and usability of GMOs in our agriculture is decided in Europe is not called into question, and that EFSA's position is not weakened. Unfortunately, I believe that such a large and easy option for countries based on not scientific but political reasons to ban the use of GMOs is wrong. It means a certain weakening of the principle of the single market and may set a precedent for other similar decisions. Moreover, given the benefits of using GMO techniques in a number of areas, I consider it to be not very functional and potentially leading to further problematic decisions. For me, these negatives outweighed the benefits of the proposal , which is why I did not support it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — (DE) I abstained from this vote because, although the basic idea of the directive is to be supported, its drafting is flawed. The possibility of introducing genetically modified organisms into food from other EU countries remains. Furthermore, there is no legal certainty for those states that do not use genetically modified organisms. Lawsuits could be the result.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This new framework for the banning of GMO cultivation by Member States may at first seem to be a favourable development to end the cultivation of GMOs in the European Union. However, it is quite the opposite that it engenders. Indeed, by nationalising the decision to authorise or ban the cultivation of GMOs, we are taking the risk of a great disparity in the use of GMOs in Europe, and therefore of possible cross-border contamination, but also of a distorted competitiveness between European farmers. Moreover, the pressure from the major international GMO-producing firms is well known, and this will now be exerted on each Member State. It is therefore highly feared that, contrary to what was put forward as an argument in favour of this proposal, the cultivation of GMOs will be expanded in Europe and that it will pose even more difficulties than before. For these reasons, I voted against this proposal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because it allows Member States to decide on the restriction or prohibition of GMOs on their own territory, which in turn will help to better plan and implement environmental policy objectives.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC shall give the Member States of the European Union flexibility to restrict or prohibit crops containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in their own territories.  The uncoverings between pro and anti-GMO countries have made this proposal blocked since 2010. This new legislation achieves a balance and simplifies the procedure so that countries can choose the regime to be followed without interfering with or colliding with the authorisation criteria of the body concerned issued by the European Food Safety Authority. That is why, in line with the position of the ALDE group, I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this directive. In particular, Member States will be given more leeway and legal certainty. They will be able to decide for themselves whether to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their territory. This directive is a major step forward in the efforts to protect its citizens from potential adverse effects. Thus, public inters and fundamental values will be taken into account in the decision on GMOs in each case.  It should be noted that to date there are no detailed studies showing the impact of GMOs on human health. In addition, allowing the cultivation of GMOs, however limited, would destroy organic or other susceptible to the effects of GMOs on farms. It is therefore essential that the states that produce GMOs implement the protection measures in an appropriate manner so that they are not on the border and do not spread to neighbouring countries. It is also essential that the EU institutions carry out strict controls and ensure a research-based risk assessment of gmo cultivation.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments, which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this block vote.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that on 23 July last, the 28 Environment Ministers adopted the Council's position on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory; Whereas it is a question of amending Directive 2001/18/EC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms, by inserting a new article extending the rights of The Member States in order to justify legally a ban at national or regional level on the cultivation of a GMO; Given that the main objective of this change to the legislative framework is to give greater flexibility and greater legal certainty to Member States wishing to prohibit, throughout their territory or part of it, the cultivation of GMOs authorised on a European scale, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — Banning the cultivation of GMOs when we do not have the ability to control and ban the importation of GMO products makes no sense. Maintaining the free movement of food under these conditions is absurd and yet this is what is planned. This text is a charade that claims to give sovereignty to peoples while taking away the possibility of knowing what they are consuming. In addition, farmers in countries that ban GMOs will be subject to unfair competition from those who allow them. So I'm voting against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) The new rules which Parliament has adopted to regulate the cultivation of genetically modified organisms are a good compromise which leaves the Member States wide discretion in their decision whether or not to grant authorization to these crops. This reform is a great step forward in terms of clarity and legal certainty: the central role of the Food Safety Agency is maintained and strengthened, and at the same time the list of reasons why Member States can prohibit such crops is being extended. Another important step for which our group has fought concerns the new strict rules to protect territories that choose not to grow GMOs and thus avoid contamination between different crops. I therefore voted in favour of this reform because I believe that it is a good compromise on a very sensitive issue and on which it is not easy to reach agreement among the many opinions on this subject. With this new directive, those who do not want to grow GMOs will be able to do so without the risk of contamination in a context of clarity and transparency that has so far been lacking.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. — I want to thank my rapporteur and colleagues and support the many provisions that have improved This proposal by Parliament, such as border buffer zones that would prevent contamination between Member States. I would also like to point out the problems of Member States located at the Union's external borders and bordering on countries where GMO is allowed and not protected. I also welcome the new provision that Member States ask the Commission, rather than biotechnology companies, not to grant GMO authorisations on their territory. I also regret that the proposal does not include a financial liability provision for any damages that would result in the introduction of GMO on the market. Lastly, I would like to proudly point out that in Croatia all counties have declared themselves GMO-free zones. Croatian GMO technologies are definitely not needed due to the good structure of production in farming and the abundance of area that we can additionally use.  The detrimental impact on the environment, biodiversity and local agricultural production, as well as public resistance, are legitimate reasons for Member States wishing to do so to have the right to restrict the introduction of GMO on their market.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC as regards member states' ability to limit or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory, as I believe that a high-quality legal framework governing the cultivation of GMOs should be established, precisely to ensure the safe development of modern biotechnology, namely GMOs. This framework follows the global objective of ensuring a high degree of protection of life, health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests, while ensuring that the internal market works effectively. Member States, in line with the principle of subsidiarity and through a two-stage procedure, are given more flexibility to decide whether they wish to grow GMOs crops on their territory. Food control needs to be improved in its entirety, in order to maintain the steady growth of the world's population, to combat hunger and climate change, which will make fertile soil much more difficult to process. At a session held on 24 December 2008, the Government of the Republic of Croatia adopted a Decision establishing a Council on Genetically Modified Organisms, which will, among other things, monitor the state and development in the field of genetic technology use and use of GMOs, monitor professional and scientific achievements, give opinions and advise competent authorities regarding the use of GMOs and genetic technology, and report to the public.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — I am glad that the European Parliament adopted the rapporteur's proposal at second reading, as in this case he has fully demonstrated his role as a defender of the interests of citizens of EU Member States in a situation where the european legislation in force has put member states in a stalemate. As early as 2011, the European Parliament made it clear that it takes citizens' concerns very seriously and that it supports Member States in their competence to decide on the use of GMOs on their territory. I am convinced of the correctness of leaving competences at Member State level, as the real impact of GMOs on whole ecosystems has not yet been reliably demonstrated, and thus less refuted. At the same time, I oppose the Council's obligation to introduce the so-called phase 1, whereby a Member State is required to explicitly ask an undertaking seeking to place GMOs on the market in the EU not to apply for such an application in its national territory. I also supported the rapporteur's proposal in this regard. Last but not least, it should be stressed that the environment should be the legal basis for the new legislation, as the European Parliament has already expressed in its first reading decision.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — I am in favour of amending Directive 2001/18/EC, which extends the rights of Member States to be able to issue a ban, at national or regional level, on the cultivation of a GMO. It is important that the placing on the market of GMOs is only permitted after authorisation has been issued on the basis of a scientific assessment of the risks to human, animal and environmental health, even if imports of GMOs intended for animal feed do not fall within the scope of this regulation. I also agree with what President Junckers of the European Commission has said, namely the need to review the legislation applicable to the authorisation of genetically modified organisms and that it is unusual, under the current rules, for the Commission to be legally obliged to authorise the import and processing of new organisms even when a clear majority of Member States oppose it. Let us remember that the main objective to be pursued by amending the legislative framework is to give greater legal power to Member States wishing to prohibit/restrict, throughout their territory or part of it, the cultivation of GMOs authorised on a European scale.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The compromise reached provides that Member States may prohibit the cultivation of "GMO varieties or groups of GMO varieties", citing certain reasons. The Agreement also introduces mandatory measures for those countries which authorise the cultivation of GMOs to protect the border areas of neighbouring countries 'unless such measures are not necessary due to geographical conditions'. I therefore supported the compromise that has been submitted, which, while far from ideal, stipulates that states may consider that they do not want to allow GMOs to be grown in all or part of their territory. Member States should be empowered to decide whether or not to promote agricultural products based on agriculture using natural methods. For my country, Polish, this is a particularly important benefit, as agricultural production boasts healthy, natural food.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The legal instability surrounding the control of GMOs in the European Union could have called into question the will of states that do not want to see GMOs established on their territory. The text proposed before the European Parliament reflects the antagonistic positions of the Member States, but nevertheless has the merit of clarifying this situation. It will now be possible for Member States, from this starting point of departure, to establish under EFSA's control or not to establish GMO crops on their territory. In addition, very strict legal criteria are governed by the authorisation of GMOs. It should be stressed that these restrictions are accompanied by measures that place expertise on an equal footing, ensuring the prevention of GMO trace consumers in their diets and creating buffer zones between Member States. France will therefore be able to continue to refuse GMOs on its territory, without fear of any questioning of any companies or states. On the contrary, if the French population were ever to accept GMOs, they could do so on the basis of scientific studies validated by the health authorities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The amendment to the current EU legislative framework on GMOs aims to give more latitude and greater legal certainty to Member States wishing to ban, in all or part of their territories, the cultivation of GMOs allowed at European level. Such prohibitions or limitations shall be based on grounds other than those covered by the health and environmental risk assessment that is part of the EU authorisation process. Among the reasons which may be invoked by Member States to justify a ban or restriction on the cultivation of GMOs are environmental criteria that complement the criteria assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) at European level, criteria relating to spatial planning, land use, socio-economic impacts, agricultural policy objectives and the need to avoid the presence of GMOs in other products. Because I believe that such a proposal will give European countries greater freedom to address specific national or local issues raised by the cultivation of GMOs, while also helping to facilitate the process of granting authorisations in this area, I voted in favour.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. — I believe that this step is a useful one in unlocking the European decision-making process with regard to the discussions in recent years on the GMO authorisation process at European level, bearing in mind that the legislative proposal only concerns responding to the request from the Member States of the European Union to be able to restrict or prohibit, where appropriate, the cultivation of a GMO culture and does not in any way alter the European authorisation system. I argue that Romania must be able to decide independently of other countries whether it wants to restrict or ban a GMO crop. Furthermore, the fact that Member States that will grow GMOs will be required to take measures to avoid cross-border contamination should be regarded as a respectful action towards the decision of other States, which decide differently.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, while Amendment 20 did give powers back, it was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and reasserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments – and we regard this as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support the bloc vote.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text and Amendment 52, which repeats the terms of the agreement reached with the Council on the sensitive issue of the cultivation of GMOs. It is a good thing that we have emerged from the current impasse and have been able to overcome the deadlock between "pro" and "anti-GMO" on this text. I supported this compromise because it takes up several key points in this matter: first, the safeguarding of the European character of the system, while opening up the possibility, for Member States that wish to do so, of restricting or banning the cultivation of GMOs on their own territory. Secondly, at the technical level, the rebalancing between the role of companies and that of The Member States during the two phases, and furthermore, the greater flexibility as to the types of grounds that can be invoked to justify the ban. I also welcome the obligation to provide for an update to the Directive on the Environmental Assessment of GMO Risks. And finally, the obligation to avoid contamination in case of coexistence between GMO and non-GMO crops. For these reasons, I supported the text, which we came to after four years of work.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment. We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - The neoliberal majority voted in favour of a Directive which gives more power to multinational biotechnology companies. We voted against it on the ground that amending the Directive would speed up the processing of authorisations for new GMOs at European level, which poses a risk to the environment, biodiversity and human and animal health. For Spain, the country with the largest crop area of genetically modified organisms in the EU, this would mean the uncontrolled entry of GMO crops, transgenic contamination of the food chain, as well as impacts on the organic agriculture sector. The new Directive does not provide any compensation for farmers whose crops have been contaminated with transgenic varieties. There is a danger of creating a 'two-speed' Europe: those States most sensitive to the sustainability of their agriculture would have the possibility of banning these crops, while it would be granted a free way to the entry of new transgenic varieties in those States where the interest of the biotechnology industry prevails. The agribusiness lobby has been pushing for a long time to relax restrictions and liberalise - through treaties such as ATCI and AECG - the entry of unauthorized GMO foods into the EU.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament confirmed the agreement in principle reached in December on this compromise text which will amend the 2001/18/EC directive and give Member States the opportunity to limit or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. Although it significantly improves the European Commission's original proposal and allows the EU to be removed from a status quo deemed untenable, this compromise is certainly not a panacea. I have therefore corrected my initial vote because this new legislation is supposed to give states the means to prevent the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, but in fact gives biotechnology companies the power to negotiate with elected governments and excludes the legal argument for banning these crops: proof of environmental damage. States should be the sole risk managers, retain their right to prevent the spread of GMOs on their territory and should not require the approval of companies seeking to take advantage of GMO crops. However, this compromise formalizes the role of the industry, which I reject. Finally, I regret that this new compromise enshrines a form of de-deferralisation.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. — I voted against because the directive is, in principle, harmful: it will enable the cultivation of GMOs in Europe. Debates in the EP and public opinion polls show both MEPs and the public's opposition to GMOs. Today, the European Parliament had a great opportunity to ban GMOs in Europe. Instead, through the efforts of the big groups and the small right groups, we have created an opaque, uncertain system of national authorisations that will not only guarantee safe food, but also create huge opportunities for corruption promoted by the lobbyists of the large crop industry corporations. I am afraid to turn out to be right, but reluctantly gives the impression that many MePs today have only played a role in the role of statists in the pre-gmo lobby-driven spectacle.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Following the Council's position adopted on 23 July 2014 by the 28 Ministers for the Environment of the Union, with a view to restricting or banning the cultivation of GMOs in their territories, the recommendation is now being made for the adoption of a directive aimed at extending member states' rights in this area through a strict legal framework which will only allow the marketintroduction of GMOs after authorisation based on a scientific assessment of risks to human and animal health as well as the environment. As can be read in the text of the Recommendation, it is in practice to amend Directive 2001/18/EC on the deliberate release of GMOs into the environment, as well as the authorised cultivation of GMOs under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on food and feed containing GMOs or produced from these organisms. In view of this phactic circumstantiality, I agree with the amendments to the proposal which essentially seek to give greater latitude and greater legal certainty to Member States wishing to ban, in all or part of their territories, the cultivation of GMOs, unlocking a deadlock that has persisted since the European Parliament's vote at first reading on 5 July 2011.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. — After 4 years, Parliament has finally adopted a recommendation providing reference points for the cultivation of GMO products. I voted in favour of this recommendation not so much because I consider it to be the best of all, but because it is the best that could be achieved at the moment. Leaving Member States the freedom to choose whether to ban or restrict the cultivation of GMOs for specific reasons is a good starting compromise.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it because the measure is not intended to protect farmers but the usual multinationals in the sector.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — The neoliberal majority voted in favour of a Directive which gives more power to multinational biotechnology companies. We voted against it on the ground that amending the Directive would speed up the processing of authorisations for new GMOs at European level, which poses a risk to the environment, biodiversity and human and animal health. For Spain, the country with the largest crop area of genetically modified organisms in the EU, this would mean the uncontrolled entry of GMO crops, transgenic contamination of the food chain, as well as impacts on the organic agriculture sector. The new Directive does not provide any compensation for farmers whose crops have been contaminated with transgenic varieties. There is a danger of creating a 'two-speed' Europe: those States most sensitive to the sustainability of their agriculture would have the possibility of banning these crops, while it would be granted a free way to the entry of new transgenic varieties in those States where the interest of the biotechnology industry prevails. The agribusiness lobby has been pushing for a long time to relax restrictions and liberalise - through treaties such as ATCI and AECG - the entry of unauthorized GMO foods into the EU.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — Positioning itself on an initial Commission proposal, the European Parliament voted in 2011 to expand the list of cases of restriction and prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). In 2014, the Council adopted a radically different proposal, which greatly limited the assumptions of a ban on GMOs. While Parliament was able to partially restore its initial position by means of the amendments made to the report as it passed through the Committee on the Environment, the final wording departs from what was adopted in 2011 and introduces enormous ambiguity respect for the cases in which States could ban the cultivation of a GMO.  In addition, the regulation of GMOs was restored to the domestic market and almost entirely diluted the financial responsibility regime previously advocated by Parliament.  The rewording makes it easier for large GMO multinationals to market their crops despite opposition from European states and peoples concerned about their consequences, without an adequate mechanism to compensate for the risks arising from this liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments, which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this block vote.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Along with the Socialists and Democrats Group I voted to support the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC on the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in their territory.  The principal objective of this modification to the legislative framework is to provide greater latitude and greater legal security to Member States wishing to prohibit in all or part of their territory the cultivation of GMOs authorised at European level.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. — I see the proposal that we approved and voted for as a step in the right direction. Member States should be able to prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. I am in favour of subsidiarity. This debate must result in greater awareness among citizens, because they should have the right to decide the fate of GMOs on their national territory. It should also be noted that we still do not know the health risks associated with the consumption of such foods, because studies on their harmfulness are still being questioned. In order for citizens to know the truth, we need a relevant debate at a professional level, in which both supporters and opponents of GMOs will have room.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I consider that the Directive allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMO opens the door to GMO and cross-border pollution across Europe and therefore I did not support its adoption.  While 500 million citizens and 19 Member States are clearly opposed to GMO, the European Union has unfortunately caved to pressure from multinationals. We are at risk of increasing the number of authorized GMO cultures. GMO products will thus make it easier for the free internal market to end up in food on the table in every European home. For the Republic of Croatia, as well as all Member States free from GMO, the expansion of them can hamper the development of small economies that are the basis of economic progress in Croatia and the last chance for the recovery of Croatian agriculture.  GMO producers can indirectly accelerate the demographic decline of the Croatian village with their negative impact, while reducing the chances of green jobs, the development of healthy industry and quality of life in rural areas.  We must enable our, especially future generations, to live with organic and healthy food and be guided by the policy of environmental protection, biodiversity and domestic agricultural production.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. — The Scottish National Party is opposed to the cultivation of GM crops in Scotland: apart from uncertainties about the long-term environmental effects, Scottish farming relies on a reputation for quality and environmental sensitivity, and we must not jeopardise consumer confidence in any way. We cannot support this legislation as it is designed to promote the spread of GM crops in Europe. It was proposed with the implicit understanding that Member States which banned GM crops on their territory would drop their opposition to authorisation at the EU level. This law does not provide enough safeguards to keep Scotland GM-free. The anti-contamination measures would not apply to the border between England and Scotland (and England will cultivate GM crops). This law would not prevent the circulation of GM products in Scotland, and it does nothing on GM labelling. We need to focus instead on reforming the EU’s environmental risk-assessment and authorisation process to reflect the opposition of a majority of Member States and of Europe’s citizens to the imposition of this technology.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the motion for a resolution so that Member States should be able to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GM Crops for reasons other than environmental criteria. Other reasons include requirements in the area of spatial planning or socio-economic reasons. I also support the introduction of 'mandatory rules', which should prevent GMOs grown in certain countries from spreading to neighbouring countries that do not grow GMOs. MON810 maize is currently the only GM crop grown in the European Union. Slovakia is a small country, growing maize for 225 thousand hectares and modified maize on only 100 hectares. The debate between supporters and opponents of the cultivation of GM crops will continue, but it is important that research in this area does not stop, that residents have all the information on the possible consequences of growing GM Crops and then including them in the food chain.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. — I have decided to support this compromise, given that it has been achieved five years after the start of the legislative process. I supported this text in accordance with the opinion of the Faction of the European People's Party and also in accordance with the opinion of the expert gestors, the Ministry of the Environment and the Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic. The compromise reached will make regulation at European level more transparent and, at the same time, for individual Member States to have a greater say on the cultivation of GMOs. I believe that a balanced compromise has been found in this sensitive area between the proposal of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament, which is why I did not vote in favour of further partial amendments.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — At the January plenary session, MEPs adopted legislation allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified plants on their territory, even if this is otherwise allowed in the European Union. Until now, the admissibility of genetically modified plants has been decided by the European Union in cooperation with the Member States, which, on the basis of a risk assessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority and the competent authorities of the Member States, has approved or rejected the application of producers of genetically modified plants. As the European Union is committed to unified rules throughout its territory, which is also in line with the principles of the internal market, it should first seek to improve existing authorisation and risk assessment procedures and to more democratically engage its authorities and Member States and their citizens in deciding on new types of GM plants. Such rules should be adopted as soon as possible, which will definitively resolve the outstanding issues relating to the cultivation of genetically modified plants on the territory of the European Union. As the directive does not propose solutions that take into account all the issues, I abstained from the vote.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Writing. — I voted against national bans on gm crops. These bans are without any scientific basis, distort the internal market and contradict the so-called Release Directive, which all the political groups in the European Parliament have agreed to. At the same time, farmers are being deprived of their freedom of choice. We have the strictest criteria for GMOs in the world in the EU. Before authorisation, GMOs are thoroughly reviewed by EFSA to ensure that they do not pose any risk to human or animal health or the environment. For authorised GM crops, Member States have laid down very broad rules on cultivation and distance to prevent the influence of conventional crops. The fact that Member States can now ban the cultivation of GMOs on every given reason violates the EU's scientific principles. For Europe as a research and development location, the decision is fatal because research activities are also affected by the cultivation bans. We are denying access to a future technology that would allow crops to adapt to the effects of climate change and could help ensure the diet of the rapidly growing world population despite the limited agricultural land. And the consumer is deceived. There will be no freedom from genetic engineering, despite the bans on cultivation. In animal production, we rely heavily on the import of GM protein feed from America.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — I welcome this agreement because it will give more flexibility to Member States wishing to restrict the cultivation of GM crops on their territory. It is important that the scientifically based authorisation system within the EU remains in place. I also believe that a thorough safety assessment and strengthening the monitoring system should also be a top priority in the area of GMO cultivation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution restricting or prohibiting the cultivation of GMO in the territory of member states wishing to do so, as there is room to accept certain cultural and geographical specifics of the area. It is important to emphasize that this is not a support to the GMO, but only the possibility of its use with irrefutable scientific evidence of safety for health and the environment and the appreciation of cultural and political practices. Member States will regulate GMO on their own, but they must not go below the EU standard. The new legislation allows EU Member States to ban the cultivation of products containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on their territory, even if these products are authorised at EU level. The directive becomes official in spring 2015 and will provide greater flexibility for Member States wishing to ban the cultivation of GMO in their country. Member States must ensure that GMO cereals do not contaminate other products if they have them, and this will be particularly true for the prevention of cross-border contamination of products. There is now no longer a risk that states that impose a ban on growing GMO food will be subject to trials. It is very important that every country in the EU, on the principle of subsidiarity, decides for itself to grow GMO food by listening to the wishes and needs of its citizens.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — In today's vote, I supported the proposed compromise, as I believe that it comes up with an effective solution to the issue. Each Member State will have the possibility to regulate the cultivation of genetically modified food on its own, which is certainly a sensible solution to this sensitive issue.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. — The aim of these negotiations has been to unblock the Union process for granting authorisation to GMOs for cultivation and import. While I welcome the efforts that have been undertaken to achieve this goal, I believe that the overall agreement we have arrived at contains a number of unsatisfactory elements, which left me unable to support it at today’s vote.  This final agreement is unsatisfactory in that it allows Member States to proceed directly to national bans, rather than first seeking a more legally sound ‘opt-out’. In addition, it allows national bans to be applied to ‘groups of GMOs’ – rather than on a case-by-case basis – and it fails to rule out completely the possibility of Member States citing environmental and public health grounds for national bans. Both of these elements conflict with the European Food Safety Authority risk-assessment process whereby the environmental and public health risks of GMOs are examined on a case-by-case basis prior to authorisation being granted.  It is my strongly held belief that a science-based approach to the regulation of GMOs must be maintained, and it was on this basis that I took the decision to abstain during the vote on the trialogue agreement.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The cultivation of GMOs from the countries of the European Union should be prohibited in so far as it has not been certified and it has been shown that their consumption does not adversely affect human health.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion on the possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit GMO cultivation. I believe that there is still no complete agreement between Member States and experts on GMOs. This is illustrated by the fact that this has been debated in the European Parliament for almost the fifth year running. Progress has finally been made in this process, and, of course, this does not mean the end of the debate between those who oppose the cultivation of GMOs and those who advocate them. I believe that member states should be given the right to restrict the cultivation of GMOs, and this requires a single directive. I think it is right that, in relation to GMOs, Member States will be able to intervene and develop the level of restriction transparently in their own judgement. In addition, the restrictions will also apply in specific border zones in neighbouring countries. Uniform regulation can also be a solution to member states' fears of legal attacks by biotechnology companies. Of course, implementation has a great responsibility on the Member States, deadlines must be met and enforced. In this connection, the EU institutions also have obligations, such as trade agreements. When discussing them, as in the case of the current TTIP, a coherent position should be taken. Even after the conclusion of commercial contracts, Member States should remain the right to prohibit the cultivation/marketing of GMOs for health reasons in order to preserve biological diversity and ecosystems.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. — (IT) The agreement on GMOs, which was welcomed by the Italian Presidency as a great success, conceals serious pitfalls for those countries which really want to protect their crops. I did not vote in favour of the agreement because it leaves too important a role for the biotech multinationals, allowing them to behave in different ways depending on whether they are faced with a state in favour of GMO crops or not. The agreement provides for states that prohibit gm crops from following the conciliation procedure with applicant companies, involving them in this way in the decision-making process. Secondly, this agreement makes the bans issued by the Member States weaker and less defensible in the event of recourse to the WTO or the Court of Justice of the European Union. Finally, there are no compensation mechanisms for any environmental damage caused by GMO crops. I voted in favour of the amendments tabled by M5S, Gue and The Greens to ensure that coexistence plans are to be drawn up in countries where GMO crops are grown. This instrument, if well used, would also have made it very difficult to test GMOs in the absence of protective measures such as confinement and cover to prevent pollination.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. — As the world population continues to grow, it is imperative that our ability to provide larger quantities of food, in as efficient and stable a manner as possible, improves. GMOs provide a potential to do this and it is therefore important that, as politicians, we approach this subject in an objective way and with a science-based approach. All too often, however, we see knee-jerk reactions based on the politics of fear and half-truths, resulting in ill-conceived policies. The proposal put forward today is, unfortunately, in this mould and I am unable to vote in favour. It would see bans apply to so-called groups of GMOs, for instance, rather than acting on a case-by-case basis – a clear example of legislation that fails to account for scientific method. In the broader sphere of this debate, I hope that we will see a pragmatic approach emerge in the coming years that sees those countries wishing to proceed with GMOs do so, and those with reservations to be respected.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The new GMO legislation was on the agenda of the European Parliament's votes this lunchtime. Of course, I voted for it. Indeed, we were successful. Member States of the European Union now have the freedom to decide whether or not to allow the cultivation of genetically modified organisms on their soil. A real victory, the culmination of four years of legislative struggle. The pro-GMO lobbies, led by several multinationals and Great Britain, were ultimately unsuccessful. Moreover, we have obtained a legal basis for the refusal to implement GMO crops, an extension of the list of reasons for banning.  These reasons for prohibition could include, for example, land-use planning obligations, socio-economic consequences, measures to prevent the accidental presence of GMOs in other products, or agricultural policy objectives. The prohibitions could also apply to groups of GMOs determined by species or characteristic.  We have also demanded binding measures of coexistence.  We have ensured that states have the power to impose sanctions to prevent the contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. — Not only does the new regulatory framework on the authorisation of GMO crops not only do not address the shortcomings of the previous System, but renationalises an issue which, by its nature, must be dealt with at European level. Crop pollution, the threat to biodiversity and other effects produced by GMOs need European solutions. On the other hand, among the cases provided for in the exercise of the ban, health risks are not included. Finally, this new scheme facilitates the approval of new GMOs beyond the only GMOs currently permitted, MON810 maize, by giving multinationals great power in the European authorisation process.  For all this, I voted against it.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. — I welcome the adoption by parliament of the GMO directive (480 votes in support, 159 against and 58 abstentions).  Previously, in the absence of a qualified majority, the Commission could authorise genetically modified crops. States such as France, which wanted to defend their consumers and their agriculture, could be condemned by the European Court of Justice.  Thanks to this directive, Member States will now be able to restrict or ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory on environmental, agricultural and socio-economic grounds.  Member States have 2 years to take measures to prevent contamination of traditional crops by GMO crops in cross-border areas.  Moreover, the European Commission is committed to revising and strengthening the risk assessment rules conducted by the Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In voting in favour of this directive, I have chosen to strengthen the security of Member States opposed to GMOs, safety for farmers and safety for European consumers.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the possibility for Member States to decide for themselves whether they wish to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of genetically modified agricultural products. Each state has a different approach and different natural conditions. I am clearly in support of the reasonable and controlled use of GMO products in the European Union.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this legislation, in order to move forward on this debate. The principle of subsidiarity upheld by our vote today is valid, but the GMO issue has to be analysed case by case, and sometimes it may seem that it has been criminalised. We want a sustainable agriculture, but we should not be dogmatically against technological progress.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. " The proposed text is biased and dishonest. It flatters national pride by making them dream of a semblance of sovereignty over the issue. European nation-states would therefore be able to choose whether or not to grow GMOs on their land BUT not to choose what will end up on the plate of their compatriots. By the single market rule, it will therefore be enough for a State to allow its cultivation to spread its products without any control in the markets and supermarkets of the whole area of the European Union. So the French would eat GMOs even if France decides not to grow them. On the other hand, I am not opposed to research on the subject. Aren't the grape varieties of our wines themselves GMOs?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted against the report, as I believe that the precautionary principle should prevail as regards the proliferation of GMOs. I find it unacceptable for the Commission to propose an authorisation for new varieties of GMOs in return for allowing Member States to ban them at a later date.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. - I have always advocated that Latvia and the European Union as a whole be free of GMOs. We must not allow our land and soil to be polluted, and we must not be able to depend on biotechnology corporations. Although the gMO's advocates claim that the harmfulness of that food has not been demonstrated, there is also no evidence of its safety.  Until now, existing EU legislation provides that if a company expresses its willingness to market GMO seeds in a particular country, the European Commission (EC) is entitled to issue an authorisation authorisation on the basis of the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. By authorising a GMO species, the EC depriving states of their right to decide whether they want to allow that GMO to enter their territory.  Of course, I would like the Member States to be able to jointly agree on a GMO-free EU. Unfortunately, there is no common position among EU Member States as to whether the EU should authorise the cultivation of genetically modified organisms, so the compromise reached will ensure that each country will have the right to decide for itself whether to authorise the cultivation of GMOs. Thus, we will also have the opportunity to abandon GMOs in Latvia and continue to grow natural food without risking the european Court of Justice's penalties.  While I am pleased with the compromise reached, which raises the confidence that we will be able to keep our land free from GMOs, there is no shortage of issues that need to be addressed, including buffer zones between countries and the possible transfer of genes between plants.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist delegation supports the agreement to give flexibility to Member States wishing to ban GMOs on their territory because it considers that the new Directive complies with the EU's basic principles with regard to GMOs: the precautionary principle, transparency and the protection of health and the environment.
