We understand that some safeguard measures could have been reached further, but the agreement reached corresponds to current scientific evidence and, above all, will serve to unblock the checkout situation of those Member States that did not want to include GMOs among their crops and who had had to appear in court at the request of some biotech companies. In this period, which opens from next spring, it will be necessary to take note of the effectiveness of the coexistence measures which will now be binding to see whether the Directive actually fulfils its task of preventing unwanted pollution, especially in the case of traditional and organic agriculture.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The outcome of the trialogue was disappointing to say the least. A handful of key elements brought forward by Parliament have been confirmed, including the obligation to draw up coexistence plans (but limited to countries where GMO crops are grown) and the possibility of banning groups of GMOs. The final text dismissed by the Council provided for Member States to be able to decide whether to require companies to restrict the geographical scope of authorisations being assessed or to impose unilateral bans. The reasons described on the basis of which gmo crops can be banned are very weak and the legal instrument adopted at the end of the negotiations with the Council is that of a directive that does not contain transposition obligations on the part of the Member States, thus leaving pending whether and how to implement its measures without up-to-date national legislation with appropriate transposition acts. Finally, the problem of coexistence, which is closely linked to the feared risk of the accidental spread of GMO seeds or pollen to adjacent conventional crops, which could lead to economic losses due to damage between producers, should crops have significant quantities of GMOs in the crop, they can no longer be certified as non-GMO products. For all these reasons, I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — Positioning itself on an initial Commission proposal, the European Parliament voted in 2011 to expand the list of cases of restriction and prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). In 2014, the Council adopted a radically different proposal, which greatly limited the assumptions of a ban on GMOs. While Parliament was able to partially restore its initial position by means of the amendments made to the report as it passed through the Committee on the Environment, the final wording departs from what was adopted in 2011 and introduces enormous ambiguity respect for the cases in which States could ban the cultivation of a GMO.  In addition, the regulation of GMOs was restored to the domestic market and almost entirely diluted the financial responsibility regime previously advocated by Parliament.  The rewording makes it easier for large GMO multinationals to market their crops despite opposition from European states and peoples concerned about their consequences, without an adequate mechanism to compensate for the risks arising from this liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. - I have no generalised objection to GMOs. On the contrary, I can see great merit in the introduction of strains that, for example, reduce the need for pesticides or increase crop yield and quality, or reduce the requirement for watering. I am committed to a science-based approach. While the final agreement reached is satisfactory, in that it allows those EU countries that so wish to grow GMOs, the downside is that it enables others to proceed directly to national bans rather than first seeking a more legally sound opt-out. It also allows these bans to be applied to ‘groups of GMOs’, rather than case by case, and it widens the basis for a ban. Apart from other considerations, these features could open up a range of potential problems and complications relating to neighbouring countries and to food exports and imports etc. I was therefore content to follow the UK Government position in Council and abstain.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — My Labour colleagues and I supported strong measures to allow Member States to ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. This vote also means that Member States which choose to cultivate GMOs must introduce coexistence measures for border areas, so that states which do not wish to have GMOs on their territory are protected from those who do.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — With this report, the European Parliament is opening a loophole in the protection against crops of genetically modified organisms. Supposed to expand the rights of Member States to justify a national or regional ban on the cultivation of a GMO, it will ultimately lead to the legal weakening of such bans.  First, its lack of clarity opens the door to legal attacks by multinational seed companies like Monsanto against countries that have banned the cultivation of one of their GMOs. This is particularly problematic at a time when the creation of private international tribunals is being negotiated under TTIP.  Moreover, the legal basis for this report is not Article 192 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which is dedicated to the environment, but Article 114, which deals with the internal market. As a result, Member States will not be able to invoke the precautionary principle or exceed the minimum environmental requirements.  I therefore voted against this report, in line with the demands of a large number of European citizens who oppose GMOs because of the risks they pose to their health, biodiversity, the diversity of farming methods and conventional and organic agricultural sectors.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — At the end of the process of discussing this directive, once again, the interests of agribusiness multinationals form privileged. Its supporters of gmos are in a majority in this parliament and, as you would expect, approve this proposal. Safeguarding the public interest, public health, the environment and sustainable agriculture, in particular small and medium-sized agriculture, but also national sovereignties have gone to the fore. With this directive, which contradicts all the calls and recommendations of the ENVI committee, States are referred to the unacceptable position of having to ask multinationals not to market Genetically Modified Organisms on their territory, and they may refuse such a request. Moreover, the legal basis is no longer the environment and public health to the internal market. It is therefore enlightening how the majority of this Parliament views this subject and its implications.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I abstained from this vote because, although the basic idea of the directive is to be supported, its drafting is flawed. The possibility of introducing genetically modified organisms into food from other EU countries remains. Furthermore, there is no legal certainty for those states that do not use genetically modified organisms. Lawsuits could be the result.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. — This was not a vote for or against GMOs, but on giving Member States the right to limit or ban GMOs on their territory even if the European Food Safety Authority has assessed them as safe or the Commission has approved them. The proposal will allow Member States to opt out of GMO cultivation at a national level, effectively giving Member States the last word on GMO cultivation. The proposal includes strengthened environmental impact assessments for GMOs, and coexistence measures for border areas, so that traditional crops cannot be contaminated by GM crops in a Member State that has opted out. Labour MEPs also supported amendments in the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee that removed the Council-backed idea of a phase of negotiations with agrichemical companies as part of negotiations over banning the cultivation of GMOs. My Labour colleagues and I voted in favour of this proposal because it provides a sound basis for Member States to have a democratic and flexible national opt-out on GMO cultivation.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, the Sweden Democrats could not support this bloc vote.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — On 13.01.2015, a vote was held on a directive allowing Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GM Organisms on their territory.  Different Member States have different views on GMOs and the provisions on this matter should depend on their sovereign decisions. So far, Poland remains free from GMO crops that are banned. Admission to such crops would inevitably expose Polish soils to degradation. I voted in favour of a draft directive allowing regulation of the cultivation of GENETICALLY MODIFIED organisms at national level, not the Union.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: in writing. — This report was misleadingly labelled as giving Member States more powers. In actual fact, whilst Amendment 20 did give powers back, this was cancelled out by the other 50 amendments which maintained and re-asserted EU control and authority over the whole procedure. The EU did not allow us to vote on individual amendments, which we regard as rather unfair. Therefore, we could not support this bloc vote.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I supported this proposal for a directive because I consider it to be a very good and balanced compromise which, in my opinion, gives The Member States, European regions, businesses and, above all, farmers an appropriate legal framework within which to move. Personally, I am glad that member states have also been given some freedom to decide on prohibitions and restrictions on cultivation. GMOs offer new opportunities for Europe, but they must by no means cause concern on the part of European citizens.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. — The compromise reached by the European Parliament and the Council on the new directive is certainly to be welcomed, as it will enable EU Member States to legally ban the cultivation of genetically modified plants on their territories, even if authorised by the European Union. The debate on this issue has always been difficult; four years have passed since the Commission presented its proposal. In the past, there may have been situations where the European Commission authorised the cultivation of certain genetically modified plants, even if the Member States were opposed. Let us remember the case of the genetically modified maize variety, which was approved by the European Commission, despite the fact that 19 Member States were against it. The new directive will allow Member States to decide for themselves whether they wish to restrict or authorise the cultivation of genetically modified crops on their territory. In future, this will be the decision of each Member State itself, in line with the position of its citizens, so governments will have to listen seriously to the views of their citizens. In addition, it is also very important that such a decision by a Member State to ban GMOs will be entirely legal and in accordance with EU regulation, so the large GMO-producing giants will not be able to challenge this decision in court, as was possible until now.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Directive giving Member States more flexibility to prohibit or limit the cultivation of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) authorised at European Union (EU) level in their territories, on the basis of environmental reasons such as the maintenance of local biodiversity, socio-economic impacts or criteria related to land use, among others. With this amendment to the current EU legislative framework on GMOs, there will be greater latitude and greater legal certainty for Member States wishing to ban, in all or part of their territories, the cultivation of GMOs allowed at European level. European countries will now have greater freedom to address specific national or local issues raised by the cultivation of GMOs.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The initial good intentions of the majority of this Parliament have once again cheld the economic interests of biotechnology multinationals, to the detriment of the defence of traditional agriculture, the environment, the interests and health of the people, as we have unfortunately hoped. This adopted text has taken out key points, such as the principle of coexistence and the introduction of clean zones between neighbouring countries, subverting and weakening the precautionary principle, the same with concerns and environmental protection, which are no longer their legal basis.  The text submitted gives more space for large biotechnology and agribusiness companies to reject and appeal in court to the application for restriction/prohibition of GMOs in the Member States that so wish. No liability, restitution and damage protection schemes are taken into account, in particular as regards liability requirements and financial guarantees, and the rights of consumers of choice and traditional farmers not to see their crops contaminated are not guaranteed. We voted against it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the new regulation on genetically modified organisms (GMOs) because it does not offer Member States a strong regulatory framework to protect and protect their crops from contamination of GMOs. The new directive is in fact unbalanced towards biotech multinationals, which are considered to be on an equal footing with states, thus limiting their political sovereignty. No new environmental/health reasons other than those already adopted by EFSA cannot be put forward to justify the ban. And the possibility of biotech multinationals taking the decisions of a Member State before the Court of Justice of the European Union is not excluded. There is also no obligation to insure GMO crops to deal with damage caused by contamination, whether accidental or not, of conventional or organic crops.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. — I supported the Frédérique Ries report, which gives EU countries the possibility to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, even though they are already authorised at EU level.  This report is the result of negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council, which we have been waiting for since 2010. It is true, the compromise does not cover all parliament's demands (legislative basis, accountability for offences...), but it is the best we have been able to achieve in a given situation. If we were to insist on further negotiations with the Council, it would be even more difficult to find a compromise. We urgently needed new legislation, as under the legislation so far, the states did not have the possibility of banning the cultivation of GMOs on their territory. If they do so, there could be lawsuits from multinationals marketing GMO materials. The compromise text also requires that there must be a boundary belt around GMO farms in order to avoid 'infecting' neighbouring farms with traditional or bio-production. The impact of GMOs on the future of agriculture, health, access to food, etc. is still unclear and their mass release into nature is irreversible. Experience from America and India even shows an increase in resistance to herbicides and increased pesticide use. EU Member States and citizens must have the right to ban such risky activities on their territory.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) The proposal is aimed at transposing into Union law a series of measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. We voted in favour of this proposal because it contains a framework of initiatives and regulations that are acceptable, important and in some cases necessary. Nevertheless, we would like to state that, once again, the European Parliament, and in particular the Committee on Fisheries, have acted in the opposite direction to the original proposal. This proposal, on certain points, is therefore weakened in its action to protect certain species, in particular red coral. The CGPM clearly established that red coral could not be collected using Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROV). RoVs were only granted for observation and research, and as long as they were not equipped with instruments that could cut and collect the coral itself. In the version released by Parliament, these indications have been overturned, leading, in all probability, to a destructive, unsustainable red coral collection, without scientific justification for this practice. We are therefore reluctantly voting in favour because we approve of the context and other rules contained in this proposal, but we express great concern about a species that already has considerable conservation problems.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation a number of provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the CGPM (General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries) agreement, of which the EU and several Member States (including Spain) are part. While the Commission's proposal was even more restrictive than the CGPM's recommendations in areas such as the protection of red corals and other marine animals, the report was diluted in its parliamentary procedure, which in addition to other gaps already present initially (such as inadequate monitoring of compliance with the recommendations) justifies my vote against it.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — I have spoken out against the report on the fisheries provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement, as its rapporteur, Gabriel Mato, wishes to promote the fishing of red coral, which is an endangered species.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — This motion for a resolution amending Regulation (EU) No. 1343/2011 of Parliament and the Council of 13 December 2011 concerning certain provisions relating to fishing in the area covered by the CGPM agreement provides for technical measures (sustainable exploitation of red coral, reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, etc.) but also specific obligations relating to the registration and disclosure of data. This text could prove binding for fishermen, already hard hit by the crisis and EU regulatory requirements. Fishermen are also subject to the requirements of the CGPM, an organization created in 1949 by an international agreement under Article XIV of the FAO constitution. There is an urgent need to find solutions that must not only protect the marine environment but also fishermen, who can no longer endure temporary fishing stoppages or the maintenance of quotas too low. For these reasons, I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — As a UKIP member of the European Parliament, my mandate from constituents is to oppose new EU legislation.  Consequently my natural instinct is to vote against, unless it seems to me that there is a pressing reason to do otherwise.   As regards fishing stocks, this once again appears to take a collectivist approach across the European Union. I believe therefore that it would be inconsistent for me to do anything other than vote against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation because it consists of transposing the recommendations of the CGPM into EU law. I support the CGPM's missions to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of live aquatic resource stocks, to design and recommend conservation measures, and to promote cooperative training projects.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to transpose into European Union law the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (UFB) on the use of red corals, the reduction of catches of conventible seabirds, sea turtles and cetries and measures to protect seal monks, sharks and skates. The UFK was established by international agreement in 1949 and consists of the Mediterranean Sea, the Black Sea and the surrounding waters. The commission's main tasks are to promote the development of living marine resources, to protect and moderate management, and to develop recommendations for conservation measures. I support the transposition of this commission's recommendations into EU law.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report because it supports the integration into EU law of measures to increase the protection of certain underwater species, including going beyond the Habitats Directive.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — This motion for a resolution amending Regulation (EU) No. 1343/2011 of Parliament and the Council of 13 December 2011 concerning certain provisions relating to fishing in the area covered by the CGPM agreement provides for technical measures (sustainable exploitation of red coral, reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, etc.), but also specific obligations relating to the registration and communication of data. This text seems binding for fishermen, who are already hard hit by the crisis and Brussels' regulatory requirements and are equally constrained by the requirements of the CGPM, an organization created in 1949 by an international agreement under Article XIV of the FAO constitution. There is an urgent need to find solutions that must not only protect the marine environment, but also fishermen, who can no longer endure temporary fishing stoppages or the maintenance of quotas that are too low. As it stands, I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal containing technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays in the area to which the GFCM Agreement applies. These measures go beyond the protection already afforded to these species at EU level by the Habitats Directive and other Union acts and include specific registration and communication obligations for both operators and Member States.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the proposal.  The Commission's original proposal proposed greater protection for, among other things, red corals and animals caught by mistake. However, most of the amendments that went through in the Committee on Fisheries have resulted in a weakening of protection compared to the Commission's proposal. Since even the Commission's proposal was not progressive enough in its defence of the environment and wildlife, and this was then further weakened by the committee, I chose to vote against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The main functions of the General Commission for Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), established in 1949, are the promotion of the development, conservation and management of living biological resources, the development and recommendation of conservation measures and the promotion of cooperation projects for training in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters. In 2011, the last transposition of GCC measures into EU law took place. Subsequently, in 2011 and 2012, the CGPM adopted new management measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral to be incorporated into our legislation. Other recommendations adopted by the CGPM establish measures to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans; measures to ensure a high level of protection for sharks and rays; or measures for the fish markets of small pelagic populations in the Adriatic Sea. To include these recommendations in EU law, it is proposed to amend Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which improves the Commission's proposal for a General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (UFJ). The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean was established by international agreement in 1949. Its geographical area consists of the Mediterranean Sea, the Black Sea and the surrounding waters. The UFK's main tasks are to promote the development, conservation and moderate management of living marine resources, to develop and make recommendations for conservation measures, and to promote joint training projects. The Commission's proposal aims to transpose the UFK recommendations into EU law. The European Parliament welcomes this Commission proposal, but notes that the proposal does not take into account measures already introduced at national level in line with these recommendations. Member States which have already transposed the recommendations adopted between 2011 and 2013 should not be required to submit requests for derogations to the Commission in the CCI RECOMMENDATIONS, also taking into account that they have not been transposed by the Commission so far. The European Parliament's rapporteur proposes to take the view that the UFM recommendations provide for a sufficient level of protection, which must be implemented by the Contracting Parties in particular before further measures are adopted.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this provision because I consider very important to coordinate and support an important sector of the Mediterranean economy such as fishing.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I welcome the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to amend Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1343/2011 of the Parliament and of the Council of 13 December 2011 on certain provisions relating to fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement (General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean). I believe that there is a need to update the existing provisions by including the measures contained in the GFCM recommendations.  These technical sustainable exploitation measures based on the recommendations of the GFCM confirm the main objective of the GFCM, which maintains a good ecological status of the Mediterranean basin and is in line with the New Common Fisheries Policy, which aims mainly to lay the foundations for economically, socially sustainable and environmentally sustainable fisheries. The proposal is important because it represents an improvement on existing fisheries provisions at European Union level. In recent years, the Commission has played an important role in encouraging the GFCM to take initiatives that enable an effective management framework to be achieved, and this needs sustainable continuity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The advanced technical measures for sustainable exploitation are to be welcomed.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Fisheries Provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the CGPM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean). The report aims to transpose into EU law a number of measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) at its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013. The CGPM is a regional fisheries management organisation established in accordance with Article XIV of the FAO Constitution. Its main objectives are to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and intermediate waters. It was therefore important to align the existing legislation with the recommendations of the CGPM.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the regulation on certain provisions for fisheries in the area of application of the GFCM Agreement (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean). In its annual sessions in 2011 and 2012, the GFCM adopted measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral in its area of expertise, for the mitigation of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, for the protection of sharks and rays, and for the fishing of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea. The vote concerned the amendment of European legislation in the light of the above recommendations. Given that the measures were to be implemented in EU law, I voted in favour of their integration.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — This proposal incorporates the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. However, as the rapporteur himself has pointed out, certain rules should be improved in order to adapt to the reality of the fishing world.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because I agree with its spirit and objectives and with its practical implementation. Indeed, I agree with the need to seek sustainable ways of exploiting marine resources, combining the opportunity ( always existed) to make a living from them with the obligation to introduce rules that will also allow future generations to continue to collect the dividend of this incredible resource, perhaps by combining fishing with tourist exploitation and the study of what we do not yet know.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the legislative motion for a resolution amending Regulation 1343/2011 because, on the one hand, it aims to ensure the sustainable exploitation of red coral and, on the other hand, it aims to preserve certain species of marine fauna from fishing activity which, without the necessary regulation, ends up damaging the marine ecosystem. With particular reference to the latter, this proposal for a regulation aims to ensure the sustainable use of marine wealth, through an ecosystem approach to the management of human activities, that is, a methodology that provides for the human community as an integral part of the ecosystems and mechanisms that regulate them.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) has adopted a number of measures that aim to ensure sustainable exploitation of red coral measures, mitigation of incidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the GFCM Agreement Areas, high level of protection from fishing activities with regard to sharks and rays, in particular those endangered or threatened, and the sustainable development of small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea. Such measures go beyond the protection already ensured to these species at EU level by the Habitats Directive and other Union Acts. I have thus voted in favour of this report which proposes amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 to include the measures contained in the GFCM recommendations.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation a number of provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the CGPM (General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries) agreement, of which the EU and several Member States (including Spain) are part. While the Commission's proposal was even more restrictive than the CGPM's recommendations in areas such as the protection of red corals and other marine animals, the report was diluted in its parliamentary procedure, which in addition to other gaps already present initially (such as inadequate monitoring of compliance with the recommendations) justifies my vote against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I gave my support to this report dealing with the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean that was set up by an international agreement back in 1949. The area covered by the agreement comprises the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and connecting waters. The main tasks of the GFCM are to promote the development, conservation, and rational management of living aquatic resources, to formulate and recommend conservation measures and to promote cooperative projects in the area of training. At its annual sessions in 2011 and 2012, the GFCM adopted measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, for the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, for the protection of sharks and rays, and for fisheries exploiting small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea. I support the aim of this report of adding the measures contained in the GFCM recommendations to the original agreement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) aims to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources and sets a high level of species protection in the Mediterranean area. This report proposes to amend EU legislation to include the measures contained in the recommendations of the CGPM. With these recommendations setting a sufficient level of regulatory protection, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Established in 1949, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM), to which the European Union is a party, aims to promote the development and conservation of stocks of living aquatic resources in the Mediterranean. The aim of this text is to transpose some of the recommendations of the CGPM into EU law. Setting a sufficient level of regulatory protection, these recommendations are welcome. They include measures to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans and provisions to ensure a high level of protection against shark and stingray fishing activities.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean was founded in 1949 by an international agreement. Its area of expertise encompasses the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters. The main functions of the GFCM are: the promotion of the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources. In the annual sessions of 2011 and 2012, the GFCM had taken measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, for the mitigation of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, for the protection of sharks and stingrays, and for the fishing of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to incorporate into EU law the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — The European Union is a contracting party to the CGPM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean), a regional organisation established in 1949 to play an active role in the conservation of fish stocks in international waters of the Mediterranean Sea. The CGPM adopts, on the basis of scientific advice, binding recommendations which must therefore be transposed into Community law, where their content is not already covered by EU legislation.  The European regulation on certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement (COM2014/0457) provides technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the area covered by the CGPM agreement. These provisions will improve the preservation of the balance of the seabed and biodiversity.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted against the report submitted because it sought to reduce, by way of exceptions, the level of protection measures proposed by the Commission, on the basis of the recommendations of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM area , as well as strengthen the protection of threatened species of sharks and rays.  The Commission is not characterised by its over-zeal in protecting the environment and any protection of the biological resources of the Mediterranean Sea is little when we take into account the state of devastation in which it is as a result of human activity. So there is no compelling reason to amend the Commission's original proposal.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We are voting in favour of this proposal because it respects the provisions of the General Fisheries Committee on the protection of all marine organisms. The unconssasted fishing of all living organisms without organisation and controls brings about the destruction of the marine ecosystem.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which incorporates into EU law measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, thus amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011, because I cannot deny the general common sense of purpose and certain measures contained herein; However, I would like to point out that, as is often the case, many of the individual acceding states have already transposed the measures expressed by the GFCM and will therefore now be forced to request a derogation from the European Commission, whose present proposal in fact ignores the right already in use in individual States, which is often better in terms of protecting and caring for the environment. I am also concerned about the risk that a species as sensitive as red coral could undergo environmentally unsustainable treatments, according to the approved text.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was established by international agreement in 1949. The area covered by the agreement includes the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and the adjacent waters. The main tasks of the GFCM are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources, formulate and recommend conservation measures and promote cooperation projects in the area of training.  This amendment will allow for sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of occasional catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the GFCM Agreement area, which deserves my support.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This agreement allows seychelles-flaunder vessels to access mayot waters and their resources. The territory of Mayot has acquired the status of the EU's Outermost Region since January 2014. As a result of status, the Mayot Exclusive Economic Zone is subject to the provisions of the EU Treaties. The conservation of mayote's marine living resources under the Common Fisheries Policy is an exclusive competence of the EU.  For this reason, the existing bilateral agreement between Mayote and seychelles – previously existing – must now be re-established by the EU. Our position on the EU's competences in this area is well known – we are against it. However, this report only aims to extend under the new conditions the same agreement previously existing, which allows a limited number of Seychelles vessels to fish in mayan waters migratory species, offering some considerations aimed at supporting the sustainable development of the fisheries sector in Mayot – consisting primarily of artisanal fleet. Which is why we have nothing to do with this agreement.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal because its aim is to incorporate into European legislation the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. These measures, which are very important for our sea, concern the sustainable exploitation of red coral and the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans. We need these provisions in order to protect and manage the fragile Mediterranean ecosystem with caution.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. — The commission's primary tasks include promoting, protecting and rationally managing living aquatic resources and developing and recommending conservation measures and supporting cooperation projects in the field of training. At its meetings, the Commission adopted measures to be introduced into European Union law on the exploitation of red coral, measures to mitigate the consequences of incidental catches of seabirds and, last but not least, measures to ensure a high level of protection against fishing activities. However, it is important to point out that the Commission's proposal in question ignores the measures already in place at national level, and the European Commission's proposal in this area is in many cases much stricter than the recommendations of the Mediterranean Fisheries Commission.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the proposal containing technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays in the area to which the GFCM Agreement applies.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the provisions on fisheries in the area of the GHAM Agreement on the conservation, respect and protection of all marine organisms.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — The main functions of the CGPM are the promotion of the development, conservation and management of living biological resources, the development and recommendation of conservation measures and the promotion of cooperation projects for training. At its annual sessions in 2011 and 2012, the CGPM adopted technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays, recommendations to be incorporated into EU law. I therefore voted in favour of amending this Regulation to include the measures contained in the CGPM recommendations and thus to ensure the present and future sustainability of mediterranean sea, Black Sea and adjacent waters resources.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — The UK has 70% of the EU’s fishing grounds and yet only 13% of the fishing quotas. Only UKIP believes that the UK should be allowed to manage and police its own territorial waters for the benefit of the British people and our fishermen.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Mato report because I think it is vital that measures are adopted to protect living aquatic resources in the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and connecting waters. It is deeply worrying that, over the past two centuries, there has been a decline in the population of sharks in the Mediterranean Sea of more than 97%, putting them at risk of extinction if current fishing levels continue. Meanwhile, nine out of 13 regular species of whale and dolphin in the Mediterranean and Black Seas are classified in categories ranging from vulnerable to critically endangered. Mitigating incidental captures and improving the protection of these and other endangered animals, such as seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and coral species, will be crucial if we want to avoid causing irreversible damage to the ecosystem of our seas.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Mr Mato's report because I believe it is very important that European legislation should take account of, comply with and respect the provisions of its recommendations by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. A Commission that sits at the same table as well as the European countries, our neighbours with which we share marine resources.  It is essential to work to reduce and avoid the accidental catch of seabirds, sea turtles and monk seals. Fishing cannot become a threat to those species such as sharks and stingrays that are in danger. Biodiversity must be protected. It is also true, Mr President, that many States had already adapted to these recommendations and that the European Union has already imposed even stricter measures with its regulations than those laid down by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. It is therefore right not to duplicate obligations, not to require States to provide for double derogations, double adjustments and the revision of appropriate national management frameworks, which have already been approved.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted against the report submitted because it sought to reduce, by way of exceptions, the level of protection measures proposed by the Commission, on the basis of the recommendations of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM area , as well as strengthen the protection of threatened species of sharks and rays.  The Commission is not characterised by its over-zeal in protecting the environment and any protection of the biological resources of the Mediterranean Sea is little when we take into account the state of devastation in which it is as a result of human activity. So there is no compelling reason to amend the Commission's original proposal.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area, because the EU, in its capacity as a contracting party to the GFCM, has made a series of commitments in recent years, on the sustainable management and exploitation of living marine resources, which need to be transposed into Union law.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — The Mediterranean sea is one of the most beautiful seas in the world, but is threatened by overfishing, bycatch and plundering of coral reefs.  The Commission's proposal was largely aimed at restoring ecosystems, but did not exclude fishing. I have proposed that fishing should no longer be allowed in the most vulnerable areas. This gives overfished fish species a chance of survival and prevents many other species from being caught. In particular, fishing with trawlnets causes a lot of bycatch of dolphins, seabirds and other mammals, which become entangled in the nets and then drown. Scientific advice calls for restrictions on trawlnets. I have asked for a total ban, because this is much easier to control. In addition, I have proposed to prevent the looting of coral reefs by prohibiting the harvesting and selling of red coral, also known as blood coral. Coral reefs are threatened because much of the coral is used to make jewelry out of them. The underwater world in coral reefs is unique and deserves our protection.  Unfortunately, many of the amendments were aimed at broadening the Commission's proposal rather than tightening it up. I voted against this much-watered-down proposal.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted against the report submitted because it intended to reduce, by way of exceptions, the level of protection measures proposed by the Commission, on the basis of the recommendations of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM area , as well as strengthen the protection of threatened species of sharks and rays.  The Commission is not characterised by its over-zeal in protecting the environment and any protection of the biological resources of the Mediterranean Sea is little when we take into account the state of devastation in which it is as a result of human activity. So there is no compelling reason to amend the Commission's original proposal.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation No 1999/2013. 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement, as the amendments to the Regulation bring certain measures contained in the GFCM recommendations that contribute to the conservation, development and rational management of marine resources. The proposal, which I support, contains some measures leading to the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of individual species, and the preservation of others in the territory of the GFCM Agreement. It is extremely important to preserve the sea wealth of the Mediterranean, which is often threatened by environmental and human factors, and which represents a significant legacy of a large part of Europe.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of Gabriel Mato's report on the fisheries provisions in the area covered by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The CGPM, which promotes the conservation and rational management of fish stocks in the Mediterranean, has adopted recommendations in recent years (notably for the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds and sea turtles) which should be transposed into EU law.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the report on fishing provisions in the area covered by the agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). This report proposes to transpose into EU law a number of measures adopted by the CGPM, including the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of certain aquatic species.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The mission of the GFCM is to promote and recommend measures for the development and conservation of living marine resources and to promote the well-thought-out management of marine resources in the Mediterranean, black sea and waters connecting to these waters. The GFCM recommendations adopted in 2011 and 2012 go beyond the protection already afforded to these species at EU level under the Habitats Directive and other Union acts and provide for specific registration and reporting obligations, so their inclusion in Community law will contribute to the sustainable development of the marine environment and fish stocks. However, we must not forget that there is also a need to take into account the interests of fishermen, fisheries-related industries and coastal communities in this regard. I therefore support the rapporteur's proposal to reject those standards contained in the Commission's proposal that are stricter than the GFCM recommendations.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement as it contains a number of welcome conservation measures for the Mediterranean, particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of the report by my colleague Gabriel Mato because I believe that this proposal establishes a satisfactory level of regulatory protection in the fisheries sector. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean is a regional organisation that promotes the development, conservation, rational management and optimum use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in both the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation a number of provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the CGPM (General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries) agreement, of which the EU and several Member States (including Spain) are part. While the Commission's proposal was even more restrictive than the CGPM's recommendations in areas such as the protection of red corals and other marine animals, the report was diluted in its parliamentary procedure, which in addition to other gaps already present initially (such as inadequate monitoring of compliance with the recommendations) justifies my vote against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM) was established in 1949 by an international agreement. Its competition area encompasses the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters. Its main functions are the promotion of the development, conservation and management of living biological resources, the development and recommendation of conservation measures and the promotion of cooperation projects for training. The European Parliament and the Council intend to amend this Regulation to include the measures contained in the recommendations of the GCC. The recommendations of the CGPM establish a sufficient level of legislative protection that must first be applied by the contracting parties, before taking additional measures. I voted in favour of this draft resolution to transpose the recommendations of the GCC into EU law.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM) promotes the development, conservation and sustainable management of the marine ecosystem in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. The GFCM cooperates with Croatia, Bulgaria, Cyprus, France, Greece, Italy, Malta, Romania, Slovenia and Spain and with many countries in North Africa and the Middle East. The General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean has adopted a number of recommendations that will regulate sustainable red coral catches, reduce accidental catches of sea turtles and birds, seals and high protection of endangered species of marine organisms such as sharks and stingrays.  I supported the report on the Fisheries Provisions of the Agreement on the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean, as I consider that the GFCM recommendations ensure a sufficient level of safety for endangered species and sustainable fishing.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the report because it contains technical measures and lays down certain provisions on fisheries in the area of the Agreement of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GPM) which are mutually beneficial to all contracting parties.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this report. The proposal contains technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area. Such measures go beyond the protection already ensured to these species at EU level by the Habitats Directive and other Union acts, and include specific recording and reporting obligations for both operators and Member States.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the regulation on certain provisions for fisheries in the area covered by the GFCM Agreement The proposal contains a framework of important initiatives and regulations aimed at transposing into European Union law the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean on the sustainable exploitation of red coral, reduction of accidental catches of seabirds , sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), set up in 1949 by means of an international agreement, is a regional organization concerned with promoting the development, conservation, rational management and optimum use of living marine resources. I share Mr Mato's view that the transposition of his recommendations by EU law is entirely desirable.  I believe, in fact, that they establish a satisfactory level of regulatory protection in the fisheries sector.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation the recommendations adopted by the General Committee on Fisheries for the Mediterranean in 2011-2013. These recommendations relate to the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of by-catch of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans, and the protection of sharks and rays, fragile species and ecosystems that we need to protect and manage with caution. The commission's proposal is therefore welcome, even if it is three years after the adoption of the recommendations. In the meantime, some Member States have already transposed and implemented the recommendations. Implementation at EU level has, on the one hand, to take due account of existing national measures and, on the other hand, to reflect the spirit and letter of these recommendations, which are the result of lengthy negotiations between the contracting parties. This is what motivated my report, which was approved by the Committee on Fisheries with a large majority (20 in favour, 4 against and one abstention).  Today I received an important negotiating mandate for the first three-way dialogue with the Council and the Commission, which will take place on 2 March.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The promotion of sustainable management and the associated protection of endangered species is in itself to be welcomed. However, since the actual reorganisation has only been outlined, but not described in detail, and this is administratively inefficient and therefore costly, I voted against the report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was established by international agreement in 1949. The area covered by the agreement includes the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and the adjacent waters. The main tasks of the GFCM are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources, formulate and recommend conservation measures and promote cooperation projects in the area of training. The CGPM Contracting Parties are: the European Community, Albania, Algeria, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Croatia, Egypt, France, Japan, Greece, Israel, Italy, Lebanon, Libya, Malta, Morocco, Monaco, Romania, Syria, Slovenia, Spain, Tunisia and Turkey. The provisions of the GFCM should be implemented in order to defend, conserve and develop living aquatic resources. Hence my assent.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because of the increased protection and conservation measures for seabirds, sea turtles, cetaceans, monk seals, sharks and rays that were incidentally caught in the GFCM Agreement area. The measures go beyond the existing directives and Union acts and now include specific monitoring obligations for both operators and Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area. The GFCM was set up under an international agreement in 1949 covering the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and connecting waters. Its main tasks are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources, to formulate and recommend conservation measures and to promote cooperative projects in the area of training.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal, the agreement contains a number of welcome conservation measures for the Mediterranean – particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which transposes into EU law a number of measures (sustainable exploitation of red coral, reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, conservation of monk seals, etc.) adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) at its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013. The aim is for these measures to be implemented in a uniform and effective manner within the Union.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We have today approved this proposal, which aims to incorporate into European Union law the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean on the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays. Some of the measures envisaged go far beyond the protection already afforded to the species in question at Community level by the Habitats Directive and other Acts of the European Union and therefore end up including certain specific obligations regarding registration and communication for both operators and Member States. We therefore believe that the GFCM's recommendations establish a sufficient level of regulatory protection which must therefore be implemented by the contracting parties before further measures can be taken in this regard.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Public Health and Industrial Policy. Mato on the provisions for fisheries in the area covered by the GFCM Agreement. Since its inception, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean has had the function of promoting development and conserving and managing aquatic resources. It can count on the support of all Member States in addition to those that embrace the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. There is therefore a need to transpose into Eu ropean Union law those provisions which characterise the GFCM agreement in order to establish a sufficient level of regulatory protection.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for the report as the proposal seeks to transpose into Union law several measures adopted by the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean (CGPM) at its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013. The GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation established pursuant to Article XIV of the FAO Instrument of Incorporation. The EU and ten Member States (Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, France, Greece, Italy, Malta, Slovenia, Spain and Romania) are Contracting Parties to the GFCM Agreement. To the extent that the content of the GFCM recommendations is not or is only partially contained in existing Union legislation, the transposition of the relevant provisions of the GFCM is necessary to ensure that they apply uniformly and effectively throughout the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — (DE) I rejected this proposal because those states which are already following stricter directives than indicated in the proposal must not be penalised. The recommendations of the GFCM should continue to be considered, but the protection of the ecological system is paramount.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of living aquatic resources in the Mediterranean while reducing the accidental capture of seabirds, sea turtles or cetaceans. Although it could have been even more ambitious in terms of environmental protection, the report contains measures that complement and complement those of other EU directives, such as Habitats.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because these measures and control and monitoring programmes will help to ensure that the Mediterranean environment is kept in an active economic situation.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. — The aim of this proposal is to transpose into EU law the recommendations of the General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean (CGPM). In particular, it includes measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM Area and protection against fishing activities for sharks and rays. All of them go beyond the protection afforded by the Habitats Directive at Community level and are in line with the efforts that many Member States have made. For all of the above, the vote cast has been favorable.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report. It is essential that the UFK recommendations are applied uniformly and effectively throughout the EU. In order to restore the ecosystem and protect vulnerable species, a system of multilateral cooperation must be effective. The technical measures envisaged will promote the development, conservation and moderate management of living marine resources. In addition, uniform legal regulation will ensure the application of uniform recommendations of conservation measures and promote the implementation of joint training projects. I believe that it is appropriate to allow remote-controlled underwater vehicles to be used only until 2015, pending extensive research. It should be noted that the Commission should take into account national management measures and plans already implemented by Member States on the basis of the UFK recommendations when transposing the recommendations. It is essential to ensure that recommendations and national measures are compatible and complementary, not the other way around.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is intended to include the measures contained in the recommendations of the GFCM; whereas it contains technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays in the area to which the GFCM Agreement applies, given that the proposal also transposes into Union law a number of measures applicable to fishing for stocks of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — I have made a positive statement on this proposal for a regulation on certain fishing provisions in the area of the GFCM Agreement. The adopted technical measures will help to care for protected species such as the Mediterranean monk bear or sea turtles, as well as efforts to sustainably use economically significant species such as red coral in the Mediterranean Sea, Black Sea and Adriatic.  In particular, I consider the adopted amendments 14, 18 and 19 tabled by the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee to be good. Amendments 14 and 18 have improved the proposed text from the position of small fishermen, especially those dealing with the catch of anchovies.  The last of these accepted amendments is also important because of the experience of fishing in the Adriatic Sea. Croatian fishermen have a higher number of fishing days than the proposed minimum, which included time spent at sea without laying nets. Namely, in more than one third of fishing days on small blue fish, there is no laying of a net in the sea at all for a number of reasons such as: sudden change of weather, appearance of dolphins or tuna that disperse fish, amplification of the current, inability to find fish on certain days, etc. The adopted text amendment provided some flexibility needed for Croatian fishermen to continue the existing fishing practice, i.e. fishing. only that time with registered catches is included at the time of fishing days.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. — I support the proposed package of provisions for fishing in the area of the Agreement of the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean. I believe that the proposed package, further enhanced by the amendments, is a good framework for fishermen in the Mediterranean. In particular, I support the provision I proposed by the adopted amendment, which, under Article 16, four Member States ensure that vessels equipped with trawling nets and surrounding nets to swimmers for small pelagic stocks set out in paragraph 2 do not operate for more than 20 fishing days with catches per month and no more than 180 fishing days with catches per year.  In my view, such a provision is fairer to fishermen and that days where there were no catches should not be subtracted from the days allowed for their activities by fishermen. This applies especially to Croatian fishermen swimmers who can only hunt on days without moons and who, unlike floating trackles, are threatened by both predators and corinths. This provision will also allow more precise keeping of statistics on the number of days without catches, fishing efforts, etc. which can be used to develop future technical measures when managing.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the Report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1002/2013. 1343/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council of 13 December 2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement (General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean) as I consider that the measures adopted by the GFCM follow the global objective of ensuring and promoting the development, storage and rational exploitation of living marine resources. The GFCM encourages joint organisation and integrated cooperation on the exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. In particular, I welcome the measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean, which focus on conservation and a high degree of protection for many living organisms, and consider that these measures constitute a satisfactory degree of protection of fishing resources. The General Fisheries Commission successfully cooperates and works with a number of countries, including the Republic of Croatia, and implements structural changes in the field of aquaculture and fisheries.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was established by an international agreement and its area of competence extends from the Mediterranean to the Black Sea and adjacent waters. The relevant tasks of the GFCM concern the promotion of the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources and the formulation and recommendation of conservation measures. Over the years, as is normal, its competences have evolved, and in recent sessions the GFCM has taken important measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral in its area of competence, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays in the area to which the GFCM agreement applies. For this reason, I support the proposal to transpose the recommendations of the GFCM into EU law.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — It turns out that the agreements of the CGPM, covering the whole of the Mediterranean, introduce stricter protection measures for marine resources and habitat. Through this vote, the European Parliament must position itself for or against the integration of these conditions into European Union law. I'm in favour of it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), established in 1949 covering the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters, has as main tasks to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources, to design and recommend conservation measures and to promote cooperation projects in the area of training. The GFCM has adopted a set of measures aimed at ensuring, for example, the sustainable exploitation of red coral; reducing accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans; a high level of protection of the shark and the ray against fishing activities, in particular those concerning sharks and rays on the list of endangered or threatened species; sustainable development of small pelagics in the Adriatic Sea. These measures go beyond the already guaranteed protection of species at Union level by the Habitats Directive and other EU acts and should be incorporated into EU law. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal amending Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011, which aims to transpose into Community law the recommendations of the GFCM.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted against the report submitted because it intended to reduce, by way of exceptions, the level of protection measures proposed by the Commission, on the basis of the recommendations of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM area , as well as strengthen the protection of threatened species of sharks and rays.  The Commission is not characterised by its over-zeal in protecting the environment and any protection of the biological resources of the Mediterranean Sea is little when we take into account the state of devastation in which it is as a result of human activity. So there is no compelling reason to amend the Commission's original proposal.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM), established in 1949, covers the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and adjacent waters. The main missions of the CGPM are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of living aquatic resources, to design and recommend conservation measures and to promote cooperative projects in the field of training. For example, the CGPM has adopted a number of measures to ensure the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans during fishing activities, as well as measures to protect sharks and rays from fishing activities. Such measures go beyond the protection of these species already provided at EU level by the Habitats Directive. The reason I voted today on this report is because it proposes to amend regulation (EU) 1343/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council, which includes certain provisions relating to fishing in the area covered by the CGPM agreement to include the measures contained in the recommendations of the CGPM.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the proposed amendment of Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council because it considers the recommendations suggested by the General Committee on Fisheries for the Mediterranean (GFCM) for sustainable exploitation of red coral to be relevant and justifiable, reduction of occasional catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, as well as the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays belonging to the ecosystem covered by the GFCM Agreement. I welcome, like the rapporteur, the proposal to transpose these GFCM recommendations into Community law, because these measures go beyond the protection that is already conferred on these species, at European Union level, the Habitats Directive and other Union acts, and for imposing specific obligations on operators and Member States to record and communicate relevant information on this matter. However, I share the rapporteur's concern about the transposition already made by the Member States of these recommendations, which should not be subject to derogation.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because this report reduces the Commission's proposal containing technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and stingrays in the area where the GFCM agreement applies. These measures go beyond the protection already afforded to these species at EU level by the Habitats Directive and other EU acts and include specific registration and communication obligations for both operators and Member States. Furthermore, the Commission's proposal is in many cases stricter than the GFCM's recommendations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted against the report submitted because it sought to reduce, by way of exceptions, the level of protection measures proposed by the Commission, on the basis of the recommendations of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (CGPM), for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, to reduce accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles, monk seals and cetaceans in fishing activities in the CGPM area , as well as strengthen the protection of threatened species of sharks and rays.  The Commission is not characterised by its over-zeal in protecting the environment and any protection of the biological resources of the Mediterranean Sea is little when we take into account the state of devastation in which it is as a result of human activity. So there is no compelling reason to amend the Commission's original proposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation a number of provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the CGPM (General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries) agreement, of which the EU and several Member States (including Spain) are part. While the Commission's proposal was even more restrictive than the CGPM's recommendations in areas such as the protection of red corals and other marine animals, the report was diluted in its parliamentary procedure, which in addition to other gaps already present initially (such as inadequate monitoring of compliance with the recommendations) justifies my vote against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. — The report voted on today is aimed at transposing into Union law a series of measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) at its annual sessions in 2011, 2012 and 2013.  The text, which I have decided to support with my vote in favour, seeks to accept the recommendations of the GFCM faithfully and in their entirety, preventing misinterpretations leading to the definition of more stringent and very often unjustifiable additional measures. I am thinking, for example, of the European Commission's initial proposal to classify as vessels ctively fishing for small pelagic vessels those for which sardines and/or anchovies account for at least 50% of the catches made on each fishing trip. Given that this time reference is not adapted to the local situation in the Adriatic, where the borders are generally less than 12 hours, I hope that during the forthcoming negotiations with the Council and the Commission, the original text of the GFCM recommendation will be taken into account and that a fair compromise can be reached in order to clearly identify vessels that actually fish for bluefish, based on more representative catch data.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. — The ec diploma proposal is an intelligent and consistent instrument to support the management of mediterranean marine biodiversity in the context of human activities. With this diploma are created specific rules to protect turtles, seabirds, monk seals, cetaceans and some species of sharks.
