With regard to the harvesting of red corals, there is also a concern from the Commission to introduce rules that limit effort. The proposal now adopted in Parliament includes the possibility of using remote-operated vehicles for commercial operation in the future. However, if this use happens, it should take into mind the negative implications that technology may have, both in contact damage and by increasing effort. We cannot allow the proposed reduction of effort in smaller depths to be technologically transposed to greater depths in a strategy of fishing down the deep. As precautionary security, marine protected areas, which have already benefited overexploited red coral populations in Europe, should be extended.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted with the majority in favour of the proposal for a regulation on certain provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area. The proposal contains technical measures for the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the mitigation of incidental captures of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in the GFCM Agreement area. I welcome this proposal which aims to transpose into Community law GFCM recommendations

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I support these amendments bearing in mind that they contain certain technical measures aimed at strengthening the sustainable exploitation of red coral, reducing accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and whales, but also preserving the Mediterranean monk bear, sharks and stingrays.  All of these species face a number of threats that threaten their survival. Red coral, which, due to its economic gain, is a frequent target of illegal exports, is particularly at risk. Also, the number of red coral populations is also influenced by the methods of its catch, so it is essential to enter a provision that would allow the catch of red coral only one specialised type of tool, thereby preventing the destruction of the entire habitat in which it is located. What further exacerbates the position of red coral is the global warming we are witnessing, as well as the growing problem of marine pollution.  For all the above reasons, but also because of the realization that red coral is a natural wealth that we will irreversibly lose if we do not react in time, we need rational management of red coral. We need to recognize as urgently as possible the limits to which coral can be optimally exploited so that we do not jeopardize the possibility of it growing again in the same habitat. I support this report because it represents the first step towards achieving this goal.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the provision for fishing in the area of the GFCM Agreement adopted at its annual sessions in 2011 and 2012 by the GFCM for the sustainable exploitation of red coral in its area of competence to be transposed into Union law. One of these measures relates to the use of remotely operated underwater vehicles. The second measure relates to the catch of red coral, which can now be unloaded in a limited number of ports with appropriate port facilities. Also, it is forbidden to collect red coral at a depth of less than 50 m until scientific studies are advised otherwise and for collecting red coral, the only permissible tool is a hammer used manually by fishermen.  I also welcome special emphasis on the care of injured animals or animals caught accidentally.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the change to the GFCM Agreement (General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean), as the proposed changes take into account science and practice. The European Commission proposes to regulate very rigidly the exploitation of red corals, sea turtles, seabirds, different species of whales and other species in the Mediterranean Sea. The Commission is seeking an absolute ban on red coral catches below 50m deep and adopts delegated derogation acts, and should not implement this on Member States that have already transposed recommendations into their legislation. Due to the nature of the fishing work, it should be avoided to the maximum that the nets surround the areas of sea turtles, and not prohibit their use in the area. Protected species return to the sea unharmed and live, and in case of death or injury they are brought to the port, which inspection authorities are notified to at the latest upon arrival of the ship at the port, and not at the time of the event. The date of delivery of information from Member States until 15 December shall also be extended and the Commission shall provide information until 31 December. Since the Adriatic Sea is also included in this provision, Croatia should take into view the opinion of scientists and edit certain issues with national legislation, in order to maximize the recognition of the specificities of the Adriatic Sea and the entire Mediterranean.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I support the proposal as it mainly entails technical and other measures that will increase the effectiveness of the measures under the GFCM Agreement. However, like the rapporteur, I do not agree that in some cases the Commission is pushing for even stricter recommendations than the GFCM, even in cases where this excessive rigour is completely unjustified and contrary to scientific advice.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The protection of all marine organisms must be a major factor in any relevant agreement, regulation or provision.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted for Mr Mato's proposal. The measures it contains go beyond the protection of these species already provided at EU level by the Habitats Directive and other EU acts, and provide specific obligations for recording and reporting data for both operators and Member States. In addition, the proposal implements certain measures in EU law concerning the fishing of small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. — The conservation of red coral in Mediterranean waters should be a major objective of European fisheries legislation. We must pursue poaching practices and strengthen sanctioning legislation. In addition, European legislation must ensure the social sustainability of fishing activities. Fishing areas must be environmentally sustainable but artisanal and inshore fishing should also be allowed. We must remember that this activity is the livelihood of many families on the Mediterranean coast.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. — I supported the report which transposes into European law the latest provisions adopted in the General Committee on Fisheries for the Mediterranean (CGPM). This commission brings together 23 countries bordering the Mediterranean, and guarantees the sustainable social, economic and environmental use of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean. These provisions are essentially intended to protect red coral, restricting harvesting conditions, and to preserve certain species such as turtles and seals, by prohibiting their on-board detention.  I am very much in favour of the work carried out by the CGPM, because today it allows the Mediterranean States to act in a concerted way to tackle the problem of fisheries resources in the Mediterranean. Today, we have far too little data about the species that live there, and the state of play is catastrophic. According to the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee of Fisheries, 95% of stocks in the Mediterranean are overexploited. The EU will have to impose research programmes and make new management proposals.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The objective of the report is to transpose into European legislation a number of provisions applicable to fisheries in the area of the CGPM (General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries) agreement, of which the EU and several Member States (including Spain) are part. While the Commission's proposal was even more restrictive than the CGPM's recommendations in areas such as the protection of red corals and other marine animals, the report was diluted in its parliamentary procedure, which in addition to other gaps already present initially (such as inadequate monitoring of compliance with the recommendations) justifies my vote against it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — There is no shortage of issues in the common fisheries policy, especially when it comes to protecting marine biodiversity and ensuring sustainable development, including for fishermen.  The draft regulation submitted to Parliament dealt with fishing in the Mediterranean; it aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of live aquatic resource stocks. Other measures will promote the sustainable exploitation of red coral, the reduction of accidental catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans, and the conservation of monk seals, sharks and rays in this area.  It is therefore the extension of other existing European texts on the protection of these species.  While we can only regret that Parliament's votes are still not up to the task of these issues, including here where the environmental requirements proposed by the Commission have been reduced, this is a step in the right direction. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This proposal aims to transpose into Community law the recommendations of the GFCM.  However, the Commission ignores the measures that are already in the Member States and which are already aligned with the GFCM recommendations. Member States that have already transposed the GFCM recommendations may not have to submit to the Commission today the requests for derogations provided for by the GFCM. However, it should be noted that disabling the derogation procedure also takes away the procedure for obtaining an independent trial to see if Member States have actually transposed the GFCM recommendations to protect red coral. The Commission's proposal is in some cases more stringent than the GFCM recommendations. For example, the Commission completely prohibits the use of underwater vehicles for the exploitation of red coral after 2014, when the relevant GFCM recommendation does not prevent it from being used in the event of favourable scientific advice. Most of the amendments proposed by the rapporteur and other Members seek to dilute the GFCM recommendations.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I rejected this proposal because those states which are already following stricter directives than indicated in the proposal must not be penalised. The recommendations of the GFCM should continue to be considered, but the protection of the ecological system is paramount.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a regional fisheries management organisation established under the FAO, whose objectives are to promote the development, conservation and rational management of marine resources. This legislative proposal aims to transpose into EU law a set of measures adopted by the GFCM. Technical measures are at stake to enable sustainable management of red coral, mitigation of accidental capture of seabirds, turtles and cetaceans, as well as the conservation of seals, sharks and rays. The Mato report generally weakens the European Commission's legislative proposal, which occasionally goes beyond the GFCM's recommendations on the protection of red coral and other wild animals that could be accidentally caught; in some cases, it does seem to call into question some of the GFCM's recommendations. Hence our vote against.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council (18 December 2014) (2014/2854(RSP)). With regard to the statement by the European Council and the Commission, I welcome, for the first time in this capacity in the European Parliament, the new President of the European Council, Mr Donald Tusk. Mr President, welcome to the European Parliament. (Applause) Mr Tusk, we look forward to working closely with you. We have just reminded us, when we came in, that you were sitting in the same place four years ago, when you were a representative of the Polish Presidency, which we remembered as a very successful Presidency, now as President of the European Council, so you have the floor immediately.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. - Mr President, here, in the Parliament of European citizens, on French soil, I want to honour the victims of the Paris attacks. We all stand with France and the French people. We will not forget. We will not fear. Three messengers of death cannot – will not – intimidate millions of people of good will. That is exactly what we proved in Paris last Sunday. May this brutal act only strengthen our unity in defence of our liberty, of our solidarity, and of our laughter. I last stood here – as you mentioned, Mr President – in 2011 as Prime Minister of Poland. Today, it is my duty and my pleasure to brief this Parliament as the President of the European Council. After an overview of the meeting in December, I will sketch out the work ahead and give you some of my ideas about our Union. You will find that they have not changed since the last time I spoke here. Honourable Members, as you know, to defend everything is to defend nothing. If you have 10 priorities, you have none. That is why, in December, I invited leaders to focus on just two crucially important issues needing our immediate attention. These are injecting investment into the European economy, and the situation at our eastern borders with Ukraine and Russia. On investment and growth, we discussed and agreed the plan to establish a European Fund for Strategic Investment. Today the Commission presented the plan in more detail. At our meeting, leaders gave their support and set a firm timeline. Now it is for you, as legislators along with the Council, to ensure that the fund is ready by June. The aim, as you know, is to unlock billions in new investment in the European economy. The European Investment Bank can already start signing off the first projects this month. This investment plan will complement our economic strategy based on sound public finances and structural reforms. Of course, I know as well as you do that the investment plan is not a silver bullet but only part of our efforts. If anyone has an idea about how to overcome the crisis at one stroke, please speak up. Personally, I am convinced that we still need constant work and many ideas, because the economic ‘philosopher’s stone’ simply does not exist. We also agreed on stepping up the fight against tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. This is an important issue – and not only for public finances: it is also a matter of fairness and social justice. We will come back to it in June. Regarding the situation in Ukraine and Russia, leaders had a frank strategic exchange. On the sanctions, we agreed that the best thing for now is to stay the course. We will decide the next steps in March. Meanwhile, we will support Ukraine and its government, including financially. The more we help the ‘new Ukraine’, the better our own future will be. That is why we discussed more financial aid for Ukraine. Last week, the Commission proposed lending a further EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine. Leaders also welcomed the intention to increase humanitarian aid. Ukrainians must know and see that Europe is with them. I also took the opportunity at the December meeting – the first of my presidency – to set out a clear agenda for the months ahead. In February, leaders will discuss ways to improve governance in our Economic and Monetary Union. I also decided, after consulting with the French President, that the February European Council will deal with the challenge posed by the Paris attacks. In March, we will discuss the European economy, the energy union and our approach to Russia, including in the context of the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga in May. In June, we will take decisions on the digital single market and review the Investment Fund. Going back briefly to December, the European Council also discussed foreign fighters and the passenger name record (PNR) issue, in the presence of President Schulz. We know this is a difficult and delicate topic. This Parliament has rightly taken seriously its role in defending the freedoms of European citizens. But I also ask you to help us protect the security of those who elected this chamber. Yet again we face the everlasting dilemma between security and freedom, and yet again we must find a wise balance between these two fundamental needs. If we are unable to build a coherent security policy for the Union, sooner or later we will put at risk the freedoms that we have built at European level, including Schengen. I do not want to see that happen on my watch. If we do not get a single European PNR, we may end up with 28 national ones. National systems would be a patchwork with holes. They would interfere with the privacy of citizens but would not properly protect their security. One European system is clearly better for security and freedom. That was true in December and, unfortunately, it is even truer today. We do not have the privilege of living in boring times. These are tough political times. This is the time when the Europe our children will inherit is being decided on, day by day. That is why, firstly, we must be clear about our fundamental values: solidarity, freedom and human dignity, including the right to live free from fear. This also means fighting the enemies of those values – whoever and wherever they are. Secondly, we need strong determination to end the economic crisis, especially to reduce unemployment. It is also our responsibility to create a genuine Economic and Monetary Union. I take this task very seriously. Our common currency, the euro, is our advantage. Lithuania’s decision to become the 19th member of the eurozone is a sign of confidence in the currency. (Applause) Thirdly, the European Union must be strong internationally. We will support those in the neighbourhood who share our values. The European Union will not turn a blind eye when borders on our continent are changed by force. We have stood united on this issue and we will continue to do so. Only unity can bring us results. Lastly, the relations between Europe and the United States are a cornerstone of our prosperity and freedom. In this context, I believe one of the most important challenges is to make progress in the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). Leaders were clear in December: the EU and the US should make all efforts to conclude negotiations on a comprehensive, ambitious and mutually beneficial agreement by the end of 2015. With all of these things, all the European institutions must work together for their common good, while respecting the role that each is here to play. We will conquer the challenges facing us with energy and optimism or not at all. Certainly no European nation, and no single state, can conquer them alone. For my part, I will use all the skills I have to keep the work of the European Council results-oriented and focused on what really matters. For a long time now, I have observed that the institutions compete with one another. It is my personal ambition to change this to total cooperation, and the first weeks of my work, together with Martin, Jean-Claude and Federica, are proving that it is possible. Honourable Members, a few words to conclude: I do not think Europe is old, haggard or barren. I have no doubt: Europe is young, dynamic and vital. (Applause) Our continent remains the best place in the world to live, and I think the European Union is the best political organisation in its history: a political organisation, which means that it is a tool in our hands, not a despot, nor a destination. There are some here who do not wish the Union well. Perhaps I could say I respect that, but I do not. If we undo the European Union, no one will be freer. No one will be better off. No one will be safer. (Applause) I believed in Europe when the Polish Solidarity movement was born in 1980. I believed in Europe when the Wall came down in 1989. I still believed when I spoke here as Prime Minister in 2011 and, honourable Members, I still believe in Europe today. I want a Europe of free citizens, a united, internally secure Europe, safe from external threats and confident about its future. We must remember that Europe is a real community of nations and peoples, and that is why we must not be afraid of tensions among us. They are often productive and creative. Equally, we often get better when we agree to disagree. I am sure that in this room we have a difference of opinion on the Charlie Hebdo cartoons, but as Europeans we share the fundamental view that no one has a right to use violence or to murder people because they have a different religion or a different sense of humour. (Applause) Similarly, for instance, we have in this room different views about Russia and different interests in relation to Russia. But no one here, I deeply believe, will ever accept a state invading and occupying the territory of another state or killing its citizens. Politics is about the disagreement we allow to play out on the rock of our principles. However, we will never get anywhere without recognising that the fates of Europeans, of all of us, are fundamentally bound together. That is why I stand here today.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen, I will be brief because I have to be brief.  I have to be because the College of Commissioners is still in a meeting, and when we are discussing important issues that require deep meditation, I would not leave them alone. It is therefore a paternal reflex that forces me to reach my colleagues as quickly as possible. I must be brief and I can be brief because the President of the Council has said what needs to be said in presenting before you the results of the first European Council which he was able and had to chair. He did so brilliantly because it was the shortest meeting of the European Council I have ever attended. I hope this will bode well and I would like us to be able to sleep at night when we are in Brussels. He drew your attention to the fact that the European Council supported, in terms of its principles and its main joints, the investment plan that I had the opportunity to present to you at the end of November.  I would like to point out here that the investment plan complements the arsenal of policies that we have at our disposal. I would like to stress once again that the virtuous triangle that we have defined is to continue the fiscal consolidation that is still needed, that it is to revive the structural reforms that European interests in the medium and long term require, and that it consists of stimulating investment in Europe, which has been failing since 2008 since the overall level of investment in Europe has fallen by more than 15% and well beyond in some Member States.  I would like once again to invite Member States to contribute bilateral payments to the capital of the Strategic Fund that we are setting up. Unfortunately, the Council has not been able to collect the first agreements that The Member States could have given at the Council meeting on 18 December, but once the mechanism is in place - and the Commission is in the process of deciding on its implementation - I would like the Member States to contribute in large numbers to give impetus to the investment plan by participating in the financing.  I would have liked to describe to you today in plenary the elements of the Commission's communication on flexibility on the Stability Pact, but as the College is still discussing it, I must postpone this presentation. It will be interesting, I can assure you. But I say once again here that the rules of the pact will not be changed. I note, including in this morning's speeches, that the expectation is great that the pact will change in nature. It will not change in nature or rules, but we will add a dose of flexibility to the pact by applying these guiding principles. Of course, the Commission feels obliged - but this was its initial intention - to present to the Council, by June, a package of measures to combat tax evasion. We agreed and I said that to you in presenting the program.  (Laughs from some EFDD MPs) Some people, when we first discussed this problem, laughed. I see, if only on the daily reading of European newspapers, that there is less and less laughter.  And they will be even less so in the future. We will present an action programme... (Exclamations from EFDD MPs) Sometimes you speak a language that is difficult to understand. I do not see the need to listen to each and every word you say in this House. Really, I do not. Irrespective of this, the Commission will do its job and present to the institutional authorities - in the Council and Parliament - a directive on automatic exchange on early tax decisions. I draw your attention to the fact that we will decide today on the establishment of the strategic fund. We could have done it ourselves - Council and Commission - without involving Parliament in this legislative work. But as I promised, we intended to rehabilitate the Community method. Therefore, we would like Parliament to be closely involved in this legislative work.  Thank you, Mr President of the Council, for allowing me to be as brief as possible. I'm leaving you with a heavy heart.  (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I would like to begin by offering him a warm welcome on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to the new President of the European Council. Today is the first time that you have been speaking in plenary and presenting a report. With Donald Tusk, we have a Poland at the head of the European Council, one of the most important institutions of the European Union. He is now the second Pole to lead, after Jerzy Buzek, who was already the pole, as one of the former new Member States, the second Pole. Perhaps it is also time to stop distinguishing between new and old countries. We are a Europe, and donald Tusk also symbolises it. (Applause) I would like to offer him a close partnership with the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and, I believe, with Parliament as a whole, which is also characterised by mutual respect, because we have different roles. The European Council's task is to describe perspectives, to describe the long-term orientation of our continent, given the power of the Heads of Government, and we, as legislators, have the task of implementing them. This respect is expressed in your words. I am grateful for that. I would also like to emphasise that you take concentrating seriously, focusing on the essential points that are now before us, because the citizens expect us to focus on the great things of Europe. I would like to ask you to do the work of the next few years: I would ask you, when communication and press conferences take place after the meetings, to remind you that they do not always just say: 'I have decided I have prevailed, I have achieved'. It would be nice if we in the Council, and I am sure you will try to do so, create a climate where it is said: 'We have moved forward and moved for Europe'. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she We are delighted that Donald Tusk is here. He has already raised a number of key points in the first session. The full support for the Juncker programme, for our President's ideas to stimulate investment, is a great success, given the debates we have had in the Council over months and years. We are pleased that the legislative proposals have been adopted today, and we also assure the President of the Commission that we will do everything possible to accompany the decisions quickly. However, we also want to provide our citizens with answers quickly. With regard to Ukraine, one of the most burning foreign policy issues that surrounds us with our neighbours, you made it clear in the first session that we continue to be partners of these people who stand for freedom and democracy. The support is there, it has also been made clear by the financial support that the European Union has decided on in recent days. I would also like to say explicitly that I welcome the fact that the sanctions are working. Some in the public debate were surprised that sanctions suddenly have economic effects. I think the aim was for them to have economic effects. We hope that, as a result of these sanctions, this economic pressure, the Russian leadership will then return to the path of partnership and cooperation. Finally, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to take up Paris, because that will be the top issue for the next Council. Europe is somewhat in shock. Feelings are mixed in Europe. Between courage, concern, fear, but also self-confidence, the feelings we feel in Europe resonate. Above all, the European Council – we then, but first of all the European Council – must take the lead and make it clear that we are giving serious answers to these challenges. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports this, and the Commission's PNR proposals are already on the table here. We want us to make progress on this. In respect of the data protection rules, we want legislation to be adopted here in order to better monitor those who are at risk. We also believe that we need to do something about the external border debate. In other words, better protection and better monitoring of Europe's external borders is one of the objectives we have to pursue. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she Working on a Europe of security is our common task. It is necessary to give our citizens the answer that we can meet the challenge and also give answers. I would like to extend a warm welcome to the new President-in-Office of the Council. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is looking forward to working closely together. (Applause)

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr Presidents, Mr Tusk, welcome. On behalf of my group, we wish you the greatest success in your management and a constant, permanent presence in this Parliament. Since this December European Council was convened, we have seen a different passion between the Commission and the Council, a different level of concreteness and commitment. Because the Commission went to the presentation of its strategic investment plan in time; it did so with a consistent amount, which does not satisfy the investment gap that the European Union has, but which is a good sign, which is a good principle. In turn, we have just been told that issues relating to the regulation of the Fund, the impact that the Fund will have on the 2015 budget, and also how to use, more flexibly, within the Stability and Growth Pact, the instruments available to us are being prepared— they are being prepared, they are being discussed. I therefore believe that the Commission has complied. I recognise the Commission's willingness to include the European Parliament through the ordinary legislative procedure. However, the Council has not been specific in the assumption of publicly funded financing commitments in the strategic investment plan. I do not know what they said in the Council; I do know what they said outside. And outside they have made no concrete commitments to the financing of that plan. Nor have they assumed the necessary neutralisation of these funds within the Stability and Growth Pact, nor have some regulations sleeping in the Council that are necessary for the union's growth, such as that relating to the Digital Agenda, been unlocked. A word about the PNR. I believe — coming from a country with experience in matters of terrorism — that legislating at highly emotional times is dangerous. And so what we have to do is, with serenity, agree, to provide more security for European citizens, but not to sacrifice freedoms and rights to advance that security. Again, welcome, Mr. Tusk.

name: Andrzej DUDA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Welcome to the European Parliament by President Donald Tusk. This is the first meeting where we have the opportunity to meet you, and it must be said loudly, as you said today, that Europe is facing many difficult challenges today. You also said that we do not live in boring times, we do not have this privilege, but you also mentioned Polish Solidarity, which has won freedom in Poland and which I also understand in the context of European solidarity. Today, much is being said about the plan to rebuild the economy in Europe, about a plan for reindustrialisation, which is to create new jobs. This plan – president Juncker's plan, which stands out here and was the subject of the last European Council – is facing a great challenge today. This challenge is the energy situation in Europe, especially in central and eastern European countries. This is particularly evident now in my country, Poland.  I ask you, the government of the Civic Platform in Poland (the party from which President Donald Tusk came here from, from which he came here to the European Council) has in recent days announced a plan for the decommissioning of coal mines, which is the main raw material in Poland – not only in Poland, but also in many countries of the European Union, especially Central and Eastern Europe. This is very dangerous for our economy, it is very dangerous for many European economies, especially in the age of the climate package, which was adopted by the States of the Union and accepted by the European Council, and if there is no intervention, joint intervention within the European Union countries on this issue, and financial assistance, it will lead to the loss of not hundreds, not thousands, not hundreds of thousands, but perhaps even more than a million jobs by the loss of many industries. , especially the energy industry.  Today in Poland, miners strike 11 mines, strike underground. Their families are terrified, because the prospect of the decommissioning of coal mines in Poland is the loss of thousands, tens of thousands of jobs, the destruction of the existence of thousands of families, the loss of bread, the loss of dignity that work represents for people – the work that they will lose as a result of these actions.  I wanted to call today, but at the same time ask a question, to call for the Juncker Plan, at the time of the adopted climate package, to take into account the needs for change in the energy economy, to take into account the needs of the necessary changes in the extractive industries, to include them in financial terms, so that there is money foreseen for the modernisation of European energy, especially in those countries which, as a result of decades of communist rule, are now still going backwards. , in terms of economic development, in relation to the strong, great states of the old European Union. This is a huge challenge facing the union as a whole today, a challenge that we must meet. I call for this and ask whether the Juncker Plan will take these needs into account, or will we see pictures like poland today in Poland – weeping people, desperate miners, desperate people from the energy industry who are at risk of real job losses? The Juncker Plan should build these places and not allow them to be abolished.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all: Mr Tusk, welcome; I should say good luck. I have always been a fan of yours; I always thought you were better in the Liberal Group than in the PPE Group, but that is only a small remark. My only request to you is not to lose your pro-European behaviour and your pro-European opinions that you always had, because you are now leading a bunch of 28 prime ministers. You know how they are; you are one of them, and it will be necessary to see the general European interests and not only the addition of the interests of the 28, and that is your main task. I think you have two priorities for the coming weeks and months. First of all, this investment plan may work. Until now we have called it the Juncker Plan; let us be honest, colleagues, we have to stop this. It has to become a Tusk plan; it has to become a Hollande Plan; it has to become a Renzi Plan; it has to become a Marco Plan, a Michel Plan, a Rutte plan; from the 28 – and that is the reason why I am a little bit disappointed by this Council of December. Let us be honest. It was a short Council; I do not criticise it, but I would have preferred a long Council, and then at the end, 28 Member States saying yes to this Plan and entering into the guarantee scheme of the investment strategy of the European Union. Because it does not count, even for the Stability Pact – we know it. That was one of the elements of the flexibility. So why was it not possible for the 28 Member States simply to say: ‘okay, we are backing this investment plan and we are entering into the guarantee scheme behind it’? Secondly, you have also to make the link with the structural reforms. It is not enough to have only announcements about structural reforms; a link between the structural reforms and investment plans is necessary. Finally, I think that the Commission has to come forward with a number of legislative packages to open up the markets, because an investment plan alone is not enough. But I think also that in that respect, Mr Tusk – I ask you, with your intervention, we have to deploy the Telecom package. We are talking about the digital market; we are always looking to Google because of their monopoly position in Europe. But it is our own mistake, because we have no digital market. A telecom package is the first step to make it possible, and I think your second priority is also very clear: that is, to have a package to counter terrorism after the dramatic events in Paris. Let us be honest. I have here all the decisions taken by the Council in 2001. I was President of the European Council at that time, and we took three big decisions. There is a paper of 21 September, two weeks after the attacks of 9/11; of 19 October, a few weeks after the attacks of 9/11; and then December, Laeken, more than 30 pages about our counter-terrorism strategy. You have to read it, because everything we are talking about today was decided already in 2001, and a number of things have been implemented – for example the European Arrest Warrant – after a long battle with Mr Silvio Berlusconi, who was against it. He thought it could be used against himself, and that could have been possible; well, after a long battle, finally it has been realised. I think we have now the need to have a second package in the fight against terrorism – and that is your task for the coming weeks and the coming months – like we did just after 9/11. I see three elements in this. The first element is to retransform INSEN – what we have today does not work, it is a lose cannon – into a real European intelligence service, because the main problem today is not that we have a lack of collecting information; the problem today in Europe is sharing the information. I can tell you, all those who were responsible for these attacks – last year in Mumbai; in Utoya, Toulouse, Paris, the Jewish Museum in Brussels; in Madrid, London; the killing of Theo van Gogh, the Dunblane killings, Boston – all the perpetrators were known by the secret services. It was a lack of sharing, a lack of common analysis, that we have in Europe, and I think that is the first element of your package. The second element is: let us extend the possibilities of Eurojust, of Europol – blocked in the Council, Mr Tusk, for the moment. Let us also have a European Prosecutor; let us also have (in my opinion) EU P and R but you have – the Commission has – to present a new proposal which responds to Parliament’s request – mainly the request that we need also a data protection regulation and directive before we can start with the P and R. Finally, Mr President (and I shall conclude with this), we have also to talk about strengthening our external borders. It is completely stupid what some people have been saying since the attacks in Paris, that we have to come back to national border control. Would that have helped? If you want to have a border in France, maybe you can make a border, as Daniel Cohn-Bendit said two days ago, between the Beaulieu of Paris and the Centre of Paris. That is the reality. What we need is not to undo Schengen; what we need is to have better external border controls, and that is the package and your task for the coming months. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, I find it odd that you talk about improving external border control when a number of parties in this House – including your own, and certainly the three political parties in my country: Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives – all want Turkey to join the European Union. Wonderful, is it not? Surely you would agree with me that the best way to fight terrorism in the European Union is to reinstate national border controls and do away with freedom of movement of peoples? (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – That is the most stupid idea that I have ever heard in this Chamber.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Tusk, welcome to the European Parliament, but I honestly do not understand why you and Mr Juncker, who has just left, are celebrating the European Council of 18 December 2014. yes, you finished it very soon. But what did you decide on that? You just exchanged wishes: "Merry Christmas and Happy New Year." What have you decided on member states' participation in the European Investment Package? Are you going to join? What amounts? By what criteria will investments be allocated? Will they go where there is more disinvestment, recession and unemployment? Or "business as usual"?  Do you know that in December 2014 the European Union and the euro area saw negative inflation, deflation? Do you know that all the Nobel Economics notes the risk of deflation and a new cycle of recession? Do you know that the world economy sees the euro area as the weak link? Do you know that since 2009 poverty and unemployment have increased within Europe and within the euro area and inequalities between north and south, between the rich and the poor, between rich regions and the south? How long will the European Central Bank try to allay the Bundesbank's objections and blackmail and not act as the European Central Bank of all Member States, buying government debt, promoting quantitative easing? Where are the new fresh resources that will succeed in implementing the Juncker Package - or the Fund, say it as you wish, Mr Verhofstadt. I have not seen anyone believe that 1 in 15 leverage can be achieved in this Europe of stagnation and deflation. Only Jesus Christ has achieved such miracles and Jean-Claude Juncker is not Jesus Christ. More and more people are saying that we must finally end this dogmatic, one-sided austerity, which brings recession, unemployment, poverty, but also disinvestment. For six years we've been trying the Berlin recipe. It is time to turn to development, a "New Deal" that will bring jobs, reclaim a social state in conditions of the rule of law. In a few days we are voting in my country, Greece, and the vote of The Greek citizens, on 25 January 2015, may be a positive turn for a Europe that is democratic, social, with jobs, with growth. My party, SYRIZA, does not want to break up Europe; wants to make Greece an equal, democratic member state of the euro area with growth, with jobs, with a social state, with the rule of law. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Papadimoulis. So I think we can say together that Mr Juncker is not Jesus Christ. That is something that the House can agree on in its entirety. How, Mr Verhofstadt, do you have any doubts about this? But that is what we say to Mr Juncker!  Mr Lamberts, sit down again, we are not there yet.  Mr Coburn, you have not been calling 'rubbish' for three minutes, so I have not come to your attention. Please, stay cool! Keep cool, colleague, one moment!

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if the gentleman agrees with me that the best thing for Greece, and for many of the states in southern Europe, would be to leave the euro, which has been an unmitigated disaster from the very beginning. It is a political currency – it is not a proper economic currency. No one in their right mind should have had it in the first place. You would be much better off out of it. Do you agree with me?

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you, Mr Coburn, for the question. This is the agenda of Mr Farage, Mrs Le Pen. Apply it if your voters leave you in your own countries. We do not want to break up the eurozone, nor do we want Greece to leave the European Union. We want Greece, as a member of the European Union and the euro area, to have no unemployment, no poverty, to develop; We want the rich to pay, not the poor. Because in Greece shipowners pay four times less tax than their crews. This is the SYRIZA programme, and it has nothing to do with the far right programme.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Tusk, welcome here. For me, Poland has always been a great State in Europe and, with your arrival at the head of the Council, I think Poland shows that it occupies its full place in the European Council. From that point of view, I look forward to your arrival.  You said: "Now is the time for serious political challenges" and I would like to draw your attention first to the seriousness of the social challenges. Europe is the promise of shared prosperity. Today, one in four Europeans is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. One in four citizens is not shared prosperity and I have not read anything about it in the Council's conclusions, other than, of course, the fact that you want to join the investment plan.  But even if he succeeded, which I doubt today, he would not guarantee a return to employment. Even reducing unemployment would not yet be a guarantee of reducing inequality. Look at the U.S.: unemployment is falling and incomes are falling at the same time. There are more working poor in the United States today than there were before the crisis.  So if we want to solve the social challenge, we have to address the tax issue. You have mentioned a few things about this, but we would like to see energy on the Council's side to focus on necessary tax harmonisation, to put an end to the tax war that the Member States are waging. The second category of challenges is environmental challenges. In this area, Poland does not have a very glorious history behind it.  The environment, Mr Tusk, is not a variable of adjustment, it is not a subject that is dealt with when we have nothing else to do. The environment is what allows you, me and all of us to live on this planet. If our environment becomes unlivable, humanity will disappear and, in this regard, I am very concerned that the environment is no longer on the Commission's agenda, is not on the Council's agenda and that, in the end, it is a concern that is left for later.  There, you have a boulevard in front of you with the energy union, which is something other than a purchasing powerhouse to ensure the sustainability and security of our energy supply.  The energy union, Mr Tusk, must be the instrument for the European Union of its energy transition, a transition that puts renewable energy and energy efficiency at the heart of its strategy with a triple dividend. First, strategic energy independence, which is an economic dividend because by leading the energy transition, we will be world leaders in transition technologies, and finally a climate dividend and an environmental dividend because we will have helped solve this existential challenge for humanity. The third challenge I would like to draw your attention to is the democratic challenge. This is the case in Poland as everywhere in Europe: the confidence of our citizens in their democracy declines with every election. People don't believe it anymore! They no longer believe that we are all defending the public interest. Today, when decisions are taken in Europe, they most often appear to be taken under the influence of industrial or banking lobbies rather than in the idea of defending the public interest.  I would like to take a few examples. When we have economic governance that, in reality, imposes decisions on public service, social policy and fiscal policy on Member States without any democratic assembly legitimising these decisions, we are no longer in a democracy.  I was very concerned to read in the Council's conclusions that you were pleased and that you absolutely wanted to reach a free trade agreement with the United States before the end of 2015 at a time when hundreds of thousands of Europeans are saying: "We do not want the clause on an investor-state dispute settlement mechanism". What does the Commission say? "Oh, it doesn't matter, we don't care." We are sending a message to our citizens that they do not count in democratic debates. That is the third challenge.  Mr Tusk, you have shown that you are a statesman. I hope that, as President of the European Council, you will be up to these three types of challenges: social, environmental and democratic.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, first I would like to give my customary welcome to incoming President of the European Council. I can see why they chose you. You are perfect. You are like the euro record that has got stuck in a groove – a completely out-of-date view of what Europe is. Clearly you have learned absolutely nothing from the results of the European elections. As you know, in the United Kingdom, immigration is the key debate. It is dominating political discourse within our country. At the heart of that is the whole question of the free movement of peoples, but your debate is the other side of the same coin. Your debate is about immigration, and time and again, you have promised the Polish voters that young Poles would return to Poland. At the same time, Mr Cameron has promised the British people that fewer Poles would come to us. It turns out that you have both been wrong and that your country has been depopulated by two million people since you joined the European Union. The reason is obvious. It is money, is it not? You yourself prove the point. You are the newest Polish émigré, and you have gone from a salary of EUR 60 000 to a salary of EUR 300 000 a year. Congratulations: you have hit the EU jackpot. But you have also scored a great victory without trying, because last week Chancellor Merkel went to Downing Street. She spent a few hours with Mr Cameron, and Mr Cameron is now a big supporter of the free movement of people. He said: ‘Let me be clear, I support the freedom of movement’. So on that one you have won a great victory against Mr Cameron without having to lift a finger. But he also says that he will now restrict the benefits of EU migrants working in Britain. In the past you have been very clearly opposed to this. Please answer me today, Mr Tusk: is it right that children who live in Warsaw should qualify for child benefits if their parents are working in London? Please clarify that point for me today. In some ways you face quite a tough test, though not with the UK – our leaders are a soft touch. Despite the Lithuanian lemmings, you have got the euro crisis, a referendum on whether the UK stays a member and, of course, the appalling growth of attacks on Jewish people. I would put it to you, Mr Tusk, that the European elections showed us one thing: the voters in Europe want change. They want massive, wholesale reform, and I am entirely confident that you are not the man to provide that.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, Mr Donald Tusk says that there is nothing that is sure to improve the situation in Europe. He is wrong. There is one way. When Poland was occupied by the Moscow-oriented socialists its rate of growth was 1%. When it became free it was 8%. Now under the occupation of Brussels-oriented socialists it is once again 1%. It is slightly better than the rest of the countries occupied by the European Union, but slightly less than Belarus. What must be done? Our enemy is not in Moscow: our enemies are in mosques, in the mosque of Paris, in the mosque of Marseilles. What we should do is reject socialism, abolish income taxes ruining industry, liquidate all social benefits attracting to Europe the worst elements and demoralising all Europeans, and reintroduce the death penalty. We cannot win the war when they kill us and we cannot kill them. In fact, if you are to survive, we must reject all the acquis communautaire. Therefore, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr. President! I believe that the statement 'our enemies are in the mosques' is incitement to the people, and I would ask you to respond accordingly! (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Bütikofer. You can be sure that the comments made by my colleague, who has just spoken, will be checked with the utmost care. I find it disgraceful.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to welcome you to the European Parliament on behalf of the Polish delegation of the Civic Platform and the Polish People's Party. I greet you not politely, but warmly. I believe that this is important for the Polish the Former Prime Minister of the Polish Government is the President of the European Council. We may have different views on the views expressed here, but above all we want to express respect for the country, its history, which you represent in this House.  Many elements were discussed during the European Council. What is obviously the most exciting is investment. A colleague from the European Left said that there are only savings, so when the word investment is said, there is a project, i think it should be developed very wisely. The question is whether this level of investment is going to be 300 billion, or whether it is going to be higher, as m.in. Polish said. Perhaps this programme should be more consolidated in terms of the share of public funds as well. Because we may sometimes suspect that some investments, in particular privately funded ones, may be those investments that would have been created anyway, and not necessarily financed, unless public money was also invested there. I therefore call for a question on what this contribution by the Member States should be and whether private sector contributions should be more balanced.  I also stress the importance of investments that concern the energy sector. We understand the energy mix differently, but we believe that energy security should come primarily from the European resources of the 28 Member States that Mr Verhofstadt spoke about here. I would also like to encourage Member States to contribute, as such a contribution should not, in my opinion, be included in public debt statistics. As for fiscal consolidation, we believe that tax avoidance – yes, but this consolidation in terms of tax equalization – is understood differently by different countries.  Finally, the strategy towards Ukraine and Russia. This neighbouring country of the European Union requires assistance, not only humanitarian aid, not only aid to Ukrainians who have suffered losses, but also development investments.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, Mr Tusk, I would like to thank Mr Tusk for his work on Polish politics has recently earned a great deal of credit. Great merit, as my colleague mentioned, is that the real extent of the investment gap in Europe has been identified. Keep breaking the denktsabus that forbid you to talk about it. It is essential that we get a realistic picture of what will help us in the future. We wish the College good luck and courage. Arrives in the economic reality of Europe, and also defines the practice of the Stability and Growth Pact in such a way that discipline, growth and stability can shake hands! But to do that, we need investment in the future. As Social Democrats, we want to make the Juncker plan work. But then we have to test it, we have to refine it, we have to correct it until it can really go into the investment fields of Europe in practice. That will be our common mandate. I am pleased that all My Fellow Members will help.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr. President! President Tusk, I would also like to welcome you very warmly, as President of the European Council. I am pleased that, for the first time, you have a pole at the head of the European Council. I believe that Poland can be proud that, as an Eastern European country, it now embodies this Presidency with you. I believe that Poland can also be proud of what it has achieved in recent years and almost decades: the economic recovery, the construction, the connection to Western Europe and its prosperity. But Poland has managed to do it on its own. Poland has done it through its own performance, and so I was surprised, Mr Tusk, that you, as a representative of a country that has managed to do it alone, have now cheered the euro as a currency as you have done, even though the success you have achieved has been precisely due to the fact that you have been able to make your own decisions with your own currency. We can see it in the example of France, which will become of countries that share the common currency and are then no longer competitive. We see countries stagnating when they can no longer withstand competitive pressure under the single currency. Mr Tusk, you are a European, as I am one, but please reconsider your position on the single currency. Nor would it be in the interests of your country.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate President Tusk. We Czechs and Poles understand each other, so I can say ‘hodně štěstí’ (‘best of luck’). I would like to make a few references on the European Council conclusions. For once, I am happy that the European Council has identified the right issues and has come forward with timely conclusions. I also appreciate the fact that we do not see Council conclusions in terms of a shopping list or a Christmas tree which is supposed to make everyone happy, but rather as something which shows what the top priorities for the upcoming period are. I also appreciate that a decision has been taken on the fund. On the other hand, there is one thing that I really miss. We did have an economic conference in the ALDE Group to which Vice-President Katainen came. He said that a significant linkage with structural reform would complicate the whole set-up. I do not agree: we need that link, otherwise we will be wasting money. The third remark is on one of the conclusions on better regulation. I must say that it is the Council, and therefore the Council structures, including the European Council, that have the worst record on better regulation. The absolute minimum is impact assessment. There is no single effort in the Council to deal with it, and I think that this is something I would like to bring to your attention. I hope that something will happen at least to match the Commission and the European Parliament on that. My last remark is on Russia. If I may quote you, ‘we need an adequate, consistent and united strategy on Russia’. I very much agree. I would only add that we need to make sure that we will implement it in a united way, that we will have a common policy. I have every confidence that you will ensure that the European Council and the Heads of Government speak with one voice. I am also critical here of some Czech politicians in this respect.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr. President! The euro zone is depressed, the debt has risen rather than fallen, the population is angry. Germany is also in a coma. You can't have a party when your neighbor's house is on fire. The troika has stifled investment. The best investment, therefore, is to bury the troika. The Fiscal Compact is stupid and an investment brake. Finance ministers who do not invest at zero interest rates are crazy. Euro investment has slumped 15 percent since the crisis. According to the Wall Street Journal, the investment gap is as high as €800 billion a year. The Juncker plan is voodoo. €21 billion of guarantees will be €300 billion of investment. Even this wonderful increase in bread – jesus Christ was mentioned here before – represents only 0.8% of EU GDP per year. Instead of siphoning off mega-wealth and drying up tax havens – as the star economist Piketty demands – insurance companies should invest in highways and schools. When the state invests, it creates wealth for all. Taxpayers have to pay for the return of the financial sharks. This is expensive nonsense. We are calling for a public investment programme of EUR 260 billion per year. This pays off with higher taxes and growth. The ECB should finance public investment through the EIB, rather than pumping liquidity into the banks without thought. We need a wealth levy for millionaires – as demanded by the IMF. Roosevelt once led the US out of the crisis – against the power of big money. We don't have a Roosevelt in Brussels, we don't have A Jesus Christ in Brussels, but we have Alexis Tsipras in Athens. It is the answer to impotence and corruption. Our investment package for Europe is called Syriza.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, maybe the only positive thing about the European Council of 18 December was that it was a short one. The problem is that, in our eyes, the investment plan is neither a short one nor a very positive one. It is not what is needed to overcome poverty and unemployment on this continent. What is needed is an end to the rigorous austerity policy and investments in energy transition, the phasing out of nuclear power, the phasing out of fossil fuels and investing in energy efficiency and in renewables – that is where new jobs will be in the future, and not in infrastructures and models of the last century. What is needed is social and ecological change; it is needed all over Europe, but also in Greece. Let me mention the change that Angela Merkel recently suggested when she said it would not be problem any more if Greece were to leave the euro. This was an irresponsible electoral support for Greece’s conservative party and it has also weakened the euro. I think that is not needed. What is needed is for the Greek citizens to decide who they are going to vote for and not to have another Member of the Council saying irresponsible things. We do not need that.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: As regards the decisions of the Pre-Christmas European Council and the further possibilities for their implementation, do you not seem to be facing new challenges – how do we enable new solutions to work if there are decisions taken in the past?  The previous term has been repeatedly discussed in the new financial period 2014-2020. This monumental 7-year document has long been discussed and combined. Today, however, in many countries, a penny has not yet been spent on these billions. I am concerned that similarly, the decision taken by the European Council in December last year to create a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which could accumulate EUR 300 billion over two years, which could be used for economic promotion and growth. Our decisions are often drowned out by the constant sea of proposals and deadlines for implementing those decisions and how to control the implementation of those decisions. Very fast decisions on employment and growth, on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, on a comprehensive energy union are what europe needs today. And the middle of this year and the end of this year are not the deadlines we could wait for.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr. President! Listening to what Mr Tusk and President Juncker have said here, we can only speak of an absurd theatre. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a political burlesque of the special class. We have the highest unemployment rate on our continent in six decades. The euro has fallen to its lowest level since 2006, and the debt levels of some countries, such as Greece, are already around 180% of their respective gross domestic product. Against this background, the two highest representatives of this Union are scattering roses and burying their heads in the sand as the problems get worse and worse. Gentlemen, no one believes you or your policy any more! Just as no one believes you that you are pursuing tax policy in Europe. After all, the European Union is the biggest tax avoidance association on this continent! While the European nomenklatura is taxing itself by a few percentage points, the tax screw for the citizens of Europe is getting more and more tightened. Ladies and gentlemen from the ruling groups, you are leading this continent to a dead end. This continent and the great peoples of Europe deserve better than your failed policy.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Mr President, many important issues were discussed at the last European Council, but after what has happened in France, it seems to me that a century has passed since then. There was talk of the Juncker plan, the fight against tax fraud, the Free Trade Agreement with the United States, but all that already sounds old to me after what has happened in France in recent days. I am going to talk to you today only on one subject and ask you to keep as a treasure the spirit of unity that we all saw last Sunday in Paris. May they make the spirit of Paris, the unity against terrorism, one of the greatest treasures of the European Union, of being Europeanists.  We have been talking about foreign fighters for a long time, but we honestly have to ask ourselves: what has the European Union done? What have we done at European level in this regard? The Paris attacks have been against France, but they have also been against Europe and, above all, they have been against our freedoms and our rights: the terrorists wanted us to have a little less freedom of expression today. We must not and cannot allow Islam to be blamed. The fault is not of any religion; it's the fault of fanaticism, whatever religion fans have and even if they don't have any religion. What about us? We will be wrong when from Europe we are exporting thousands of terrorist apprentices and allowing them to then become adult terrorists to kill us. It is in our hands to approve the air passenger data plan. There's no point in us not approve of it. It would help fight terrorism. That's not all there is to do, all right. But that's what we can do. I hope there's no other attack! But, if any, surprise this Parliament by doing its homework. May this Parliament be surprised by having done everything it should. May this Parliament be surprised to explain to the citizens that there was nothing left to do to ensure that it did not happen.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: Mr President, I was pleased to see the Council acknowledge the harm from aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance, both in its statement in the December meeting but also reiterated again now by both Presidents. However, the only concrete measure referred to, both in the statement and now in our discussion today, has been the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings in the EU. While that transparency is, of course, welcome, as my group has long argued, we need far stronger measures to tackle tax fiddling. In particular we need country-by-country reporting of profits by all multinationals, we need a common definition of tax havens, and we need to blacklist those firms engaged in tax fiddling and the advisers who help them to do this. Some of these measures, as well as the creation of a common consolidated corporate tax base, have been held up by particular Member States within the Council. Those intransigent countries, of course, have included that of the President of the Commission, Luxembourg, but indeed also my own home country, the UK. So can I please implore Presidents Tusk and Juncker to make sure that these long over-due measures are genuinely unblocked at that meeting in June? By doing so, you could unlock one trillion euros, which certainly puts the investment package into perspective. We are counting on you to do something about this issue. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask Congresswoman Dodds what she would consider a really good solution to aggressive tax planning? I ask only because, for example, in my own country, Hungary, the Hungarian Government just the other day imposed a tax of half a euro per kilogram on solar panels, which can be classified as environmental investments.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: blue-card answer. – I think there is a whole range of options for dealing with aggressive tax planning which have actually been put on the table in the past but – as I mentioned before – have been blocked. So if, for example, we could have common definitions around taxable assets and activities across the EU, that would solve many of the problems. If we could have more transparency around where profits are generated, and if we could have better enforcement of agreements reached and wider freedom of manoeuvre for the Code of Conduct Group within the EU, that would go a long way towards dealing with some of these problems. We have an opportunity now, following LuxLeaks, and we need to make use of that opportunity.

name: Vicky FORD
text: Mr President, the EU does need to change: there are serious problems in many Member States. Our national leaders need to listen more closely to the people, and we in this Chamber need to listen more closely to our national leaders. There are still deep problems in many European economies. We need investment in energy, transport, digital, innovation, production, but politicians cannot keep spending taxpayers’ money, so we must encourage that private investment. But the private investment is facing global competition for that money. We need trade, and investors do need rights. Our single market is meant to help businesses and consumers to trade easily across borders, to remove bureaucracy, to boost competitiveness. We must make it work, and we must make it work in a digital age, or we will lose it. It is time for Europe to do less and do it better: reduce costs, bring down burdens and build the economy fit for the 21st century.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we join in the congratulations that the European Council sent to the Ukrainian Government in December. We congratulate the Ukrainian Government on the great political innovation, instead of ministers chosen by the people, now as many as three foreigners selected by an international recruiting agency. Among them is the finance fund, a Us woman, a former employee of the US State Department who went on to run a Ukrainian Investment Fund and received citizenship on the day of her appointment.  We congratulate ourselves on this new perestroika, business will finally become transparent and we Italians will no longer be the only ones with conflicts of interest in politics for appointed or hetero-direct governments. We congratulate the financier Soros, who has admitted that he helped overthrow the Ukrainian government and who sponsors the recruiting agency of foreign ministers. On the anniversary of Auschwitz, we congratulate the Ukrainian Minister of the Interior, who is under his control of the Nazi Azov Battalion, whose emblem was already in use in the SS.  We welcome the one million persecuted refugees most of whom have fled to Russia, and ask why! We welcome the sanctions, the damage done to thousands of European businesses, the billions we have and should be paid in aid from the taxes of our citizens who are still being asked to make sacrifices for austerity while they risk being involved in the Third World War on their doorstep. The new Ukraine truly a masterpiece worthy of the greatest historical mistakes of the worst masters and advisors overseas, the same ones who want TTIP. It is not a question of being against or pro-Russia, but of being neutral and doing the interests of european citizens for once.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, As is my custom, I wanted to make a very calm and comprehensive speech in the sense that we see this Europe economically as a disaster, and I say this also as mayor, seeing my citizens with all the difficulties they have.  In these few seconds, I would like to point out two things to you: this Europe, over and above the economy that is going wrong, lacks courage. We have all seen the (unfortunately) issue of Paris, so I put on my shirt to remember with a historical cartoon what the tragedy in Paris was, but I also want to remember – because I would like there to be a European Guantanamo in Europe to try to combat violent Islamic terrorists, including the flag of ISIS. We must have the courage to say that ISIS must be fought and destroyed! We must destroy these people, I am not with the Islamists as such, we would miss nothing else! Everyone has their own religion, but it is right that, if they come to Europe they must stand by our customs and customs and must respect us. The West is not an enemy, the West is a source of culture and if they want they come here and stay by our rules otherwise they will come home to them, including ISIS!

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Firstly, I would like to greet President Tusk, wish him all the best in his duties and say that, for the EPP and also in my case as Portuguese, it is an honour to finally have a Polish at the head of the European Council. I think that is a sign of the vitality of Europe that I wanted to welcome here. Secondly, I would also like to give a word to our French colleagues following last week's attack, a word of solidarity and brotherhood, and to review here everything that our Spanish colleague González Pons said about the tasks that the Community institutions and, in particular, the Council on terrorism have been all about. I would like to leave two words on the last Council: one to welcome the Commission's investment plan and the way in which the Council has embraced it and wishes that the Council can now, and each of the States represented in it, support the implementation of this plan 100%, because we need this determination to recover the European economy and in particular , those economies, as is the case with the economies of the countries under assistance, which are more depleted and more fragile, this is a point.  And the second, which I have very much adore here, is the importance that has given the energy union, the single energy market, which is fundamental for the European economy and european security and which is very important, in particular, for the countries of the Iberian Peninsula, which could make a major contribution to the diversification of energy sources and which , without this single market and without new links through France, they will not be able to do so.  I greatly welcome these two results of the last European Council.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, the main conclusion of the Council summit is that investment in Europe must be encouraged after years of failed austerity policies. Of course, we can only agree with that conclusion. The debate between us is about how we can revive this public and private investment.  I must tell you that I wonder, along with many European citizens, when I read in the final Council document that negotiations for the transatlantic treaty between the United States and Europe must be accelerated. Why such a rush at a time when studies by economists and scientists are taking place that show very clearly that the economic benefits of this treaty for Europe are largely hypothetical? These studies also show very clearly that there can be risks to exports from most European countries and downward pressure on wages, in short, that today the risks and threats are real.  Therefore, at the end of this Council, I ask the following question: by trying to move very quickly for ideological reasons, are we not threatening the European project and should we really continue this leak forward?

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, in my speech, I would like to comment on only one thing discussed at the European Council, namely the European Strategic Investment Fund of EUR 315 billion. We can certainly all agree on the importance of accelerating strategic investment in Europe, which should help to grow faster and help to be more competitive. There will certainly be a very complex debate on the direction of these funds in specific projects, not only in Parliament, but also at Council and Commission level. What remains unknown, however, is the fulfillment of this huge investment package. The debate on allocation from Horizon 2020 and CEF in the European Parliament will not be easy. Today, it is also unclear whether member states and the private sector will be replenished. The big question mark for me remains in the idea of the speed of the debate in the European Parliament, when trialogues are planned as early as May. For me, it's too much uncertainty about such an important thing.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The first step should surely be to manage taxpayers' money responsibly in this house. Donald Tusk has Herman Van Rompuy as his greatest idol according to his own statement. After all, Mr Van Rompuy is now leaving office in Parliament with an indefensible share of taxpayers' euro banknotes in his pockets. Over the next three years, he will receive EUR 730 000. There's money coming after that, too, of course. Severance pay and pensions at levels that are a mockery of every ordinary worker in the Union only underpin the contempt and disinterest of ordinary people who have worked hard to get a decent standard of living at retirement age. But what they get is crumbs compared to what Herman Van Rompuy and what his successor Donald Tusk will get. You also see it as an obligation to implement genuine economic monetary union, unlike me, which sees it as a very great threat to those countries that then find themselves having fallen as obeying states under the EU headquarters.
