If this is achieved, the United States of Europe has finally been constructed. I and my group will do everything in our power to put an end to this megalomania. You no longer have the trust of ordinary people in this house. Voter disdain is only increasing, and voter participation is only declining.

name: Milan ZVER
text: I would like to thank the President of the European Council, Mr Donald Tusk, for an excellent and comprehensive presentation of the conclusions adopted in Brussels in December by the Heads of State of the European Union. It is right that the Council has paid the most attention to the new Juncker Investment Plan for Growth and Jobs, as this is crucial for the long-term development and stability of the European Union. We have already laid the foundation for a new start-up of the economy under Barroso, when we focused on balancing public finances and structural reform. Now is the time to spin, and these are investments – only then can they bring the more vital European Union that you have spoken about, Mr President. The investment plan, which was supported by the leaders in December, will mobilise more than €300 million over the next three years with the help of a new European fund, thus boosting economic growth, job creation and increased competitiveness. What is important here is that it is not just taxpayers' money. The Juncker project will only be successful if it is supported and if everyone does what they have to do – especially the Commission and the Member States. We must create a legal basis, take all measures, but, dear friends, this project will fall if it is understood by citizens and the economy as a bureaucratic project. They have to take it as their own. It will be shown whether the European institutions are willing and sufficiently capable of doing business.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Mr President, I would like to address Mr Tusk in saying that his appointment as the head of the European Council has a high political meaning, and we congratulate him. Mr Tusk, you are arriving at a very special moment – a moment where the European Union can only deliver if it is possible to pool national resources. We believe this will be your most important and challenging task. We need to pool national resources in order to foster investment and job creation; we need to pool natural resources to provide better energy solutions, more internal and external security and also to ensure real faith in European integration. Let me tell you that you can count on the European Parliament and also on the S&D Group for this purpose.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Ms Rodrigues, I have two very quick questions. First of all, would you not agree that the best way to get more investment going in any economy is through confidence, and the confidence will not be there as long as debts continue to pile up through excessive spending? Could you also explain – to the British people particularly – why it is an attractive prospect to us to pool our national resources across Europe when we already do not have the things we require in our own country? You suggest that we pool our resources for them to be dissipated all across the EU. Could you explain why that is attractive to us?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card answer. – Let us take an exact example, coming back to the last European Council. We are creating a fund for strategic investment, and if we want this fund to pool resources and lend on a larger scale, we need to have clear contributions coming from Member States. So I believe this should be a task for the European Council at its forthcoming meetings: we need to have a stronger fund for strategic investment.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr Tusk, let me also congratulate you on your important position as President of the European Council. The Council you chair is calling for the creation of a €315 billion investment package. European politicians have always liked to devote themselves to redistributing money earned by someone else. Unfortunately, this package is just marketing. Juncker's $315 billion package is marketing. It's not going to work. It will not bring new jobs, it will not bring real investment. If you want more investment, stop defending them first. We have unrealistic climate objectives, absurd regulations on safety at work, absurdly high social protection. No wonder investors are leaving. I think that this is your task: to improve conditions so that quality and solid business can be done again in the European Union.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, I have two points. Firstly, having listened to this discussion and the shouting from over there today, it strikes me that the problem of the extreme right in this House is that they are not at all right, only extreme – extremely wrong, and I think that their correct name should in future be ‘the extreme wrong’. Their only idea is disrespect and contempt for other people. That is an idea we have seen too much of. It is so wrong and so extreme that their name should be ‘the extreme wrongs’. Secondly: the investment plan. Do not invent the wheel again. I think it is good to have a plan in order to mobilise capital financing of new investments, but the gap we have in Europe is much bigger than any public investment plan can bridge. The investment plan and the bridging of the investment gap will need real political reforms and structural changes. The digital agenda, the telecom package – do it! The internal market and the service directive – ensure that it is done! This will bring an opportunity for profitable investments with a return on investments, because the nature and the spirit of commercial investments are that they are both commercial and investments – not spending. That is the way we should proceed. We need to deregulate, make things easier and ensure that we can have an open Europe. If we can do that, we will fight the lack of growth and the lack of the extreme right, who are the extreme wrong. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the  I would like to ask Mr Hökmark: there is a debate in Parliament that we should develop a version 02 of the Small Business Act, because, of course, it is precisely the Small Business Act, with the new ideas of the Juncker package, that would have a great chance of being enforced in all 28 Member States. Do you think it is possible to revise this Small Business Act and adapt it to the Juncker package in a new version?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Rübig, you are quite right, because this is exactly what we need. We need a structured reform process, making it easier for new companies, small companies, medium-sized companies and big companies to invest and flourish in Europe. Your approach is a very good one: make it easier, then we will get some of the growth; invest more and then we will get more growth.

name: Paul TANG
text: The European summit on the investment package was supposed to last two days, but lasted about two hours. You could say that countries like the chickens were there to miss their chance. Because the Member States have good words about jobs and growth, but forget the deeds, which are to reform their economies, but they will also free up money for private and public investment. Only with contributions from countries can Juncker's investment programme have sufficient effect.  Now the economic policy of the Member States is similar to that of the gold standard. That is not a good harbinger for the euro as a currency and certainly not for European citizens. They pay the price for low growth and high unemployment. I therefore ask the Commission and the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, to urge European countries to take their chances.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Mr President, first of all, I welcome the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Mobilising EUR 315 billion for investment over the next two years is a gratifying thing, which could stimulate investment if we ensure that the funds are used correctly.  I stress here the lack of clarity on the strategy for using these funds. There is talk in the conclusions of the European Council very much about the economy, but too little of people. There is talk of the European single market, fiscal consolidation, integrated capital markets, the transatlantic partnership, but citizens, social policies, equity in the distribution of funds, but especially who we help with these funds.  I wonder if we want to save banks again at the expense of citizens, if we want to save venture capital again at the expense of national or local budgets? I fear that by creating these alternative funds to the European budget we are moving away from the principles and values of European solidarity and that we are seeking to reduce cohesion funds in the future. I will fight, as a Social Democrat and Romanian MEP, for a europe developed homogeneously and with a single speed; I hope that the European Council also wants this.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, I would like to go back to two points of the Conclusions of the European Council.  First of all, the extreme caution shown with regard to the importance of public investment in The European recovery. Yet, at a time when austerity policies have demonstrated their human and socio-economic damage, at a time when private investment is showing prolonged timidity, is it not time to restore public investment to its full importance in reviving an economy that is still failing at the expense of jobs and people? Should we not consider neutralization in the calculation of the debt of public investments that are the promoters of economic and social growth? Shouldn't we also consider a more proactive attitude by the ECB in supporting these public investments? Secondly, one element I would like to stress is the Council's recognition of the urgency of - I quote - 'redoubling efforts against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning at EU level'. Similarly, the Council stresses the importance of transparency and looks forward to the Commission's proposal on the exchange of information on tax rulings. This is, of course, a vital issue for the very existence of the Union, which cannot be built on fiscal and social injustice. We will therefore remain fully vigilant in the coming months, including on the ongoing investigations, but we will also be a force of proposal to extend the anti-harmful tax engineering scheme for the European project.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime, welcome President Tusk to this House and wish him well in his work. In December, at the last meeting of the Italian Presidency, the Council also called for the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments as a priority in order to mobilise the famous EUR 315 billion between 2015 and 2017. It is clear how it is for all of us to give impetus to economic growth in Europe and, consequently, to a new impetus for employment, especially for youth employment.  We all know how much growth is linked to investment, which in these years of crisis – given in hand – have fallen sharply. For us Socialists and Democrats, overcoming the policies of austerity alone is fundamental to europe's very survival. What is the point of having budgets in order if we cannot then give hope and answers to the 27 million unemployed throughout Europe if we do not return to investing in growth and employment and development opportunities?  The Juncker Commission, which had the vote of the Socialists precisely in order to establish a policy of change, is meeting today to approve the regulation of the investment plan, a regulation that we will evaluate very carefully and on which we will have to reach an agreement as soon as possible so that new investments can be activated immediately, together with the reforms that countries are putting in place.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, Mr. Tusk, I welcome you and succeed in your new post.  Speaking of the conclusions of the first Council meeting you chaired, I express my satisfaction with the initial support for the investment plan. It is not often that leaders of all member states reach consensus relatively easily and support a proposal politically, as happened with Mr Juncker's proposal. There is a broader consensus among both member state leaders and different political groups in the European Parliament. On the necessity of such a plan after years of recession and stagnation in the European Union, caused by the lack of investment, I support the proposed plan as one of the first promises fulfilled, but I expect further work by the Council on the economic and social reconstruction of the European Union.  As regards the Union's policy towards Ukraine and other Eastern Partnership countries, they have been exposed for too long to the negative consequences of tense Relations between the New East and the New West. I agree with your assessment that the European Union needs to lead a proactive policy. Ukraine is not an important part of a post-Soviet entity in the making, but a country in the regular process of joining the European Union, and besides politically it deserves our more serious financial support.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, I just wanted to welcome the possibility of change that this decision on the investment package means in relation to the change in melody, from a tragic melody of cuts and austerity to a melody of investment and job creation. On the other hand, it also introduces the fundamental aspect of flexibility of this golden rule which we wanted to introduce, once and for all, to help those Member States which have the greatest difficulties in relation to investments imposed by their European commitments. But in any case, we have a small question left in relation to all the regulations, all the legislation that this Parliament has drawn up for the adoption of the financial perspective for the next six years: the possibility that decisions on new projects will not be confused or to create confusion as to which projects, how to finance them and how to implement them with the new package. We'd like that to be clear.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In your speech, you used the phrase 'euro – our single currency', yet the euro is not the currency of all the countries of the European Union. It is the currency of most countries. The European Union is also the United Kingdom and Denmark, which have treatyally stipulated that they do not want the euro, that is, Sweden, which voted in the referendum to post the introduction of the single currency indefinitely, and everyone has a duty to respect this decision, and this is Poland, which in the constitution constantly guarantees the existence of its own national currency. You, Mr President, are not the president of some technical body of the European Union, but of the European Council, an intergovernmental body representing all the States of the Union. I do not know if this is interesting for you, but I hope that in your work you will respect all the countries of the European Union, including those that have not adopted the single currency, and above all Poland – our country.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! Flexibility is on everyone's mouth right now. I doubt that you can fight sovereign debt with even higher public debt. From that point of view, it is right to focus on reindustrialisation and growth. Europe is an ageing continent with a declining population, the markets are saturated with needs, and I still lack an innovation offensive, a business start-up offensive, a technology offensive on the part of the Council and the Commission. We need to do more in research and development. We must tackle the problems at the root, tackle the root cause!  I have the impression that people are returning to old concepts and believe that government credit-financed stimulus can overcome the weakness of growth. I don't think so. From this, I believe that Europe can only survive if we become an innovation union. We would have liked to have seen statements from you, President Tusk.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: The Council's statements are more of the same. It insists on an insufficient investment plan, based on a mere creative accounting exercise, from which it relies on the miracle of the multiplication of loaves. It uses the euphemistic expression of fiscal responsibility and insists on structural reforms, knowing that it is austerity and attack on the social state that are at the root of this unprecedented social and economic crisis. It insists on the unbridled liberalisation of trade relations with the United States through ttip.  Finally, it brings ukraine together as a revealing element of a European Union in tow of the United States and NATO. We are now paying the bill to a Ukraine that sinks day by day. We are already going on the third loan, an amount that already exceeds 3.5 billion euros.  Here we cut the budget to serve the interests of the United States, NATO and big capital. The European Union is much more generous.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, in this debate we have seen attacks on the extreme right – and rightly so. We must indeed oppose those extremes, just as we must oppose the extreme left. In the United Kingdom we in UKIP have proved that a moderate party which seeks controlled immigration – managed migration, not uncontrolled immigration – has been able to kill off the extreme right, the racism and xenophobia of the BNP. But here in this place, commitment to democracy is lacking. I note, for example, Juncker’s comments about Greece, telling Greece to avoid the ‘wrong outcome’ in its general election. Those are unacceptable. The only crime of Syriza is to oppose austerity, and it is right to do so. It is entitled to do so. Such interference in Member States is not acceptable. Democracy must come before politics, but in this debate I have seen lip service only paid to democracy.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, just a brief one. Regarding Rule 162, I would seek an interesting clarification: my colleague just gave a fantastic speech – far better than I was going to do. But I had asked an hour before him to speak. Was your criterion that you knew he would be better than me?

name: Olli REHN
text: Mr Etheridge, my aim is to ensure equal treatment, so if somebody has already spoken, that is taken into account when distributing blue-card time. We try to have equal treatment for all Members in this House. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and on behalf of the President of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to welcome President Tusk to his first debate in this role, even if – as you mentioned – it is not the first one. I am standing in for President Juncker here, and I have just come back from the College meeting where we adopted, on the one hand, a proposal for a Parliament/Council regulation to set up a European Fund for Strategic Investment, and, on the other hand, a communication on flexibility – namely on how to use and apply in full the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. I think this is an example of a virtuous exercise. In November, the Commission presented a plan to relaunch investments here in Strasbourg; in December we discussed it in the European Council; and in January – less than 50 days after that – we delivered a proposal to put the fund in place here in Strasbourg. Now we will obviously need to continue working with Parliament and the Council to ensure their swift adoption. President Juncker will present this in detail tomorrow morning, and the Vice-Presidents and Commissioners competent for the plans and the communications themselves will have the opportunity to present them in detail to Parliament’s competent committees. I also know that a series of points were raised during the debate on the other priorities on which we are working. Let me just mention a few of them. I hope we will continue to work on them in the same way, delivering quickly and clearly: on the energy union strategy ahead of the March European Council and on the digital single market proposals ahead of the June Council. On TTIP negotiations, let me say that my colleague Cecilia Malmström is carrying out the work, both in terms of the negotiations with the US – I will visit Washington myself very soon to tackle this as well – but also internally on the level of transparency. We know that this is not only an issue for Parliament, it is also an issue for our people. We have to make sure that we have a good outcome of the negotiations that is for the benefit of all in Europe – and in the United States as well. However, our job is to make sure that it is a good outcome for Europeans. Many of you – and we had a discussion about this in the Council – referred to the need to develop a coherent strategy on Russia and on our relations to Russia. Let me say that we are working closely on both the Commission and Council sides – and here I should probably change seat a couple of times. Work is ongoing at this time on preparing for the decisions and discussions that we will have in the European Council in March. At a meeting of the Foreign Affairs Council next Monday we will already start to discuss the issue, and we are preparing this work very closely together. The virtuous institutional triangle that we see here today has allowed us to deliver so quickly on some of the things we have discussed today. These augur very well for the next five years.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your warm welcome here in the European Parliament. It is a nice surprise for me, because I have heard a lot about your temperament here in this Chamber. Let me say a few words in response to your interventions. I can only echo what Manfred Weber said in saying that I have no doubt that good communication between the institutions plays a key role. Let me again assure you that I am ready to change the logic of competition into the logic of cooperation. I can promise that I will use 'we', and not 'I'. Of this you can be sure. As regards the investment plan referred to in the interventions made by Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Guerrero Salom and Mr Papadimoulis, you should have no doubts that 28 Members said yes to the Juncker plan in December 2014. What we need now is for the legislation to be agreed between the Council and Parliament. We decided that the fund will be opened to the contributions of Member States, and they are really interested in this project, but we have to organise the staff and the legal context. I can understand why the Member States are waiting today for more details and concrete arguments as regards the legal context. It is obvious that, in December 2014 – at the beginning of this process – Member States would not declare contributions to the fund. I did not expect that they would announce specific sums of money for this fund. However, this is not because of distance or reservation – this was our plan. Mr Verhofstadt, I took note of your position on PNR. We need an open mind in seeking compromise on that. Nothing is simple in this issue. I believe that better information-sharing and cooperation between the intelligence services will be one of the results of the informal European Council in February. It is also my task to organise the discussion about the very concrete problems you mentioned. Mr Lamberts's intervention was about renewables. There will certainly be a place for renewables in the Energy Union. You should not be afraid, but it cannot only be about renewables because Energy Union is about more than just the environment issue. We need to ensure much more energy security. This is why we want to prepare it, but we will discuss it in March, also in the context of renewables. You can be sure of that. Referring to what Mr Farage said, I am impressed and satisfied. Ever since his famous speech five years ago here in this Chamber about Herman Van Rompuy, I have known that he is perhaps the best example of political and personal culture, as well as of political decency and elegance. What more can I say? I am really impressed. Keep it up, Mr Farage. (Interjection from Mr Verhofstadt: 'He is never there when you respond to him') I know, because this is about political culture, as I mentioned a few seconds ago. Let me now turn to Polish to answer Mr Duda's conclusions or his questions about the crisis in Polish mines and the possibility of possible support through money from the so-called Juncker Fund. There are no restrictions at the moment on the areas, on the part of the economy in which we will invest the money raised in this fund, but from the outset we assumed that the criteria on the basis of which loans or guarantees from this fund will be granted cannot be political criteria, but business criteria. Hence, among other things, the unequivocal intention, supported by all Member States, that the criteria and decision-making process be in the hands of managers and experts rather than politicians. Therefore, a key role in this decision-making process (where the money that we will raise in the fund) will be played by people who are substantively connected with the bank's activities and will be guided by one commandment: that this money should work for the development of the whole of Europe and, above all, to contribute to the growth of jobs. That is why possible energy proposals will be assessed in the same way. In my opinion, if we forget about politics, campaigning, etc., and we talk honestly about energy versus the Juncker Fund, that is, the Juncker Plan, then we would have to look in Poland and other countries for such projects, including in the energy sector, which will have a chance of commercial success in the future, because of course the investment fund is not intended as support for projects for which there is no chance of commercial success. to make them profitable. That's understandable. They must guarantee sustainable development and not be used for emergency assistance. I do not exclude that in this area too – I am talking about energy, also in Poland or the mining industry – there may be projects that will gain the approval of experts. Do not pre-empted any idea, no idea. For now, we are at the beginning of this work, also when it comes to collecting projects and ideas that will possibly be financed through guarantees and loans in connection with the Juncker Investment Plan. And I am convinced that all interested parties, including in Poland, will try to prepare well for this. One final remark when it comes to the Polish MEP, Mr Jurek: I will of course treat everyone equally. When I speak the single currency, I speak the language of the Treaty. The euro is the currency of the European Union, although we all know that not all countries have joined the euro area, but this does not change the fact that the euro is our European EU currency. And this is not subject, I also feel in this House, to discussion.

name: Olli REHN
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The European Council Conclusions of 18 December state that 'the new approach to investment, together with the commitment of Member States to intensify structural reforms and move forward with growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, will provide the basis for growth and employment in Europe'. However, it is clear that the obsession with structural reforms and fiscal adjustment policies has not improved the economic performance of the EU and the euro area since 2010, as evidenced by low economic growth, high unemployment figures insufferable in countries such as Spain, and the near-deflation scenario. This approach is not working, even if we add up the Investment Plan for Europe, because structural reforms and rapid fiscal consolidation are procyclical policies. Instead, the pace of fiscal adjustment should be reduced and policies capable of generating short-term growth should be put on the table. The Council should propose new general guidelines for the Union, focusing on productive countercyclical reforms and the implementation of new fiscal policies. The European Council should support increased flexibility in the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I warmly welcome the European Council’s green light for the EUR 315 billion Investment Plan, a plan that clearly demonstrates a willingness to get Europe out of the crisis and bring along the full recovery of the European economy in the interest of future generations. I see this Investment Plan as a strong signal of our commitment to get on a new path for Europe towards growth and jobs, and I hope it will be an effective and successful plan in attracting private investments and, at the same time, helping economic actors, in particular SMEs, to boost economic growth and truly create jobs. I see this Investment Plan as a unique opportunity to finance strategic projects: projects that will help realise our European vision of society and build a Europe that is socially just and environmentally friendly. Lastly, I see that this Investment Plan is ultimately about people: it is about ensuring that the millions of Europeans who are still unemployed will find a job again; it is about raising millions of Europeans out of poverty; it is about Europeans who are well trained and equipped with the right skills; and it is about ensuring that our children will have a good future.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – On page 1 of the Conclusions of the European Council dated 18 December 2014, it is stated that ‘the new focus on investment, coupled with Member States’ commitment to intensifying structural reforms and to pursuing growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, will provide the foundation for growth and jobs in Europe’. However, if we note the low economic growth, high unemployment figures and near-deflation scenario in our continent, it is clear that the focus on structural reforms and fiscal adjustment policies has not improved the economic performance of the EU or the eurozone since 2010. It is pretty clear that the current policy mix is not working, even if we add to it the Investment Plan for Europe, because structural reforms and rapid fiscal consolidation are pro-cyclical policies. Instead, the pace of fiscal adjustment must be reduced and policies capable of generating growth in the short term should be put in place. Thus, the European Council should come up with new general orientations for the Union focusing on anti-cyclical productive reforms and the implementation of new fiscal policies. The European Council should support increased flexibility of interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I would like to join the welcome of the new President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, and wish many successes, which will at the same time become European achievements. Your taking up this important position shows that the line between the old and the new EU countries is blurring. You are right to say that the European Strategic Investment Plan is not a panacea for all the ills of the Union, but it is a viable plan with a chance of success if, of course, the Member States treat it with due attention.  Parliament is ready to cooperate. The discipline of public finances and stability, supported by wise investments, will bring growth. However, it is necessary to make clear what the ways in which this plan will be financed and the availability of funds for future investors will look like. The sooner the plan comes into effect, the better. Let us hope that the work will be completed under the Latvian Presidency and that the package will start to work before the summer holidays.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I am very pleased that the European Council, in its conclusions of 18 December, calls for unrestricted access to the crash site of Flight MH17. Why has the EU not made a similar appeal in the event of the Smolensk disaster? Why was President Tusk, as Prime Minister of the Polish Government, unable to react in the same way when the tragedy affected the highest figures in our country and their families? Why did Mr Tusk not insist on the participation of representatives of EU investigative bodies who have expressed their willingness to participate in the work of the Technical Commission during the investigation? As a result of your inertion, independent experts did not have access to the crash site, and the wreckage of the plane remained in the hands of Russian experts. This situation fully illustrates your duplicity and lack of concern for the welfare of the victims and their families. I regret that, in the case of two similar events, the eu's actions are very different.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – On page 1 of the ‘Conclusions of the European Council’ dated 18 December 2014, it is stated that ‘the new focus on investment, coupled with Member States’ commitment to intensifying structural reforms and to pursuing growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, will provide the foundation for growth and jobs in Europe’. However, if we note the low economic growth, high unemployment figures and near-deflation scenario in our continent, it is clear that the focus on structural reforms and fiscal adjustment policies has not improved the economic performance of the EU or the eurozone since 2010. It is pretty clear that the current policy mix is not working, even if we add to it the Investment Plan for Europe, because structural reforms and rapid fiscal consolidation are pro-cyclical policies. Instead, the pace of fiscal adjustment must be reduced and policies capable of generating growth in the short term should be put in place. Thus, the European Council should come up with new general orientations for the Union, focusing on anti-cyclical productive reforms and the implementation of new fiscal policies. The European Council should support increased flexibility in the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Dear! At the outset, I would like to warmly welcome President Tusk here in the European Parliament. I remember, as Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland, presenting the assumptions of the Polish Presidency of the Council, and then the main comments were also about the high bar and the great expectations that our Prime Minister not only met, but also moved the bar even higher.  Today, commenting on the beginnings of the new role of our Prime Minister, I am sure that he will not only surprise everyone again with his effectiveness, but also with a new vision of the old Europe. However, returning to the subject of today's debate, namely Jean-Claude Juncker's EUR 315 billion investment plan, the positive signal of agreement from the Council is only the first small step towards rebuilding a strong Europe. The Investment Plan is not a promise of success and growth in the European Union, but an opportunity that we must seize. An opportunity for growth and new jobs and an opportunity whose success depends only on the Member States. We cannot analyse the planned investments in terms of the next guarantee for the expected change of citizens. So I have a reserve to speculate on the success of the investment plan until we see the specifics and analyses of the business and industry worlds. So I am among the millions of citizens who expect effective solutions, concrete solutions and real policies. I know that with the new EU staff and the new President of the European Council, all this is possible.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Twenty-five million people, including five million young people in the EU, do not have a job, 124 million people are exposed to poverty. Despite efforts at both national and European level, the recovery is weaker than anticipated a year ago. If we invest more in high-return projects, our economy will grow faster and we will create more jobs. This will even help us reduce debts in the medium term. At the same time, we need to examine what has hampered Member States in the EU when they are investing 15% less than before the crisis, while the US is able to invest at a pre-crisis level. We must remove these obstacles. Economists and politicians across the EU are already talking about mobilising €315 billion by the end of 2017. In addition to private investors, we also need to involve public investment in the process. However, if individual states are to increase their investment capacity, we must adopt new flexibility rules that allow countries, under certain conditions, not to include these investments in the permitted deficit.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The investment programme launched by the European Commission at the end of 2014 is an important pillar of the Juncker strategy on the economic recovery of the European Union. However, the success of this investment programme depends on the response that capital markets will give in mobilising financial resources for projects planned to be carried out. But capital markets will not give positive signals until there is a firm commitment by the Member States of the European Union to the success of this investment programme. We are already in mid-January 2015 and member Member States' reactions are still weak. I believe that the President of the European Council has a duty to keep this investment programme on the agenda of European leaders and to act so that Member States are quickly committed to achieving it.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya. As such, I am pleased, wisha happy New Year to the High Representative, to give her the floor to make the introduction to this subject (2014/3018 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - Mr President, Libya is one of the issues which – when we remember to do so – we say we have to pay more attention to, but then it is not necessarily the case that we are coherent in our actions. That is why I really appreciate the chance of having this debate in Parliament today, and also the resolutions on the table. I talked just a few minutes ago with Bernardino Léon, the UN Secretary-General’s special envoy for Libya. We have been in permanent contact during these difficult weeks and months, and you probably know very well that tomorrow is a crucial time for Libya. Tomorrow, starting in the early afternoon, Bernardino Léon has convened talks and is holding talks among different parties. Not all the actors have yet decided to participate, but many have, and let me take this chance first of all to praise those on both sides who are participating in the talks in Geneva tomorrow, and also to encourage – and I think this debate could also be a way of doing so together – all those in Libya who have not yet decided to participate in the talks, to do so now or later in the process. This is an opportunity that the Libyans cannot afford to miss. The strongest message which can come to them from here is: take this opportunity, because we are not sure there will be other opportunities for dialogue in the future. This is going to be the last chance – and I hope it is not going to fade, and so it will the last successful chance – but it could be in any case the last chance to give the country a future in terms of the political process – and also a present in terms of a ceasefire – to stop the violence which, as we know, since the last resolution, the last debate in Parliament (in September if I am not wrong), has deteriorated significantly. There is no alternative to dialogue; there is no alternative for the international community than to support – when and if it takes place – any decision to move towards a national reconciliation or a national dialogue. This is a decision which is in the hands of the Libyans. Our role can and will be that of supporting a process that needs to start in Libya itself. I can assure you that the international community, starting from the regional community, is coordinating very strongly now. This has not always been the case in the past, but finally it seems to be the case. We will not only have the international community, with regular meetings of the special envoys, but there will also be the African Union, the Arab League, the European Union itself and obviously the United Nations framework. We will have on Monday a Foreign Affairs Council, where I have decided to put Libya on the agenda to make an assessment of what is going to happen – or is not going to happen – in Geneva in the coming days. Your debate today will also be an excellent opportunity to contribute, with the resolutions, to the debate of the Ministers on Monday, and I will be particularly pleased to report back to the Ministers about the debate and the decisions of the European Parliament. In the resolutions there are a number of issues which I might return to in more detail in my concluding remarks, such as the review of the mandate of EUBAM, and other things I know that many of you are interested in. But let me say again that the timing of our discussion today gives us a unique opportunity to send a strong political message to those participating in the talks to go ahead, and to those still in the process of deciding on their participation, not to miss this historic opportunity.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, as you said, the meeting announced in Geneva by the UN Special Representative in Libya is an opportunity that should not be wasted. I congratulate Bernardino Leon for his action, and stress that we must continue to cooperate closely with him and the United Nations. I'll insist on three axes.  First, a ceasefire and a roadmap are needed for the resumption of democratic transition. Taking into account the lessons learned to overcome extreme polarization requires the efforts of all parties to continue the Ghadamès dialogue.  Second, the regional perspective is crucial for sustainable stabilization. The positive role of actors such as Egypt and the Arab League should be welcomed, not to mention the negative forces and the need for more adequate responses to regional problems.  As for the role of the European Union, I have three questions on this subject. 2015 might be an opportunity to take stock of the EU's strategy for the Sahel. Has there not been a geographically and thematically restrictive approach? Has the link between security and development been established operationally? We must find a way to stop the proliferation of weapons and other trafficking that have grown and continue to destabilize the entire Sahel-Saharan region.  The EUBAM mission: what about the reconsideration of its mandate and the reallocation of resources to take into account the current situation? Finally, I will conclude by recalling the urgent need to reach a point of no return in the dialogue between the parties to the conflict. Libya must not become a bis repetita of the Syrian case. In this context, the action, visibility and proactivity of the EU counter-terrorism coordinator are becoming all the more important.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, let me say that if time is precious, as Mr Bernardino recently said: 'time is running out for Libya and for us', it is all the more important to use the time we have at our disposal to prevent a complete dissolution of the Libyan state. I do not want to talk about the errors committed by several of the European Union states in Libya and in relation to Libya in recent years. But we are faced with a situation so serious and so tense that the authorities of this state are not functioning or are hardly working at all. We are close to the typical situation of a failing state. On the other hand, we have a situation where the Supreme Court has decided to delegitimize parliament and government, which creates an enormous complication.  The European Union must act firmly and united in this case, with the singular initiatives of some states having to be avoided because we simply no longer have time to fix what we could spoil. In this respect I believe that: 1) it is necessary to stop the fighting immediately between militias operating in Libya both on their own behalf and on behalf of external actors in Libya; (2) it is essential to prevent the conflict in Libya from turning into a conflict with broad regional implications that may affect an already fragile situation; 3) prevent the possibility of Libya becoming a new base of Islamic State operations knowing that elements of Islamic State are already being implanted in Libya.  In this respect, I believe that the European Union must fully support the efforts of the Special Envoy and the UN Secretary-General for a positive solution, and the European Union must cooperate massively and consistently with it. I welcome the statement given by the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, and at the same time call on the European Commission to cooperate closely with Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco in order to stabilise the situation in Libya at regional level.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as rival governing factions from Libya are meeting in Geneva, under the mediation of Bernardino León, the situation back home remains very precarious. Following the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime, ethnic, tribal and regional divisions have been woven now into a patchwork of rival governments and militias. The legitimately-elected government, having been forced from Tripoli by Islamists in the summer of last year, is now based in the north-eastern city of Al Bayda’. Whilst it claims – that is, the legitimate government claims – to be in control of all but eight of Libya’s largest cities and to remain responsible for approximately 80% of the country’s oil exports, military power is actually being exercised by an ex-Gaddafi general, Khalifa Haftar, in the form of the ‘Dignity’ movement. Whether one looks to the humanitarian crisis presented by the movement of refugees across the Mediterranean, the allegiance between ISIS and some of the jihadist militias – particularly Ansar al Sharia – or the potential for wider destabilisation of the Sahel region, Libya is a country that the EU cannot afford to ignore. Furthermore, Member States must do more to investigate reports of support for jihadist groups from third countries such as Qatar and Turkey.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the situation in Libya is reaching a point of no return. The holding of the negotiations in Geneva next week surely represents - as Mrs Mogherini said - the last opportunity for the two factions to lay the groundwork for a ceasefire and the formation of a government of national unity to advance the pacification of the country and the stabilization of the region.  If there is no progress in Geneva in a final solution to the conflict and in the creation of a state subject to the principles of international law and the rule of law, Libya and part of the region will be in danger of falling definitively into absolute chaos. Chaos, ladies and gentlemen, which, as we all know, will create the perfect conditions for terrorist groups linked to Al Qaeda and Islamic State and tribal warlords to find room to grow and create much more important bases, with the added danger of contagion to neighboring countries. Today's resolution can not only be a condemnation and a description of Libya's terrible situation, but a clear and resounding warning that, if the negotiations do not come to fruition, the Balkanisation of North Africa may be inevitable and its consequences, not only in the region, but on the southern border of the European Union , can be catastrophic, as evidenced by the migratory pressures suffered by the European Union as a result of the conflict.  We must therefore support and exert as much pressure as possible to ensure that the negotiations come to fruition and provide as much assistance as possible also to the Libyan authorities to ensure a prosperous and stable future for both the country and neighbouring States, so that they can effectively control their borders and prevent the expansion of the conflict and its consequences. If not, we may need to be prepared to move from words to deeds.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the situation in Libya is of absolute disaster. A country destroyed, fragmented and about to be unworkable. But that disaster is not a natural catastrophe. It was the result of NATO's intervention. The solution cannot start from those who generated that disaster. That is why we not only oppose any Western military intervention, but we understand that, for the sake of the Libyan people, the proposals of neighbouring countries must be heard. The Algerian-led dialogue initiative must be taken into account. And it's the second chance. That's how I let Mr Bernardino León know. We would have avoided this war with another proposal from Algeria that had the consensus of the parties. I would like to hear Mrs Mogherini's opinion. Do you think Algeria is an actor capable of leading the dialogue between the parties? Don't you think a neighbor is an added value in finding a solution? What is unacceptable is that the arsonists put out the fire. Many countries, with the political support of this Parliament, supported NATO's intervention that led to the destruction of the country. For the sake of the Libyan people, this Parliament and the High Representative must step forward and shoulder their shoulders with Libya's neighbours, who are well aware of these wars induced and supported by those on one side and on the other of the Atlantic who strive to reorder the Middle East at the stroke of war, bombs and suffering.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The civilian population in Libya is repeatedly exposed to attacks by the competing factions. People are being driven from their homes, injured, killed and living in great fear of new attacks. In the autumn, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights even spoke explicitly of war crimes and called for an immediate cessation of these military attacks, which are carried out indiscriminately directly on populated areas. From the outside, we should by no means unilaterally support one of the opposing groups militarily. For this would block the way to dialogue, which is absolutely necessary, should not disintegrate the whole state. We very much hope that the new UN dialogue attempt scheduled for this week will bring concrete progress. In order to create more pressure, we also recommend using the revenues from oil sales, for example by establishing an international mechanism whose task is to hold back the revenues in large parts so that they are only available to a national unity government that is forming. The militias in Libya have become accustomed to not being held accountable for their lawless behaviour, for their human rights violations. That is why it would also be very useful to set up an international and independent commission of inquiry to document the serious human rights violations and war crimes on all sides and to make the perpetrators accountable.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Libya, final act of a tragedy? The proxy civil war sponsored by the Emirates, Egypt and the United States, on the one hand, and Qatar and Turkey, on the other, has fuelled the outsized ambitions of the contending factions to achieve total victory. The result is a real national economic suicide. Falling production and falling oil prices have reduced revenue to 19 billion from 59 billion in 2013. It is now a state that has failed as politically as it is economically.  The policy of the two furnaces, indeed the two wells, adopted by the Libyan Central Bank is dead and buried and the caliphate of Derna, the third inconvenient ready to take advantage of it, thanks. That is why, in the forthcoming negotiations, it must be noted that the political solution must necessarily also involve moderate Islam in a government of national unity, otherwise we will pave the way for terrorism to turn Libya into a jihadist just a few kilometres from Europe. We can still prevent this if we look to the good of all and not just to the interests of a few.

name: Diane DODDS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative for her assessment of the situation in Libya and of the potential within the current talks process. In the middle of the variety of very pressing issues in that particular state, I want to focus the attention of this House for a moment on two in particular. Firstly, High Representative, I want to thank you for your letter to me of 7 January 2015 regarding compensation from the Libyan authorities for the innocent victims of Irish Republican terrorism in Northern Ireland. The Gaddafi regime funded a campaign of terror and death in Northern Ireland with their partners in the IRA. Negotiations between UK representatives and the Libyan authorities have stalled during the internal fragmentation and violence that Libya is now experiencing. However, the innocent victims of Libyan-sponsored terrorism in Northern Ireland need to see justice and compensation, and we need your support, High Representative, to achieve that. I am asking you to make this a priority of your term of office and to talk and meet with these innocent victims in Northern Ireland. I hope that you can find the time to do this fairly soon. Finally, the issue of the persecution of Christians who live in Libya. We of course have seen the results of violent extremism in France in the last week. Those are dreadful and sad scenes. However, Libyan Christians have lived with these scenes for a very long time. They need your support; they need the support of this Chamber and of the European Union institutions.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: Mr President, this is the fourth time I have been speaking in this House to discuss the situation in Libya and the consequences of the fall of Gaddafi in libya, in the Sahel countries and now in Tunisia, where there are more than eight hundred thousand Libyan refugees who can destabilize their recent democracy. But now is not the time for reproach, but for possible solutions. Libya's stability is paramount to Europe, its proximity and the country's wealth. The failed state situation in which it is located must be resolved. We must not forget the serious risk we are taking if we allow radical Islamism to settle permanently at the gates of Europe. This Geneva meeting, of all parties involved, is being held these days to resolve this conflict from the dialogue. And we must listen more to neighboring African nations, something that was not done when Gaddafi fell.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Libyan conflict has a major impact on the economy and security throughout the Mediterranean basin. The risk of an escalation of the conflict at regional level is real. The chaos that prevails today and the massive amount of weapons available can turn the country into an ideal territory for the activity and formation of extremist groups, including ISIS as we have seen.  In this context, action must be taken, moving away from the state of inattention that has characterised European policy for some time. The Libyan emergency must be resolved by obliging all Libyan representations to sit at the enlarged table, starting, of course, from Geneva on the basis of the work to be supported by Bernardino León. This diplomatic offensive must not be wasted at all, because it is crucial to finding a political solution and must be facilitated by the role of its neighbours and must be favoured by Europe. This is the urgent task that we have today in full awareness, on the one hand, that for Libyan political society, without a successful conclusion of the negotiations, it will be even more chaos and disaster and, on the other, for Europe which, after the mistakes made, can no longer go wrong or will face a very dangerous drift. (The speaker accepted a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that one of the overriding factors of the problems that we see across the world at the moment, especially with the rise of terrorism and Islamism of an extreme nature, has been brought about by well-meaning interventions by the West, and that Madam Mogherini has got one heck of a tough job to do this right when every example that we see of Western intervention has just made things worse and worse? Would you not agree that this is extremely dangerous territory?

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I tried to say in my speech that some mistakes have been made, and it is fair to say so! It is precisely on the basis of these mistakes that we must no longer make mistakes and that action must be taken to ensure that dialogue is established and that the conditions for lasting peace in that country are built. Europe in particular needs it!

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, time is running out for Libya, certainly, although I appreciate greatly the efforts undertaken by Bernardino León. Similarly, I appreciate your leadership in this respect. I am very worried about the emergence of a self-proclaimed caliphate in Darna and around the Al Bayda’ region, and also about disappearances of persons in Libya. We are seeing the next stage of events with radical Islamism there, and surely you need much more insight into this situation as well as cooperation within the European External Action Service.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, the Western-led bombing to oust Gaddafi was supposed to be a success story for a new kind of warfare. Politicians such as Cameron and Sarkozy wanted us to believe they had devised a surgical military intervention. More, the bombing was supposed to show that European leaders could exert influence in North Africa to match America’s. What blood-soaked European vanity that has turned out to be! Libya is not a failed state. It is no kind of state at all. It is a territory of murder and chaos, of kidnapping and butchery. The EU should do nothing but stay out. Ms Mogherini’s eurocrats can do no good by meddling in a civil war which Europe helped cause – and with whom would they negotiate anyway? With which set of Islamic extremists or tribal war lords or American favourites? Our interference turned loose chaos in Libya. We must not enter conflicts that are not in the national interests of Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – Mr Carver, if you had been Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and you were in a position to decide, what would you have done when you heard Mr Gaddafi say he was going to butcher every man, woman and child in Benghazi? Had Mr Cameron not intervened, and had that massacre taken place, surely the world would have said we got it wrong? It is clear we have huge problems in Libya and the outcome is far from desirable, but what would you have done, given the threat from a paranoid dictator like Muammar Gaddafi?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Tannock. What I would have done is that I would have learned from the previous experiences of our former Prime Minister, Mr Blair, and the tragic intervention in Iraq. I would have hopefully used the diplomacy to get to the state of being a prime minister to understand that conflicts in the Middle East need to have a Middle Eastern dimension if it is to be resolved properly. Western influences in the Middle East only leads to further distraction and further problems; it prolongs the issue. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" question. "Mr. Carver, do you share my view that we intervened in the run-up to the mandate that the United Nations had given to the nations that intervened?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – Yes I do. I think the whole issue with regard to intervention in Libya on the back of what was happening in other parts of the Middle East was a huge mistake, and yes, I believe we did exceed.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: As an MP, I visited Libya when the country had another head of state to meet in a tent set up in a maze of concrete walls. The head of state was still a charade at the time, and the unity of his country was a sham, which was covered by the vague titular of president of the Jamaharia, a conglomerate of the revolution, and by a military dictatorship. The concrete walls turned out to be not so much to protect the President of the Jamaharia from the American missiles, as he tried to make us believe, but above all, as it turns out, against the various hideous and bloodthirsty elements that resided on Libyan soil and houses, and which will never form a unit, but will always and at most be a forced gathering. I hope that you will realise how few opportunities you have of creating a stable country, and it seems to me appropriate, as a Westerner in general and as Europe in particular, to be a little modest after the enormous failure of your political and military strategy on Libya. The Arab Spring was not a revolution of democracy, but an illusion that has strengthened Islam terrorism more than anything else.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini, the Libyan crisis is a matter of great concern to Europe and to all of us. In Libya, a few hundred kilometres from Europe's southern gates, there is an increasingly violent and dramatic clash between anti-Islamists and pro-Islamists, with the presence of formations that appeal to terrorist groups and ISIS.  The massacres in Paris and the threats to Europe by the Caliphate are too acute an alarm not to increase any effort to reach a political solution to the crisis. The humanitarian crisis that is taking place in Libya, with the massive migratory phenomena taking place towards Tunisia and towards our Mediterranean coasts, must be stopped and Europe with the United Nations has a duty to take a strong and effective political initiative.  More than sanctions on the sale of hydrocarbons, we need to take action by introducing a comprehensive arms embargo, because too many countries are feeding the parties militarily. In order to stop these conflicts taking place within Libya, Mrs Mogherini, it is necessary to establish a permanent forum among all those involved as soon as possible in order to finally start that dialogue that promotes stability and social peace. The idea of splitting Libya into two states would be a disaster of enormous proportions and must be avoided. I am convinced of this that the entire European Parliament is aware of this, and that is why I believe that our strong, determined and unequivocal position is absolutely essential and urgent. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Cesa, do you not appreciate the issue with regard to the wider conflict here and the wider political elements of the many countries involved in the supply of arms to various groups with different interests across what was the state of Libya? How can we have an arms embargo when so many Member States have so many different issues? Is this not a case – picking up on what your colleague Ms Gabriel was saying as the first speaker in this debate – that actually the European Union, the Arab League and the African Union have a far greater position to play with regard to these negotiations than this place that caused so many problems?

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that some mistakes have inevitably been made, we must acknowledge this, but we must face the reality that we are experiencing. And we who are in Italy perhaps live it more than others, because we have a dramatic situation on the Mediterranean, having ISIS a stone's throw from our country, and so I think that the indication I have allowed myself to give to High Representative Mogherini is to fight not through the oil embargo but through the arms embargo, is an absolutely necessary instrument. So realpolitik right now, stand with your feet on the ground!

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, the hostage-takers in In Amenas, Algeria, the leader of the Ansar Dine jihadists and the killers of The French journalists Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon, in 2013 in Mali, have one thing in common: they all found themselves at one time or another in Libya to train, supply themselves with weapons and thus commit atrocious terrorist crimes. These three very concrete examples depict the reality of what has become of Libya, a failed state, which has given way to a terrorist hub at the gates of Europe. Southwestern Libya but also its border is worrying, where groups have already pledged allegiance to Daïch near the city of Derna. Miracle solutions do not exist in Libya and armed intervention is not part of the solution. Political dialogue, over and over again, is the only credible solution. If there is an urgency, then, it is the urgency to bring together all regional forces and international organizations so that a framework for intra-Libya dialogue can emerge. Without it, the threat of instability and terrorism will never leave the Libyan sands.  We are counting on you, Madam High Representative, and on the international community as a whole.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Four years after the Arab spring gave hope for a more democratic and freer Libya, the country is in danger of becoming the second major war zone in the Middle East. In addition to the Islamist and secular militias, IS is also active in all provinces. In a broader geopolitical picture, we see that Egypt and the Emirates are diametrically opposed to Turkey, Quatar and Sudan in their support for these militias. We must therefore be most concerned about the situation in Libya and absolutely avoid the disruption of neighbouring countries - i.m. in particular Tunisia. If Libya is not to go down completely, an immediate ceasefire is needed and all relevant players must be quickly involved in some kind of national transitional council, similar to the conference organised after the revolution. Concrete commitments by the European Union and the Arab League are indispensable. Madam Vice-President, we support your efforts. The UN consultations must be given every opportunity.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the heinous crimes that France has experienced are also the heinous, abject and despicable children of the mad policy pursued by France and Europe behind the United States with the incredible pretension to rule the affairs of the world.  In a stateless Libya, where armed militias are the law, the smuggling of human beings, among those of arms and drugs, is booming. This country has become the last point of immigration to Europe. The central Mediterranean route has become the road to death and all traffic, as unfortunately Italy can see today.  So, dear Madam, we are not convinced - to say the least - by the policies of intervention in Afghanistan, Iraq and Libya with all the flood of deaths and massacres. The leaders change, but the massacres remain.  We therefore call on the Arab League, Turkey and the petrodollars of the oil monarchies to finally take care of this policy which is within their sphere of influence and not to intervene directly in matters that are not our responsibility.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, for too long the situation in Libya has been on the sidelines of the international community. It is time to change this because the fight between the authorities in Tobruk and the Islamist militias, and of course the growing influence of the so-called Islamic State in Libya, they are turning this country back into a threat to international security. Such a situation on the shores of the southern Mediterranean requires strong engagement of the European Union, primarily its external service, but also development policy especially in the field of building effective institutions. It is situations like Libya that we want to include development goals on peaceful societies and institution building in the new Global Development Framework. But it's a long-term strategy. Maybe that's what had to be done after the dismissal of gaddafi's regime, but immediate action is needed now. The role of the High Representative here is crucial in coordinating the possible activities of the Member States, in contacts with the US and NATO, but also with other important actors such as Qatar or the United Arab Emirates. It is also important to strongly support the work of un secretary-general Bernardino Leon's envoy, and I am pleased that the High Representative has done so. However, I believe that another issue must be raised, namely Turkey's policy towards Islamist factions in Libya, and clearly indicate the EU's support for the legitimate authorities and the House of Commons in Tobruk.  Finally, I would like to stress in particular that even in the case of Libya Christians are a particular target for Islamist radicals and that a way to specially care for and protect the Christian minority needs to be found.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work I share your view on the diagnosis of the situation in Libya and, moreover, I would like to say that I also share your assessment and your determination to resolve matters. I share your view on social issues, on the social situation, on the exit for the population, which is very, very complicated at the moment, on the economic and political situation. I also share your concern that there is no chance of stabilising the situation inside Libya without external support – without wise external support. Therefore, imagine conflicts on religious basis and, within the framework of religion, also often religious or ceremonial, so I do not share those voices that have been in this Chamber, so as not to mix. Yes, we have to be present, it is also in our interest, it is too close, it is too important for us economically. But it is important that we are simply effective in this cry for order and order. Let us seek such a formula so that we can do well in the process of restoring peace and peace in Libya.

name: Bas BELDER
text: In Libya, too, there is a growing presence of the Islamic State, according to alarm signals from American military circles. These are not only training camps in isolated Libyan regions, but also the mediterranean city of Derna. Mind you, Derna is only 200 km from the European coast. I have two simple questions for the High Representative: 1. Are the American alarm signals about the growing presence of Islamic State jihadists on Libyan territory correct? Are they verifiable? 2. And if so, how does the European Union intend to deal with the IS threat to its own continent from Libya? Finally, I would like to echo Mr Dodds' call for European attention to the vulnerable Christians in Libya.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The resolution on Libya that we adopted on 16 September describes the situation in the country in terms of power vacuum, violence and political instability. Today, those words are inadequate. Today, there is reason to talk about anarchy and civil war. At the same time, another human catastrophe is underway. In 2014, the Italian Navy rescued around 100 000 refugees in the Mediterranean, mainly from ports in Libya. But thousands of the fugitives could not be saved, their fragile vessels never reached the shores of Europe.  Now that we are discussing Libya, there are a couple of distressing facts that deserve to be mentioned. There is currently a lack of legal pathways into Europe. The vulnerability of boat migrants is perhaps the clearest and most tragic consequence of this. The Italian rescue operation Mare nostrum had more than twice as much resources as its successor Triton has. The lack of willingness of the Member States to help is discouraging. It is our duty to talk about this, about the lack of a fair division of responsibilities between the EU Member States. It is only together, through common solidarity, that this disastrous refugee situation can be resolved. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Should we not now turn our attentions away from a diplomatic solution, leaving that to the United Nations, Arab League and other such international players, and actually turn our attentions to what this House always professes to be so good at, namely dealing with the humanitarian crises largely caused by European leaders? Would you not agree with me that we should turn our emphasis to actually helping the hundred thousand refugees that you just spoke of?

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: answer ("blue card"). That is exactly what I am talking about, namely that we can do much more on the part of the European Union in helping the people fleeing war and from persecution. Europe is one of the richest regions in the world, one of the richest parts of the world. Nevertheless, we have received only a fraction of the fellow human beings fleeing war and persecution. We can do much more and, above all, we can distribute responsibility and solidarity between the Member States in a much better way than we do today.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Ħadt gost nisimgħek tgħid li rridu nkunu koerenti ma' dak li nkunu qegħdin ngħidu għaliex tajjeb li l-Unjoni Ewropea tiffoka l-attenzjoni taghaħ fuq il-pajjiżi li hemm mal-fruntiera tal-Lvant, imma ħafna drabi nħoss li għamlet dan a skapitu tal-pajjiżi li hemm mal-fruntieri tagħha fin-Nofsinhar. Nieħu gost nara li aktar pajjiżi qed jaqblu li bi qbil bejn il-fazzjonijiet għandu jkun hemm il-possibilità ta' azzjoni favur iż-żamma tal-pa大i mmexxija mill-Ġnus Magquħda biex terġa' tkun stabbilita s-sigurtà filj paji. Kellna lil Malta li pproponiet dan u huwa inkoraġġanti li issa l-Italja qalet li lesta tieħu rwol ewlieni taħt l-awspi大i tal-Ġnus Magħda favur iż-żamma tal-pa大i fil-Libja. Ma nistgħux nagħlqu għajnejna għal dak li qed jiġri. Ma nistgħux inħallu aktar 大ittadini inno大enti jsofru jew addirittura jinqatlu. M'għandniex il-lussu li nħallu t-terroriżmu, il-fanatiżmu u l-ideoloġiji estremi jiffermentaw. Huwa veru; huma l-Libjani nfushom li jistgħu jagħmlu d-differenza imma l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha r-responsabilità li tiffoka bis-serjetà fuq dak li qed jiġri fil-Libja u fil-pajjiżi tan-naħa tan-Nofsinhar tal-fruntieriħit.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Less than five years ago, the attention of Europe and the world focused on the possibility of changing the socio-political situation in North Africa and the Middle East, and we looked forward to this possibility. Today, there is little left of this hope, and Libya is a good example of this, because the civil war and the total political destabilisation of the country, the economic collapse, the rampant crime – that is libya's image today. That is why, in my opinion, as the European Union, with the cooperation of other international organisations, we should, however, take on this responsibility in order to do everything and bring about a mastery of the internal situation in Libya as soon as possible.  This is, above all, of very important strategic importance: it is a country that lies in a very important part of the world, especially in the context of the threat of Islamic fundamentalism. Ethnic, religious, mainly Christian, civil and refugee persecution is of concern. In my opinion, there is nothing to wait for and we need to start talking seriously about Libya and start supporting this country seriously.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, libya today appears to be one of the hottest areas in the world: the country is torn apart by heavy armed clashes between militias of opposing factions and government forces, in some cases by aerial bombardment. There have been suicide bombings, kidnappings of Western citizens, there is a very large and heavy presence of Islamic extremist groups and jihadists, responsible for attacks, killings of civilians and guerrilla acts. In Libya, the presence of ISIS is active and very strong.  The impossibility for government law enforcement agencies to guarantee effective control of the territory has resulted, in addition to a high number of victims, a huge volume of refugees trying to move towards European borders, especially Italian ones, as demonstrated by the 826 migrant landings that took place in 2014 on the Italian coasts for a total of 141,000 people. All this on Europe's doorstep, Europe must intervene, we must act together and together we must find a solution and try to help these people within their own country. Almost four years after the fall of Gaddafi, there is no border control, and we must also understand who is a refugee and who is illegal, and we must also be quicker in identifying these two types of people.

name: Ana GOMES
text: There is an urgent need to halt the civil war and the worsening humanitarian crisis within Libya and in the neighbourhood, with thousands of refugees, the risk of environmental disasters by burning oil plants and barring the use of Libyan territory as a sanctuary for terrorist organisations, such as the one that has just struck us criminally in Paris. It is regional, European and global security that are under threat from a failed state in Libya.  The time has come to join African countries calling for international military intervention, duly led by the United Nations Security Council and articulated with regional partners: the Arab League, the African Union.
