There is an urgent need for a UN peacekeeping mission to help restore security conditions to enforce a political agreement between all Libyan factions, as the UN special representative, Bernardino Léon, has been promoting.  Such an agreement between Libyans is possible! And I also hope it will happen tomorrow! But we must not ignore the that today, in Libya, a proxy war is being played, involving the same powers that are behind the so-called Islamic State, whatever the variation of the terrorist hydra. The European Union must use its political and diplomatic influence against such interference and must redirect its own mission and the BORDER Assistance Mission (BAM) within the framework of the Common Security and Defence Policy to meet Libya's real security needs.  It needs to be part of a UN peacekeeping mission, which has to take as a priority the collection of weapons, disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration of militias and armed groups, and the formation of security institutions under state control.  Europe also has responsibility for the degradation of post-Gaddafi Libya, even for not prioritising security sector reform. Some Member States have refused to act in coordination, competing with each other to promote their own interests. The Union has given up coordinating them. It is urgent that the High Representative confronts them, changes this legacy and gives strategy, effectiveness and coherence to the European Union's action in Libya and the region, as Mrs Mogherini today acknowledged that it was necessary. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 149(8)).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – We have seen in Afghanistan that military intervention without a clear military objective can often lead to unintended consequences. We have seen in Iraq that the despotic regime of Saddam Hussein was replaced – if that is possible – by something worse. If we are seeking military intervention now: first of all, why? Secondly, what lessons have been learned from Afghanistan and Iraq?

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Arnott, I do not know whether you ever set foot in Libya. I did, and I did in the middle of the war against Gaddafi, and I saw that this was no Iraq. This was no invasion like in Iraq in 2003; this was a real people’s revolution, albeit aided by an international intervention – with a UN mandate, by the way. I was there even last December and I was speaking to Libyan parties in the region, in Tunis, and I know that the people of Libya at this moment really welcome such an intervention, because they think this is the only way to have what they need, which is a reform of the state that Gaddafi simply did not have. So we have our responsibilities, and one of our responsibilities is to protect the people of Libya, to correct our mistakes, and that is why I say, together with African neighbouring countries, that we need a UN-mandated international intervention according to international law for peace and for saving people, the people of Libya.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Mr President, as we know, the situation in Libya is at the moment chaotic, as different groups are fighting each other to get power. This is a very bad situation for every citizen, but I would like to stand up for one group of them, who are only half a per cent of the population but a group who suffers the most – the Christians. The situation for Christians is horrible due to different fundamental Islamist groups fighting each other and, moreover, the current official government does not tolerate Christians at all. Christians are kidnapped, beheaded, beaten, put under huge psychological pressure, forced to convert to Islam and heavily discriminated against. According to the brand new World Watch List compiled by Open Doors, the situation is getting worse and worse. Besides this, destabilised countries and regions fighting with Islamic extremists cause considerable problems in Europe. European recruits who are fighting for these groups are afterwards coming back to Europe and becoming a real threat for us. Therefore, I would like to urge the High Representative to pay special attention to helping and protecting minorities, and especially Christians.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I am, as other speakers have said, almost four years since the Libyan uprising against Gaddafi's regime began, and the situation is today very bad in this country. There are few analyses that warn of the risk of Libya being a "failed state." It is very clear that, on the one hand, the polarisation of society, on the other hand, the exacerbation of violence has led to civil war - this is, I believe, the best expression to characterise the situation in Libya, and this is happening not 500 kilometres from Europe's borders. As we know, in addition to the legitimate authorities at Tobruk, we have self-proclaimed authorities in Tripoli and Misrata – the pinnacle!, places that once symbolized resistance against Gaddafi. We have, on the other hand, rival claims for control of the central bank, the national oil company and so on.m and hence totally and utterly absurd situations - a few days ago we saw this in the case of Maltese visa applicants - or quite tragic situations - 10 days ago, namely on 4 January, a Greek oil tanker was attacked in the port of Derna and a Greek and a Romanian they also lost their lives. This is what is happening in Libya: absurd and tragic in a civil war.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, as is well said, we have experienced the most serious situation since the fall of Gaddafi: a very serious political conflict, institutional chaos and human rights violations. This is in a country, as mentioned, which is a few kilometres from the European Union, where the European Union has a great historical responsibility and with which it shares common challenges. One step away from the civil war, one step away from a new failed state and this very close to us. As the High Representative has commented, I think it is important to congratulate Bernardino León (the United Nations High Representative in Libya) on his work, to support the work of reconciliation between the factions he is developing and to think that the solution will become political, for supporting human rights in the country, seeking a government of national unity that gives way to national reconciliation : our target in the area.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Today, Libya as a state is virtually non-existent. Riots against Mu'ammar Gaddafi's long-standing rule also erupted in Libya during the Wave of the Arab Spring. These were governments critical of the European Union. Gaddafi was certainly not a Democrat. He certainly supported terrorism, but after the American intervention of April 1986, he dramatically reduced it. It was grotesque, it is true, but the Libyans provided a kind of peace and peace. The 2011 riots were too weak to change power in Libya. Democratic states have decided to help the Libyans. They carried out the action "Dawn of the Odysea". This operation has had the blessing of the UN, the European Union and led to the twilight of Gaddafi and his rule, but there is no dawn. A night of internal conflict continues in Libya. There was a plan to overthrow Gaddafi, but what next? None of those involved in the overthrow of Gaddafi have an idea, there is even a desire to do anything for Libya. I wish the Commissioner good luck, but I am afraid that we can expect another fiash. The moral of this, we see it once again, that easy military interventions ending in victory can lead to the defeat of the policies and the defeat of those on whose behalf they intervene, and the irony of fate is that none of the interveners benefit from it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Mr President, today the situation in Libya remains extremely serious and dialogue between all the parties to the face is urgently reached. We're talking about a crisis that affects all of us. The crisis in Libya poses a threat to the European Union, the Mediterranean, the Sahel and Africa as a whole, given the arms, drug and organised crime trafficking corridor, in general, which unites Libya, Niger, Chad and Mali.  This environment is conducive to radical movements. Organizations like IS can more easily move and recruit people. It is worth noting, in this respect, the increasing presence of IS on Libyan soil, where the black flag already waves in the city of Derna. Unfortunately, this city has historically been a nursery of terrorists, as the Spaniards know well from the murderous terrorists of ETA and also from the IRA of Northern Ireland, who trained in that area. To reverse the situation you have to promote the dialogue. I welcome the efforts made by the Special Representative of the United Nations, Bernardino León, who has managed to bring dialogue back to the parties in the face. Finally, I do not want to refer, logically, to the humanitarian question. A humanitarian crisis that is living in the country, with hundreds of thousands of displaced persons and refugees affecting the entire region. I am proud that we are, dear Vice-President, the first international donor and I welcome the European Union's efforts in this regard. However, there is still much to be done to coordinate policies between all, south and north, and to make our support effective in the face of the wave of refugees. Finally, I stress what was discussed at the Madrid Conference in September last year: Libya's unity, sovereignty and democracy must be preserved.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! The growing disintegration of state structures in Libya is particularly depificing the civilian population. Where there are no instruments of the rule of law, people are exposed to arbitrariness. The catalogue of human rights violations resulting from this is incomprehensible: kidnapping, deprivation of liberty, torture and physical ill-treatment, deliberate destruction of livelihoods and executions.  Violation of human rights has become the norm in Libya in the event of conflict, not only because there is no functioning statehood, but above all because those who flout all human standards do not have to fear punishment. It is therefore necessary for the International Criminal Court to take up its duties and for account suspensions and entry bans to be imposed on all war criminals. A corresponding UN Security Council resolution would already make such an approach possible.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: The situation in Libya has deteriorated considerably in recent months. All components of the civilian population in the country, including women and children and minorities living in Libya, including Christians, are suffering from escalating violence, as has been mentioned here. I consider attacks on civilians to be a particular manifestation of cruelty and bigotry that has no place in a civilised world. Recent events therefore require Libya to urgently take measures to increase internal security, to take action against the spread of terrorism and to commit to addressing the internal situation peacefully.  The international community, and the European Union in particular, must fully support the establishment of an inclusive community-wide dialogue in Libya based on mutual understanding, respect and the will to deal with the situation. Dialogue is a prerequisite for a constructive process of stabilising the country. I therefore support putting political and diplomatic pressure on the country to transform it into a functioning democratic state.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, the first thing that we have to bear in mind, if we want to deal effectively with the critical situation of Libya, is that our priority must be to protect civilians whose lives are being threatened and whose access to food and water has been limited since the start of the civil war. I therefore fully agree with the statement that the solution must be political and not military, based on dialogue between all parties, carried out throughout the mediation of the United Nations, and with more involvement of the European Union, as the situation in Libya is influencing Europe’s security. We Europeans must step up our efforts to help stabilise the region. We must underline the need to implement a ceasefire and secure the withdrawal of forces. We must push for the establishment of a transitional government that is inclusive of all factions and tribes, in order to prevent the spread of terrorism and to weaken and disarm local armed groups. The situation in Libya continues to deteriorate. Violence is escalating in the territories not under government control. Restoring stability in Libya will not be possible without broad-based political reconciliation. This must be our goal.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogiris, colleagues, the Arab Spring has become an Islamist winter. The entire Mediterranean, the Horn of Africa, the Middle East are in Islamist chaos. Only Egypt has so far been able to overcome this turbulence, this disintegration, and stop the Islamists' march to power. But Libya is an example of how revolutions in Africa and Asia can become a boomerang and return to our own heads.  Today, according to all my colleagues in the chamber, Libya is no longer a state. This is a territory divided not into 2, not 3, but not less than 10 parts. The government controls only a tenth of the territory. Tripoli, Darna, Misrata and territories south to the border with Chad and Sudan are controlled by various Islamist groups unquestionably linked to Islamic State. A caliphate has also been declared in Libya. Mrs Mogherini, what the European Union needs to do is work out a clear position and a desire for what it wants to achieve in Libya. We need to understand that we can't negotiate with terrorists, we need to understand that we're at war with the Islamic State.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! The situation in Libya is a tragedy thanks to the interference, the military intervention also of the West. There is chaos in the country and it has not been possible to integrate the numerous tribes and the militias into the security system. As a result, the number of boat refugees is steadily increasing. 130,000 people arrived in Europe in the first half of 2014, twice as many as in the previous year, 118,000 of whom arrived in Italy alone. A recent study shows that the travel planning to Europe is interesting for many refugees! – via Facebook. Behind this is a sophisticated system with information on how best to overcome borders and how to move the asylum procedure after successful entry with good information, and tips on how to bypass authorities' routes in the countries of entry. We must therefore work together on a strategy to help Libya, on the one hand, and to stop this illegal immigration into Europe, but also, of course, to resolve the roots of these conflicts, because people are fleeing conflict, and we must intervene in this regard.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to contribute constructively to this debate. Instead of criticising what has happened, we should ask what we as Europeans can do for Libya? First of all, we should demand a ceasefire and the restoration of order and security, and the parties to the conflict will lead to this. Secondly, Libya as a state must remain whole, and thirdly, the European Union should prevent the supply of arms to Libya and increase the escalation of the entire conflict. Commissioner, I think the stability of Libya means the stability of Italy and the stability of the entire European Union.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, Libya is in the midst of a bitter civil war. Around 400 000 people are internally displaced, and humanitarian access to those affected remains a challenge. Thousands of others are risking their lives fleeing instability in an attempt to reach European territories. Libyan people want and deserve peace. They should not be held hostage by a small minority that seeks to win this conflict by military means. I welcome the Geneva talks. The conflicting parties should put the national interest above all other considerations and work towards resolving their differences and building a national unity government for Libya. Outside powers must stop perpetuating the conflict and fuelling violence by equipping and funding armed groups. They must adhere to the September statement against interference and play a positive role by pushing their allies in Libya towards reconciliation. The EU must support the achievement of these goals and remain fully committed, without taking any sides, to assisting the Libyan people to resolve the crisis and ensure unity, governability and institution-building, so as to achieve peace and stability for all Libyans.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Mr President, the situation in Libya has been discussed for a very long time, but unfortunately we have seen too few concrete actions. Libya is a country of enormous potential, destroyed by an internal conflict, which affects not only the Libyans, but the rest of the world, sometimes indirectly, sometimes, as has happened recently, directly. A few days ago, a Romanian and a Greek sailor were killed in Libya after a rocket launched by a Libyan army fighter jet exploded aboard the ship they were on. The Libyan army justified its attack by the fact that the ship came too close to a port in the hands of separatist insurgents. We see, therefore, how tense the situation is. The murdered Romanian sailor, from Galați, was 22 years old and on his first voyage and certainly hoped that Europe and his country would provide him with protection, wherever he was.  I take this context to extend my sincere condolences to the family and to ask you, those who decide, to act concretely in memory of these victims and thousands of other people who lost their lives in Libya. Concrete action by the European Union is needed and we call on the United Nations Security Council and including international peacekeeping forces to resolve the situation in Libya.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Unstable and militarised Libya is a major threat to both regional and pan-European security. Although the entire world community, like the European Union, is in favour of a peaceful settlement of the conflict, no real tangible results have been achieved so far. It is a pity that the planned peace talks that were due to take place on 5 January, which the United Nations had to mediate, have already collapsed this year. And the situation in the country is drastically deteriorating and this needs to be taken into account. Four years of continuous violence is too much, and I therefore join colleagues in urging the High Representative to actively consult and look for ways to stabilise the situation in the country as soon as possible with the international community and to protect the peaceful population.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, I wanted to re-claim the role that Mr Bernardino León is developing in the talks with the parties who want to go to Geneva, but I would like to tell Mrs Mogherini that we have already experienced great hope and some frustration in some other country close to Libya — in the case of Tunisia — so I would like to ask you the following question. Mrs Mogherini has said that this opportunity must be seized by those who are not yet going to Geneva - although they should be encouraged to go - but how can those who have gone to Geneva say that it was worth going to Geneva? What is there, moreover, for those who have gone to Geneva with regard to those who have not gone? Is the European Union...? Can we in any way ensure that it is worth starting to negotiate or talk to the European Union?

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, many of the Members used the term ‘failed state’, and I have to say that sometimes I think we are beyond that. That is why those who spoke of the need to use the limited time we have – and it might be days or hours, not weeks or months – to avoid total collapse are right. Libya is a rich country in terms of resources, but it is still a country that can represent a perfect storm: a perfect mix of risks. Let me name just a few of them: one of the highest concentrations of arms per square metre; oil and gas revenues, so potentially a lot of money ready to be used by different actors; an instrumental use of religion to spread acts that are close to terror; no control of land or sea borders, so a flow of asylum seekers, refugees and migrants that is not under the control of any authority on the ground. Here we have a humanitarian catastrophe, an environmental disaster ready to happen, as some of you mentioned, and a risk of spill-over into the neighbouring countries. Think of Tunisia, of how many refugees Tunisia is receiving constantly. We always concentrate – and being of Italian nationality, I do it myself very often – on how many people we are receiving in Europe, but let us just think about how many people the neighbouring countries are receiving in more difficult situations than those of our European Union Member States. So we are right to be extremely worried, and we should have no illusions about the facts. I am sorry many of your colleagues have left, but there should be no illusion that we can stay away from Libya. We could stay away from Libya, but Libya is not going to stay away from us. The question is how to make sure that we lend a rational helping hand to try and avoid the country’s total collapse, because this is going to affect us in one way or another. Let me express my condolences to, and solidarity with, the families, and also the authorities of Greece and Romania, for the loss of two members of the crew of a tank that was attacked a few days ago. On the same day I was on the phone to the Foreign Ministers of Romania and Greece to express my condolences, and this shows exactly that, one way or another, this is going to affect our security and the security of the region and the security of the world. So, even if we wanted to stay away – and I am not sure that would be the right and wise thing to do in any case – I do not think it would be possible. The question is: what do we do to support a positive process? Many of you – almost all of you – mentioned what should be the outcome of a process: a Libya that is not divided, an immediate ceasefire, a structured dialogue for some kind of national reconciliation, getting to a national unity government or some sort of transition structure that can guarantee some kind of government for the country. But, as we list these elements of a framework – or a horizon – we also have to be clear that even the talks which are taking place tomorrow in Geneva, even the simple convening of a meeting, present huge difficulties that we could not have imagined. It is just by working on this every day, almost every hour, that you realise how difficult it is even to decide who to invite to a meeting, who ought to sit at which table, how to set the agenda, and how to define the next steps. Even calling for a meeting is a major diplomatic challenge, so we are not under any illusion about the difficulties of the exercise. We have to bear that in mind as we reflect on the next steps, namely the role of the neighbours and the role of the European Union. Many of you asked about the role of Algeria, for instance, or other countries in the neighbourhood. First of all, we have to be aware that there is not a single attitude among the neighbours: there are different attitudes among different neighbours, and the neighbours are very different from one another. That is why I believe – and again I would say that the role of the European Union in this is to go hand in hand with the United Nations, because we need a United Nations framework – that in order to shape all these differences in the neighbourhood, which are crucial, into something that it makes sense to support, the exercise has to be undertaken along with the appropriate organisations. That is why the effort we are making is not an EU-Libya one, but rather an EU-Arab League and EU-Arab League-African Union one, with different formats of the neighbours – and I will not trouble you with all the different formats – constantly talking to everyone, and especially to those with different attitudes, be they Egyptians, Emirates, Turkish, Algerians or Qataris or representatives of some of the African countries that are neighbours as well. I said at the beginning that, maybe for the first time now, we are seeing a slightly more constructive and positive attitude among the neighbours in their totality. This is maybe because we are all realising that we are running out of time and that this is the last chance for us too – for the regional community and for the international community – to show some sense of responsibility for what is happening there. The only way of keeping the region united is by working on this multilateral level and with this approach. When it comes to the role of the European Union, I believe it has to be better defined. We will see the day after tomorrow whether these efforts for dialogue are going to produce something or not. We can put a lot on the table there. We have different scenarios on the table, and when I say it depends on the Libyans to define the scenario, the kind of instruments the European Union will be able to put in place also depends on the Libyan reaction. If we have the start of a process of dialogue and reconciliation or a united government, and then a ceasefire starting to take place, then obviously the European Union could work towards measures and instruments to monitor achievements on the ground. We have to think of the review of the mandate of Libya, for sure. The mandate will expire in May, so we have time, and that is exactly why we are holding this discussion with the Ministers on Monday, with some options on the table as to what we can do in one case – positive developments we can monitor and support – or, in the event of a total lack of positive development, as to the kind of instruments with which we could press for a possible engagement, or as to implementing, or working on implementing fully, some of the UN Security Council resolutions which, for the moment, are on paper but not fully implemented. We are living currently in a strange bubble, which is the fact that we have this 24-48 hours, with this last chance of dialogue, hopefully, taking place, to see if this starts a positive dynamic. We will have to be flexible. We use that word sometimes in different scenarios, and in foreign policy too, you have to be flexible. You have to have clearly in mind what your potential is – and we have a huge potential in all scenarios. We have to take stock of what will happen – or not – in Geneva in the coming hours, and define how we can best either push, in one direction, or support the results that the Libyans achieve once this happens. Obviously we also have to get ready to act if the scenario is the worst possible one. We are working on that as well. That is not something I would discuss today, and I thank you for not having that discussion today, because today is the day of sending to the Libyans, and to the region and to the rest of the international community, a clear message: this is the last chance for dialogue, and we should not and cannot waste it. Whatever you can do afterwards, you get ready to do. You always have to get ready for the worst-case scenario, but today is the day of pushing for the worst-case scenario to be avoided, and the responsibility for that lies in the hands of the Libyans, even as we speak. Thank you for a good debate. I think a message can come strongly from here to the Libyans that we are ready to support them because we care, because we know it is in their interest, and also in our interest and in the interest of the region’s stability. We have instruments to do that but, again, the decision has to be their own decision. I really hope that the message from here comes clear and strong to all parts of Libya in the coming hours: that national dialogue and common engagement need to take place. There is no alternative to that. All other options take Libya a step closer to total collapse, and we cannot afford that, and the Libyans cannot afford it.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The motions for resolutions to be submitted in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be announced at a later date. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I express my solidarity with the Libyan people and I am deeply concerned about the suffering of the civilian population in Libya. The ongoing fighting is perpetuating the serious violation of human rights and causing a dramatic escalation of violence. Libya is in chaos, and this poses a threat to the stability of the entire region. The EU must clearly condemn all those who are responsible for violence and selective killings, kidnappings, torture and other grave human rights violations against civilians. It is urgent to find a negotiated political solution with the formation of a united and inclusive government, so the EU must continue to back the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) in moving forward with the Ghadames Process with a view to bringing the parties in the conflict together in a national dialogue. The EU must assist Libya in building national dialogue and, with the Member States, must support Libya in state building, institution building and the reform of the justice system. The EU must assist Libya in resuming a democratic transition which promotes the rule of law and the protection of human rights.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - A humanitarian catastrophe, fires that can trigger an environmental catastrophe and a potential blockade of an international airport are only part of the everyday life faced by libyan residents. Due to the extremely difficult situation, an increasing number of people in search of a better life go the way of Europe, paying smugglers very high amounts, and these then leave them at sea on the so-called ghost boats without water or food. While the basic conditions for Libya's development are very good and the state has oil supplies sufficient for about the next six and a half decades, on the other hand state institutions in Libya are virtually out of business. Islamists openly oppose the elected government, and extremists spread terror. Efforts by the international community, which continues to call for dialogue between the parties to the conflict, have yielded no results. Threats from Islamists in Libya, threats to all of us. The Institutions of the European Union must help ensure peace and stability in Libya, as this is a precondition for the stability of the whole region. At the same time, due to continued attacks on Christians in Libya and on other religious minorities in breach of the right to religion, effective monitoring of respect for human rights in Libya should be introduced when concluding new bilateral agreements between the EU and the Member States with Libya.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – I believed that we outsiders who are friends of Libya had better allow the Libyan people to find their way to stability and peace by themselves. Recent developments have persuaded me that it could be helpful if friends of Libya suggest the political structures that they feel could best serve Libya's future interests. I have heard Sakharov prize winner Mr El Senussi relate the events of 2014 and his proposals for a new constitution are most likely to provide a stable settlement that is fair to all interested parties. This is for a federal arrangement, similar to the system in operation during the fifties and early sixties of the previous century. It would allow space for all interests to participate under equal conditions, bringing together traditional and modern, religious and secular elements. It would offer scope for reintegration into the society to those who presently feel completely alienated. It may sound futile to discuss now possibilities for future constitutional structures. But if one wishes to find a way out of the current impasse, one needs to first show that it can exist. The vision promoted by Mr El Senussi would be a most attractive option for a future Libya.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: In writing. We have neglected our commitments under the PSDC, the Thessaloniki Council, as well as the Petersberg missions and the overall Helsinki objective (dating back to the 1990s). Thus, faced with the situation in Libya, the European Union is powerless and unable to take action to help this failing state. However, it is not too late to remedy this defect. Notably France is still in possession of two Mistral boats that have not been delivered to Russia. Considering the current political climate it would be foolish to hand these boats over to Russia. However, these boats could be used as a platform to coordinate conflict resolution in the Mediterranean area. Under the PSDC, the acquisition of these vessels will form a solid base for the Union's defence forces. Ceterum censeo, we must be up to the task.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next point: Council and Commission statements - Recent incidents of trafficking in human beings in the Mediterranean (2015/2507(RSP))

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: pašreizējā Padomes priekšsēdētāja. - Godātā priekšsēdētāja, godātie deputāti! Man ir liels gods pirmo reizi Latvijas prezidentūras Eiropas Savienības Padomē vārdā uzstāties Eiropas Parlamenta plenārsēdē. Rīt šeit Latvijas ministru prezidente Laimdota Straujumas kundze jums prezentēs Latvijas prezidentūras prioritātes, bet jau šodien es gribu uzsvērt, ka Latvijas prezidentūra vēlas cieši strādāt kopā ar Eiropas Savienības institūcijām, lai virzītu uz priekšu aktuālos Eiropas Savienības jautājumus. Un mēs ceram uz ciešu un konstruktīvu sadarbību ar Eiropas Parlamentu. Mēs ceram uz ciešu sadarbību, lai kopīgi virzītu un pieņemtu lēmumus, kas ir nepieciešami Eiropas iedzīvotāju labklājībai un drošībai un Eiropas Savienības konkurētspējas stiprināšanai. Madam President, I would like to begin by commending the work done by the persons and services involved in the rescue operations. These operations have helped to save the lives of hundreds of people. The Council is deeply concerned by the continuing large-scale arrival of migrants, in particular in Italian waters. In this context the Ministers are, of course, aware of the new phenomenon of ghost ships – large disposable cargo vessels bearing hundreds of migrants across dangerous waters and which are deliberately abandoned, with men, women and children on board, close to EU coastal waters. The very recent rescues of the vessels Blue Sky M and Ezadeen clearly show that action needs to be taken on this new modus operandi. Effective measures should be taken against smugglers and traffickers in order to combat and dismantle criminal networks which exploit migrants and expose them to the risk of hazardous journeys across the Mediterranean, as well as to prosecute those involved in such activities. It is important to recall that in the context of the work carried out by the Task Force Mediterranean, and in the Council conclusions of last October, reinforced border surveillance and the fight against smuggling and organised crime are considered priority areas of action. Several specific measures identified by the Task Force and in the October Council conclusions are currently being implemented. The successful deployment of the Triton operation is a clear sign of solidarity between Member States on this issue. In this context, the Council would like to highlight the very efficient way in which joint operation Triton is conducted by Frontex, the participants of which, with the support of the Italian coastguard, have managed to save the lives of thousands of migrants aboard these abandoned ghost ships. However, recent events clearly show that we need to step up and further reinforce our common action and to increase its effectiveness. On 2 January 2015, in a statement issued in relation to the smuggling of migrants in cargo ships, Commissioner Avramopoulos again stressed the need to combat the criminal organisations which exploit desperate people trying to escape conflict and war. The Council fully shares this assessment. Commissioner Avramopoulos noted that the fight against the smuggling of migrants would be a priority and referred to the development of a plan to be presented by the Commission in due course. The Council looks forward to the proposals that the Commission will submit in this context and will consider them as a matter of priority. The Council will also continue to regularly monitor the migratory situation, in particular in the Mediterranean region, and will address this subject as a top priority on its agenda.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I am standing here before you today because the European Commission is determined to take action. We have all heard what happened over Christmas and the New Year. The lives of around 1 200 migrants, mostly Syrians, were saved when the Italian Coast Guard and Frontex, in the framework of Joint Operation Triton, rescued two cargo vessels: the Ezadeen and the Blue Sky M. These are only two tangible examples among the more than 12 cargo vessels that have arrived in Europe since September 2014. Of course, many more people have risked their lives, coming in numerous small boats and experiencing difficult journeys via land borders. This is unacceptable. Why? Because we cannot allow ruthless smugglers to make a fortune through criminal acts, exploiting migrants looking for a safe passage to Europe. People in need of protection should not be risking their lives to obtain this protection. We all know the facts: conflicts in our neighbourhood generate a constant influx of refugees towards Europe. This will not go away. On the contrary, if decisive and coordinated EU-wide action is not taken, the flows will continue. In 2014, more than 276 000 migrants arrived in the European Union, representing an increase of 138% compared with the previous year. The recent events also show that smugglers are finding new routes to Europe and are employing and engineering new methods in order to exploit desperate people who are trying to escape conflict and war. In order to respond to the constantly evolving strategies of smugglers, the European Union, its agencies and the Member States have to step up their cooperation and common action in a spirit of solidarity and responsibility. Better coordination and a more comprehensive approach will help to address the roots of the current flows of irregular migrants and of smuggling. Let me first elaborate on the fight against smuggling and the rescue of migrants at sea. The recent events show that Joint Operation Triton, which started – as you all know – on 1 November 2014 and is coordinated by Frontex, has saved the lives of thousands of migrants. Since the launch of the Triton operation, and together with the Italian Navy, almost 16 000 asylum seekers and irregular migrants have been rescued or intercepted and 57 facilitators arrested. In addition, other European agencies have undertaken many important initiatives to tackle smuggling. At The Hague, Europol’s team in intelligence-sharing and cross-border investigations of smugglers’ networks has been reinforced, resulting in the arrest of hundreds of facilitators. In Malta, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) has launched a project to gather information from asylum applicants about the routes taken during their journeys. The Commission will support its agencies in order to intensify their efforts, but we also count on the financial and operational support of the Member States. We need to intervene and inform prospective migrants about the risks of entering Europe illegally. Reinforcing intelligence-gathering and the sharing and promotion of practical cooperation between the Member States and EU agencies are also crucial in order to prosecute more smugglers, undermine criminal networks and deprive them of profit-making. Smuggling is a criminal offence, but we need to make our legal instruments more effective. In this respect, the Commission is currently assessing the existing EU criminal framework in an effort to improve its practical implementation. Cooperation with countries of origin and transit is also a cornerstone of the Commission’s strategy to fight smuggling. Given that Turkey has become one of the alternative routes for smugglers to reach the European Union, we are in close contact with the Turkish authorities to quickly adapt our strategy. Of course, the cooperation with third countries cannot be limited to the fight against smuggling. We will cooperate with them in an integrated approach, encompassing broader foreign policy considerations, development assistance and humanitarian actions. One clear example of our integrated approach is the cooperation with many African countries. For the countries of the Horn of Africa, we have made available almost EUR 6 million – not only to support and facilitate the fight against smugglers and traffickers but also to improve the provision of direct assistance to migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. In the context of the Syrian crisis, the European Union – including the Member States combined – is the largest donor, making more than EUR 3 billion available for humanitarian and other aid in Syria and in the neighbouring countries. It also is vital that EU Member States fully implement the Common European Asylum System as soon as possible. Moreover, the European Union and the Member States must work together to establish a truly European programme for the resettlement of refugees. Following a recent pledging conference, Member States have so far offered over 36 000 places to Syrian refugees, making it the largest pledge in the history of EU resettlement efforts. However, a total of 207 000 people have crossed the Mediterranean irregularly. Furthermore, more than 3.5 million Syrian refugees have fled to countries neighbouring Syria. So there is no doubt that Europe needs to do more. We have to increase the number of refugees resettled in European Union countries. In order to ensure that Member States share this responsibility, the Commission has set up a resettlement and relocation forum to develop – always in cooperation with Member States – a fair distribution key. In this critical hour, where Europe is facing a growing number of challenges, the European Union and the Member States together have to take credible and effective action on migration. Europe has to take charge. We have no time to spare. Together, we will move forward with commitment and resolve.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I also warmly welcome the Latvian Presidency, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks for your hard work, Commissioner, to present in the last nine minutes the integrated approach that we want and must take together. What is striking about the last two ghost ships in the last incidents is that the first, the thirteen before that, have not even been noticed. There were a total of fifteen vessels of this type that came, twelve to Italy, two to Greece, one to Cyprus. If you look at the size of the financial profits of the traffickers, it is simply a ship with 700 to 800 people = EUR 5 million for the traffickers. In other words, this is a brutal human business, which the relevant criminals use and then push their criminal branches of a different kind accordingly. That is why it is important and necessary that we counteract this trafficking in human beings. What depresses me is that all 15 ghost ships came from Turkey. In other words, Turkey, as a partner of the European Union, must also maintain the common links in such a way that we can actually achieve an effective fight against organised crime, which is moving from Turkish soil towards the European Union. Combating it must also be effective and sensible. That, in our cooperation with Turkey, we must then consider how we can solve problems for the countries that have taken in a particularly large number of refugees – whether that is Turkey, whether it is Lebanon, Jordan, Tunisia or similar countries, which are struggling with large numbers of refugees and therefore want our support, including the approach of legal migration. , as far as is possible. However, this also requires improved cooperation and division in the Member States, so that we can really implement such a legal approach with each other.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, both the communication from the Latvian Presidency – which I too welcome – and commissioner Avramopoulos' very strong speech give us a dramatic scenario that unfortunately repeats itself. We have reached a point of no return, ladies and gentlemen!  Europe is facing one of the most challenging challenges of recent times and while people in Paris are demonstrating and strongly defending the right to freedom of expression, an unprecedented number of men and women fleeing war and poverty are risking their lives in Europe's desperate attempt to reach European shores. These people need our help because every human life matters! Because human rights are indivisible and inviolable rights and must be protected and promoted effectively.  If we do not want to be hypocritical, there is only one way to do this: to work together to build a common European immigration policy. In order not to be hypocritical, the decision-making command centre must be in Brussels, the European Commission and not the capitals of the individual nation states. If we do not resolve this political issue, we will be slicing our mouths, we will be raising our consciences, or we are going to make some instrumental and demagogic remarks, but we will not solve the problem. The problem is that it is Brussels, it is the European government that must plan the flows, that must have relations with third countries, that must discriminate between legal immigration and illegal immigration, that is, that it must then have the capacity to protect the right to integration of these citizens.  This is a great challenge, Commissioner, which we do not have in this parliamentary term – I say this to you and I say this to the representative of the European Council – if we really want to be deserving of the confidence and esteem of the citizens, we must take this great step forward, otherwise we will not be deserving and, you see, the world is global and globalisation brings out new poverty, there are hotbeds of war , of death, of terror, of disease, from which we flee, and it goes without saying that we raise our borders because raising borders is no use. Those who flee death, disease, terror, will always flee!  The world will never be a sum of shutters or closed classrooms, the world is inter-global, there is only one way: to govern together, to govern this phenomenon at European level, to welcome and take up this challenge and to show that we are worthy of representing our people. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pittella, the UN estimates that people trafficking makes gangsters and terrorists USD 15.5 billion a year and allegedly funds the terrorists who killed 2 000 people in Nigeria and the innocents in Paris. Will you, therefore, do nothing and continue to rescue the boats in the Mediterranean, thus continuing to fund those terrorists who are committing the crimes in Paris and elsewhere in the world?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, why do you believe that terrorists are on migrant ships? But there are poor people on migrant ships, desperate people or some small criminals, but certainly not the big terrorists who carry out the attacks! The big terrorists have money, they are financed by a network of terror, it is not those poor rags, unfortunately, who are forced to die on shuttles, we do not get around! Above all, we are not taking European citizens around, European citizens need serious answers, and the serious answer is: govern migratory flows, have European control, provide ourselves with infrastructure, improve cooperation with third countries, improve European intelligence, improve the exchange of data while safeguarding the rights of European citizens, if we are to be serious and effective.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Madam President, recent tragedies in the Mediterranean have shown us that the situation there, and the migratory pressures which the EU faces, are not at an end. Migrants are not deterred by the risk to their lives. They are often fleeing desperation, extreme poverty and war, but too often they are aided by ruthless and exploitative human traffickers. Year on year, more lives are lost within sight of the European coastline. Now it is time for more straight talking and proper action, not just pointing out the problems. We need to look at strengthening the EU’s border surveillance, and the role of Frontex. Mediterranean countries need to step up their humanitarian responsibilities to treat those arriving with dignity. The Commission needs to make sure that all Member States are living up to their obligations, particularly with regard to detention conditions. We need more solidarity and more joined-up thinking. Member States must process efficiently and quickly the applications of asylum seekers who arrive, even if it means more administrative work and resources. We especially need to ensure that unaccompanied minors are protected and safe, and that their best interests are at the forefront of our actions. We need the toughest penalties for human traffickers across the EU, and third countries must take action against them too. The EU also needs an efficient and effective returns policy through cooperation with third countries. Of course we need to support Member States with resettlement and community integration, but we also need to stop demonising citizens who do have genuine concerns about immigration and integration, otherwise this Parliament merely plays into the hands of those with an anti-immigration agenda.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I think it is important that we have this debate this evening because we are being reached continuously, week after week, month after month of information on boats that are slipping in the Mediterranean and about people drowning. This is the message that haunts us. We politicians must today acknowledge our defeat, because people continue to die in the Mediterranean and the Mediterranean has turned into a sea of death, a gigantic cemetery without borders. People smugglers continue to find new ways of making even more money from desperate people. To find a solution, we must try to get to the bottom of the problem. These are people fleeing war and persecution and in desperate situations. There are no legal ways of coming to Europe. The only alternative is ruthless people smugglers who make a lot of money from other people's misfortune. The smugglers have a monopoly on the market and continue to exploit people's desperation to make money as long as we do not take our human responsibility. We cannot continue to refer to third countries. We must be involved too. Our mission must be to take away the people smugglers' business idea. Only in this way will we put an end to these journeys across the sea. It is by creating legal, safe routes to Europe, increased resettlement, humanitarian visas issued at embassies and consulates, in refugee areas and in refugee camps. To come here safely is not the same as opening the doors to a mass wave of migrants, as some critics seem to think. Those who come here, like everyone else, are allowed to go through an asylum process, and those who have reasons are allowed to stay and those who do not are allowed to stay. It is never up to anyone else to solve Europe's difficult problems. We have to take our responsibility and do it now because it is on fire.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour son on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Of course, it is inhumane for people smugglers in the Mediterranean to abandon ships carrying hundreds of refugees on the high seas, and it is, of course, reprehensible that old cattle carriers should be used to come to Europe with crammed refugees, and to see this as a new business idea. But quite honestly, if the Council and the Commission now stand up and mourn the new level of inhumanity of smugglers, then it is hypocritical. It is hypocritical because the question of why refugees use these unsafe escape routes in the first place is ignored. It is ignored that Frontex itself, through its actions, contributes to ever more and more dangerous escape routes, that many refugees objectively cannot obtain visas at all, and that with the end of Mare Nostrum, the high seas are now left to the smugglers and the smugglers with Triton, and no one asks about the refugees.  If the interior ministers of the Member States now also think that they need to strengthen the repressive border protection policy, then I say that the more they upgrade at the external border, the worse the methods of smugglers will get, that is a fact!  What we need is a kind of disarmament, in other words a change of course in asylum policy, not a outsourcing strategy to Khartoum, but integration strategies, and legal routes to Europe, that is what it must be about. Let us rethink! It is a matter of human lives, and we are not saving a single human life by more repression at the border.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her With the phasing out of the Mare Nostrum maritime rescue programme, the European Union has finally left the Mediterranean to sometimes brutal smuggling gangs. Frontex is not a substitute for this, it cannot be a substitute for it. We finally need a coordinated sea rescue here in Europe, in the Mediterranean. And the Commission? Commissioner, you now want to fight the smugglers more strongly. How do you intend to achieve this? With Libya, a state that is hardly one? In cooperation with Turkey, where refugees find little protection? In this way, the crossing will only become more dangerous, even more expensive for the refugees. The only thing that is really effective against smuggling gangs, the only thing that really helps refugees is legal immigration, the possibility for refugees to seek legal and safe protection here. Sorry, Commissioner, but 37 000 resettlement places are really not enough. The UNHCR asked for 100 000. There are many Member States of the European Union that do not resettle a single refugee. Dear representative of the Council, I would have liked to hear what you intend to do, because this is a humanitarian disaster. We must finally act more!

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, people-smuggling across the Mediterranean is a human tragedy. The word ‘criminal’ is inadequate to describe the abandoning of men, women and children in a leaky ship on the open sea. Such criminals are not fit even to be described as human beings, and the severest penalties should be imposed on convicted people-smugglers. The Commissioner said earlier that Turkey was now an alternative route into Europe, and Mr Kirkhope of the Conservative Party spoke about the need for strengthening borders. But I wonder if he is aware that the Conservative Party’s policy, recently stated by David Cameron, is to further open up borders and to allow Turkey to join the EU and allow another 72 million people the right to come to Britain? There will be no need for the people-smugglers to put people into leaky ships, because all they will have to do is to give them forged Turkish passports and they can come freely. Such is the Conservative Party’s policy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, it is well known that the Mediterranean is the main gateway to Europe not only for illegal immigrants but also for people who are used by international circuits for illegal activities that offend their personality and violate their human rights. Such activities are prostitution, child labour, crimes, drug trafficking, but also acts of terrorism. As far as Greece is concerned, these unfortunate people are placed on old ships and abandoned in the country's territorial waters near the border with Turkey, while being forced to pay between $3,000 and $10,000 per capita. Because all illegal immigrants come from Muslim states, among them islamic fanatics, who come to Europe to prepare and wage their holy war, jihad. So if the states of Europe do not cooperate effectively to deal with this danger, I very much fear that the tragic events in Paris will simply be the beginning of the jihadists' action in Europe.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Fl-aħħar ġimgħat erġajna rajna aktar traffikar ta' nies minn organizzazzjonijiet kriminali fil-Mediterran. Kellna bastimenti għar-rimi jimxu għal riħhom lejn l-Ewropa mingħajr ekwipaġ. Ir-ritratti li rajna ta' nies vulnerabbli jibqgħu jkexkxuna għal għomorna. Rajna nies mgħobbija f'ammonti kbar. Qed nissugraw li jkollna traġedja oħra fil-Mediterran.  Dawn it-trends ġodda i nistgħux i nagħtux kashom. Irridu nieħdu azzjoni b'mod konkret u urġenti; irid ikollna strateġija olistika, kif qal il-Kummissarju,. biex nindirizzaw dan it-traffikar illegali li jsir minn nies li jabbużaw minn dawk li huma l-aktar vulnerabbli. Irid ikollna l-kuraġġ politiku li neżaminaw x'azzjonijiet fit-tul jistgħu jittieħdu u li jmorru lil hinn mill-mandat politiku. Irridu nesploraw alternattivi oħra legali dwar l-immigrazzjoni. Iva, irid ikollna wkollna wkoll il-kuraġġ li ngħidu li din il-kwistjoni tal-immigrazzjoni ma tistax tintrafa' biss mill-pajjiżi Mediterranji fil-periferija tal-Ewropa.  Kull gvern Ewropew għandu jħoss responsabbiltà bħalma jħossu r-responsabbiltà Malta u l-Italja. Mhuwiex a大大ettabbli li jkun hemm min jaħrab mir-responsabbiltà sempli大 għax mhumiex qegħdin fil-Mediterran. Fl-aħħar sena u nofs dan il-Parlament approva żewġ riżoluzzjonijiet importanti li sejħu sabiex tittieħed azzjoni fil-Mediterran. Il-Kunsill issa jrid jieħu azzjoni.  Din hi kwistjoni Ewropea u jeħtieġ li jkun hemm soluzzjoni Ewropea mill-pajjiżikollha tal-Unjoni Ewropea.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President! At the turn of the year, a driverless freighter carrying some 1 200 refugees was apprehended off the Italian coast. Yes, the methods of smugglers are unacceptable, as human lives are at risk for up to USD 8 000 per crossing. But the real problem is that many vulnerable people see no other way to come to Europe and apply for asylum here. This is being exploited by criminal groups. We must not give the impression that we just wanted to close ourselves off now. Combating smuggling must only be part of our response. We must call for European solidarity in asylum policy, ensure fair participation by all Member States and monitor the implementation of new asylum rules critically. The Council must do more, for example in the area of resettlement and humanitarian visas. Lithuania could perhaps set a good example. The Commission's pilot project for 10 000 refugees from civil war is a start. But I expect more courage and new proposals from the Commission – including in the area of legal labour migration beyond blue cards and seasonal work.  Europe can offer protection, and Europe needs immigration. Greater commitment to integration is needed – for a further peaceful coexistence and also as an important building block against any form of radicalisation. Let's get it done!

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: Madam President, the root cause behind these incidents is the ambivalent – one might say schizophrenic – immigration policy of the European Union and its Member States. It is difficult and dangerous to come here, but once you do, it is very likely that you will obtain a residence permit, be entitled to family reunification and so on, whether you are fleeing from persecution or just from poverty. As long as this continues to be the case, there will be more and more people trying to get to Europe. As long as there is demand for sea transport, there will be criminal organisations satisfying that demand. So we will have more and more of these tragedies. The problems that create migration cannot be solved by migration or new legal rules; neither can Europe indefinitely afford this kind of immigration.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Madam President, Commissioner, as you have made clear, the European Union must act quickly and effectively in the face of this European fiasco, this image of the detestable Europe that is ours in the Mediterranean, in the graveyard it has become. We need three key answers. Firstly, a tightening of legislation in the face of trafficking, human trafficking and the organisation of a real reaction against this new squalid and extremely lucrative economy used by criminal smugglers with ghost cargo ships. This reaction must be relentless and strong in the face of these smugglers who act in an unspeakable manner with unaccompanied migrant children.  Secondly, FRONTEX, which is absolutely outdated, must have real budgetary resources, clean equipment and a compulsory contribution from states and not optional.  And finally, as our colleague Cecilia Wikstrom has pointed out, we must ensure legal migration routes.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in a European Union where interior ministers are obsessed with collecting air passenger data, it is astonishing that ghost ships can arrive, 13 in 3 months, with hundreds of fugitives that we cannot protect from traffickers! It is scandalous that some Mediterranean countries pretend not to see ships and refuse rescue when the first S.O.S. is launched as for Blue Sky. We call for scrupulous compliance with the rescue obligations even beyond thirty miles from the coasts imposed by Frontex, for Frontex to be sanctioned when it criticises Italian rescues over thirty miles. Things are not going so well, neither for Triton nor for Blues Sky, I would like to say this to the Commissioner and the Latvian Presidency. We call, in order to stop the traffickers and not to put an end to the right of asylum, for the immediate establishment of legal humanitarian corridors.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Mr Avramopoulus, I may have been inattentive, but I did not hear you make the promise you made in the LIBE Committee in September to also examine the possibility of establishing humanitarian visas. We have been able to read that the fight against trafficking in human beings should be a priority. I hope that humanitarian visas are also part of this fight. Legal routes are a very concrete way of prioritising the fight against traffickers. The ingenuity of people smugglers is, as we know, endless, and they will always be one step ahead of us. The ghost ships are just one in a series of many years. Our only way to win that fight is to remove their market, just as Cecilia Wikström said earlier. A broader resettlement programme, greater joint responsibility between Member States, asylum visas, but also more support for conflict resolution and the fight against poverty – they are all, individually, part of the solution in the fight against smugglers, so I hope that all parts are given equal priority.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the phenomenon of ghost ships laden with migrants apparently abandoned by crews on routes to Europe is a danger to the safety of shipping and human life. Investigations into the recent landings in Calabria, Puglia and Sicily reveal that the business of sea carts filled with migrants is of great proportions, yielding millions of dollars, as well as that related to publicly funded reception systems.  Some Mediterranean countries allow ships to pass through the Italian coast without intervening, it would be appropriate for the European Union and the Member States bordering the Mediterranean to counter any form of connivance more effectively, promoting forms of cooperation to prevent trafficking in human beings by provideing for legal routes of access to Europe and by adopting every valid instrument for the protection of human lives and fundamental rights. , and that they dismantle criminal networks and protect the states most exposed to the pressure of flows.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the European Union is unable to combat immigration channels effectively. As proof, 160,000 migrants arrived by sea in Italy in 2014, an average of 450 migrants per day. And things are getting worse as three cargo ships full of Syrians arrived from Turkey between December 22 and January 3. Smugglers charge these immigrants up to $8,000 per person. It's a business that works well. The European Union does not dare to solve the problem. His Triton program is an admission of impotence. Its Khartoum process is an empty shell and it does not even dare to challenge Turkey, which openly organizes immigration by sea. The Union has so little courage that it continues to consider the accession of a country that makes fun of it. Personally, I believe that the only way for European states to control immigration is to regain their sovereignty.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: Madam President, the dramatic situation in the Mediterranean area raises many issues and questions which should be solved immediately, since the problem of illegal immigration is increasing. I believe that our priority is to regulate the problem of illegal immigrants, not by temporary actions but by common immigration law and organised programmes which will provide assistance in all cases. Furthermore, it is also necessary to look at why the common European asylum system is not implemented in all EU Member States. All these actions could open a legal and safe way to Europe for illegal immigrants and effectively stop the smugglers. It is also crucial to activate the main tools, especially under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. This would effectively manage immigration flows and enhance fair and effective strategies which would contribute to combating the irregular immigration process. Commissioner, in your statement you mentioned the European programme for the resettlement of refugees and the fair distribution key between Member States. In that context, solidarity and an integrated approach are vital, but it raises many questions and challenges. Since each EU Member State has a different population, GDP and, most importantly, market and absorption capacity, as well as a different human welfare position, how does the Commission plan to regulate issues concerning the fair allocation mechanism for refugees within the EU? Which particular distribution method of asylum seekers is foreseen among Member States?

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, some might exclaim: "Another debate on migration in the European Parliament!".  Indeed, recently, not a plenary takes place without the subject of migration being discussed among the debates. It is the new methods of smugglers that have, for the most part, motivated today's debate. Garbage cargo ships, departing from Turkish or Egyptian ports, abandoned along the way, which are capable of transporting even larger groups of migrants. This macabre business does not know the crisis, quite the contrary, with networks of smugglers ever more powerful and sophisticated who in passing pocket millions of euros.  If the modalities are new, the causes are not. The conflicts in Syria, in Iraq, the instability in Afghanistan have appalling consequences, forcing tens of thousands of people to take ever more expensive and perilous roads. If the terms and conditions are new, the solutions are not. Like other colleagues, I have repeatedly reiterated in recent debates the need for a comprehensive approach to migration, including the promotion of legal channels.  From an asylum perspective, there are already several mechanisms for admitting refugees without having to risk their lives. Whether we are talking about resettlement, humanitarian temporary admission, a more flexible visa policy or family reunification, solutions exist and others can also be considered. Now the clock is ticking.  Two questions to conclude. What does the European Commission envision, in concrete terms, in terms of legal routes in its comprehensive approach to migration and how do Member States intend to strengthen their cooperation in the area of interception, rescue at sea and the reception of migrants?

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Madam President. Mr Avramopoulos, I too must tell you: hundreds of thousands of desperate people are willing to pawn everything they have to embark on an uncertain journey. And the mafias are illegally enriched by it, and these people are punished with all kinds of vexes during the dangerous journeys. We know, but mafias find a hole in the holes and deficiencies of our asylum and immigration system. We do not have a common European policy on visas, borders or asylum, and police persecution, unfortunately, is not enough. Frontex and Triton must gain capabilities and resources. We do not have a common intelligence policy developed and traffic penalties can be tightened and harmonized in countries. Condemn. Regret. But let's do it! Let us launch a coordinated Strategy of the European Union to end these practices. Mr Avramopoulos, count on our group and our party to do so.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Madam President, once again, indeed, we are talking about the tragedy of migrants in the Mediterranean. Despite Mare Nostrum or even Triton, the death toll has never been higher. Probably 4,000 dead, or more: Syrians, Iraqis, Eritreans and many others. Their nationality shows that they are refugees to whom the Member States of the European Union refuse protection. Never before have emigrants taken so many risks, so never have the smugglers taken so little. Commissioner, they know the risks they are taking and they are paying for it.  The solution is not to close borders, to return problems to third countries, to withdraw and to feed fears. I would like to say here how outraged I am - and the word is weak - by the political recovery of certain European heads of government from the dramatic events that took place in France. Immigration has nothing to do with these deadly attacks. It is not enough to march in Paris to show solidarity. We have to do something. It is no longer enough promises of welcome. You have to do it and you're a long way off.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his We have really seen enough human dramas in the Mediterranean. Turning to the left: I too would very much like to save the whole world, but we will not be able to do so if I only think of our problems here in Europe. For years, people have been watched here by unscrupulous criminals in nut shells. For several months now, this new tactic has been in place on former cargo ships, where the smugglers are leaving these people there alone. The profit margin of the smugglers is enormous. The departure points, according to Frontex, are located in the south-east of Turkey. So this is a new tactic, and the idea clearly comes from Turkey. Here, for example, Turkey, as a candidate country and the recipient of billions in subsidies, would be called upon to counteract these things. In my opinion, the Australian model is used in this matter. Instead of helping the smugglers and making their business model possible, namely to haul the refugees to Europe, these smuggling gangs must be deprived of their business base and the boats brought back to their place of origin.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: I want to pay tribute to the efforts of many, and I would like to point out that the Italian authorities, who , but more than 3500 died trying to cross the Mediterranean. On Christmas Day alone, 1300 were saved.  We now see one: abandoning large freighters, on autopilot, loaded with third-country nationals. There were more than 1000 immigrants in inmane conditions. I agree with Commissioner Avramopoulos. We must think about working on the source of the problems, including through agreements with countries of origin, legal immigration routes, development aid. That's the only way we can.  But it is imperative to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming yet another scenario of tragedy. Many have said that. We must and must be: men, women and children who try to escape those scourges.  That is why it has the means at its disposal. And we need a real. And we have to. Last year, we passed a regulation establishing mandatory rules on search and rescue operations for migrants at sea.  Different rules must now be rethought between operations financed from the Union budget and the responsibility of the Member States.   \*Saving human lives should be a priority for everyone!

name: Tanja FAJON
text: What we are witnessing in the Mediterranean is alarming. Organised criminal gangs on coxless ships cram hundreds of desperate people, who often pay for their life savings for the journey, leaving them in a hopeless situation with nothing in the middle of the sea. All this is happening before our eyes, on the doorstep of Europe, politicians are constantly warning of the problem, but nothing happens – I regret it. Unfortunately, 2014 was another record. We need to act more quickly, we need a comprehensive approach. Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of organised crime, we are talking about women and children, not numbers. We are asking the European Commission, as we already adopted in the report of the CRIM Special Committee a year ago, – more safe and legal routes to Europe, especially more financial support and more solidarity between Member States. And listen, dear colleagues, honest listening to the call of desperate people.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Madam President, I have been to Melilla this weekend and I have to say that I still have the pain and anger tucked into my body for all that we have seen there and for all that we have heard.  Trafficked women and girls from Nigeria repeatedly raped along the long journey to pay for their trip to Europe and the rest of the group. A debt that never ends, a debt they continue to pay here, victims of the cruellest sexual exploitation at the hands of mafias dealing with them and their daughters. In Nigeria there is an armed conflict, fueled by the weapons sold to them by European countries, just as there is war in Syria, with three million displaced people, just as there is war in Afghanistan, with two million displaced people, or in Mali or many other places. Conflicts fed, if not provoked, by the West.  Add to this the lack of humanitarian corridors and the lack of legal avenues to enter Europe, we have the perfect breeding ground for these mafias that traffic with humans. With their policies of wars, of expoliating the countries of the South and with the armour of borders they are being complicit in these mafias.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: When we talk about people who can pay $8,000 for a crossing, we're not talking about pathetic refugees. With $8,000, you're rich in Africa. These are people who make an investment decision. One-off investment with the return on investment of a bed, a bath, a benefit and family reunification. But we in Europe have come to an end with our reception capacity. And every asylum seeker or happiness seeker we admit is at the expense of the people who are already in Europe. Allowing this mass immigration is therefore to deny the fact that there are limits to money, resources and opportunities to give people a decent life. It reminds me a bit of the childlike naivety of my little girl, who thinks that there is an infinite amount of money in an ATM and that her father can keep pinning. I will tell you: I have never done this before. And europe will not succeed either. There is also a real risk that among the people we bring in here are jihadist elements, who may have a very different purpose with our society than we currently have. Finally, we must keep Europe livable, and that is why we must immediately stop admitting and accepting people. Close the borders, better today than tomorrow.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, our answer to the mounting and multiple challenges in the Mediterranean is not to close the borders but to open safe and legal ways for refugees while combating criminality and abuse. Citizens have legitimate concerns, too many are coming too fast, but populism is never the answer. Our target should be the smugglers and not the refugees. Our response to the ruthless criminals who abandon children, women and men in ghost boats should be clear: increase security cooperation, increase cooperation with third countries like Turkey, strengthen Frontex, Triton and the Eurosur coordination system with more resources. All Member States should assist the Mediterranean states facing this emergency, and I commend Italy for the ‘Mare Nostrum’ policy. But solidarity should also be with the countries that welcome most of the asylum seekers, like Sweden. More Member States should take more responsibility for more refugees, including with resettlement. The new common rules in the asylum package should be implemented by all. The time has come to change the way we look at refugees. Yes, in the short term they are a cost; but in the long term, let us be honest, we need them. We do not say ‘go home’; we say ‘go to work’. Integration has to go hand in hand with asylum, and I am proud that Europe is a humanitarian superpower. We should continue to protect people fleeing from war and terror.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Madam President, the flow of migrants from third countries through Turkey to Bulgaria and Greece is increasing steadily and poses serious risks to the European Union's external land borders. This is not the first time I have paid attention, Commissioner, because this situation may become even more severe than the Mediterranean. The Bulgarian-Turkish border is a hard-to-reach region and an ideal environment for smuggling and trafficking in human beings. More than 45 rescue operations were carried out by the Bulgarian government - more than 1,500 police officers guard the border around the clock, there are already casualties on both sides. Ninety percent of illegal immigrants have entered with the help of traffickers and more than 170 smugglers have been detained in 2014 alone. The tragedy of the victims has become a lucrative business, organized even through the Internet. There is a great risk that terrorists who pay well for services will also be infiltrated through them.
