Bulgaria ranks third at the request of Syrians after Germany and Sweden and at the same time receives one of the lowest budgets from the Migration Fund. At the same time, there is also no political solidarity – the country is making enormous efforts for the security of the European Union's border, while denying it Schengen membership.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, I am astonished by the tone of this debate. I hear from a number of colleagues who say that, in order to remedy the situation of these ghost cargo ships, which are populated by hundreds, thousands of unfortunate people who seek to immigrate illegally, it must be said, in our European countries, the solution would be to open up legal immigration more. It reminds me of the one who, to avoid getting wet in the rain, would dive all dressed in the pool, which is obviously can be a little more effective.  In fact, ladies and gentlemen, why are these unfortunates rushing to risk their lives? Well, it is because for the last seven or eight years , when I went to Lampedusa with the parliamentary group that I chaired - we now know very well all over the world and in Africa that when we set foot in Europe, would it be illegally, we never leave.  If you really want to stop this trafficking, you must not just prosecute the criminals and make representations to Turkey. How can we believe that hundreds of people can be rounded up on a cargo ship, restored without this being apparent to the authorities of the country of origin? But we must also, alas, repatriate, with the help of the United Nations, the unfortunate refugees from which they come. This will be the only effective measure.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul When we talk about international organised crime, we make a clear distinction between people smuggling, which is the subject of this discussion, and trafficking in human beings and trafficking. The most important difference lies in how we see the victims. We have made progress in the fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of those who are victims of such trafficking. There is a European Convention and an EU directive setting a common standard. However, it does not seem interesting to discuss how to protect victims from people smuggling. There is a huge legal and political vacuum here. The EU contributes to the exploitation of people in the Mediterranean through a restrictive migration policy and by focusing on guarding borders rather than on saving lives and providing protection. As a consequence of the EU's border policy, people are forced to turn to smugglers and are not seen as exploited, but as illegal or even criminals themselves. This must stop. We have to see them as victims.  Between 2007 and 2013, the EU spent €2 billion on strengthening surveillance of the EU's external borders, and only €700 million to improve the situation of refugees and asylum seekers.  We should reallocate resources to improve the situation of refugees and create safe routes to europe for all. This is the only way to prevent the market for people smuggling.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Blue Sky M, Ezadeen, Norman Atlantic: the names of these three ships full of illegal immigrants bound for European shores symbolize the complete failure of European immigration policy.  Over the past twenty years, the Schengen Agreements have transformed the signatory states into a gigantic sieve whose holes are constantly widening. The worsening of the social aspirant pumps in favour of illegal immigrants only amplifies this phenomenon. The nationals of the Member States are the first victims because of the destabilization of their society by this uncontrolled and incessant influx. Illegal immigrants are also collateral victims of a mafia trafficking system that not only robbed them of their limited resources but also puts their lives at risk.  It is therefore urgent to give Member States back control of their borders and to put an end to this mad flight forward.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Madam President, when Operation Triton was presented, I have already reported that the technical and economic means were insufficient, especially if we compared them to those of Operation Mare Nostrum, by which one hundred and fifty thousand lives were saved. A bad decision was also to restrict the radius of action to forty-two kilometers from the coast. Unfortunately, time has given us reason and its inefficiency has been proven. The number of abandoned ships adrift has only increased, as has the number of shipwrecks and dead in the Mediterranean. This result forces us to rethink the European strategy in the fight against trafficking in human beings and we need legal, operational and criminal intelligence measures aimed, inter alia, at strengthening the roles and competences of Frontex, Europol and ASO. We need to provide them with budgets according to the challenge they face. It has been shown that border control operations alone are not sufficient to address this situation. Police cooperation measures are needed to combat trafficking in human beings. And not only at our borders, but also by cooperating with third countries of origin and transit. I applaud the arrival of the new operation and invite the Commission to promote its development by giving Europol the necessary funds. The involvement of all States, not just thirteen of them, as well as their coordination with Interpol and Frontex among others is necessary, as it is important that Europol has the ability to use operational intelligence data so that Member States and Frontex can collect and use it in neutralizing these operations.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the last days of 2014 were marked by a massive flow of migrants heading to the Italian coast, over a thousand in a few days, abandoned adrift in cargo ships, a sign of the obvious evolution and adaptation of human traffickers. The cold and drastic downsizing of the Italian mare nostrum mission did not stop the departures, while since 1 January what remains of the operation has ceased.  Those fleeing war, Mr President, have no choice but to rely on the hands of the traffickers of death; the war on Europe's doorstep presents us with the need to guard the southern borders with a particular emphasis on the humanitarian aspect, that of saving people. Operation Triton – of course – is insufficient. A response that acts more deeply on the causes, on combating trafficking but also on organised crime and corruption is now indivisible. That is why I welcome the Commissioner's willingness and openness to be able to tackle immigration with a comprehensive approach in order to find a solution to all that is also the problem of illegal immigration, strong international policy, strong development cooperation but also legal migration.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! Thank you for your indulgence for my late ness to speak, but it is a very important issue, and I believe it is also very important that, as they say, not only the neighbouring countries express themselves on this issue, but it is a task for the European Union as a whole. We also see, as we also say, that everything is linked to everything, however beautiful it is when small improvements are made. For example, we were all proud that we had achieved a democratic freedom movement in the north of Africa. But, of course, this freedom movement has also achieved an increase in the flow of refugees.  We ourselves were surprised by the intensity and rightly said again: we must, of course, ensure that someone who goes to the Mediterranean does not simply drown: that is why we said that we would then save the people.  However, we note again that, of course, smugglers are using this very strategy to take even more refugees into the European Union. Firstly, it is really important that we stand together here and, secondly, that we also, of course, also make agreements with the states where the refugees are – I say – being let on the water. It is simply not acceptable for money to be made with the suffering of other people. People need not only to be put to work, people simply need to be punished.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in my view, the first thing that needs to be admitted is that the European approach has been wrong. It was wrong as a whole; Operation Mare Nostrum was wrong because if lives were to be saved – we must not forget that last year there were more than 3 000 victims in the Mediterranean, and that was a record! European international policy was wrong because we created instability where there was stability, by increasing migratory flows, and it was wrong for Europe to favour these boats and these people who arrive in this way because they then came to be in the slave market.  You have to imagine, for example, the fact that of the 14 000 children who arrived in Italy last year, the traces of some 4 000 children have been lost, I leave it to you to imagine where these children may have ended up! And of the 150 000 rescued, only a third have remained in reception facilities, the others will probably safely go around Europe and not all of them are refugees and not everyone has the right of asylum, and so policies should also be made to repatriate these people.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, immigration is becoming an increasingly complex phenomenon day after day, requiring increasing attention from Europe. In 2014, according to data released by the UN Refugee Agency, more than 207,000 migrants attempted to cross the Mediterranean, with more than 3,400 losing their lives. In recent months there have been a number of episodes, which have been mentioned in a very detailed way in this House, which show a change of strategy on the part of criminal organisations, namely the phenomenon of so-called ghost ships in which automatic pilots are placed in the hope of being rescued at sea. What is even more serious is another fact, namely that many of these ships depart from the ports of Turkey, which has become the main sorting centre for irregular migrants in Europe, the same Turkey that has expressly been asking for many years to join the European Union. That is why I believe that There is an absolute need on the part of Europe to initiate cooperation actions with all third countries, but with Turkey in particular, in order to combat trafficking in human beings and to stop these criminal and criminal acts.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Madam President, that this debate speaks of 'incidents in the Mediterranean' already shows the extent to which we are wrong. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in the Mediterranean is a 'great drama', so this debate should be called. It's a great disgrace, because so many human beings die.  And it is also a great ridicule for the European Union, because criminals are beating us the game and they are making a fool of our defence capacity and our capacity for protection. Imagine that these vessels instead of people brought goods or let alone whether armed people came: wouldn't we deploy our full capacity to prevent these goods from arriving or to prevent armed people from coming to our shores? How is it possible that we are not able to prevent hundreds of people from dying in the Mediterranean? In this afternoon's debate, solutions have already been said, political will is now needed.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: Madam President, the fight against human trafficking networks, these criminal networks, is of course an absolute necessity.  We have been witnessing for some years the proliferation of these criminal networks, these networks of smugglers who, in the most ignominious way, exploit human distress and misery. But it is the scandal of these garbage cargo ships, of those cargo ships that have been allowed to drift in the Mediterranean with hundreds of men, women and children on board that has rightly moved European public opinion so much and which motivates our debate today.  So what to do, Commissioner? You have outlined a comprehensive plan for this comprehensive approach to migration that we are calling for. The answer must be European. It must be coordinated, it must be common, of course. You mentioned the legal instruments to combat trafficking and you called for strengthening these instruments. We will look very carefully at your proposal and we would like to see a tougher instrument of repression against smugglers who commit human trafficking.  But I also wanted to say two more things at this point. There needs to be clarity in the missions and we must put an end to hypocrisy. Clarity in missions: the humanitarian mission and the mission to protect our borders must not be confused. These are not the same missions, they are not necessarily the same operators who have to be at work. And we must also put an end to the hypocrisy, the hypocrisy of many of our governments who are struggling with the need to give more budgetary resources and more operational resources to European agencies and different operators. Triton does not have enough money and will soon run out of money.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, on large cargo ships that are 50 years old, with forged papers to Europe travel people who risk drowning, endless wandering the sea and death, because they want a better life. They are fleeing mainly the war zones of the Middle East and the poverty of Africa. Among these people, most of whom were from Syria and Eritrea last year, there are many children and pregnant women.  The annual turnover of traffickers is around 8 billion euros and they will do everything not to lose that money. There are four main human trafficking routes: the Western Mediterranean, the Middle, Eastern and Balkan routes. Most illegals arrive by the most dangerous - by sea - from Turkey along the eastern route to Italy set off by ships found last week, so-called ghost ships abandoned near European waters, packed with women and children. The real question is why Turkey has not acted in a timely way, because Frontex, as an agency for managing operational co-operation at the external borders of the Member States of the European Union, cannot enter the open sea and the Turkish coast.  Frontex's main role is to protect Europe from illegal immigrants, human trafficking and terrorist entry, but the question is how many human traffickers have been prosecuted so far and whose role is to help refugees and immigrants. Member States have an obligation under international laws to rescue all those who are at sea, but the abolition of some national projects seems to be growing expectations of Frontex, and this organisation has neither enough money, nor sufficient capacity and people nor authority to deal with these problems and human destinies effectively on its own.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: Il-Human smuggling huwa negozju ille大itu u immorali li jattakka d-dinjità ta' dawk li jaqgħu vittmi tiegħu u huwa wkoll theddida għall-Istati Membri. Dawk l-aktar affettwati qegħdin fil-Mediterran; l-akbar konfini fuq il-baħar tal-Unjoni Ewropea.  Sal-lum l-Unjoni kellha strateġija għall-Mediterran li tinvolvi ġestjoni tal-fruntieri. Iżda l-fatt li n-numru ta' in大identi tal-human smuggling dejjem jikber, huwa xhieda li din il-miżura waħedha hija insuffi大jenti. Dan id-dibattitu jissinifika de大iżjoni sabiex l-Unjoni tirrinforza l-azzjoni tagħha ħalli tista' tiġġieled ir-reat aħjar.  Għal dan il-għan hemm bżonn li nieħdu azzjoni li tmur oltre dik li diġà ppruvajna u falliet. Irridu naħdmu aħjar u aktar fuq ir-relazzjoni tagħna ma' pajjiżi terzi fejn is-smugglers isibu mhux biss id-dgħajjes iżda anki l-vittmi tagħhom. Fl-istess waqt għandna bżonn aktar coordinazzjoni tal-azzjoni li jieħdu l-Istati Membri u mhux biss dawk l-aktar milquta. Fl-aħħar, Kummissarju, napprezza l-ħidma tiegħek f'dan il-qasam u nawgura li ssib is-sapport ukoll tal-Istati Membri.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam Speaker, I will be very brief on my motion of order.  You are not responsible for this procedure, which has been observed in other debates. But I would like to say that we are no longer in an on-demand intervention procedure. If the groups are to register in advance and register their speaker, it is an extension of the debate. These are no longer on-demand interventions. On-demand interventions have been a procedure. I am an old parliamentarian and I experienced the beginnings of this procedure which was meant to be spontaneous, in which everyone waved a blue card and the former spoke. I think there is a real procedural problem with these on-demand interventions.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Congressman, I'm sorry. Believe me, I've been sitting on the other side long enough and I know how hard it is to get a word in a catch the eye procedure and how difficult it is. I would like to say that the collection of requests for contributions is done by members sitting in from the beginning of the debate, indicating their need to comment. In fact, they sit through the debate, wait their turn, and then get their chance. By the way, I am telling a Member that, from her group, Mr Corrao applied for catch the eye sooner. This debate should be decided among themselves, our timeframe is given. Next up is Mrs Tomašić. Congresswoman, I would like to thank you for your Do you want to draw attention now or a matter of order?

name: Diane JAMES
text: Madam President, I find it interesting that you are re-writing the rules this evening. I have made it abundantly clear for nearly the last 90 minutes that I wanted to speak. I have tried to blue card, you have stopped that. I have indicated to your colleagues twice to ‘catch the eye’. I have also expressly indicated to you that I wished to do so, and yet you appear to be applying some form of discrimination to an EFDD Group Member. Maybe you would like to explain why you are personally preventing me from speaking this evening.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Believe me, I have no intention of preventing your comment. In fact, I appreciate you sat through the debate – one of the Members who sat through it. I didn't collect the "catch the eye" commenters, I couldn't have done it, that's why my colleagues are there. And colleagues considered that your fellow Member raised his hand sooner than you did during the procedure. That's what I'm asking you to do. I have no intention of subwriting or rewriting the House rules. The next contributor is Representative Tomašić of the ECR. Give me a call.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: (the beginning of the speech is an incomprehensible) pressing European problem, so I welcome the institutions' awareness of the need to approach it as quickly and comprehensively as possible.  I believe that we must fight the problem at its centre through cooperation with third countries in whose territory are the main strongholds of criminals who make money off of someone else's tragedy. But I believe that by encouraging legal migration under the auspices of the fight against smugglers, we will only cause new problems. Opening up new legal migration routes will not necessarily keep criminals out of lucrative business, but it will certainly create additional financial and security pressure for Member States.  I believe that opening up to new migration waves must have a clear foothold in the mutual needs of the European labour market or education system on the one hand and migrants on the other. Otherwise, it is only an additional burden on the already overburdened social system of many Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, the problem we're dealing with today is a problem that's been going on for decades, in one variant or another, but it's been going on for decades. It will continue, and it will become more pronounced and increasingly dangerous the more dangerous our neighborhood will be affected by social and, unfortunately, war riots, especially in recent years. Therefore, I rank with those who think we need solidarity, but mixed solidarity. Solidarity with the people who are suffering, solidarity with those who are in accident, but also solidarity between us here in the European Union, among the Member States. And that's the solidarity we need. We need humanitarian corridors and we need a proper visa regime, and we need everything that colleagues have put forward before because that's the only way to solve the problem. Repression is not an alternative to solving problems.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since operation Mare Nostrum ended and Operation Triton began, the disturbing phenomena that we have renamed 'ghost ships' have increased, which are old cargo ships that are being left adrift on autopilot and then clearly a life-saving signal is being sent out so that the coastguard can intervene. There have been 13 cases, 2 recent, that of the Ezadeen and the Blue Sky M.  I heard Commissioner Avramopoulos say that we are increasing our cooperation with Turkey, but the point is that these ships have passed through Turkey, they have sailed from Turkey and the Turks have probably not noticed, so I also wonder how we are working with Turkey, because it is a country with which we have considerable relations. There is a crazy profit from those who do this business, this organised crime, which is estimated at billions of euros, and there are complicit states, so that a common policy must be a common policy in practice, a policy decided on this issue of immigration.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President! The immigration of human beings is as old as humanity itself, but within the limits of legal possibilities quite fine. Today, however, we are talking about illegal immigration, that is to say, non-legal immigration, and that of hundreds of thousands of people a year towards Europe. This, of course, also raises the problem of overburdening our society, of overburdening our citizens with this immigration. Ignoring the problem here is highly reprehensible and, above all, dangerous, ladies and gentlemen. The problem of illegal immigration across the Mediterranean must be tackled where it happens. This means offering and creating reasonable life prospects for people in their home countries. It will be just as important to make the countries bordering the Mediterranean accountable – these states where these ships start and where these immigrants board these ships illegally. Ultimately, financial aid to these countries – as for Turkey, as well as to Libya, and Tunisia – must also depend on efficiency and willingness to cooperate in combating this illegal immigration.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Madam President, let me just make a technical point. I think that when someone raises their hand that they want to make a technical point, I have read the Rules of Procedure and I should take precedence, that is the first thing. And the second thing is, Madam President, I am already at the next meeting that you are chairing, and perhaps if you were to end the speakers' speeches in time, then there would be no discussions about who should and for how long to speak. Thank you very much and I firmly believe that we will work better together in the future.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to the Members of the European Parliament who requested this Commission and Council statement and gave us the opportunity to meet here today and have this very interesting debate. Most of you focused on smuggling, and actually that was the main title of this meeting. As I said at the beginning, smugglers have discovered new methods and new routes, but we are determined to address this issue with determination. There is no doubt that smuggling is a criminal offence, but we need to make our legal instruments more effective. I said before that we have decided to proceed with better coordination and – as was repeatedly said – with a more comprehensive approach in order to address the roots of the current flows of regular migrants and also smuggling. It has been said during this meeting today that cooperation with third countries is of great importance. There is no doubt about this. I just want to remind you that about ten days ago we met in Rome during the Khartoum and Rabat processes and, at the same time around the same table, we had countries of origin, countries of transit and countries of destination. We all decided to fight this phenomenon more effectively, but we need the engagement of these countries, including Turkey. As far as resettlement is concerned, the first exploratory discussion with the Member States on a more balanced allocation, or distribution, for resettled refugees has only just begun. The Commission hopes to be able to discuss this point in a more detailed way during the Justice and Home Affairs Council which will take place in March. As far as distribution is concerned, for the time being – I will be frank with you – I cannot speculate on the exact nature of such criteria, although elements such as the total number of asylum seekers per capita and GDP will certainly be included. Our objective at this stage is to avoid extensive negotiations on a comprehensive list of criteria and instead to agree on a minimum set of criteria. This will allow us to launch a pilot as soon as possible. This pilot phase will give us the opportunity to adjust the practical modalities of the implementation of the distribution key. In the light of experience acquired last time, we will consider any possible further criteria in order to take into account the interests of all parties involved including, obviously, those of the refugees. Resettlement and the humanitarian mission remain, and this is my answer to Cecilia Wikström, who is very sensitive on this, the main routes of legal access to the European Union. The Commission, together with the High Commissioner for Refugees, has been calling on the Member States to consider other alternatives, such as more generous family reunification or student-worker visa schemes for Syrians, where feasible and appropriate, of course. Legal migration is also an important tool in this context. Regarding all other forms of entry, such as humanitarian visas: as was underlined before, the discussion so far indicates that there is unanimous opposition from the Member States to even considering such options at this point. We keep trying and we continue the political dialogue. Coming back to what was said before, fighting smuggling will be a top priority in the comprehensive approach to migration. Our discussion today has confirmed that all migratory challenges are closely interrelated and require a credible and coordinated European response. As announced in the Commission work programme for 2015, the Commission intends to present this comprehensive approach in a European agenda on migration. Be sure that we are committed and resolved to move forward.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for giving me the opportunity to intervene on the recent events of people-smuggling in the Mediterranean region. I could not agree more with the view that abusing the hopes of desperate people is a crime. We are speaking of a true human tragedy. The Council, of course, is fully aware of the grave risks to human lives and to the fundamental rights of thousands of immigrants, as well of as the challenges for the Union emerging from this new route used by smugglers who ferry out their passengers, mainly from Turkey, towards Italy. The Council’s competent bodies, in close cooperation with the other institutions, agencies and stakeholders concerned, intend to address this issue as a matter of priority. In the context of fighting the smuggling of immigrants on the criminal level, I would like to point out that the Council adopted in 2010 the EU policy cycle for organised and serious international crime, which established a multiannual policy cycle and a clear methodology for setting, implementing and elevating priorities in the fight against organised and serious international crime. In the framework of this policy cycle, the Council set priorities for the fight against serious and organised crime for the cycle 2014-2017, including the fight against facilitation of illegal immigration and trafficking of human beings in the following terms: to disrupt organised crime groups involved in facilitation of illegal immigration operating in the source countries, at the main entry points to the EU, on the main route and, where evidence-based, on alternative channels; to reduce organised crime groups and the abuse of legal channels for migration, including the use of fraudulent documents as a means for facilitating illegal immigration; and to disrupt organised crime groups involved in intra-EU human trafficking and human trafficking from the most prevalent external source countries for the purpose of labour exploitation and sexual exploitation, including those groups using legal business structures to facilitate their criminal activities. During the cycle, four-year strategic goals are defined for each crime priority, which are implemented by operational action plans, one per priority and per year. Honourable Members, the very important and fruitful debate that we had today clearly proved that it is our joint challenge and joint priority to step up efforts to prevent the smuggling of immigrants, to fight it and to prosecute those involved in such activities. We look forward with great interest to the Commission’s assessment of the existing instruments as announced by Commissioner Avramopoulos just now. To achieve the objectives of fighting against these criminal situations, it is crucial that all stakeholders make an active contribution. Along with the Council and the Commission, the European Parliament has a fundamental role to play in this respect. The Council stands ready to consider all the necessary actions and measures and to report to the European Parliament on their adoption and implementation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – Trafficking and trafficking in irregularly located migrants for profit is one of the most appalling and appalling activities of organised crime. These hateful practices pose a serious risk to the lives of migrants and pose a challenge for the whole European Union. The number of people trying to cross the Mediterranean in 2014 again reached a new record, surpassing the figure of 200,000. The European Commission and the Member States must take the necessary measures to deal with these crimes by bringing persons or groups involved in the exploitation of vulnerable migrants, refugees and asylum seekers to justice. In addition, extensive information campaigns need to be established to publicize the types of risk faced by those who put their lives in the hands of smugglers and those who are victims of human trafficking. These crimes against human dignity must end, and what is happening has to be a call for attention for all of us.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – The situation in the Mediterranean region caused by the unprecedented migration wave is extremely serious. It is right that we make the difference between refugees and illegal migrants again, because a large part of the migrants are not refugees, but are economic migrants.  The reasons for forcing these people to seek the EU's social benefits are rooted in the failure of their own countries, in the destruction of the secular character of many countries along the North Coast of Africa, in the rise and invasion of radical Islamism. Those countries and economic interests that organized the so-called "economic interests" are also to blame for this. an Arab spring that destroyed statehood and gave way to extreme Islamist factions such as IS, al-Qaeda, Boko Haram, al-Shabaab and the mujahedin.  The fight against migration must be fought with its causes where they arise. The role of Turkey's neo-Nazi government, which supports and organises traffickers and organisers of human trafficking channels, should also not be forgotten. More European solidarity and financial assistance is also needed for countries at the borders of migratory pressures, including Bulgaria, which currently carries a disproportionately high financial and organisational burden. European financial assistance is needed to complete the protective facility along the entire Bulgarian-Turkish border.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – Trafficking and trafficking in irregularly located migrants for profit is one of the most appalling and appalling activities of organised crime. These hateful practices pose a serious risk to the lives of migrants and pose a challenge for the whole European Union. The number of people trying to cross the Mediterranean in 2014 again reached a new record, surpassing the figure of 200,000. The European Commission and the Member States must take the necessary measures to deal with these crimes by bringing persons or groups involved in the exploitation of vulnerable migrants, refugees and asylum seekers to justice. In addition, extensive information campaigns need to be established to publicize the types of risk faced by those who put their lives in the hands of smugglers and those who are victims of human trafficking. These crimes against human dignity must end, and what is happening has to be a call for attention for all of us.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. Sandy, ghost ship, 700 migrants. Blue Sky M, ghost ship, 970 migrants. Ezadeen, ghost ship, 400 migrants. It seems by chance, yet since we moved from Mare Nostrum to Triton a new strategy has spread and old routes have reopened. No more carts of the sea, but merchant ships. No longer the Lampedusa route, but again that of Levante. Migrants pay more for the illusion of travelling in safer boats. These reports highlight the limits of European action, the inability of Frontex and the inadequacy of Triton. The failure of the European response. We can't wait any longer. And they cannot wait for the thousands of people who are the first victims of this trafficking. The key word must be security and the right to life, of those who face that desperate journey fleeing war, persecution and poverty. Let us not forget, Commissioner, that those crossed by these ships are very busy and an un commanded ship creates many dangers, not just for those on board. Action to be effective must be shared, all Member States must work together to stop a phenomenon which, rather than migration, has the character of trafficking in human beings.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Schengen Convention and then the Treaty of Amsterdam deprived member states of their national borders and of the necessary and necessary controls. The free movement of goods and people advocated by Brussels has given rise to and develop over the years, an obvious call for air to illegal immigration. Moreover, after "Mare Nostrum", The European Union's Operation Triton, which aims to rescue ships full of smugglers and abandoned by mafia smugglers in the middle of the Mediterranean, only aggravates the situation. Thus, it is with the support of the EU that illegal immigrants will finally land on European soil instead of being taken back to their country of origin, as common sense would dictate and demand justice. The Schengen area has made signatory Member States a real sieve. Even better, genuine social drive for illegal immigrants has been created by governments on the left and right, further increasing the phenomenon of illegal immigration. Our societies are destabilized by the weight of this illegal immigration. Illegals are victims of smugglers while European citizens are victims of the laxity of their rulers.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – Following a humanitarian tragedy not far from Lampedusa, when hundreds of immigrants and asylum seekers lost their lives in a shipwreck, we unanimously sought effective action by the European Union against human trafficking. It welcomed the launch of Operation Triton under the EU-funded Frontex Agency, which aims to strengthen border controls in waters off the Italian coast. In December, the European Parliament approved the EU budget for 2015. For foreign policy, the budget increased by €32 million, frontex agency also received more funding. Unfortunately, in recent weeks we have witnessed a new dimension that is taking on the smuggling of illegal immigrants to Europe: smugglers have replaced small vessels with cargo ships! As of December 20, three unmanned cargo ships with a directional autopilot system with about two thousand illegals had ended up on the Italian coast. The smuggling mafia is expanding a lucrative million-dollar business and the crime is taking on megalomaniac proportions that merit the qualification of attempted mass murder. Increasing funding is not enough, this is about EU foreign policy and relations with Turkey from which "haunted ships" depart. A decisive and holistic approach to migration policy, a strong interaction between EU domestic and external policy in the issuing of a legal settlement under international law of the sea, and strict criminal sanctions for trafficking and trafficking in human beings are needed.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. At the beginning of the year, in less than a week, two cargo ships adrift landed in Italy. The disaster was narrowly averted: nearly 1,200 migrants and asylum seekers were rescued. These new practices of smugglers call for a strong and coordinated response from the EU. For this to happen, it is essential not to react in haste but to think about a comprehensive and sustainable strategy in the long term, in cooperation with the international community. Since the end of Mare Nostrum, migrants and asylum seekers have continued to pour into our continent, and Triton's human and financial resources have not been sufficient to help them. The EU's migration plan will not prevent further drama in the Mediterranean if it focuses on combating migrant trafficking. The real priority is the development of legal migration channels for migrants and the definition of safe access routes to the EU for asylum seekers. Finally, there is an urgent need to implement the humanitarian visa proposal, to enable people in need of international protection to access refugee status without having to take ever more dangerous routes to Reach Europe.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – Trafficking and trafficking in irregularly located migrants for profit is one of the most appalling and appalling activities of organised crime. These hateful practices pose a serious risk to the lives of migrants and pose a challenge for the whole European Union. The number of people trying to cross the Mediterranean in 2014 again reached a new record, surpassing the figure of 200,000. The European Commission and the Member States must take the necessary measures to deal with these crimes by bringing persons or groups involved in the exploitation of vulnerable migrants, refugees and asylum seekers to justice. In addition, extensive information campaigns need to be established to publicize the types of risk faced by those who put their lives in the hands of smugglers and those who are victims of human trafficking. These crimes against human dignity must end, and what is happening has to be a call for attention for all of us.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. – Reports of drowned refugees in the Mediterranean are now, unfortunately, so commonplace that they are hardly news-like any more. With the new method of smugglers leaving overloaded refugee boats without a guide to their fate, the next misfortune is only a matter of time. It is important not to forget that smugglers are just a symptom of a much wider problem. We must recognise that we will not stop smuggling with border guard boats. Instead, we finally need safe entry corridors and the possibility of applying for asylum in the EU in third countries as well. Only in this way can we prevent people from risking their lives in the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean, and only in this way can we deprive people of the economic basis of smuggling. Conversely, if refugees are also allowed to apply for asylum in Europe in third countries, we must also discuss fair burden-sharing between Member States. One thing is clear, however: the current shock will claim more lives. That is why the EU must finally adapt its migration system to current circumstances.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – Viktor Emil Frankl, a well-known Austrian psychiatrist, once came up with the idea that there should also be a Statue of Responsibility on the West Coast next to the Statue of Liberty on the east coast. In my opinion, this idea is more true today than ever. The events of recent months, and especially recent ones, have shown us that people smuggling from unstable areas is becoming a thriving business. The groups that organise this smuggling are not about getting people safely out of conflict zones into the EU, but making a lot of money from their suffering. For me, it is essential that the EU takes responsibility here, finds these organised groups and punishes them properly. But the EU's responsibility must also be part of its internal policy. If Europe accepts migrants from problem areas, it must also take responsibility for them. These people mostly – if at all – work in unskilled positions, and let us be honest, the EU needs these workers to some extent. It should therefore be our duty to behave responsibly towards these immigrants, just as they must integrate responsibly in Europe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on women on company boards (2015/2509(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, women on company boards are the next topic. The subject of the gender balance on company boards is a very important topic. There is a broad consensus in Europe on the need to increase the number of women in decision-making, especially in businesses. I firmly believe that Parliament, the Council and the Commission already agree in principle on the most crucial thing, namely that equality before the law is not enough – we also need equality in practice, and this also means ending vertical segregation. There is no reason in the 21st century why businesses, banks and the economy as a whole should be mainly run by men. Allow me therefore to thank the European Parliament for keeping this issue on the agenda and for insisting on progress. As the Commission has also stressed, European business needs the talents of Europe’s highly-educated women, and increasing diversity is also a way to improve the performance of companies. We look forward to constructive exchanges with the European Parliament’s new rapporteur on this file, Ms Gabriel. According to the latest figures, the average share of women on boards of the largest publicly-listed companies in the EU is now 18.6%. This is a clear sign that concrete measures must be taken to remedy the situation. How do we ensure that our largest companies can benefit from the talents and dynamism of both women and men? It is a generally political question and policymakers have divergent views on approaches and what tools we should use. We should therefore not be surprised if more time is needed to agree. The goal we share can be reached by different roads. As you know, some Member States have already introduced binding quotas. Others are wary of interfering with company law and prefer self-regulatory measures. By means of example, the share of women on the boards of Latvia’s largest companies is 31%. I am proud to say that this result has been achieved without any formal measures of positive discrimination. How do we crack the glass ceiling? What is the EU’s proper role in this? The Commission’s proposal for a directive in this area seeks to answer the question in its own way. The proposal itself is a compromise of sorts. It does not provide for binding quotas. Instead, it sets quantitative objectives. The main obligations that the proposal contains concern the procedure for selecting board members, which should be fair, merit-based and transparent. I note that the European Parliament already adopted its first reading position on the Commission’s proposal in late 2013. In that opinion your institution broadly endorsed the approach suggested by the Commission. It is no secret that the negotiations on the Council side have been challenging. Despite efforts made by successive presidencies, our discussions have not yet been completed. Views still differ between the Member States regarding the best approach. The diversity between Member States needs to be respected in term of company law, the degree of gender balance already achieved and the national measures already taken to improve it. The Member States are taking action but in different ways. We must also remember that the Member States start from very different levels. One thing is becoming clear: from the subsidiarity perspective, any future measures at European level should recognise the fact that there is no one-size-fits-all solution. This was the spirit of the approach taken by the Italian Presidency. Building on this work, we will continue our search for a solution under the Latvian Presidency. On behalf of the Council I assure you that we will take forward this work with a view to reaching an agreement.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I would like first to thank you for adding this item to the agenda because it gives me an opportunity to present here the clear position of the Commission, and of myself, on this important piece of legislation which is – hopefully – in the process of adoption. We are fully aware that major steps on the road to effective gender equality need to be taken. The adoption of the directive on improving gender balance on company boards will be an important step on that road. The directive will help smash the glass ceiling that prevents qualified women from holding top jobs. The directive is smart and flexible: it puts qualification and merit centre stage. This European Union instrument is as necessary as ever. On boards of private companies we still have only 18% women. At the same time, 60% of new university graduates in Europe are female. Their talent should not be wasted, in particular in light of the demographic changes we face in Europe. It is well recognised in numerous studies that a range of talents, experience and skills in the boardroom improves business performance and governance and drives economic growth. If we want to maintain Europe’s competitiveness and stay ahead of demographic changes, we need more women at work, especially qualified women. Some Member States have seen positive developments, mainly those such as France, Belgium and Italy that have introduced, or are considering, legally binding measures. However, in others the situation is stagnating or even worsening. We have tried non-legislative action at EU level, but with limited results as you all know. Only a legally binding measure at EU level can effectively contribute to greater gender equality in the area of economic decision-making. We will therefore intensify our efforts to speed up the process of the adoption of this directive. Let me remind you that what the directive seeks is progress and fairness. We do not want women to be privileged because they are women. We want qualified women to get a fair chance. This is why, rather than imposing a particular result, the proposed directive requires Member States to ensure that qualification, competence and professional performance play the key role during the process of selection to board positions. This approach is in line with the case law of the Court of Justice, which has set rules and conditions for positive action for the under-represented sex in employment. It requires a comparative assessment of all candidates on the basis of objective criteria. Since there are highly qualified women capable of being selected as candidates, this approach is the right one to take. I see that considerable efforts have been made by previous presidencies; this is very welcome and there are concrete results from these efforts. The proposal is moving closer to achieving a qualified majority in the Council. In particular, the Italian Presidency has worked intensively on this directive and I am convinced that, on this solid basis, it is possible to agree that subsidiarity concerns be fully addressed. This should ensure the support of a sufficient majority of Member States. Latvia is among the Member States which have recently adopted a more positive approach to the directive. The Commission is therefore encouraging the Latvian Presidency to use this positive momentum, actively to pursue the discussion and then to reach a compromise solution.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, here we are in 2015 and it is clear that, since November 2013 and the adoption in plenary of the Kratsa-Regner report, by our two colleagues Rodi Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou and Evelyn Regner, proposing, following the European Commission, a mechanism to ensure a better gender balance on the boards of major European companies - the Women on Boards project - , the situation has made little progress.  After our own position, little progress has been made in the Council. We were disappointed to see that the Italian Presidency had failed to finalise its work and reach a compromise, especially at the last Competitiveness Council on 11 December. However, for its part, the European Parliament had shown great pragmatism on the basis of the principle of an unconstrained target, accompanied by fairer and more transparent procedures for selecting directors.  The position of the European Parliament had been built on the basis of consensual work between the different groups and struck a balance by balancing the need to increase the presence of women on the boards of large companies with the importance of respecting the legal frameworks, traditions and applicable national laws on management and corporate law in each member state. Moreover, the target of the text is quite circumscribed: the large European companies listed on the stock exchange. There is therefore both a reasonable objective but, at the same time, a symbolic, highly symbolic objective. A strong symbol that should allow us to offer future generations a path to increase female leadership, to finally break the glass ceiling.  With regard to the means, we can see that when legislative arrangements are implemented - and this is the case in all the countries of the Union, starting with my own - results are achieved. We must therefore now put all the goodwill - I would say all the female energy that has been expressed by the voice of the Commissioner, by the voice of the minister and, under the leadership of the Latvian Presidency, the Prime Minister of Latvia - to achieve a compromise. The European Parliament, for its part, is quite willing to work on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Anna HEDH
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr There are many who claim that quotas do not work, perhaps because it is such a simple solution. It forces companies to hire competent people, but 40% of them are women, and a lack of competent women is not. It is also about changing perspectives. Either we believe that women are not enough, that they do not have the necessary knowledge and experience, which is not true, or we turn it around and focus on the companies and structures there. Why don't they manage to hire women?  It has now been over a year since the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly on the Commission's proposal. Since then, a minority of EU Member States have blocked the proposal in the Council and forced a compromise that wateres down the original proposal and which this minority now does not seem to accept either. These countries point out that it is up to the Member States themselves to introduce any legislation on quotas, and that it should not be at EU level. That's bullshit! I say. Very little has happened in the Member States during this year of blocking. This attitude sends a clear signal to the women of Europe: 'We are not going to do anything to ensure that company boards are more equal'. A signal that there will at least be a crack in the glass ceiling or that competent women do not reach top jobs because they are women. I feel offended by the Council's actions. I know a lot of other women are too. Lowering the ambition, as is done in the compromise of the Italian Presidency by not making the 40% target binding, underlines once again the patriarchal structure that governs the EU's policy on gender equality or, rather, actively opposes the work of an equal Europe. The fact that quotas for company boards would be a universal solution to all gender equality problems is, of course, an illusion, but it is an important step along the way and sends a clear signal that gender equality is of the utmost importance for Europe and our future.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR group – The natural desire of each person is to realise their potential. As a mother of three who has been active in politics for several years, I believe that regardless of whether a woman decides to devote her life purely to family or family and wants to connect her work, it is our duty to create the right conditions for her to do so. Unfortunately, the proposal laying down quotas for the representation of women on company supervisory boards does not create such conditions. This is also clearly demonstrated by the example of Norway, where quotas were introduced in 2006 but did not achieve the desired effect. Norwegian employers' representatives agreed that not only for women in top positions, but also for their overall participation in the labour market, a sufficient number of kindergarten places and well-set parental leave are much more crucial. In addition to some Member States, an example of good practice in the area of parental leave is the European Commission itself, whose employees or employees can take part of this leave flexibly until the 12th year of a child's life. With this modification, I was inspired and I am currently trying to enforce it in the Slovak Parliament. I believe that in this way I will contribute much more meaningfully to women being able to realise their potential and not be squeuing them with the question: Work or family?

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, gender equality is one of the core objectives of the European Union, and the right to work is an essential precondition if women are to enjoy effective equal rights. Figures clearly show that discrimination against women is still a serious problem. The unemployment rate is higher for women than for men; the gender pay gap involves nearly every occupational sector; and moreover, while more education is an effective tool for increasing earnings, it is not an effective tool in fighting the gender pay gap. Sadly, many people out there still argue that women themselves are the problem. Needless to say, this is certainly complete nonsense. It is a shame – and for me unbelievable – that we all, including parents, still accept that the opportunities for young boys are still better than those offered to young girls. Discrimination and unacceptable inequality has to be eliminated, irrespective of the means and the rules we have to apply.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is clear that the media resonance of this measure is very high and so many are talking about it, but we did not want to miss this opportunity to remind the Commissioner that there are other realities and other problems of inequality between men and women which are priorities today.  The reality around us is shocking. In the European Union how many more women are in poverty and unemployed today? How many are affected by precarious work and go part-time with no time for them, their families or anyone else? How many are they asked in job interviews just to get a job if they want to be mothers? How many suffer from violence and bullying and sexual harassment in your workplace and at home? How many more and more health care rights are denied in pregnancy and family planning? How many have to feed their children alone when the minimum social support they had been cut off in recent times? There's going to be a lot of them! These women may never reach business administrations, but they represent the dominant reality that we hope they will not forget.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, only 18.6% of board members in Europe are women. Among the top executive positions the figure is only 3.3%. Three point three per cent, that is how far we have come 222 years after Olympe de Gouges died under the guillotine and 66 years after Simone de Beauvoir published her famous book ‘Le Deuxième Sexe’. Really? This is not only a minor problem of justice in the European Union. It is a frustrating scandal – a scandal that we could change. We could change it if only we could bring to a successful end the process of really making the European Union a champion for women’s rights. The introduction of a binding quota was started by courageous women. It was watered down; it was debated, praised and condemned. We as women, and also men, in this Parliament need to stand up for it now. We need to make very clear that we will fight for an ambitious, binding and European right as regards quotas for women in executive board rooms, and we will not give up until women get what they deserve – half of the power in boardrooms, in politics and in our societies.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, since the draft directive was proposed legislative pressure has been working. Companies searched for and found qualified and competent women to fill these seats to the tune of 18.6%.  Paradoxically, despite the force of the evidence, we trample. It has been more than a year since Parliament proposed a basis for negotiations. Two presidencies later, the Council has still not reached an agreement. There is therefore an urgent need for Member States to move forward on this issue with three key arguments to support. Yes, Commissioner, women make up 60% of graduates in the European Union, but their role in the labour market does not reflect this available competence. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy can never be achieved without breaking the glass ceiling. There is an urgent need to move away from the logic of the burden to the industry and to go and tap into the t. Secondly, to those who are allergic to quotas, Parliament has already given a pragmatic response. Quotas are not an end in themselves, they are an instrument to ensure that recruitment procedures are in place that are transparent and non-discriminatory.  Third, it is about instiling positive momentum by starting with boards of directors and relying on a snowball effect at other hierarchical levels to reduce vertical segmentation of the labour market.  Today, we all call for greater gender equality in the Union. It is high time that these wishes were translated into concrete action. At European level, there is a reduced room for manoeuvre. Where there are opportunities, it is politically irresponsible, in the face of our fellow citizens, not to seize them.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: We in the European Parliament have already adopted our position on this directive in 2013, which could serve as a good example for gender equality in other areas. But why are there still fears about the use of educated women, able women, to finally leave the European Union out of economic stagnation? Because in fact, we have to make such decisions so that women can work on company boards. Yes, in some countries the situation is better: in France, Italy or Belgium, but still, at the general level of the European Union, only 18% of women are on company boards, because other Member States do not have such legislation. This means that a common directive is needed and we really need quotas to achieve that 40%. Yes, it will not be easy, but I look at my neighbour, the Latvian Presidency and the honourable Minister. I really wish you the best of luck to work a lot, work responsibly and reach a consensus and then really be a good result.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I agree that there are few women on supervisory boards, but I absolutely do not think it is right for the European Parliament to regulate this issue. Let us leave it to the Member States.  But if we are talking about women in the European Parliament today, I would like to talk about the situation of women in Poland, about the situation of women in Silesia today. Today, women in Silesia are on strike against irresponsible government action that will create thousands of jobs and the situation on the labour market within the mines is dire. You will think: What is the relationship with the European Parliament? Well, it has. What is happening in Silesia is a consequence of the zealous implementation by the Polish of EU climate policy. Let's take care of women's real problems! Unemployed women, homeless women, women who fight for jobs, often go on hunger strike, women who want to combine work and parenthood. Let us address the real problems of ordinary women, millions of women in the European Union.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: I would like to express my joy and agreement after the commitment made to maintain the initiative, despite the problems created by the Council. This very important initiative, not only for equality, but also for competitiveness in Europe. Today, like it or not, female talent is marginalized in the European productive system by pure and simple machismo. Given that women accumulate sixty per cent of higher qualifications in Europe, their residual presence on the advice of large European companies is incomprehensible. That is why it is inefficient and opposes the principles of the Europe 2020 Strategy, because it marginalizes much of the talent available in making the big strategic decisions. European men, lose the fear of equality and dare to live on equality, because they will be surprised how much they have to earn, because the first victim of the "alpha male" are the men themselves. And this has to do with it.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in November 2012, the then Commissioner, Mrs Reding, boldly and decisively presented a draft legislation aimed at promoting a fairer inclusion of women on the boards of listed companies. A year later, this Parliament provided proof of foresight and courage and decided, by an overwhelming majority – I remember by 459 votes in favour – to support this proposal.  We have been one step away from incorporating into the body of Community legislation a directive which will support a more rational integration of women into the economic and social life of the Community. This would have been a very important, flexible legislative reference, capable of ensuring the proper employment inclusion of women in Europe, but the Council has failed to meet this challenge and so have the Member States, some Member States.  But what I most regret was the failure of the Italian Presidency, which was unable to take home this very important battle for equality between women and men, and I particularly regret that my country has been a forerunner in this field through the adoption in June 2011 of a bipartisan piece of legislation precisely on access to corporate bodies. I now hope that the Latvian Presidency will promote a constructive debate in the Council, but above all a dialogue that will lead to the effective adoption of this directive, which, as Commissioner Thyssen says, 'today, more than ever is necessary'.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Mr President, only eighteen per cent of women are on the board of directors in Europe. It is the obvious symptom that something we are doing wrong; therefore, the symptom and reflection that we live in an unequal society in which women are not having the opportunity to join in economic decision-making, in the public sphere, or in the private sphere. And now we all agree on the need to push for action in this area. But what we cannot do is dispel the proposals, what we cannot do is decaf these proposals because, if we leave it to the voluntaryness of the companies themselves the incorporation of women in decision-making, we will not be achieving the objective of increasing this participation. Therefore, it is essential, it is necessary, it is clear that we have to set real objectives so that they can be fulfilled and for that participation of women in economic decision-making to be real and effective.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Mr President, this directive has been stuck in the Council since 2013. Just why are we still waiting for constructive dialogue to make progress? Just what are they scared of? One can only wonder. But we have actually come a long way on gender quality in the EU. We tend to move in fits and starts, but we are moving forward. In the UK a report last year highlighted real progress. Women now account for just over 20% of non-executive board positions on the FTSE 100 – and yes, shockingly, we still think that 20% is progress. The disparity on company boards is undeniable and there is no justification. The increase in the number of women on boards is much, much too slow. The absence of women in leadership positions creates a vicious circle. The lack of women as role models reinforces the belief that women simply cannot make it in the corporate world. This House is testament to the fact that it is not true. Commissioner Jurová, I was delighted to hear that this directive on women on boards was one of your main priorities. I urge you and the Council to keep the discussions moving forward on this essential topic. That way we can make full use of everyone’s talent, regardless of their gender.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. We need more women in corporate leadership. I think we all agree on that. We have also discussed this for many years. At that time, the European Commission, under the leadership of your predecessor, Mrs Jourova, put on the table a very intelligent, wise proposal also for the Member States. I can only underline what the Commissioner said: this proposal is smart and flexible, as you said. I find so too. It gives the Member States the freedom to act according to developments in the countries. I would like to stress that I am from Germany. We have had a very difficult time introducing a quota for women, but we are now on the verge of being introduced, including legislative ones. The Bundestag will shortly discuss the bill that the Federal Government has put in place. I would also like to underline this: the first success of the proposal, the directive, is to be seen in the fact that, even in a large country such as Germany, a step has been taken here. So it is a good news thing about the political message that Commissioner Reding has always sent out, to do more for women, to put women in leadership responsibilities. I wish the Presidency of the Council a good success. I will certainly also use my contacts to Berlin to motivate Germany to give in here. It is time for this proposal to be finalised. As I said, you have my support as long as you also exclude small and medium-sized enterprises from the directive. I would have been pleased if the family businesses had also been excluded. All in all, however, this is a proposal that deserves only support in terms of content.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr. President! Almost half of the working population are women. But they are hardly represented in Europe's executive floors. On average in the EU, women earn significantly less than men, even though they are well educated as never before. I think that is simply no longer acceptable. These depressing facts on the subject of "gender equality of opportunity" have been discussed time and again. But it is more than long overdue for something to change. That is why the European Parliament has acted. That is why it adopted an ambitious and balanced legislative text back in 2013. It has sent a clear signal to businesses and, of course, we expected the governments of the Member States to move. But what has happened so far? In essence, nothing, and that is simply unacceptable! We in Europe must finally start to take our Charter of Fundamental Rights seriously.  Article 23 states that equality between women and men must be ensured in all areas, including employment and pay. The principle of equality, it states, does not preclude the maintenance or introduction of specific benefits for the under-represented sex.  In this sense, the Latvian Presidency should make every effort to put an end to the blocking attitude in the Council. Latvia could succeed. It has the highest proportion of women on supervisory boards, at 31%, as you pointed out, Minister. Set an example and use it to end the blockade in the Council.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking It is absolutely natural and necessary to strive for full equality between people of different sexes in the public sector in a modern society. However, as far as the private sector is concerned, the specific instruments necessary to achieve this lofty objective must be taken very responsibly, especially when we are talking about doing business. It consists in the activities of traders in their own name, on their own behalf and at their own risk, based solely on the principles of economics and mutual trust. Sacred property rights should be under special protection, owners must have a decisive influence on the fate of their property, and therefore on the way in which it is management. I believe that states have the right to lay down rules on governance, including the establishment of gender quotas, but only in the case of public property. The desire to impose the same rules on owners of private sector companies must be questionable. I therefore believe that the proposals discussed today should be reassessed.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you ended your presentation by saying: 'Give me arguments that will allow me to negotiate properly with the Council'. I would say that I would ask the Council to make arguments that would allow it not to fight the injustice of this misrepresentation of women on boards of directors. Are there any arguments that we can hear that justify the opposition to more women on boards? I don't think so and I'm not the only one. According to the Eurobarometer, 88% of Europeans believe that women should be represented in management positions in companies and 75% support the adoption of EU legislation in this direction. So I say to the Council: "Go ahead, you have the support of the people".  Companies that have chosen to have women on their boards are achieving positive results in terms of creativity, innovation, competitiveness, performance and governance. All these elements should give you, the Council and The Member States, a way to fight for these women to be properly represented on boards of directors.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Strong legislation with binding targets is needed for power to be shared. That is my conviction after following this debate for many, many years. Power is not shared voluntarily. It's naïve to think so. Those who think it will have to wait another 100 years before seeing a change. Women have long acquired the necessary qualifications and the necessary training to compete with men, but myths are created in society in order to effectively withhold power from women. One such myth is that there would not be qualified women. There are many who wish to spread that myth. The truth, however, as I said, is that power is not happy to share. An example, I think, is actually the hall in here to prove that about power. We know that we have 751 Members. Nevertheless, a few men choose to give priority to this debate. In the beginning, there were only three male Members here. I think that says something about how vested interests usually sit where the heart is and where you set your priorities. So it's time for tough legislation!

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr. President! How long have we been discussing equal rights for women in the labour market, and what has been the impact of this years-long discussion, which has been so non-binding? As has already been said, around 18% of women in management positions on supervisory boards are in EU-wide. Women in Europe still do not have equal pay, they do not have the same opportunities for promotion, even though they are at least as qualified as their male counterparts. It is time we got a binding quota. Achieving this on supervisory boards can be the beginning to pave the way for all women in Europe. Parliament has done its homework here, and now it is the turn of the Council. The Christian Democrats in Germany have realised that their previous position has been wrong and that voluntary action is of no use. Now, in the grand coalition, they have voted in favour of a mandatory quota of women on supervisory boards, and this must now also be reflected in the Council – in the German attitude, in the attitude of other Member States – the blockade must be lifted, otherwise women will still be hit by the much-vaunted glass ceiling in 100 years' time.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: Mr President, no less a person than Mrs Angela Merkel said recently on German radio that we simply cannot afford to do without the skills of women. But this draft directive which has come from Parliament is about more than skills and company performance. It is about equality, something which the EU as an institution has believed in since its very foundation in the Treaty of Rome in 1957. So it is absolutely shameful that the Council has sat on this and has blocked this measure for such a long time, and I think we need to do all that we can to get movement. I think Latvia is beginning to do that now, and we should welcome that. This is an eminently reasonable measure that we are putting forward. There are qualified women out there who are quite capable of doing a very good job on company boards. Women in leadership is an EU matter. We need to do it and fight for all the women throughout the European Union.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too believe that the blockade that has been put in place in the Council on the measure we are debating is simply shameful, it has no reason. Opposition to the measure is purely ideological in nature, with baseless arguments. You rightly asked for some indication, some advice on how to force this state of affairs; I try to tell her quickly what I think.  Gender equality is a fundamental right of the individual, which is now being denied by the hostility of the Council. Gender equality for the things you have heard reported here and also in countries that have had important experiences is a great advantage for the production system, because women are bearers of a particular point of view, an important culture and knowledge that men often do not have. For this reason, I believe that it is very important, on the one hand, to have quotas, because voluntarism alone is not enough and, on the other hand, to have sanctions. If you believe that you are using all these arguments to unblock an objectively intolerable situation, we cannot talk about a Europe of rights as long as discrimination of this nature remains.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: There are too few women in the field of decision-making. We are also in the minority in the European Parliament, but the situation is improving. In October 2013, 17.8% of board members in europe's leading companies were women. If there were no various activities at European Union level, such as the European Strategy for Gender Equality and the legislative initiative on women's quotas on boards, there would be less than 14%. Reducing the gender gap is an area where the European Union can and must play a leading role and an important role, but there is too little action only at the end of the chain. Women's quotas in politics, the economy are welcome, but if we want lasting change, we need to take action at different stages of the life cycle. As, for example, familiarise young people with different career options beyond stereotypes – women in computer programming, men as carers in hospitals. Encourage fathers to take more care of their children and take part of their parental leave. The price of inequality we pay in the European Union is high, as research shows that the european Union's gross domestic product per capita is around 10% lower due to labour market inequalities.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the obstructionism surrounding the proposal for a gender balance in the CDAs of listed companies is truly incomprehensible, as well as totally unacceptable. The agreement that could have been reached thanks to the mediation of the Italian Presidency provided, among other things, that Member States that already performed well had the right to continue their policies without the obligation to transpose the directive and, above all, that the threshold of 40% of women did not represent an obligation to result.  This means that no state would ever be penalised if the objective was not achieved. Now, let us also leave out all the research and data that testify to the positive effects of the presence of women in the button room – and these obviously do not stop at the numbers – but could the Council explain what the fear is? What are the states afraid of this directive, which does not even provide for sanctions? I really hope that the answer is not that the problem is cultural and has nothing to do with the management economy. I also hope that the Latvian Presidency will not let this issue fall into a vacuum and force us to stalemate for another six months.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, under-emancipation of women in management positions in European companies is one of the first-rate political challenges, but I'm afraid we're approaching it too one-dimensionally at the moment.  I believe that there is almost no person in this chamber who believes that a much lower percentage of women in corporate management positions than men is something good. But many, among whom I am myself, feel that forcibly raising this number could very well turn out to be counterproductive.
