Any discrimination should be rigorously punished, but the big question is whether the quota system will make women respected in the world of business. I would rather say that this, unfortunately, will make them objects that serve to fill the form instead of subjects who, with their knowledge and ability, absolutely deserve the respect of male colleagues.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, there is a single labour market in the European Union that must ensure equal rights and equal chances for women and men, including high positions on company boards, but this does not happen everywhere, although in a number of Member States the problem has national regulation. The draft directive makes it possible to overcome inequality, it is a policy of equality in action, not promises that do not deliver results. While a small step forward in view of its impact, the Directive will ensure a fairer distribution of women and men in leadership positions in the European single market. We should be consistent in our words and deeds and introduce it at European level, I wish you success, Mrs. Jourová

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we women do not want to achieve the objective of an equal presence in the world of work in relation to men simply because we are women, but because we know that we have all the right skills and the skills to achieve the meritocratic level that we are entitled to. In order to do this, however, we need a social system behind us that puts us in a position to devote fully and fully to our work, so that in order to make a career, women must not have to give up their role within the family. Only with this in mind do we believe that the 40% quota is acceptable. In addition, the European Union should have a less punitive and more encouraging approach to this sensitive issue for companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, in terms of social, family and labour policies and equality between men and women.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I know we have a shortage of time, so just a few words. Thank you for the discussion and for all the arguments put forward here today. As Ms Arena said, we should also deal with the arguments put forward by the Council. I have a very wide agenda in my portfolio, and cultural difference and cultural background is prominent in the agenda of equality between men and women, so this might be part of it. However, I must also tell you that I had many discussions on this matter with many ministers and representatives of the Member States, and nobody said that the goal is wrong. Everybody admitted that this is the proper thing to seek, but many of the people I spoke to reacted allergically to the quota. They are criticising the instrument we are going to use. We need to explain better that the quota is the necessary instrument and that the legislation itself – including sanctions – is the necessary instrument, because all the other ways have already been tested and they simply did not work. These are the arguments, and we have some time ahead of us during the Latvian Presidency to explain better the goal and how this instrument will be used, and also perhaps to put more emphasis on the diversity issue. It simply proved useful to have diversity in the boardrooms and to have more women there. They were useful during the crisis, they saw the crisis coming and they brought about good solutions. But I do not want to repeat the arguments which we have already heard. Thank you for the discussion, and thank you also for the offer I heard here – for instance from Ms Niebler – that you will help us in negotiating in your countries where there are opposite positions. Thank you for the encouragement and enjoy the rest of the day.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, the Latvian Presidency is grateful for these exchanges with the European Parliament. We also note that the new Commission remains fully committed to its proposal for a directive for improving the gender balance on company boards. The Latvian Presidency fully shares the view that it is a matter of political importance to have more women in decision-making positions. Gender balance in the company boardroom sends a positive signal all the way down to the company floor. It also creates more role models that benefit society as a whole. This is a modern and fair way. An equal society should be equal at all levels, honestly. The Latvian Presidency will certainly play its part in seeking to demand a discussion in the Council on this important file. We look forward to working together with Parliament in a constructive spirit in the interests of European companies in pursuit of fairness in society and for the benefit of European women and men. Thank you very much for this great discussion.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. Diversity necessarily leads to an improvement in the results and impacts of each production process. No agreement has yet been reached on this important directive on gender balance in companies because several Member States do not provide for national legislation in this area. The problem concerns the sanctions to be applied in the event that a company does not reach the share of at least 40% of female non-executive directors. On the other hand, the real objective of the measure is not to protect women as such, but to promote meritocratic selection mechanisms, in which posts are assigned to the best, without discrimination caused by prejudices about the sex to which they belong. From this point of view, the recognition of rights is not only right, but also useful. For this reason, an alternative way of dealing with this issue is proposed: more than focusing on quota-related sanction mechanisms or simple indications by the EU of a quota to be reached, we introduce and promote reward mechanisms for companies that reach the quota. This would also have a positive effect on small and medium-sized enterprises currently excluded from this directive.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – I am deeply disappointed to find this item on our agenda anno 2015. More than one year ago, this Parliament called loud and clear for legislation on transparent recruitment procedures, so that by 2020 at least 40% of non-executive directors of EU companies would be women. Yet this seems to have fallen on deaf ears in the Council. As a result, the average proportion of women on EU company boards is not even one in five. Meanwhile, the UK Government is quoting high national percentages of women on boards, but fails to mention that the number of women executives in the top 100 companies on the London Stock Exchange is at a meagre 6.9%. Women in the UK still earn just 80 pence for every pound a man earns. House of Commons data shows that, under the current UK Government, the gap has closed at a snail’s pace of just 0.3% per year between 2010 and 2013. At this rate, it could take over 60 years to deliver equal pay. The status quo is unacceptable, and I hope that under the Latvian Presidency, the Council will finally break with its tradition of inaction on this crucial issue.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – This proposal for a Directive has been blocked in the Council since November 2013, in the face of the refusal of such important countries as Germany and the United Kingdom. Currently, only 17.6% of non-executive managers of listed companies are women, and this Directive establishes a clear common strategy for all Member States to achieve the objective of obtaining a less represented sex presence of at least 40% among non-executive managers of listed companies by 2020 and 2018 , in the case of state-owned listed companies. The Italian Presidency tried to reach an agreement, but this was not possible. However, in order to unlock it, a flexibility clause has been introduced which would enable Member States to achieve the objectives of the Directive by the means they decide, and to suspend procedural requirements, provided that States have taken other equivalent measures or managed to approach the objectives set out in the Directive. Let us hope that this is certainly the first step in achieving this very important directive on women's equality and empowerment as well as in the fight against the glass ceiling that many women have to face.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – By 2020, 40% of supervisory boards in listed companies are to be women, according to the draft of the European Commission under discussion today. This quota will be implemented through a transparent selection procedure. A company that does not comply with the transparency criteria can be penalised. It may also be excluded from public procurement. In addition, measures must be taken by the Member States to ensure the implementation of the 40% quota. In 2014, 24.7% of the supervisory boards of companies listed on the DAX were female. Only 5.5% of THE DAX boards are women. A recent study from the USA shows that it is primarily superiors who slow down women in their careers. A binding quota for women is proving to be an inappropriate means of promoting women in the long term. It is not because of the qualifications either, as today more than half of the university graduates are female. Rather, the following points need to be implemented: (1) We need a clear commitment to the promotion of women in companies and (2) diversity must be anchored as a central management task in the corporate mission statement. This is the only way to sustainably increase the proportion of women on supervisory boards and corporate management functions.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Directive on gender balance among non-executive directors of listed companies, which aims to increase the participation of women in decision-making positions, has been opposed by some countries. The official argument is incompatibility with the principle of subsidiarity and, consequently, an indication that legitimate demands for equality between women and men should be pursued at the level of national law. This argument can only be considered if countries actually have or are preparing their national solutions and the participation of women in decision-making positions is adequate and proportionate to their qualifications. Not all opponents of the directive fulfil this condition, which puts into question the intentions of opponents. Meanwhile, the waste of women's knowledge and talents limits the competitiveness of the European economy. Women make up more than 60% of masters and 35% of employers, but only a dozen percent of them participate in decision-making processes in governments and large companies, and their share of the labour market is much lower than that of men. Removing barriers such as gender stereotypes or a shortage of childcare institutions and dependent persons can increase employment rates and improve the quality of management in politics and business, and, above all, make full use of citizens' qualifications and talents. Given the shrinking labour market caused by ageing populations, gender balance is the most important challenge for today's economy and the key to solving economic and social problems.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. The latest study by the International Labour Organisation once again demonstrates the positive link between women's participation in senior roles and the performance of structures and business. However, the same study points out that, without positive action, it will take 100 to 200 years to achieve full gender equality at the top. While I understand the necessary application of the principle of solidarity, which is at the root of the rigidity of some Member States on this issue, I believe that the compromise text developed by the Italian Presidency is a long way from giving rise to concerns in this regard: by not imposing quotas - as is the case with many national laws, including Italian law itself - it does not interfere at all with the management of the Member States but merely set quantitative targets. It is therefore to be hoped that the work done so far will not be wasted and that agreement will be reached in the Council as soon as possible.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – Gender equality is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union – the reality is shameful: neither pay nor promotion opportunities are equal for women. Excuses such as poorer qualification or lower performance have long been refuted by reality – women prove themselves every day by working harder to achieve the same as their male counterparts, despite the often still existing double burden. We in the European Parliament have done our homework and in November we adopted by an overwhelming majority the report on the balanced representation of women and men on supervisory boards. Now it is up to the Member States. In December, Germany adopted a mandatory quota of 30% on the supervisory boards of listed companies. This can be seen as a turnaround for Germany. I am therefore counting on Germany to abandon its blocking stance in the Council and finally clear the way for a more balanced representation of men and women in the corporate management floors.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – The proposal for an EU directive on the 40% representation of women on company boards is argued by only 15% of women in these bodies and the resulting inequalities. What should we say then to the situation that in some political bodies and functions women are not represented at all? Those who appoint and elect managing authorities should be interested in harnessing the potential of women. Personally, I have long supported the representation of women in political and public office, and I support the building of their professional and academic careers. Surprisingly, no woman has asked me to introduce quotas, but women have repeatedly asked me to improve the conditions for the compatibility of their parental role and employment. It should make more sense to consider quotas for equal representation of both sexes in public administrations, possibly in the governing bodies of state-owned companies or public bodies, as well as in electoral laws. The aim should be a balanced representation of women wherever they are decided. It's in the interests of women to be there and have a strong voice. However, the representation of women on the supervisory boards of large companies is rather in the interest of the companies themselves. Some understand it and thrive, others don't deal with it, and it's their business. For private firms, the European Commission should come up with a positive incentive, not regulation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The media impact of this measure is always very large. Unfortunately, however, there are, and as the Commission should know, many other problems of inequality between men and women are priorities. We look around us and see an endless series of shocking examples. Look at the statistics of poverty, unemployment and social exclusion. Your face is always feminine. How many women in the EU are unemployed and poorer today? How many are affected by precarious work? How many women are asked in interviews to get a precarious, underpaid job if they think they're going to get pregnant? How many suffer from violence and bullying and sexual harassment in the workplace and at home? How many are denied the rights to health care in pregnancy? How many have suffered from cuts in social support, and in particular in support for their children, because of the troika's impositions in Portugal, Greece or Ireland just to name a few countries? These women will probably never get to the management of a company. But these, unfortunately, are the overwhelming majority and they are the ones who suffer, more than men, the effects of austerity policies that, more day less day, and with the struggle of all workers, men and women, will end.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – The Commission is absolutely right to pay attention to the number of women on company boards across Europe. It is clear that various measures, such as quotas and intra-company guidelines, have resulted in an increase in women's places – in countries that have legislated for women's quotas on company boards, over the last 10 years we have seen an increase of up to a fifth in the number of women on company boards.  However, challenges remain. It is important for each Member State to break down the legal barriers that prevent women from progressing in their careers and management positions. One of these relates to parental leave: to promote a more even distribution of parental leave between men and women. Culture is changing slowly, so it is worth keeping a close eye on the increase in the proportion of women on company boards and encouraging member states to move forward.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – The debate initiated by the European Commission on 'women on company boards' is dishonest in two respects. On the one hand, the European Commission is presenting a work programme to de-clutter legislation in general and to promote small and medium-sized enterprises. Nevertheless, the same institution is introducing new bureaucratic hurdles with the quota of women. The EU Commission, like many other national and international political organisations and institutions, does not live up to its own ambition. In other words, the EU's political institutions oblige economic companies to have rules that they themselves cannot comply with. There is no reason to bring women into management positions of companies simply in order to symbolically shift responsibility, to meet a politically motivated quota and thus to further promote the institutional management of values and norms in the EU. The decisive criterion for top posts must be professional qualifications. The right policy approach should be based on equal opportunities rather than equality of outcomes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on European measures to combat organised crime and corruption (2015/2510(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to address the issue of organised crime and corruption. It is our obligation to guarantee our citizens a general area of justice, freedom and security by preventing and combating serious and organised crime as well as corruption. We have to mobilise all our instruments to this end and combine efforts to adopt a comprehensive and coherent approach to crime. Europol’s Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessment estimated in 2013 that 3 600 organised crime groups were active in the European Union. Criminal organisations are becoming increasingly flexible and are diversifying their activities. Links are steadily growing with a broad range of other lucrative criminal activities, such as drugs or even trafficking in human beings or exploiting technological developments for criminal purposes. Huge criminal proceeds are generated which are infiltrated into the illicit economy. As a result, criminal groups are increasingly capable of influencing the operation of the legal markets, and even the institutional and political processes across the EU, by engaging in corrupt practices. The Council has been continuously engaged in a range of initiatives, targeting organised crime and corruption, and has been treating them as a matter of the highest political priority. A key measure is the EU policy cycle, which was adopted in 2010. This cycle ensures an operational response to organised and serious international crime through optimised coordination and cooperation between national law enforcement authorities, EU institutions, agencies and other relevant partners. Within this framework the Council agreed to a series of operational actions targeting, among other things, counterfeiting and cybercrime, which were agreed as EU crime priorities. Emerging crimes, like wildlife trafficking, illegal waste trafficking or trafficking in cultural goods, have also been identified by the Council as areas which need attention. Such crimes will be closely monitored by Europol, which is expected to submit to the Council an interim Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessment at the end of March 2015. The Council attaches great importance to the EU Anti-Corruption Report, which was issued for the first time by the Commission on 3 February 2014. This is a valuable tool in consolidating anti-corruption efforts and promoting high anti-corruption standards across the EU, based on a comprehensive approach. We believe it will provide further incentives for the Member States to ratify and effectively implement the existing anti-corruption instruments. The role of asset recovery has been acknowledged as an integral part of the fight against serious and organised cross-border crime. Criminal groups can amass huge profits from the various criminal activities and markets, and it is generally agreed that disrupting and recovering the financial flows of a criminal group is an efficient way to stop crime paying. The new directive on the freezing and confiscation of proceeds of crime, adopted by the European Parliament and Council in 2014, provides broader opportunities for confiscating the proceeds of crime in cases where a conviction cannot be delivered because the person concerned has absconded from justice or has fallen ill. It also provides for a reinforced system of extended powers of confiscation or confiscation from a third party. This instrument is a clear step forward in ensuring that criminals can no longer have access to assets derived from certain types of criminal activity, and this contributes to strengthening the response to serious forms of crime. Nonetheless, during the negotiations leading up to the adoption of the instrument, the Council and Parliament felt that still more could be done in this field. To that end they adopted, together with the directive, two declarations calling upon the Commission to consider the possibility of submitting further proposals on this matter. The Council is looking forward to the Commission’s initiatives in this respect. Finally, please allow me to comment briefly on the review of the internal security strategy. This will be a high priority for the Presidency, as we wish to respect the deadline set by the European Council calling for a review and update of the internal security strategy by mid-2015. In December last year the Council adopted conclusions which set out the Council’s considerations on the general structure and some key principles of the renewed EU internal security strategy. One of these key principles is that the renewed internal security strategy should identify the main common threats and challenges. For the coming years, in the field of internal security, the Council considers that serious and organised crime in all its forms constitutes one of these threats.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, many thanks for giving me the opportunity to present the Commission policies and actions to fight organised crime and corruption across the Union. The resolution on renewing the internal security strategy, which this Parliament adopted on 3 December 2014, rightly puts this fight among the few priorities on which we should continue to focus our joint efforts in the years ahead. By preventing and combating crime in all its forms, the European Union will contribute to creating a safer Europe and a more trustworthy environment for its citizens and businesses. Combating the infiltration of organised crime into the legal economy will contribute to economic recovery and growth. This is particularly the case with regard to corruption. European citizens are concerned about corruption. In our Eurobarometer Survey in 2013, more than half of Europeans said corruption in their country had increased over the previous three years. Four out of ten European companies consider corruption to be an obstacle for doing business in the internal market. Preventing corruption and promoting integrity has rightfully moved up the European agenda in the past decade. Last year’s first anti-corruption report shows that the nature and extent of corruption varied from one Member State to another, and that corruption affects all Member States. The report identified areas in need of further attention. It is important to build cooperation with the Member States, among the EU institutions and with the relevant international organisations in order to follow up. The next report is due in 2016. There have been calls to include in the second report an objective independent evaluation of all EU institutions. We will consider this request in full dialogue with the other European institutions. The Commission, as you know, has just taken measures to increase its own transparency, which is essential for preventing corruption. Let me turn now to organised crime. The seriousness of the threat is well documented in Europol’s annual threat assessments. The estimated 3 600 organised crime groups involved in serious transnational crime in the EU are involved in many types of crime, including economic crime, corruption and money laundering, cybercrime and environmental crime. Their investments are increasingly transnational too, thus leading to the infiltration of organised crime into the legal economy across the Union and beyond. EU legislation needs to be fully implemented: particularly the 2008 Framework Decision on the fight against organised crime, on which the Commission will issue an implementation report this year. The directive adopted last year on the freezing and confiscation of assets is a significant step forward. Lastly, the recent agreement on the fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive is promising in terms of enabling financial investigations to identify criminal beneficial owners of companies more easily. Alongside legislation, the Commission promotes operational cooperation between Member States, and between them and third countries through Europol. The current operational priorities of Europol include illegal immigration, human trafficking, counterfeit goods, excise fraud, synthetic drugs, cocaine and heroin, cybercrime, firearms and organised property crime. Funding is provided through parts of the internal security fund: roughly EUR 1 billion over the period 2014-2020. I will mention firearms trafficking, as it echoes last week’s tragic events and was identified by Europol as an emerging threat. An EU strategy to fight the illicit trafficking of weapons was adopted in 2013. The Commission is now evaluating the possibility of proposing the approximation of some criminal offences related to weapons and to strengthening the checks for some categories of firearms. Better exchange of information on illegal firearms is also essential. Prevention should be a strong component of the fight against organised crime. The Commission has actively engaged with third countries and relevant international organisations: for instance, we have a full agenda with the United States as regards the fight against cybercrime and child sexual abuse. With Eastern partners the focus is on corruption. Fighting cybercrime, given its clear impact on our societies, is a self-standing priority in the current internal security strategy. Cybercrime impacts on the economy and also, when the personal data of employees or customers are stolen and property is lost, on fundamental rights. The European Union has responded with the creation of the European Cybercrime Centre within Europol and the Cyber Attacks Directive, which Member States should implement by September 2015. I call on Parliament to ensure that the draft directive on network information security, still under discussion, includes provisions on the reporting of cyber-security incidents of a criminal nature to the law enforcement authorities, as proposed by the Commission. Criminal investigations into cybercrime require speedy access – subject to due process – to criminal evidence held by private companies under different jurisdictions and in different locations. The Commission is ready to work with the Member States to ensure that the existing legislation on, firstly, cyber attacks, secondly, payment fraud and, thirdly, child sexual abuse online is correctly and swiftly implemented. The Commission is committed to enabling closer public-private cooperation in fighting cybercrime. This cooperation has also started to address the challenges of the suppression of illegal content from the internet, and to counter online terrorist propaganda and radicalisation. To conclude, let me mention the work, during the previous term, of Parliament’s Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering, which was seminal. I trust that it heralds productive cooperation with you in the months and years to come.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. In the fight against organised crime, I still take a somewhat critical view of the European Union. I believe that organised crime in logistics, in the ability to network, in the brutality of the procedure and in the modernity of its instruments, is partly still superior to our measures. That is why we will have to make a great effort to counteract organised crime in its diversity. I am thinking in particular of the area of the Internet, where there are now a wide range of forms of crime, which are being massively promoted by the Internet. For example, the sexual abuse of children has received a real boost via the Internet. The number of children affected has increased significantly. However, I must also say that I regret that some colleagues from other groups have refused to discuss the new studies and findings in this Parliament; we should do so again. If crimes committed via the Internet and the Internet are not punished, then this is a real trigger factor to engage in more criminal activity. In other words, we have many tasks ahead of us. In one and a half minutes, it is not possible to execute them all. But we will still have to deal intensively with the internal security strategy. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "Thank you very much for the opportunity to speak up. I also want to help Mrs Hohlmeier a little by not being able to go through with the list. But he was actually talking about crime, and today's topic includes corruption. My question: What do you think of the case where the organised form of corruption is the government of that Member State itself?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work Corruption is part of the octopus of organised crime. It is the attempt of organised crime to have a massive influence on politics, to create ways of dealing with corruption, and if they have managed to gain a foothold wherever they are, then it is our task to remove them from these possibilities accordingly, with all the possibilities and instruments at our disposal. We have a lot in front of us. Corruption is still widespread.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, representing the Presidency of the Council, I should like to begin by expressing my appreciation to the Italian Presidency for the work it has done on this issue over the six months, albeit conditional on the beginning of the summer period and the renewal of Parliament and the Commission. However, I believe that I must welcome the significant progress made on important legislative dossiers such as the PIF directive, the regulations on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, but also for further important results, such as the resolution on the operational network to combat mafia-type groups, forms of serious crime, the action plan on illicit arms trafficking between the European Union and the regions of South-Eastern Europe and the conclusions on cooperation in the fight against food crime.  The Presidency has also called on the Commission to prepare without further delay the report on the implementation of the 2008 Framework Decision on Organised Crime, a report that has been awaited for more than 2 years and is also necessary with a view to drawing up new measures, in particular with regard to the attack on criminal assets. In this regard, however, I would like to reiterate my call for a new and more ambitious initiative on the confiscation of instruments and proceeds of crime as soon as possible, even in the absence of conviction; Finally, I believe that this Parliament must equip itself to play a constant role in this parliamentary term, especially in order to ensure that the fight against crime in all its forms becomes a central issue in Parliament's work.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We artificially combine the discussion on corruption with the discussion of organised crime or crime in general. Corruption is a separate phenomenon. Corruption is a disease and a pathology of power, and we should have this approach. If the state is working properly, if state institutions are operating properly, there are no conditions for corruption. There is a saying: doctor, but yourself. And when we in the European Union are talking about corruption, we should look at how our actions, which are taking place in the Member States, often lack transparency. Transparency is one of the basic anti-corruption mechanisms. I myself in Poland have a problem with getting information about who used money from the European Union to fight E.coli bacteria (there was once such a problem and large compensation). It turns out that EU rules do not allow this. This should not be the case! Transparency is an essential tool against corruption.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for A year ago, we adopted a special report on organised crime. This resulted in a number of recommendations, including a European Public Prosecutor's Office, additional financial resources for Europol, Eurojust and Frontex, and the implementation of the Victims' Rights Directive, legal information and witness protection programmes. I would now like to address the Commission and the Presidency and ask how far it has actually come in fleshing out all these recommendations. The Treaty of Lisbon gave us the opportunity for this improved cooperation between police and prosecutors in our Member States, but we also now need to see more effective European legislation to combat fraud and cross-border crime, such as trafficking in human beings. This can be done within the framework of Europol and Eurojust and a well-functioning Public Prosecutor's Office at European level. Our legal systems must also be able to provide security guarantees such as legal aid and the protection of minors. However, everything we do must strive to strengthen the Union's security of citizens and be judged against the background of the principle of necessity and proportionality. Nothing could be more important these days when we live in the shadow of what has happened in France. That is why this is a huge priority.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I think it is striking that we are talking about corruption and do not talk about political corruption. And perhaps the reason we include it in a single debate along with organized crime is that we don't want to talk about political corruption. It is the corruption of the citizens of my country that concerns them that takes forty billion euros a year; that system of government created by the big parties of the government. And when we talk about political corruption, it's not just about pre-varication, money laundering, fraud and fraud. We must also call fiscal engineering operations under ad hoc legislation that allows tax avoidance to large multinationals corruption, attracting state resources, as President Juncker has done. There are nine signatures left today for the signing of a commission of inquiry into this gentleman that none of the fourteen members of the Spanish Socialist Party has signed. Let us begin, ladies and gentlemen, if we want to fight corruption by signing this document.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – The lack of effective anti-corruption action, which led to a question from the Commission in December, is underscoring the credibility of democracy and the Union. What is needed is a comprehensive, unified European anti-corruption strategy, strict regulation to implement it and coordination of member states' policies. A European institutional system and cooperation between Member States. To set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office, because it can control all this. If we do not act urgently, the heavily torn European solidarity will be further weakened, because if, for example, Europe devotes its cohesion policy resources to stuffing the pockets of certain oligarchs in the Member States, then at the same time those who have paid the money will turn away and question the meaning of cohesion policy and lose faith and confidence in Europe, which is the focus of cohesion policy but ultimately does not enjoy its positive effects. The issue is not just a policy, but a restoration of trust and faith in Europe.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased and also a little proud that the issue of combating the Mafia and corruption has finally returned to the attention of the European institutions. Thanks to the initiative of the 5 Star Movement and the support of many colleagues from different groups and nationalities, which we warmly thank. I would have been much happier if our Italian PD colleagues had put aside the logic of belonging, typical of the old Italian politics, with their support shamefully denied to a cross-party initiative that belongs to everyone and not just to those who stand as a champion of the antimafia. Organised crime, the Mafia and corruption are a cancer that distorts and kills the economy, politics and social structures of europe as a whole and that no one can afford to underestimate any more: from these considerations arises the idea of an oral question mysteriously transformed into a declaration to reopen the debate interrupted in October 2013 with the adoption of the report of the CRIM Committee.  Today we want to urge the Institutions of the Union to resume the interrupted path immediately: Parliament, together with the Libe Committee, will follow up the mandate given to it by CRIM; the Commission shall take appropriate legislative initiatives for the introduction of the crime of association with mafia-type crimes at European level, increase the legislation on the confiscation of the proceeds of crime and introduce the measure of delayed seizure or arrest where necessary to acquire evidence or to catch representatives of organised crime; the Council undertakes to coordinate internal security policies between Member States in the field of mafia-type organised crime and corruption. In this last respect, it is regrettable that the Italian Presidency has done nothing to follow up the recommendations of the CRIM Committee that have just been mentioned. The lack of support for the oral question by Renzi's PD is further confirmation of how the fight against the Mafia is neither his priority nor his entire thought.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, on the issue of combating organised crime and corruption, both in the public and private sectors, there are laws in the Member States and in European legislation to tackle the phenomenon. The question is whether the laws apply to everyone, without exceptions and without interference.  I will remind you of the Siemens scandal in Greece. Millions of euros went into the pockets of kickback policies in order for the company to have access to government procurement and selective treatment vis-à-vis its competitors. The Siemens man in Greece, Mr. Christoforiko, who arranged the bribery of political persons, as it emerged from the investigation of the scandal, Germany never handed him over to the Greek authorities for trial - although a total of three European arrest warrants had been issued against him - naturally protecting the German interests of Siemens. In this way he also protected some politicians from the two major political parties in Greece, as he confessed to the Munich prosecutor in 2009 saying that he was giving them sponsorships to cultivate the political landscape. Ladies and gentlemen, we are voting on laws and European directives. But do they apply them as all Member States should?

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: Madam President, the internal security of the European Union is threatened by organised crime, corruption, money laundering, terrorism — and we know well that terrorism is, in many cases, funded by organised crime networks. In practice, billions of euros are lost every year because of these crimes and because dirty money is out there, unconfised and producing new networks of organised crime, money laundering and corruption.  That is why confiscation is an essential thing, an essential weapon in the fight against this type of crime. I would like to call into question the Confiscation Directive and stress that the implementation of this directive, the extended confiscation and the third-party confiscation in each Member State is essential and must be carried out and applied exactly and precisely — this and for cooperation between Member States.  I also call again on the Commission to produce the study it undertook when we concluded the Confiscation Directive on the benefits of confiscation produced by judicial proceedings, but not following a criminal conviction, but through confiscation in civil proceedings, which, for example, the United Kingdom practices and which is very, very effective. If we don't take the money, one more time, we're investigating for nothing. And the last thing: the European Prosecutor is very important.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! Organised crime and corruption damage the future and jeopardise the social cohesion of each country.  Of course, it is primarily the responsibility of the Member States to combat these phenomena. But the EU is also a common area of security, freedom and justice. That is why the situation in the individual member states always affects the whole of all, especially since organised crime has a high cross-border dimension. Europe must play a stronger role in the fight against organised crime. We must press vehemently for the principles of the rule of law to shape our coexistence. The fight against organised crime is reaching its limits wherever money laundering is involved. Many Member States have been too lax in their efforts to secure economic benefits in the past against tax fraud and tax evasion. Tax havens are an ideal breeding ground for mafia-like economic structures. We need to be much more rigorous about this. The anti-money laundering directive, which I hope we will vote on here soon, is an important step in this direction. The fight against organised crime must be rigorous, but we must always pay attention to the protection of fundamental rights. Only such a course of action will make our societies truly sustainable.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Madam President, organised crime poses a growing security threat to Member States. In addition to undermining their legal order and financial stability, it is increasingly involved in the supply of financial resources, weapons and manpower to terrorist groups.  Recent tragic developments from France have shown that our mutual cooperation is more necessary than ever. Today's media reports on how the bullets from the Paris crime scene originated in Bosnia and Herzegovina and arrived in France via Croatia, deeply disturbed me, because they laid bare many shortcomings in our security network.  I believe that security cooperation between Member States must be intensified, but I hope that this will be done through concrete actions at the lowest levels, not by amassing administration and unnecessary joint bodies that exist far from the terrain and a real threat to the security of our citizens.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, the European Parliament's resolution on combating corruption has, in fact, been left dead. Because there was no political will to implement it effectively.  But in addition to fighting corruption in the future, the consequences of corruption in the past must also be addressed. Part of the over-indebtedness of many Member States of the Union is due to the fact that corrupt politicians have, in particular large multinational companies, essentially useless public works and commissions at inflated prices, thus burdening national budgets. The equivalent of this excessive and pointless burden on public debt is shameful debt, which citizens cannot be called upon to pay through social spending cuts.  The European Union must take responsibility for all this and accept the audit of the debt and the write-off of its shameful part through the convening of a pan-European debt conference.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul In the last week, we have talked a lot about terror and contempt for freedom of expression and the threats to democracy. However, there is another threat that comes from within, a disease that attacks the core or heart of the body, i.e. trust in our fellow human beings and trust in the common society. Corruption destroys trust in a functioning society and thus the innermost cohesive glue of democracy. The European institutions should give priority to the most important and leave a great deal more to one side. It is not being done today. The Commission should develop an anti-corruption strategy, and we must have the courage to say what needs to be done and who is doing wrong. The peoples of Europe must receive much stronger support from the EU institutions in order to push the Member States for the necessary changes.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Giovanni Falcone, a Sicilian judge and hero, said 'follow the money and you will find the Mafia'. We must start from a starting point, the Mafia is a globalised phenomenon, we are not talking about something abstract, we are talking about associations, organized crime, which can be globalised more quickly than the markets. I am Sicilian and I remember perfectly when I was a child and it was believed that the Mafia was a phenomenon that existed only in Palermo or Corleone, while already operating with money in Northern Italy and in the other countries of Europe. We must start from this premise: the Mafia is present in Paris, Berlin and London exactly and more than it was present in the places where it was born, and so it must be tackled in a cohesive and decisive way – and I am addressing the Council and Commissioner Avramopoulos for this.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not have the same reading as the Council and the Commission on Crime. I believe that the tragic events that France has just experienced cannot be decoupled from the fight against serious crime. The Islamic State in the Levant and Iraq, Boko Haram and many other groups feed on serious crime. The three sinister killers, like those who preceded them, like a Kelkal, a Merah or a Nemmouche, before becoming the flag bearers of radical and terrorist Islamism, had already distinguished themselves in the great crime. Coulibaly had been the author of some fifteen robberies before committing his atrocious acts. I must tell you that many leaders of the European Union have enabled the criminals of yesterday and the terrorists of today, through their lax and unconscious policies, to ensure that they proliferate and sow more and more deaths in our country. The Schengen Treaty and the mad operation against Syria and Libya show us today that, unfortunately, crime is not managed here in the European Community.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: Madam President, honourable Members, we are all aware of the data showing how much corruption and organised crime are worth to European economies and European citizens. There is, however, something much more important. Something that can't be measured - it's about trust. The acute sense of corruption and organised crime destroys the credibility of the institutions, and democracy is this political regime that is most dependent on the trust of its citizens towards itself. That is why the battle against corruption and organised crime has another dimension – this is a battle for the quality and future of democracy in the European Union. Therefore, this battle must be fought and won with pan-European institutions, and here I do not mean only the Pan-European Prosecutor's Office, whose construction is late, but I am also talking about the acute need for a European intelligence service with an extremely strong and well-developed financial intelligence unit, which will not only increase trust, but also create a sense of security, because we are all aware of the sinister link between organised crime and terrorism. As a Bulgarian MEP, I must recognize that Bulgaria is one of the countries with the highest index of corruption and low confidence in the judiciary. That is why I want to wish the new reformist government success in judicial reform.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, this European Parliament has long been well aware of the importance, the need, to fight organised crime, money laundering from illicit business and corruption very effectively.  But here we are no longer in the awareness-raising phase, but in the action phase, and it is absolutely imperative that the Commission move from the commission's plans to adopt a common definition standardising at European level of what is 'organised crime', in order to regulate the confiscation of property from criminal offences, to combat piracy, counterfeiting and cybercrime and , above all, to ensure that we carry out this dossier which we have called for the protection of the Union's financial interests as a true embryo of a European Public Prosecutor's Office capable of acting against cross-border European crime, ensuring efforts to combat money laundering in the interests of full transparency to identify suspected laundering through a public register of trusts , trusts, foundations containing information on the accounts and their beneficiaries and intermediaries, improving coordination in the activity of national authorities to combat the phenomenon of corruption and transnational economic crime.  And finally, corruption, organised crime and laundering are a threat not only to the economic interests of the Union but to democracy itself, to the civilisational values of the European Union, to the credibility of the institutions, to people's confidence in democracy and to which the institutions actually represent people. So it is not only an economic logic but a strictly democratic logic that says that fraud has to be pursued and the submerged economy has to emerge, because that generates resources not only for growth and employment but for the recovery of the credibility of the institutions and democracy itself in Europe.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Madam President, one thing that we can all do immediately is to speed up the EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive. It has been mentioned – and I agree with previous speakers – that organised crime was behind last week’s killings in Paris. They were funded through organised crime and by organised crime. We need to act together: the institutions of Europe need to act together, we need to share information, support one another at state level and also move forward on this directive, which would be a vital element in equipping our security services to combat organised crime and terrorism. Organised crime is a threat to society, whether it be through drugs, drug importation, drug smuggling or arms smuggling. And, of course, trafficking in human beings is an extremely serious crime against human beings that we need to tackle. It is particularly so for Europe, which values its protection of the individual. Crime against children, and specifically cybercrime, is a major challenge. Sexual abuse of children on line is a horrendous crime that needs to be tackled, and I would urge the Commission and the Council to ensure that the internet companies assume responsibility here and play their part in ensuring that we can work together to tackle this vile crime.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Madam President, last December the Portuguese Attorney General closed the case on the purchase of submarines from a German consortium, after nine years of investigation based on strong suspicions of corruption, fraud and money laundering. The Portuguese prosecutors wrote that the investigation was blocked by the lack of cooperation from their German colleagues who, despite many rogatory letters and other requests, never sent to Portugal determining elements of proof, many of them seized in a joint search. This was different to what was done towards Greece in the same case involving submarines, although in Germany corruptors for Portugal and Greece were convicted. Who are the corrupt Portuguese that Germany is covering up? This is intolerable in the context of European judicial cooperation and, Mr Avramopoulos, the Commission must intervene, otherwise the corrupt, the money launderers and other criminals will continue to use internal market freedom to retain impunity and keep the profits of crime. And why is the Commission waiting to urge Member States to stop the sale of ‘golden visas’, which, besides being immoral, are obviously the source of the importation of organised crime into the EU? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Madam President, today we have heard the information about a certain disaster, a certain failure, a collective and shared failure for which we are all responsible. But today we have to choose between pursuing the effects or combating the causes of what we are talking about. It is not enough , and I say this quite clearly , to better or finally implement the legislation in force. There is an empty regulatory space in Europe, a space that Europe has not occupied so far and which I do not see properly reflected in its proposals. Organized crime and corruption are, let's be clear, creatures born of the deregulation of the global financial system. A deregulation that began thirty years ago. They are creatures unwanted by anyone, but which today have become very real monsters, monsters installed in our system with all impunity. That is why we must change this general economic regulation, the fiscal regulation, that of the financial system, which connects money laundering with all known crimes.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Madam President, I would like to point out, in this context, circumstances which, in my opinion, are very important. Of course, crime prevention, a safer environment in Europe, transparency to be the way to combat corruption, but also the number of 3 600 estimated groups of criminal gangs – all this is indicative of this proposal or for a greater level of combating corruption. However, as a lawyer, I would also like to draw attention to the misuse of operational means by state authorities. And I would like to call on the Commission, at the same time, to think about citizens' privacy, to protect their rights and to strike a meaningful balance when looking for measures to combat corruption. I'd be very grateful to her for that.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Madam President, corruption and organised crime have no borders, no political colour, no nationality, only a weakness of people or society. The European Union must combat this scourge through concrete and clear mechanisms to support the European judicial system, those who dedicate their lives to justice, but also citizens against possible abuses.  I come from a country where the judiciary is starting to work again, and I congratulate the professionals who have allowed it. We in politics must have the will to support a strong and European judicial system because both corruption and organised crime affect the whole of society. If we want confidence in the European Union to grow, if we want politicians to be credible again, if we want citizens to get more involved, we must restore their hope in court. A European judicial system and closer cooperation between Member States would show that no one can escape justice and that criminals, thieves or corrupts have no place in the European Union and that we here in the European Parliament are fighting against these scourges.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Madam President, one of the most profitable and despicable organised crimes is the trafficking of human beings: the buying, selling and abusing of vulnerable people with little more respect than that offered to a sack of potatoes. Shockingly, in the EU, most trafficked people are Europeans. But of course, it is impossible to be accurate about the true numbers who are trafficked. Victims of trafficking are still being prosecuted for crimes that they have been forced to commit rather than being treated as victims, and this adds to their injustice. We have very welcome developments such as the Anti-Trafficking Directive and a most effective and committed Anti-Trafficking Coordinator, but there is still much to do to protect these vulnerable people. Cross-border policing, joint investigative teams and the work of Europol are all essential, but not enough. We must continue to raise the issue and to educate people to see the signs and report them, in order to make sure that together we can fight these crimes, which are, by their very nature, cross-border and complex.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Madam President, first of all I wanted to stress that it is curious that those who know the most about corruption (the Members of the People's Party of Spain) have not taken the floor in this debate and it is a pity because they could have illustrated a lot of us.  In the Spanish state there are more than a thousand cases open for corruption cases, about 500 defendants and just over twenty political leaders in prison. Most cases involve the People's Party, but it must be said that the Socialist Party does not fall short either. And it is also curious that from Europe we look the other way while in Spain we are robbed and looted by public coffers. Perhaps it is because ninety percent of corruption cases affect the two parties here that support their policies.  So don't tell us that you want to fight corruption when what you do is reward it, for example by commissionering Mr Cañete of the People's Party, or by making Mr Juncker, the promoter of tax evasion, President of the Commission.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Avramopoulos and the Minister for being here, as stated by a very large number of colleagues whom I agree with – and I am very pleased – that the regulatory gaps between the European states must be filled absolutely. That is why – since I only have one minute – I give you an example of what happened in Italy on the work of the Tav, the Turin-Lyon high-speed line, where there are proven Mafia infiltrations in the management of contracts, and the President of the Italian Anti-Corruption Authority Cantone has stated that the work of the TAV will not be used as an anti-Mafia interdiction because the legal leaders are subject to the French , where the rule is not present, and so I would ask you to give us a move, please, because politics must represent the honest and must not represent organised crime.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, we all agree that organised crime undermines not only our economy but also our social cohesion and our security. There is no doubt that it is a growing threat, and this requires us to face our responsibilities. But Europe has not been inactive. As you know, concrete policies have been adopted and institutions have been set up by Europol. There is the Drugs Agency, the appointment of an anti-trafficking coordinator and, of course, the European Cybercrime Centre within Europol, and a cyber-attack directive which Member States should be implemented by September this year. The Commission also decided to engage third countries and relevant international organisations. I mentioned at the beginning our strong cooperation with the United States, but we also promote and encourage cooperation among Member States. At European level, organised crime is defined in Framework Decision 2008/841 on the fight against organised crime. This instrument also criminalises offences relating to participation in a criminal organisation. Criminal organisations such as the Mafia – which was mentioned many times during our debate – are covered by general provisions in the framework decision on all types of organised crime. As you know, the Commission will this year present a report on the implementation of the framework decision. To conclude, what unites us all here and within Europe is our determination and our resolve to combat organised crime effectively in all its phases, and to create a safer Europe and a more trustworthy environment for its citizens and business people.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank you for having this very important discussion on the measures to fight organised crime and corruption. I would also like to thank you for giving me the opportunity to intervene on this very important topic. I would like to answer the question from the honourable Member Wikström, and I would like to stress that organised crime and corruption require effective, comprehensive and coherent action by the European Union. The EU policy cycle has provided us with a strong methodology to combat crime in a more coordinated way, making the best use of our resources. We firmly believe that the renewed internal security strategy will represent another step forward in developing a Union that protects the rights and freedoms of our citizens. We should make continuous efforts to strengthen the framework by providing for more comprehensive responses to the challenges posed by organised crime and corruption. The Council remains fully committed to working constructively towards the adoption and effective implementation of concrete measures in that respect.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – Corruption, organized crime and money laundering pose a threat to democracy, citizens and the proper functioning of the legal economy. At a time of economic and financial crisis, resources that retract from the legal economy through fraud must be recovered and put at the service of the real economy, taking precedence over the creation of quality, legal and decent jobs. The Commission and Council's plans to combat these phenomena should be known in 2014-2019 and efforts to combat money laundering should be increased and a system of 'total transparency' should be increased, more easily identifying suspicions of laundering through a European public register of trusts, trusts and foundations containing account information , beneficiaries and intermediaries Coordination of the activity of the competent national authorities to combat the phenomenon and that of european sectoral agencies should also be improved.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – Corruption, organized crime and money laundering pose a threat to democracy, citizens and the proper functioning of the legal economy. At a time of economic and financial crisis, resources that retract from the legal economy through fraud must be recovered and put at the service of the real economy, taking precedence over the creation of quality, legal and decent jobs. The Commission and Council's plans to combat these phenomena should be known in 2014-2019 and efforts to combat money laundering should be increased and a system of 'total transparency' should be increased, more easily identifying suspicions of laundering through a European public register of trusts, trusts and foundations containing account information , beneficiaries and intermediaries Coordination of the activity of the competent national authorities to combat the phenomenon and that of european sectoral agencies should also be improved.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – I welcome the decision of colleagues to bring this issue back on the agenda of major importance to the EU. As a Member of the European Parliament, I would like to stress one important thing: organised crime is becoming a strong global player and it must be borne in mind that around 3600 active international criminal organisations have been registered in the European Union alone, according to the SOCTA report[1].  We are all witnessing a dangerous phenomenon: the links between criminal and terrorist groups are growing and pose a serious threat to the security of European citizens. In this context, consumer security, the protection of legal enterprises, free competition and democratic principles are seriously threatened by the expansion of these criminal organisations, corruption and money laundering. I would like to stress the importance of strengthening cooperation and increasing transparency through the exchange of information between the judicial and police authorities of the Member States, Europol, Eurojust, OLAF and ENISA. Furthermore, strengthening the roles of judges, prosecutors and liaison officers and encouraging judicial training are welcome to enable stakeholders to combat organised crime, including cybercrime, in a faster and more effective way.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – Our citizens are very concerned about corruption and the state of democracy in Europe. Last year, the European Commission published the first reports on the state of corruption in the Member States, unfortunately belatedly, apparently due to pressure from certain countries that did not like the content. Reports have revealed that corruption is indeed a problem for the whole of Europe. All of us! The next report will be issued by the Commission next year. It would be right that the reports also contain a section on the state of corruption in the EU institutions. To my great surprise, the Commission is still delaying this decision, even if european citizens lose hundreds of millions of euros every year to the EU institutions because of fraud in the EU. What exactly is the Commission afraid of? Is there a rule this time that whoever is afraid of the truth is hiding from her? You have to fight corruption all the time. However, we must always start with ourselves, and this applies especially to those who shape policy, starting with the European institutions. We in the European Parliament have done a great deal of work in the CRIM committee over the past term. We have adopted a number of concrete recommendations, which have still not been put into service in most cases. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to put more effort into truly eliminating tax secrecy and tax havens and to combat this cancer more fully.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The terrorist attack in Paris is further deplorable evidence that internal security in the EU requires careful reassessment and significant reinforcement. Internal security concerns in the context of the fight against organised crime, terrorism and violent extremism are also closely linked to the ongoing economic downturn and political developments in the EU's neighbourhood, where many criminal activities come from or are organised. Our society must be able to face security threats in a comprehensive way, the dimensions and refinement of which are constantly growing. In a globalised world, crime ignores borders and it is no longer in the power of individual Member States to resist these threats on their own. Solidarity and cooperation are therefore key to success. We must act together in order to achieve the level of security that EU citizens deserve and which they expect of us as public figures.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. I would like to draw the attention of this Parliament to the issues of corruption and organised crime in Italy, because I believe that these are very underestimated issues at European level. I come from a country where the connivance between the political and criminal systems is increasingly taking on the contours of a tragedy. From the squandering of public funds - especially European funds - to the criminal system by which companies are awarded contracts for works of service to citizens, malprain is now rampant. Bribes, mafia collusion and lucrative mechanisms that citizens are forced to endure in general impotence. Unfortunately, the reports available to Europe show only a small part of what is reality. For example, it does not appear that Italy, as found in the latest ranking published by Transparency International's Corruption Perception Index 2014, is the first in Europe for corruption. I urge the Commission and the Council to take note of this tragedy and to act more effectively, especially on the control systems available to Europe at institutional level.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The scandals of recent months have shown that the current Hungarian Government is not only unsuitable to fight corruption, but is also a patron and an active part of it. The U.S. ban scandal, the fidesz real estate cases, the opaqueness of EU applications all serve one purpose: to give pro-government politicians, their companies and their families huge sums of money. The Hungarian government now has a paper on this: according to an international organization, Viktor Orban is the second most corrupt politician after his idol, Vladimir Putin. The Hungarian Government is no longer a guarantee that public money and EU funds will be spent fairly in the interests of the Hungarian people. That is why I have appealed to the EU Anti-Fraud Office on a number of cases, and I therefore urge the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as soon as possible, which would prevent perennal government corruption and abuse. I therefore call on OLAF and the Commission to thoroughly investigate suspected cases of corruption in the interests of the Hungarian people.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. Thanks to the efforts of the SPECIAL COMMITTEE CRIM, which was set up last parliamentary term, on cross-border organised crime, this issue has finally managed to get the 'European attention' it deserved. This hard-earned attention must not, however, fade away after all the excellent work done so far. Europe must not underestimate the damage that cross-border criminal activities do, especially economic ones, when it comes to money laundering or corruption. Unfortunately, we in Italy are well aware of these issues and we also know how expensive it is for honest people to live in a territory infiltrated by corruption, the black market and money laundering. We also know, however, that special and extraordinary means are needed to combat this crime, and that is precisely what I believe Europe must develop. Criminal organisations, however based they may be in certain specific countries, operate and operate throughout the Territory of the Union, no country excluded. The experience of suppressing these phenomena in certain territories must be shared in a climate of mutual trust and close cooperation between the police authorities and the European courts. A Crime of a European dimension must be accompanied by strong European action to help citizens cope with phenomena that weaken our economy and our society.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is becoming increasingly involved in the fight against corruption, m.in. implementing the first anti-corruption report in the EU of 3 February 2014. It would be appropriate to establish a definition of the concept of corruption at European and international level, as well as the concept and protection system of whistleblowers. These are persons disclosing to the public illegal practices of governments, administrations, companies or private associations. We are talking about a passive and active instrument in the fight against corruption at the same time.  Given that reporting infringements is hampered by a reluctance to flag unlawful activities within my own organisation and for fear of retorts, I believe that a whistleblower protection programme (e.g. the US Sarbanes-Oxley System of 2002) should be set up in the EU with the requirement to apply it. There should also be an organisation to protect these people. The need for an effective whistleblower protection system has been talked about for years by the international organisation Transparency International. Also in his 2014 publication 'Good administration in practice', the European Ombudsman points out the need for a comprehensive and effective whistleblower protection system. This instrument would increase the sense of security of potential whistleblowers, increase awareness, build a culture of integrity in organizations. It would undoubtedly be useful in the fight against corruption in all EU Member States.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing – Organised crime and corruption are global crimes that require the fight against them to be based on close cooperation between the courts not only in Europe but also at international level. Only in this way will their cross-border nature be limited and it will be demonstrated that there is no stable and rule of law where their perpetrators can hide. I believe that the European Union's attention to the fight against organised crime should focus on three areas. First is the fight against financial fraud by European means through the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. European funds are not intended to finance criminal activities, but to guarantee the well-being of European citizens. Enhanced police cooperation is also needed through more joint teams, cross-border operations and more timely data exchange. It will only lead to an effective fight against organised crime and corruption in Europe, because there is no country that can tackle these crimes on its own. Last but not least, tighter controls are needed on financial flows related to criminal activities. I welcome the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the Financial Transaction Regulation and insist on its swift implementation in the Member States.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. – Corruption, organized crime and money laundering pose a threat to democracy, citizens and the proper functioning of the legal economy. At a time of economic and financial crisis, resources that retract from the legal economy through fraud must be recovered and put at the service of the real economy, taking precedence over the creation of quality, legal and decent jobs. The Commission and Council's plans to combat these phenomena should be known in 2014-2019 and efforts to combat money laundering should be increased and a system of 'total transparency' should be increased, more easily identifying suspicions of laundering through a European public register of trusts, trusts and foundations containing account information , beneficiaries and intermediaries Coordination of the activity of the competent national authorities to combat the phenomenon and that of european sectoral agencies should also be improved.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The threat of organised crime and corruption is a real threat to EU society and economy. In addition to traditional types of crime, such as money laundering, trafficking in human beings and drugs, new challenges are emerging. The biggest ones are terrorism and widespread cybercrime. Discussions traditionally highlight improvements in crime prevention and law enforcement. This is right, as there are still significant reserves in areas of cooperation between authorities, such as the exchange of information or the transfer of detained criminals.  However, two other areas should be highlighted. Firstly, it is necessary to cooperate in the confiscation of criminal assets. The point is that criminals cannot benefit from their ingless activities anywhere in any European country. The second problem is to increase the role of Europol. There is a question in the EU about the need to create new institutions to fight organised crime. In my opinion, europol's human, operational and financial support would be simpler and more efficient than the multiplication of beings.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: writing – Corruption is a phenomenon with huge negative economic and social consequences, and we must therefore constantly draw attention to its harmfulness and take measures that reduce the motivation and scope for corrupt behaviour of public officials. Corruption drains precious public resources from the areas to be spent, makes it impossible to improve (or causes deterioration) in the quality and accessibility of public services, and hampers economic growth. Corruption also negatively affects good governance and contributes to the erosion of trust in public institutions and democratic processes. Slovakia is one of the countries with the highest degree of perceived corruption (CPI) within the EU, but at least in the legislative sphere it has achieved a significant improvement in reducing the scope for corrupt behaviour over the last decade. Examples include the reform of the commercial register, an increase in the proportion of enforceable permits and licences, or the recent approval of a law that significantly increases the incentive to report corrupt behaviour, both by more effectively protecting the corruption reporter from possible sanctions on the part of the employer, but also by the possibility of obtaining financial reward for reported corruption. More than shortcomings in anti-corruption legislation, the problem in the fight against corruption in Slovakia is currently very poor law enforcement, which is related to the long-term state of justice.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the supervision of lawyers in the European Union (2015/2511 (RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
