text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, honourable Members, the Council has been asked to speak on the issue of surveillance of lawyers in the European Union. We understand that an oral question on the subject has also been presented by honourable Member Sargentini, who referred to the alleged surveillance of a law firm by a national security agency of a Member State. First of all, I would like to point out that the Council Presidency is not in a position to make any comments about an allegation that a Member State’s secret services carry out secret surveillance of lawyers and their clients. Under the Lisbon Treaty the maintenance of law and order and, in particular, the safeguarding of internal security are responsibilities of the Member States. The Council is therefore not informed of any surveillance activities carried out by the national departments responsible for safeguarding national security. I would also like to point out that the collection and processing of personal data by such national security services is currently not regulated by EU law, as neither the 1995 Data Protection Directive nor the 2008 Framework Decision on Data Protection applies to them. The 2012 Commission proposal for a directive on data protection by competent authorities for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences explicitly states that the directive shall not apply to the processing of personal data in the course of an activity concerning national security. For the same reason the Presidency is not in a position to express itself as to the compatibility of these alleged activities with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The EU directive on the right of access to a lawyer states that Member States shall respect the confidentiality of communication between suspects or accused persons and their lawyers in the exercise of their right of access to a lawyer. However, this provision, like the whole directive, is without prejudice to the work carried out, for example, by national intelligence services to safeguard national security in accordance with the Treaties.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, the Commission is concerned about media reports of Member States’ intelligence services putting client-lawyer communications under surveillance. The right to privacy, including communication between clients and lawyers, as protected by Article 7, and the procedural rights protected by Articles 47 and 48 of the Charter are of the utmost importance in the EU. However, it should be pointed out that the Charter is applicable only to the Member States where EU law is implemented. The matter of national security remains within the competences of the Member States so, where the Member States initiate secret surveillance activities for national security reasons, these fall outside EU law. Consequently the Charter is generally not applicable. That being said, the exemption clause needs to be interpreted strictly. In the light of settled case law of the Court of Justice, any Member State which seeks to take advantage of an exemption needs to prove that it is necessary to have recourse to it in order to protect the state’s essential security interests. Where the Charter does not apply, the national systems provide fundamental rights protection procedures that are applicable in these cases. The Commission also aims at a high level of protection of fair trial rights in the European Union. Since 2009 we have made considerable progress in this direction, with the adoption of three directives: on the right of interpretation and translation in 2010; on the right to information in 2012; and, recently, on the right of access to a lawyer. The directive on the right of access to a lawyer needs to be transposed by Member States by 27 November 2016 and the Commission will closely monitor this process. Article 4 of the directive clearly sets out the principle of respect for the confidentiality of communication between suspects or accused persons and their lawyer in the exercise of the right of access to a lawyer. However, it should be underlined that the directive focuses on the rights of suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings. This is why it clarifies, in its recitals, that confidentiality applies only to genuine communication in the exercise of the rights of defence between the lawyer and a suspect and/or accused person. It does not apply to lawyers who are involved in the alleged criminal activities of the suspect or accused person.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – The relationship and communication between a client and his lawyer are of a special nature and the confidentiality of that relationship and that communication is crucial to maintain citizens' trust in the rule of law and thus crucial to the functioning of our democracy. At the same time, it was not said that this kind of information should never be collected on this, that this would be impossible or undesirable. I believe that eavesdropping on conversations between clients and lawyers should be possible in very exceptional cases, where this is adequately warranted and where it would be in the specific demonstrable interest of national or public safety. That right, in the context of national security, to collect information on even these very special conversations is also crucial for Member States to ensure the safety of their citizens. I actually wonder what exactly the purpose of this debate is here tonight. As the Council and the Commission have already indicated, this is a national competence. The Supervisory Board for the Intelligence and Security Services in the Netherlands has issued a comprehensive opinion. This has been made public and presented to the national parliament. Please let the national security services and intelligence services, as well as the national parliaments, do their job.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, thanks to the Commission, thank you, Commissioner. It gives the impression that this debate is a debate on a minor issue on the big issues that this European Parliament can deal with, but it is a false or resoundingly wrong impression, because it is a major debate. We are talking about surveillance of lawyers in the European Union, particularly in the Netherlands, no less than a founding country of the European Union. But we are talking about setbacks in rights and freedoms and threats to the guarantee of the privacy of communications and, of course, to the guarantee of the right to defence, which is professionally implemented by law, not only in the Netherlands, but in all the Member States of the European Union. We are therefore talking about the backward European civilisation, threatened by this mass surveillance, this universal espionage and this disengagement of the rules of law from the intelligence and security apparatus of the Member States which are believed to be in a willingness to destroy everything simply because technology can afford it. We have an obligation to say no. We have an obligation to say no, that we will prevent you, with the law in hand, with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights in hand, with the Lisbon Treaty in hand and with the ability of this European Parliament to act as a legislator on fundamental rights and as a criminal legislator, where appropriate , to suppress, prosecute and punish serious transnational crime, such as that which undermines fundamental rights, the right of access to defence, the right to legal aid and the defence and defence of a fully independent lawyer at all stages of the judicial procedure, including the police investigation. We are therefore talking about the fact that, in terms of parliamentary scrtrolling, this House has an obligation to inquire the Commission about the actions it may take to clarify these facts entirely and to establish European legislation that will make them impossible in the future. This is the compromise, it has to be the compromise, of this European Parliament.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for A fundamental pillar of our European rule of law is the right to be able to talk freely in confidence with your legal representative, his lawyer. Article 4 of the 2013 directive on the right to a lawyer, as well as the Charter of Fundamental Human Rights, also sets this out very clearly. If, then, if our intelligence services collect information between lawyers and their clients, it means, of course, that this fundamental principle is being undermined and, by extension, the rule of law of the European Union is being undermined in a totally unacceptable way. It now appears that the Dutch law firm Prakken d'Oliveira has been under surveillance for a succession of years by the Dutch security services. There are several other similar examples in the Member States. I now really want answers to the question of the Commission and whether the Council believes that this type of espionage against law firms is compatible with European law, with the Treaties, with the Charter of Rights and all the rights that they give us citizens. Because if it were the case now that you really believe that this falls within the framework of national security, then I really want to know how you define the concept of 'national security' and whether you believe that it should automatically mean that European citizens are rightless. I would now like to ask the following questions, firstly: what steps does the Commission and the Council intend to take to ensure that confidential contacts between lawyer and client are respected? Secondly, do you intend to take concrete action against the Netherlands? Thirdly, when do you intend to come back to Parliament with an acceptable definition of the concept of 'national security'?

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to tell you about the situation in my country, the Basque Country, Euskal Herria. The Civil Guard arrested sixteen citizens yesterday: twelve of them lawyers defending Basque political prisoners; three are part of the defending team of the thirty-five militants of the left abertzale who were to be tried since yesterday at the National Hearing for their political work. The operation took place two days after eighty thousand people called in Bilbo for an end to prison policy, based on the dispersal and violation of prisoners' rights. Police went on to search a union premises to take the money raised on the march thanks to the solidarity of the protesters!  This operation is political and these people have been arrested for their legal work defending prisoners, it is an attack on the peace process. It is inadmissible that a Member State infringes fundamental rights, including the rights of the defence, with such impunity.  It is inadmissible that a Member State rejects the application of Community legislation in order to double sentences already served and that nothing happens. That's not justice, that's revenge. If they were to happen elsewhere, these events would be a major scandal and Parliament would call for an emergency debate. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, it is a question of rights, whether a state is democratic or not and the Spanish state is obsessed with proving that it is not. It strives to move further and further than a rule of law should be. I encourage the European Union and, of course, also the Spanish State to take firm steps to resolve the political conflict peacefully and democratically. Basque society calls for human rights, peace and resolution; that's our commitment. (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Europeans count on a fair government, a government they can trust, that abides by the law. That trust has been betrayed by the revelations in the large-scale wiretapping scandals. It was really only a matter of time before it became clear that somewhere in Europe a secret service is bugging a law firm for a long time.  And it has become the Netherlands, where the Minister of the Interior, Ronald Plasterk, admits that he eavesdropped on law firm Prakken d'Oliveira in Amsterdam for a long time. This touches on the rule of law, this affects our confidence in the government. If a conversation with a lawyer is no longer safe, what about a conversation with a doctor, or someone else with a professional secret? The Council says that this is a national matter, but I say: 'No, it is not.' Because there is a 2013 European directive on the right to a lawyer, which Article 4 stipulates that there is an obligation to guarantee confidentiality. There is also the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which guarantees the right to a fair trial. This is not a simple national competence. Hence my question to you, Mrs Jourová, and to Mr Timmermans, who is very familiar with the Dutch Minister of the Interior: are you going to address the Dutch government on the fact that it has not complied with the law and are you going to oblige the Dutch government and the other Member States to respect the confidentiality between client and lawyer?

name: Axel VOSS
text: Madam President! I repeat myself, but it is true and it remains the right thing to do: the relationship between lawyer and client is based on trust and this protection of this professional secrecy also enjoys fundamental protection, and it exists not only for lawyers, but also for doctors and journalists, and it is ultimately also a fundamental element of all democracies and therefore also of all EU Member States. As politicians in the European Union, we are, of course, called upon to maintain and safeguard this as a pillar of the rule of law. However, I still have the feeling that this is an isolated case which plays an important role in this area of security in particular. And in this particular case, I therefore think that there are, in fact, only limited competences here, including the European Union.  This must also be taken note of, because these are security issues and, as has already been said, national security is primarily the competence of the Member States. The Council cannot take any action against a potential breach of confidentiality in the Member States and it is the responsibility of the institutions, the judiciary and the Netherlands' Ministry of the Interior. I believe that the Netherlands is a democratic state enough to investigate this properly, nor is it a surveillance state.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Madam President, we need to talk about two issues. Firstly, this is not the first instance of a Member State hiding behind the so-called exception on national security in the Treaty. We learned about the case in which the British intelligence service destroyed information from journalists, and we have now heard about cases of surveillance of lawyers: all justified by ‘national security’. It is high time that the Commission investigated and asked the Court for a clear definition of what constitutes national security. This needs to be done if the Member States do not want to do it. We need it now. The Commission has to do it, and Parliament needs to push for it. The second question which we need to talk about is what the surveillance of lawyers and journalists entails – especially here in the case we have before us, involving lawyers. After the attacks which we saw last week, I would say that we are talking about blanket retention, and this affects journalists and lawyers too. If we are collecting all this data, then we need to talk about safeguards.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Madam President, I am a little sorry that I have not been given the opportunity to speak in the area of women's quotas, given the Commissioner, but at least in this area I would like to comment on the subject that is being discussed here. The Commissioner cited articles in the Charter which clearly show that European law regulates this issue, but probably not sufficiently in the way that the Member States, not the Institutions of the European Union, are primarily responsible for security policy and the implementation of these principles. However, what if it is demonstrated that the Member States are in breach of this rule? From the point of view of European law, who and how can it remedy these violations and enforce compliance with the Charter? I think that there are fundamental issues that we should consider in the context of this debate. Trust between a client and a lawyer is truly sacred. Then one might ask where this abuse will stop. Will it be in the confessionals where people confess to their confessor?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: Madam President, the right of privilege and protection of personal information is under threat in a number of areas. The arrest on Monday of 16 individuals, including 12 lawyers representing Basque political prisoners, was contemptible. Money was also seized during coordinated raids at several locations, including trade union offices. Everyone is entitled to legal representation, and lawyers must be allowed to carry out their work without state interference and intimidation. Unfortunately, in Ireland we know all too well what can happen when the state tries to prevent human rights lawyers from carrying out their work. The killings of human rights lawyers Pat Finucane and Rosemary Nelson, carried out by loyalist gangs in collusion with British state agents, illustrates exactly what can happen when states attempt to frustrate justice.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not agree with Mr Lenaers when he says that talking about an oral question or having a debate on it is not important. I believe, however, that the issue raised by Mrs Sargentini is very important, because I would not like to see the 'national security' speech end up in a police state where it is admitted that basic rights, such as the right to confidentiality, the right to a defence, the rule of law and due process, can be overcome. Let us try to understand that there are rights that have taken so long to win them over, so if they are to be violated, there must be a really serious reason and there must be certain procedures, not a veiled threat. There is a directive of 2013, which in this case is being violated in its entirety, and the case in the Netherlands could take place in all the countries of Europe. It is important for the Council and the Commission to take a position, including on the Member States, on this issue.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I agree that this is a serious problem but I have to repeat that, at the moment, it falls under the jurisdiction of the Member States, which set out the rules for the surveillance carried out by national security bodies. The Commission is ready to monitor the implementation of the directive on the right of access to a lawyer, which sets out, as I said earlier, the principle of respect for the confidentiality of communication between suspects or accused persons and their lawyers. So this is the current state of affairs. The Commission will follow closely the ongoing developments on this issue at European and national level, including relevant cases pending before the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, I am grateful to Members for the issues and concerns which have been raised during the course of this debate. I will certainly ensure that the Council is aware of the outcome of our discussion. However, as I said at the outset, the Council has not discussed the specific issue which is the subject of this debate, and has certainly not taken a view on it, for the reasons which I have already explained. It is for the Member States individually to lay down their own rules regarding national security.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.
